2: ¶Of Mans First Disobedience, and the Fruit
3: Of that Forbidden Tree, whose mortal tast
4: Brought Death into the World, and all our woe,
5: With loss of *Eden*, till one greater Man
6: Restore us, and regain the blissful Seat,
7: Sing Heav'nly Muse, that on the secret top
9: That Shepherd, who first taught the chosen Seed,
10: In the Beginning how the Heav'ns and Earth
11: Rose out of *Chaos*: Or if *Sion* Hill
12: Delight thee more, and *Siloa's* Brook that flow'd
13: Fast by the Oracle of God; I thence
14: Invoke thy aid to my adventrous Song,
15: That with no middle flight intends to soar
16: Above th' *Aonian* Mount, while it pursues
17: Things unattempted yet in Prose or Rhime.
18: And chiefly Thou O Spirit, that dost prefer
19: Before all Temples th' upright heart and pure,
20: Instruct me, for Thou know'st; Thou from the first
21: Wast present, and with mighty wings outspread
22: Dove-like satst brooding on the vast Abyss
23: And mad'st it pregnant: What in me is dark
24: Illumine, what is low raise and support;
25: That to the highth of this great Argument
26: I may assert th' Eternal Providence,
27: And justifie the wayes of God to men.
28: ¶Say first, for Heav'n hides nothing from thy view
29: Nor the deep Tract of Hell, say first what cause
30: Mov'd our Grand Parents in that happy State,
31: Favour'd of Heav'n so highly, to fall off
32: From their Creator, and transgress his Will
33: For one restraint, Lords of the World besides?
34: Who first seduc'd them to that fowl revolt?
35: Th' infernal Serpent; he it was, whose guile
36: Stird up with Envy and Revenge, deceiv'd
37: The Mother of Mankinde, what time his Pride
38: Had cast him out from Heav'n, with all his Host
39: Of Rebel Angels, by whose aid aspiring
40: To set himself in Glory above his Peers,
41: He trusted to have equal'd the most High,
42: If he oppos'd; and with ambitious aim
43: Against the Throne and Monarchy of God
44: Rais'd impious War in Heav'n and Battel proud
45: With vain attempt.  Him the Almighty Power
46: Hurld headlong flaming from th' Ethereal Skie
47: With hideous ruine and combustion down
48: To bottomless perdition, there to dwell
49: In Adamantine Chains and penal Fire,
50: Who durst defie th' Omnipotent to Arms.
51: Nine times the Space that measures Day and Night
52: To mortal men, he with his horrid crew
53: Lay vanquisht, rowling in the fiery Gulfe
54: Confounded though immortal: But his doom
55: Reserv'd him to more wrath; for now the thought
56: Both of lost happiness and lasting pain
57: Torments him; round he throws his baleful eyes
58: That witness'd huge affliction and dismay
59: Mixt with obdurate pride and stedfast hate:
60: At once as far as Angels kenn he views
61: The dismal Situation waste and wilde,
62: A Dungeon horrible, on all sides round
63: As one great Furnace flam'd, yet from those flames
64: No light, but rather darkness visible
65: Serv'd only to discover sights of woe,
66: Regions of sorrow, doleful shades, where peace
67: And rest can never dwell, hope never comes
68: That comes to all; but torture without end
69: Still urges, and a fiery Deluge, fed
71: Such place Eternal Justice had prepar'd
72: For those rebellious, here their Prison ordain'd
73: In utter darkness, and their portion set
74: As far remov'd from God and light of Heav'n
75: As from the Center thrice to th' utmost Pole.
76: O how unlike the place from whence they fell!
77: There the companions of his fall, o'rewhelm'd
78: With Floods and Whirlwinds of tempestuous fire,
79: He soon discerns, and weltring by his side
80: One next himself in power, and next in crime,
81: Long after known in *Palestine*, and nam'd
83: And thence in Heav'n call'd Satan, with bold words
84: Breaking the horrid silence thus began.
85: ¶If thou beest he; But O how fall'n! how chang'd
86: From him, who in the happy Realms of Light
87: Cloth'd with transcendent brightnes didst outshine
88: Myriads though bright: If he whom mutual league,
89: United thoughts and counsels, equal hope,
90: And hazard in the Glorious Enterprize,
91: Joynd with me once, now misery hath joynd
92: In equal ruin: into what Pit thou seest
93: From what highth fal'n, so much the stronger provd
94: He with his Thunder: and till then who knew
95: The force of those dire Arms? yet not for those
96: Nor what the Potent Victor in his rage
97: Can else inflict do I repent or change,
98: Though chang'd in outward lustre; that fixt mind
99: And high disdain, from sence of injur'd merit,
100: That with the mightiest rais'd me to contend,
101: And to the fierce contention brought along
103: That durst dislike his reign, and me preferring,
104: His utmost power with adverse power oppos'd
105: In dubious Battel on the Plains of Heav'n,
106: And shook his throne.  What though the field be lost?
107: All is not lost; the unconquerable Will,
108: And study of revenge, immortal hate,
109: And courage never to submit or yield:
110: And what is else not to be overcome?
111: That Glory never shall his wrath or might
112: Extort from me.  To bow and sue for grace
113: With suppliant knee, and deifie his power
114: Who from the terrour of this Arm so late
115: Doubted his Empire, that were low indeed,
116: That were an ignominy and shame beneath
117: This downfall; since by Fate the strength of Gods
118: And this Empyreal substance cannot fail,
119: Since through experience of this great event
120: In Arms not worse, in foresight much advanc't,
121: We may with more successful hope resolve
122: To wage by force or guile eternal Warr
124: Who now triumphs, and in th' excess of joy
125: Sole reigning holds the Tyranny of Heav'n.
126: ¶So spake th' Apostate Angel, though in pain,
127: Vaunting aloud, but rackt with deep despare:
128: And him thus answer'd soon his bold Compeer.
129: ¶O Prince, O Chief of many Throned Powers,
130: That led th' imbattelld Seraphim to Warr
131: Under thy conduct, and in dreadful deeds
133: And put to proof his high Supremacy,
134: Whether upheld by strength, or Chance, or Fate,
135: Too well I see and rue the dire event,
136: That with sad overthrow and foul defeat
137: Hath lost us Heav'n, and all this mighty Host
138: In horrible destruction laid thus low,
139: As far as Gods and Heav'nly Essences
140: Can Perish: for the mind and spirit remains
142: Though all our Glory extinct, and happy state
143: Here swallow'd up in endless misery.
144: But what if he our Conquerour, (whom I now
145: Of force believe Almighty, since no less
146: Then such could hav orepow'rd such force as ours)
147: Have left us this our spirit and strength intire
148: Strongly to suffer and support our pains,
149: That we may so suffice his vengeful ire,
150: Or do him mightier service as his thralls
151: By right of Warr, what e're his business be
152: Here in the heart of Hell to work in Fire,
153: Or do his Errands in the gloomy Deep;
154: What can it then avail though yet we feel
157: Whereto with speedy words th' Arch-fiend reply'd.
158: ¶Fall'n Cherube, to be weak is miserable
159: Doing or Suffering: but of this be sure,
160: To do ought good never will be our task,
161: But ever to do ill our sole delight,
162: As being the contrary to his high will
163: Whom we resist.  If then his Providence
164: Out of our evil seek to bring forth good,
165: Our labour must be to pervert that end,
166: And out of good still to find means of evil;
167: Which oft times may succeed, so as perhaps
168: Shall grieve him, if I fail not, and disturb
169: His inmost counsels from their destind aim.
170: But see the angry Victor hath recall'd
171: His Ministers of vengeance and pursuit
172: Back to the Gates of Heav'n: The Sulphurous Hail
173: Shot after us in storm, oreblown hath laid
174: The fiery Surge, that from the Precipice
175: Of Heav'n receiv'd us falling, and the Thunder,
176: Wing'd with red Lightning and impetuous rage,
177: Perhaps hath spent his shafts, and ceases now
178: To bellow through the vast and boundless Deep.
179: Let us not slip th' occasion, whether scorn,
180: Or satiate fury yield it from our Foe.
181: Seest thou yon dreary Plain, forlorn and wilde,
182: The seat of desolation, voyd of light,
183: Save what the glimmering of these livid flames
184: Casts pale and dreadful?  Thither let us tend
185: From off the tossing of these fiery waves,
186: There rest, if any rest can harbour there,
188: Consult how we may henceforth most offend
189: Our Enemy, our own loss how repair,
191: What reinforcement we may gain from Hope,
192: If not what resolution from despare.
193: ¶Thus Satan talking to his neerest Mate
194: With Head up-lift above the wave, and Eyes
195: That sparkling blaz'd, his other Parts besides
196: Prone on the Flood, extended long and large
197: Lay floating many a rood, in bulk as huge
198: As whom the Fables name of monstrous size,
201: By ancient *Tarsus* held, or that Sea-beast
202: *Leviathan*, which God of all his works
203: Created hugest that swim th' Ocean stream:
204: Him haply slumbring on the *Norway* foam
205: The Pilot of some small night-founder'd Skiff,
206: Deeming some Island, oft, as Sea-men tell,
207: With fixed Anchor in his skaly rind
208: Moors by his side under the Lee, while Night
209: Invests the Sea, and wished Morn delayes:
210: So stretcht out huge in length the Arch-fiend lay
211: Chain'd on the burning Lake, nor ever thence
212: Had ris'n or heav'd his head, but that the will
213: And high permission of all-ruling Heaven
214: Left him at large to his own dark designs,
215: That with reiterated crimes he might
216: Heap on himself damnation, while he sought
217: Evil to others, and enrag'd might see
218: How all his malice serv'd but to bring forth
219: Infinite goodness, grace and mercy shewn
220: On Man by him seduc't, but on himself
221: Treble confusion, wrath and vengeance pour'd.
222: Forthwith upright he rears from off the Pool
223: His mighty Stature; on each hand the flames
224: Drivn backward slope their pointing spires, & rowld
225: In billows, leave i'th' midst a horrid Vale.
226: Then with expanded wings he stears his flight
227: Aloft, incumbent on the dusky Air
228: That felt unusual weight, till on dry Land
229: He lights, if it were Land that ever burn'd
230: With solid, as the Lake with liquid fire;
231: And such appear'd in hue, as when the force
232: Of subterranean wind transports a Hill
233: Torn from *Pelorus*, or the shatter'd side
235: And fewel'd entrals thence conceiving Fire,
236: Sublim'd with Mineral fury, aid the Winds,
237: And leave a singed bottom all involv'd
238: With stench and smoak: Such resting found the sole
239: Of unblest feet.  Him followed his next Mate,
240: Both glorying to have scap't the *Stygian* flood
241: As Gods, and by their own recover'd strength,
242: Not by the sufferance of supernal Power.
243: ¶Is this the Region, this the Soil, the Clime,
244: Said then the lost Arch Angel, this the seat
245: That we must change for Heav'n, this mournful gloom
246: For that celestial light?  Be it so, since hee
247: Who now is Sovran can dispose and bid
248: What shall be right: fardest from him is best
249: Whom reason hath equald, force hath made supream
250: Above his equals.  Farewel happy Fields
251: Where Joy for ever dwells: Hail horrours, hail
252: Infernal world, and thou profoundest Hell
253: Receive thy new Possessor: One who brings
254: A mind not to be chang'd by Place or Time.
255: The mind is its own place, and in it self
256: Can make a Heav'n of Hell, a Hell of Heav'n.
257: What matter where, if I be still the same,
258: And what I should be, all but less then hee
259: Whom Thunder hath made greater?  Here at least
260: We shall be free; th' Almighty hath not built
261: Here for his envy, will not drive us hence:
262: Here we may reign secure, and in my choyce
263: To reign is worth ambition though in Hell:
264: Better to reign in Hell, then serve in Heav'n.
265: But wherefore let we then our faithful friends,
266: Th' associates and copartners of our loss
267: Lye thus astonisht on th' oblivious Pool,
268: And call them not to share with us their part
269: In this unhappy Mansion, or once more
270: With rallied Arms to try what may be yet
271: Regaind in Heav'n, or what more lost in Hell?
273: Thus answer'd.  Leader of those Armies bright,
274: Which but th' Omnipotent none could have foyld,
275: If once they hear that voyce, their liveliest pledge
276: Of hope in fears and dangers, heard so oft
277: In worst extreams, and on the perilous edge
278: Of battel when it rag'd, in all assaults
279: Their surest signal, they will soon resume
280: New courage and revive, though now they lye
281: Groveling and prostrate on yon Lake of Fire,
282: As we erewhile, astounded and amaz'd,
283: No wonder, fall'n such a pernicious highth.
284: ¶He scarce had ceas't when the superiour Fiend
285: Was moving toward the shore; his ponderous shield
286: Ethereal temper, massy, large and round,
287: Behind him cast; the broad circumference
288: Hung on his shoulders like the Moon, whose Orb
289: Through Optic Glass the *Tuscan* Artist views
290: At Ev'ning from the top of *Fesole*,
291: Or in *Valdarno*, to descry new Lands,
292: Rivers or Mountains in her spotty Globe.
293: His Spear, to equal which the tallest Pine
294: Hewn on *Norwegian* hills, to be the Mast
295: Of some great Ammiral, were but a wand,
296: He walkt with to support uneasie steps
297: Over the burning Marle, not like those steps
298: On Heavens Azure, and the torrid Clime
299: Smote on him sore besides, vaulted with Fire;
300: Nathless he so endur'd, till on the Beach
301: Of that inflamed Sea, he stood and call'd
302: His Legions, Angel Forms, who lay intrans't
303: Thick as Autumnal Leaves that strow the Brooks
305: High overarch't imbowr; or scatterd sedge
306: Afloat, when with fierce Winds *Orion* arm'd
307: Hath vext the Red-Sea Coast, whose waves orethrew
309: While with perfidious hatred they pursu'd
311: From the safe shore their floating Carkases
312: And broken Chariot Wheels, so thick bestrown
313: Abject and lost lay these, covering the Flood,
314: Under amazement of their hideous change.
315: He call'd so loud, that all the hollow Deep
317: Warriers, the Flowr of Heav'n, once yours, now lost,
318: If such astonishment as this can sieze
319: Eternal spirits; or have ye chos'n this place
320: After the toyl of Battel to repose
321: Your wearied vertue, for the ease you find
322: To slumber here, as in the Vales of Heav'n?
323: Or in this abject posture have ye sworn
324: To adore the Conquerour? who now beholds
325: Cherube and Seraph rowling in the Flood
326: With scatter'd Arms and Ensigns, till anon
327: His swift pursuers from Heav'n Gates discern
328: Th' advantage, and descending tread us down
329: Thus drooping, or with linked Thunderbolts
330: Transfix us to the bottom of this Gulfe.
331: Awake, arise, or be for ever fall'n.
332: ¶They heard, and were abasht, and up they sprung
333: Upon the wing, as when men wont to watch
334: On duty, sleeping found by whom they dread,
335: Rouse and bestir themselves ere well awake.
336: Nor did they not perceave the evil plight
337: In which they were, or the fierce pains not feel;
338: Yet to their Generals Voyce they soon obeyd
339: Innumerable.  As when the potent Rod
341: Wav'd round the Coast, up call'd a pitchy cloud
342: Of *Locusts*, warping on the Eastern Wind,
343: That ore the Realm of impious *Pharoah* hung
344: Like Night, and darken'd all the Land of *Nile*:
345: So numberless were those bad Angels seen
346: Hovering on wing under the Cope of Hell
348: Till, as a signal giv'n, th' uplifted Spear
349: Of their great Sultan waving to direct
350: Thir course, in even ballance down they light
351: On the firm brimstone, and fill all the Plain;
352: A multitude, like which the populous North
353: Pour'd never from her frozen loyns, to pass
354: *Rhene* or the *Danaw*, when her barbarous Sons
355: Came like a Deluge on the South, and spread
357: Forthwith from every Squadron and each Band
358: The Heads and Leaders thither hast where stood
359: Their great Commander; Godlike shapes and forms
361: And Powers that earst in Heaven sat on Thrones;
362: Though of their Names in heav'nly Records now
363: Be no memorial, blotted out and ras'd
364: By thir Rebellion, from the Books of Life.
365: Nor had they yet among the Sons of *Eve*
366: Got them new Names, till wandring ore the Earth,
367: Through Gods high sufferance for the tryal of man,
368: By falsities and lyes the greatest part
369: Of Mankind they corrupted to forsake
370: God their Creator, and th' invisible
371: Glory of him, that made them, to transform
372: Oft to the Image of a Brute, adorn'd
373: With gay Religions full of Pomp and Gold,
374: And Devils to adore for Deities:
375: Then were they known to men by various Names,
376: And various Idols through the Heathen World.
377: Say, Muse, their Names then known, who first, who last,
378: Rous'd from the slumber, on that fiery Couch,
379: At thir great Emperors call, as next in worth
380: Came singly where he stood on the bare strand,
381: While the promiscuous croud stood yet aloof?
382: The chief were those who from the Pit of Hell
383: Roaming to seek their prey on earth, durst fix
384: Their Seats long after next the Seat of God,
385: Their Altars by his Altar, Gods ador'd
386: Among the Nations round, and durst abide
388: Between the Cherubim; yea, often plac'd
389: Within his Sanctuary it self their Shrines,
391: His holy Rites, and solemn Feasts profan'd,
392: And with their darkness durst affront his light.
393: First *Moloch*, horrid King besmear'd with blood
394: Of human sacrifice, and parents tears,
395: Though for the noyse of Drums and Timbrels loud
396: Their childrens cries unheard, that past through fire
397: To his grim Idol.  Him the *Ammonite*
398: Worshipt in *Rabba* and her watry Plain,
399: In *Argob* and in *Basan*, to the stream
400: Of utmost *Arnon*.  Nor content with such
402: Of *Solomon* he led by fraud to build
403: His Temple right against the Temple of God
404: On that opprobrious Hill, and made his Grove
406: And black *Gehenna* call'd, the Type of Hell.
407: Next *Chemos*, th' obscene dread of *Moabs* Sons,
411: The flowry Dale of *Sibma* clad with Vines,
413: *Peor* his other Name, when he entic'd
415: To do him wanton rites, which cost them woe.
416: Yet thence his lustful Orgies he enlarg'd
417: Even to that Hill of scandal, by the Grove
418: Of *Moloch* homicide, lust hard by hate;
419: Till good *Josiah* drove them thence to Hell.
420: With these came they, who from the bordring flood
421: Of old *Euphrates* to the Brook that parts
424: These Feminine.  For Spirits when they please
425: Can either Sex assume, or both; so soft
426: And uncompounded is their Essence pure,
427: Not ti'd or manacl'd with joynt or limb,
428: Nor founded on the brittle strength of bones,
429: Like cumbrous flesh; but in what shape they choose
430: Dilated or condens't, bright or obscure,
432: And works of love or enmity fulfill.
433: For those the Race of *Israel* oft forsook
434: Their living strength, and unfrequented left
435: His righteous Altar, bowing lowly down
436: To bestial Gods; for which their heads as low
437: Bow'd down in Battel, sunk before the Spear
438: Of despicable foes.  With these in troop
440: *Astarte*, Queen of Heav'n, with crescent Horns;
441: To whose bright Image nightly by the Moon
442: *Sidonian* Virgins paid their Vows and Songs,
443: In *Sion* also not unsung, where stood
444: Her Temple on th' offensive Mountain, built
445: By that uxorious King, whose heart though large,
447: To Idols foul. *Thammuz* came next behind,
449: The *Syrian* Damsels to lament his fate
450: In amorous dittyes all a Summers day,
451: While smooth *Adonis* from his native Rock
452: Ran purple to the Sea, suppos'd with blood
455: Whose wanton passions in the sacred Porch
456: *Ezekiel* saw, when by the Vision led
457: His eye survay'd the dark Idolatries
459: Who mourn'd in earnest, when the Captive Ark
460: Maim'd his brute Image, head and hands lopt off
461: In his own Temple, on the grunsel edge,
462: Where he fell flat, and sham'd his Worshipers:
463: *Dagon* his Name, Sea Monster, upward Man
464: And downward Fish: yet had his Temple high
465: Rear'd in *Azotus*, dreaded through the Coast
469: Was fair *Damscus*, on the fertil Banks
471: He also against the house of God was bold:
472: A Leper once he lost and gain'd a King,
473: *Ahaz* his sottish Conquerour, whom he drew
474: Gods Altar to disparage and displace
475: For one of *Syrian* mode, whereon to burn
476: His odious offrings, and adore the Gods
477: Whom he had vanquisht. After these appear'd
478: A crew who under Names of old Renown,
480: With monstrous shapes and sorceries abus'd
481: Fanatic *Egypt* and her Priests, to seek
482: Thir wandring Gods disguis'd in brutish forms
483: Rather then human.  Nor did *Israel* scape
484: Th' infection when their borrow'd Gold compos'd
485: The Calf in *Oreb*: and the Rebel King
486: Doubl'd that sin in *Bethel* and in *Dan*,
487: Lik'ning his Maker to the Grazed Ox,
488: *Jehovah*, who in one Night when he pass'd
489: From *Egypt* marching, equal'd with one stroke
490: Both her first born and all her bleating Gods.
491: *Belial* came last, then whom a Spirit more lewd
492: Fell not from Heaven, or more gross to love
493: Vice for it self: To him no Temple stood
494: Or Altar smoak'd; yet who more oft then hee
495: In Temples and at Altars, when the Priest
496: Turns Atheist, as did *Ely's* Sons, who fill'd
497: With lust and violence the house of God.
498: In Courts and Palaces he also Reigns
499: And in luxurious Cities, where the noyse
500: Of riot ascends above thir loftiest Towrs,
501: And injury and outrage: And when Night
502: Darkens the Streets, then wander forth the Sons
503: Of *Belial*, flown with insolence and wine.
504: Witness the Streets of *Sodom*, and that night
506: Yielded thir Matrons to prevent worse rape.
507: These were the prime in order and in might;
508: The rest were long to tell, though far renown'd,
510: Gods, yet confest later then Heav'n and Earth
511: Thir boasted Parents; *Titian* Heav'ns first born
512: With his enormous brood, and birthright seis'd
514: His own and *Rhea's* Son like measure found;
515: So *Jove* usurping reign'd: these first in *Creet*
516: And *Ida* known, thence on the Snowy top
517: Of cold *Olympus* rul'd the middle Air
518: Thir highest Heav'n; or on the *Delphian* Cliff,
519: Or in *Dodona*, and through all the bounds
520: Of *Doric* Land; or who with *Saturn* old
522: And ore the *Celtic* roam'd the utmost Isles.
523: All these and more came flocking; but with looks
524: Down cast and damp, yet such wherein appear'd
525: Obscure som glimps of joy, to have found thir chief
526: Not in despair, to have found themselves not lost
527: In loss it self; which on his count'nance cast
528: Like doubtful hue: but he his wonted pride
529: Soon recollecting, with high words, that bore
530: Semblance of worth not substance, gently rais'd
531: Their fainted courage, and dispel'd their fears.
532: Then strait commands that at the warlike sound
533: Of Trumpets loud and Clarions be upreard
534: His mighty Standard; that proud honour claim'd
535: *Azazel* as his right, a Cherube tall:
536: Who forthwith from the glittering Staff unfurld
537: Th' Imperial Ensign, which full high advanc't
538: Shon like a Meteor streaming to the Wind
539: With Gemms and Golden lustre rich imblaz'd,
540: Seraphic arms and Trophies: all the while
542: At which the universal Host upsent
543: A shout that tore Hells Concave, and beyond
544: Frighted the Reign of *Chaos* and old Night.
545: All in a moment through the gloom were seen
546: Ten thousand Banners rise into the Air
547: With Orient Colours waving: with them rose
548: A Forrest huge of Spears: and thronging Helms
549: Appear'd, and serried Shields in thick array
550: Of depth immeasurable: Anon they move
551: In perfect *Phalanx* to the Dorian mood
552: Of Flutes and soft Recorders; such as rais'd
553: To highth of noblest temper Hero's old
554: Arming to Battel, and in stead of rage
555: Deliberate valour breath'd, firm and unmov'd
556: With dread of death to flight or foul retreat,
557: Nor wanting power to mitigate and swage
558: With solemn touches, troubl'd thoughts, and chase
559: Anguish and doubt and fear and sorrow and pain
560: From mortal or immortal minds.  Thus they
561: Breathing united force with fixed thought
562: Mov'd on in silence to soft Pipes that charm'd
563: Thir painful steps o're the burnt soyle; and now
564: Advanc't in view they stand, a horrid Front
565: Of dreadful length and dazling Arms, in guise
566: Of Warriers old with order'd Spear and Shield,
567: Awaiting what command thir mighty Chief
568: Had to impose: He through the armed Files
569: Darts his experienc't eye, and soon traverse
570: The whole Battalion views, thir order due,
571: Thir visages and stature as of Gods,
572: Thir number last he summs.  And now his heart
573: Distends with pride, and hardning in his strength
574: Glories: For never since created man,
575: Met such imbodied force, as nam'd with these
576: Could merit more then that small infantry
577: Warr'd on by Cranes: though all the Giant brood
578: Of *Phlegra* with th' Heroic Race were joyn'd
579: That fought at *Theb's* and *Ilium*, on each side
580: Mixt with auxiliar Gods; and what resounds
583: And all who since, Baptiz'd or Infidel
587: When *Charlemain* with all his Peerage fell
589: Compare of mortal prowess, yet observ'd
590: Thir dread Commander: he above the rest
591: In shape and gesture proudly eminent
592: Stood like a Towr; his form had yet not lost
593: All her Original brightness, nor appear'd
594: Less then Arch Angel ruind, and th' excess
595: Of Glory obscur'd: As when the Sun new ris'n
596: Looks through the Horizontal misty Air
597: Shorn of his Beams, or from behind the Moon
598: In dim Eclips disastrous twilight sheds
599: On half the Nations, and with fear of change
600: Perplexes Monarchs.  Dark'n'd so, yet shon
601: Above them all th' Arch Angel: but his face
602: Deep scars of Thunder had intrencht, and care
603: Sat on his faded cheek, but under Browes
604: Of dauntless courage, and considerate Pride
605: Waiting revenge: cruel his eye, but cast
606: Signs of remorse and passion to behold
607: The fellows of his crime, the followers rather
608: (Far other once beheld in bliss) condemn'd
609: For ever now to have their lot in pain,
610: Millions of Spirits for his fault amerc't
611: Of Heav'n, and from Eternal Splendors flung
612: For his revolt, yet faithfull how they stood,
613: Thir Glory witherd.  As when Heavens Fire
614: Hath scath'd the Forrest Oaks, or Mountain Pines,
615: With singed top their stately growth though bare
616: Stands on the blasted Heath.  He now prepar'd
617: To speak; whereat their doubl'd Ranks they bend
618: From Wing to Wing, and half enclose him round
619: With all his Peers: attention held them mute.
620: Thrice he assayd, and thrice in spite of scorn,
621: Tears such as Angels weep, burst forth: at last
622: Words interwove with sighs found out their way.
623: ¶O Myriads of immortal Spirits, O Powers
624: Matchless, but with th' Almighty, and that strife
625: Was not inglorious, though th' event was dire,
626: As this place testifies, and this dire change
627: Hateful to utter: but what power of mind
628: Foreseeing or presaging, from the Depth
629: Of knowledge past or present, could have fear'd,
630: How such united force of Gods, how such
631: As stood like these, could ever know repulse?
632: For who can yet beleeve, though after loss,
633: That all these puissant Legions, whose exile
634: Hath emptied Heav'n, shall faile to re-ascend
635: Self-rais'd, and repossess their native seat.
636: For me, be witness all the Host of Heav'n,
637: If counsels different, or danger shun'd
638: By me, have lost our hopes.  But he who reigns
639: Monarch in Heav'n, till then as one secure
640: Sat on his Throne, upheld by old repute,
641: Consent or custome, and his Regal State
642: Put forth at full, but still his strength conceal'd,
643: Which tempted our attempt, and wrought our fall.
644: Henceforth his might we know, and know our own
645: So as not either to provoke, or dread
646: New warr, provok't; our better part remains
647: To work in close design, by fraud or guile
648: What force effected not: that he no less
649: At length from us may find, who overcomes
650: By force, hath overcome but half his foe.
651: Space may produce new Worlds; whereof so rife
652: There went a fame in Heav'n that he ere long
653: Intended to create, and therein plant
654: A generation, whom his choice regard
655: Should favour equal to the Sons of Heaven:
656: Thither, if but to prie, shall be perhaps
657: Our first eruption, thither or elsewhere:
658: For this Infernal Pit shall never hold
659: Caelestial Spirits in Bondage, nor th' Abysse
660: Long under darkness cover.  But these thoughts
661: Full Counsel must mature: Peace is despaird,
662: For who can think Submission?  Warr then, Warr
663: Open or understood must be resolv'd.
664: ¶He spake: and to confirm his words, out-flew
665: Millions of flaming swords, drawn from the thighs
666: Of mighty Cherubim; the sudden blaze
667: Far round illumin'd hell: highly they rag'd
668: Against the Highest, and fierce with grasped arm's
669: Clash'd on their sounding shields the din of war,
670: Hurling defiance toward the vault of Heav'n.
671: ¶There stood a Hill not far whose griesly top
672: Belch'd fire and rowling smoak; the rest entire
673: Shon with a glossie scurff, undoubted sign
674: That in his womb was hid metallic Ore,
675: The work of Sulphur.  Thither wing'd with speed
676: A numerous Brigad hasten'd.  As when bands
677: Of Pioners with Spade and Pickaxe arm'd
678: Forerun the Royal Camp, to trench a Field,
679: Or cast a Rampart.  *Mammon* led them on,
680: *Mammon*, the least erected Spirit that fell
681: From heav'n, for ev'n in heav'n his looks & thoughts
682: Were always downward bent, admiring more
683: The riches of Heav'ns pavement, trod'n Gold,
684: Then aught divine or holy else enjoy'd
685: In vision beatific: by him first
686: Men also, and by his suggestion taught,
687: Ransack'd the Center, and with impious hands
688: Rifl'd the bowels of thir mother Earth
689: For Treasures better hid.  Soon had his crew
690: Op'nd into the Hill a spacious wound
691: And dig'd out ribs of Gold.  Let none admire
692: That riches grow in Hell; that soyle may best
693: Deserve the pretious bane.  And here let those
694: Who boast in mortal things, and wondring tell
695: Of *Babel*, and the works of *Memphian* Kings,
696: Learn how thir greatest Monuments of Fame,
697: And Strength and Art are easily outdone
698: By Spirits reprobate, and in an hour
699: What in an age they with incessant toyle
701: Nigh on the Plain in many cells prepar'd,
702: That underneath had veins of liquid fire
703: Sluc'd from the Lake, a second multitude
704: With wondrous Art founded the massie Ore,
705: Severing each kinde, and scum'd the Bullion dross:
706: A third as soon had form'd within the ground
707: A various mould, and from the boyling cells
708: By strange conveyance fill'd each hollow nook,
709: As in an Organ from one blast of wind
710: To many a row of Pipes the sound-board breaths.
711: Anon out of the earth a Fabrick huge
712: Rose like an Exhalation, with the sound
713: Of Dulcet Symphonies and voices sweet,
714: Built like a Temple, where *Pilasters* round
715: Were set, and Doric pillars overlaid
716: With Golden Architrave; nor did there want
717: Cornice or Freeze, with bossy Sculptures grav'n,
718: The Roof was fretted Gold.  Not *Babilon*,
720: Equal'd in all thir glories, to inshrine
723: In wealth and luxurie.  Th' ascending pile
724: Stood fixt her stately highth, and strait the dores
725: Op'ning thir brazen foulds discover wide
726: Within, her ample spaces, o're the smooth
727: And level pavement: from the arched roof
728: Pendant by suttle Magic many a row
729: Of Starry Lamps and blazing Cressets fed
731: As from a sky.  The hasty multitude
732: Admiring enter'd, and the work some praise
733: And some the Architect: his hand was known
734: In Heav'n by many a Towred structure high,
735: Where Scepter'd Angels held thir residence,
736: And sat as Princes, whom the supreme King
737: Exalted to such power, and gave to rule,
738: Each in his Herarchie, the Orders bright.
739: Nor was his name unheard or unador'd
740: In ancient Greece; and in *Ausonian* land
741: Men call'd him *Mulciber*; and how he fell
742: From Heav'n, they fabl'd, thrown by angry *Jove*
743: Sheer o're the Chrystal Battlements: from Morn
744: To Noon he fell, from Noon to dewy Eve,
745: A Summers day; and with the setting Sun
746: Dropt from the Zenith like a falling Star,
747: On *Lemnos* th' *Aegaean* Ile: thus they relate,
748: Erring; for he with this rebellious rout
749: Fell long before; nor aught avail'd him now
750: To have built in Heav'n high Towrs; nor did he scape
751: By all his Engins, but was headlong sent
752: With his industrious crew to build in hell.
753: Mean while the winged Haralds by command
754: Of Sovran power, with awful Ceremony
755: And Trumpets sound throughout the Host proclaim
756: A solemn Councel forthwith to be held
758: Of Satan and his Peers: thir summons call'd
759: From every and Band squared Regiment
760: By place or choice the worthiest; they anon
761: With hundreds and with thousands trooping came
762: Attended: all access was throng'd, the Gates
763: And Porches wide, but chief the spacious Hall
764: (Though like a cover'd field, where Champions bold
765: Wont ride in arm'd, and at the Soldans chair
766: Defi'd the best of Panim chivalry
767: To mortal combat or carreer with Lance)
768: Thick swarm'd, both on the ground and in the air,
769: Brusht with the hiss of russling wings.  As Bees
770: In spring time, when the Sun with Taurus rides,
771: Poure forth thir populous youth about the Hive
772: In clusters; they among fresh dews and flowers
773: Flie to and fro, or on the smoothed Plank,
774: The suburb of thir Straw-built Cittadel,
775: New rub'd with Baume, expatiate and confer
776: Thir State affairs.  So thick the aerie crowd
777: Swarm'd and were straitn'd; till the Signal giv'n,
778: Behold a wonder! they but now who seemd
779: In bigness to surpass Earths Giant Sons
780: Now less then smallest Dwarfs, in narrow room
781: Throng numberless, like that Pigmean Race
782: Beyond the *Indian* Mount, or Faerie Elves,
783: Whose midnight Revels, by a Forrest side
784: Or Fountain fome belated Peasant sees,
785: Or dreams he sees, while over head the Moon
786: Sits Arbitress, and neerer to the Earth
787: Wheels her pale course, they on thir mirth & dance
788: Intent, with jocond Music charm his ear;
789: At once with joy and fear his heart rebounds.
790: Thus incorporeal Spirits to smallest forms
791: Reduc'd thir shapes immense, and were at large,
792: Though without number still amidst the Hall
793: Of that infernal Court.  But far within
794: And in thir own dimensions like themselves
795: The great Seraphic Lords and Cherubim
796: In close recess and secret conclave sat
797: A thousand Demy-Gods on golden seat's,
798: Frequent and full.  After short silence then
799: And summons read, the great consult began.
802: ¶High on a Throne of Royal State, which far
803: Outshon the wealth of *Ormus* and of *Ind*,
804: Or where the gorgeous East with richest hand
805: Showrs on her Kings *Barbaric* Pearl & Gold,
806: Satan exalted sat, by merit rais'd
807: To that bad eminence; and from despair
808: Thus high uplifted beyond hope, aspires
809: Beyond thus high, insatiate to pursue
810: Vain Warr with Heav'n, and by success untaught
813: For since no deep within her gulf can hold
814: Immortal vigor, though opprest and fall'n,
815: I give not Heav'n for lost.  From this descent
817: More glorious and more dread then from no fall,
818: And trust themselves to fear no second fate:
819: Mee though just right, and the fixt Laws of Heav'n
820: Did first create your Leader, next, free choice,
821: With what besides, in Counsel or in Fight,
822: Hath bin achievd of merit, yet this loss
823: Thus farr at least recover'd, hath much more
824: Establisht in a safe unenvied Throne
825: Yeilded with full consent.  The happier state
826: In Heav'n, which follows dignity, might draw
827: Envy from each inferior; but who here
828: Will envy whom the highest place exposes
829: Formost to stand against the Thunderers aime
830: Your bulwark, and condemns to greatest share
831: Of endless pain? where there is then no good
832: For which to strive, no strife can grow up there
833: From Faction; for none sure will claim in hell
834: Precedence, none, whose portion is so small
835: Of present pain, that with ambitious mind
836: Will covet more.  With this advantage then
837: To union, and firm Faith, and firm accord,
838: More then can be in Heav'n, we now return
839: To claim our just inheritance of old,
841: Could have assur'd us; and by what best way,
842: Whether of open Warr or covert guile,
843: We now debate; who can advise, may speak.
844: ¶He ceas'd, and next him *Moloc*, Scepter'd King
845: Stood up, the strongest and the fiercest Spirit
846: That fought in Heav'n; now fiercer by despair:
847: His trust was with th' Eternal to be deem'd
848: Equal in strength, and rather then be less
849: Car'd not to be at all; with that care lost
850: Went all his fear: of God, or Hell, or worse
851: He reckd not, and these words thereafter spake.
852: ¶My sentence is for open Warr: Of Wiles,
853: More unexpert, I boast not: them let those
854: Contrive who need, or when they need, not now.
855: For while they sit contriving, shall the rest,
856: Millions that stand in Arms, and longing wait
857: The Signal to ascend, sit lingring here
858: Heav'ns fugitives, and for thir dwelling place
859: Accept this dark opprobrious Den of shame,
860: The Prison of his Tyranny who Reigns
861: By our delay? no, let us rather choose
862: Arm'd with Hell flames and fury all at once
863: O're Heav'ns high Towrs to force resistless way,
864: Turning our Tortures into horrid Arms
865: Against the Torturer; when to meet the noise
866: Of his Almighty Engin he shall hear
867: Infernal Thunder, and for Lightning see
868: Black fire and horror shot with equal rage
869: Among his Angels; and his Throne it self
870: Mixt with *Tartarean* Sulphur, and strange fire,
871: His own invented Torments.  But perhaps
872: The way seems difficult and steep to scale
873: With upright wing against a higher foe.
874: Let such bethink them, if the sleepy drench
875: Of that forgetful Lake benumme not still,
876: That in our proper motion we ascend
877: Up to our native seat: descent and fall
878: To us is adverse.  Who but felt of late
879: When the fierce Foe hung on our brok'n Rear
880: Insulting, and pursu'd us through the Deep,
881: With what compulsion and laborious flight
882: We sunk thus low?  Th' ascent is easie then;
883: Th' event is fear'd; should we again provoke
884: Our stronger, some worse way his wrath may find
885: To our destruction: if there be in Hell
886: Fear to be worse destroy'd: what can be worse
887: Then to dwell here, driv'n out from bliss, condemn'd
888: In this abhorred deep to utter woe;
890: Must exercise us without hope of end
891: The Vassals of his anger, when the Scourge
893: Calls us to Penance?  More destroy'd then thus
894: We should be quite abolisht and expire.
895: What fear we then? what doubt we to incense
896: His utmost ire? which to the highth enrag'd,
897: Will either quite consume us, and reduce
898: To nothing this essential, happier farr
899: Then miserable to have eternal being:
900: Or if our substance be indeed Divine,
901: And cannot cease to be, we are at worst
902: On this side nothing; and by proof we feel
903: Our power sufficient to disturb his Heav'n,
904: And with perpetual inrodes to Allarme,
906: Which if not Victory is yet Revenge.
907: ¶He ended frowning, and his look denounc'd
909: To less then Gods.  On th' other side up rose
910: *Belial*, in act more graceful and humane;
911: A fairer person lost not Heav'n; he seemd
912: For dignity compos'd and high exploit:
913: But all was false and hollow; though his Tongue
914: Dropt Manna, and could make the worse appear
915: The better reason, to perplex and dash
916: Maturest Counsels: for his thoughts were low;
917: To vice industrious, but to Nobler deeds
918: Timorous and slothful: yet he pleas'd the eare,
919: And with perswasive accent thus began.
920: ¶I should be much for open Warr, O Peers,
921: As not behind in hate; if what was urg'd
922: Main reason to perswade immediate Warr,
923: Did not disswade me most, and seem to cast
924: Ominous conjecture on the whole success:
925: When he who most excels in fact of Arms,
926: In what he counsels and in what excels
927: Mistrustful, grounds his courage on despair
928: And utter dissolution, as the scope
929: Of all his aim, after some dire revenge.
930: First, what Revenge? the Towrs of Heav'n are fill'd
931: With Armed watch, that render all access
932: Impregnable; oft on the bordering Deep
933: Encamp thir Legions, or with obscure wing
934: Scout farr and wide into the Realm of night,
935: Scorning surprize.  Or could we break our way
936: By force, and at our heels all Hell should rise
938: Heav'ns purest Light, yet our great Enemie
939: All incorruptible would on his Throne
940: Sit unpolluted, and th' Ethereal mould
941: Incapable of stain would soon expel
942: Her mischief, and purge off the baser fire
943: Victorious.  Thus repuls'd, our final hope
944: Is flat despair: we must exasperate
945: Th' Almighty Victor to spend all his rage,
946: And that must end us, that must be our cure,
947: To be no more; sad cure; for who would loose,
948: Though full of pain, this intellectual being,
949: Those thoughts that wander through Eternity,
950: To perish rather, swallowd up and lost
951: In the wide womb of uncreated night,
952: Devoid of sense and motion? and who knows,
953: Let this be good, whether our angry Foe
954: Can give it, or will ever? how he can
955: Is doubtful; that he never will is sure.
956: Will he, so wise, let loose at once his ire,
958: To give his Enemies thir wish, and end
959: Them in his anger, whom his anger saves
960: To punish endless? wherefore cease we then?
961: Say they who counsel Warr, we are decreed,
962: Reserv'd and destin'd to Eternal woe;
963: Whatever doing, what can we suffer more,
964: What can we suffer worse? is this then worst,
965: Thus sitting, thus consulting, thus in Arms?
966: What when we fled amain, pursu'd and strook
967: With Heav'ns afflicting Thunder, and besought
968: The Deep to shelter us? this Hell then seem'd
969: A refuge from those wounds: or when we lay
970: Chain'd on the burning Lake? that sure was worse.
971: What if the breath that kindl'd those grim fires
972: Awak'd should blow them into sevenfold rage
973: And plunge us in the Flames? or from above
975: His red right hand to plague us? what if all
976: Her stores were op'n'd, and this Firmament
977: Of Hell should spout her Cataracts of Fire,
979: One day upon our heads; while we perhaps
981: Caught in a fierie Tempest shall be hurl'd
982: Each on his rock transfixt, the sport and prey
983: Of racking whirlwinds, or for ever sunk
984: Under yon boyling Ocean, wrapt in Chains;
985: There to converse with everlasting groans,
987: Ages of hopeless end; this would be worse.
988: Warr therefore, open or conceal'd, alike
989: My voice disswades; for what can force or guile
990: With him, or who deceive his mind, whose eye
991: Views all things at one view? he from heav'ns highth
992: All these our motions vain, sees and derides;
993: Not more Almighty to resist our might
994: Then wise to frustrate all our plots and wiles.
995: Shall we then live thus vile, the race of Heav'n
996: Thus trampl'd, thus expell'd to suffer here
997: Chains & these Torments? better these then worse
998: By my advice; since fate inevitable
1000: The Victors will.  To suffer, as to doe,
1001: Our strength is equal, nor the Law unjust
1002: That so ordains: this was at first resolv'd,
1003: If we were wise, against so great a foe
1004: Contending, and so doubtful what might fall.
1005: I laugh, when those who at the Spear are bold
1006: And vent'rous, if that fail them, shrink and fear
1007: What yet they know must follow, to endure
1008: Exile, or ignominy, or bonds, or pain,
1009: The sentence of thir Conquerour: This is now
1010: Our doom; which if we can sustain and bear,
1011: Our Supream Foe in time may much remit
1012: His anger, and perhaps thus farr remov'd
1013: Not mind us not offending, satisfi'd
1014: With what is punish't; whence these raging fires
1015: Will slack'n, if his breath stir not thir flames.
1016: Our purer essence then will overcome
1017: Thir noxious vapour, or enur'd not feel,
1018: Or chang'd at length, and to the place conformd
1019: In temper and in nature, will receive
1020: Familiar the fierce heat, and void of pain;
1021: This horror will grow milde, this darkness light,
1022: Besides what hope the never-ending flight
1023: Of future days may bring, what chance, what change
1024: Worth waiting, since our present lot appeers
1025: For happy though but ill, for ill not worst,
1026: If we procure not to our selves more woe.
1027: ¶Thus *Belial* with words cloath'd in reasons garb
1028: Counsel'd ignoble ease, and peaceful sloath,
1029: Not peace: and after him thus *Mammon* spake.
1030: ¶Either to disinthrone the King of Heav'n
1031: We warr, if warr be best, or to regain
1032: Our own right lost: him to unthrone we then
1033: May hope, when everlasting Fate shall yeild
1034: To fickle Chance, and *Chaos* judge the strife:
1035: The former vain to hope argues as vain
1036: The latter: for what place can be for us
1037: Within Heav'ns bound, unless Heav'ns Lord supream
1038: We overpower?  Suppose he should relent
1039: And publish Grace to all, on promise made
1040: Of new Subjection; with what eyes could we
1041: Stand in his presence humble, and receive
1042: Strict Laws impos'd, to celebrate his Throne
1043: With warbl'd Hymns, and to his Godhead sing
1044: Forc't Halleluiah's; while he Lordly sits
1045: Our envied Sovran, and his Altar breathes
1047: Our servile offerings.  This must be our task
1048: In Heav'n, this our delight; how wearisom
1049: Eternity so spent in worship paid
1050: To whom we hate.  Let us not then pursue
1051: By force impossible, by leave obtain'd
1052: Unacceptable, though in Heav'n, our state
1053: Of splendid vassalage, but rather seek
1054: Our own good from our selves, and from our own
1055: Live to our selves, though in this vast recess,
1056: Free, and to none accountable, preferring
1057: Hard liberty before the easie yoke
1058: Of servile Pomp.  Our greatness will appear
1059: Then most conspicuous, when great things of small,
1060: Useful of hurtful, prosperous of adverse
1061: We can create, and in what place so e're
1062: Thrive under evil, and work ease out of pain
1063: Through labour and endurance.  This deep world
1064: Of darkness do we dread?  How oft amidst
1065: Thick clouds and dark doth Heav'ns all-ruling Sire
1066: Choose to reside, his Glory unobscur'd,
1067: And with the Majesty of darkness round
1068: Covers his Throne; from whence deep thunders roar
1069: Must'ring thir rage, and Heav'n resembles Hell?
1070: As he our Darkness, cannot we his Light
1071: Imitate when we please?  This Desart soile
1072: Wants not her hidden lustre, Gemms and Gold;
1073: Nor want we skill or art, from whence to raise
1074: Magnificence; and what can Heav'n shew more?
1075: Our torments also may in length of time
1076: Become our Elements, these piercing Fires
1077: As soft as now severe, our temper chang'd
1078: Into their temper; which must needs remove
1079: The sensible of pain.  All things invite
1080: To peaceful Counsels, and the settl'd State
1081: Of order, how in safety best we may
1082: Compose our present evils, with regard
1083: Of what we are and where, dismissing quite
1084: All thoughts of Warr: ye have what I advise.
1085: ¶He scarce had finisht, when such murmur filld
1086: Th' Assembly, as when hollow Rocks retain
1087: The sound of blustring winds, which all night long
1088: Had rous'd the Sea, now with hoarse cadence lull
1089: Sea-faring men orewatcht, whose Bark by chance
1090: Or Pinnace anchors in a craggy Bay
1091: After the Tempest: Such applause was heard
1092: As *Mammon* ended, and his Sentence pleas'd,
1093: Advising peace: for such another Field
1094: They dreaded worse then Hell: so much the fear
1095: Of Thunder and the Sword of *Michael*
1096: Wrought still within them; and no less desire
1097: To found this nether Empire, which might rise
1098: By pollicy, and long process of time,
1101: *Satan* except, none higher sat, with grave
1102: Aspect he rose, and in his rising seem'd
1103: A Pillar of State; deep on his Front engraven
1105: And Princely counsel in his face yet shon,
1106: Majestick though in ruin: sage he stood
1108: The weight of mightiest Monarchies; his look
1109: Drew audience and attention still as Night
1110: Or Summers Noon-tide air, while thus he spake.
1111: ¶Thrones and imperial Powers, off-spring of heav'n,
1112: Ethereal Vertues; or these Titles now
1113: Must we renounce, and changing stile be call'd
1114: Princes of Hell? for so the popular vote
1115: Inclines, here to continue, and build up here
1116: A growing Empire; doubtless; while we dream,
1117: And know not that the King of Heav'n hath doom'd
1118: This place our dungeon, not our safe retreat
1119: Beyond his Potent arm, to live exempt
1120: From Heav'ns high jurisdiction, in new League
1121: Banded against his Throne, but to remaine
1122: In strictest bondage, though thus far remov'd,
1124: His captive multitude: For he, be sure,
1125: In highth or depth, still first and last will Reign
1126: Sole King, and of his Kingdom loose no part
1127: By our revolt, but over Hell extend
1128: His Empire, and with Iron Scepter rule
1129: Us here, as with his Golden those in Heav'n.
1130: What sit we then projecting Peace and Warr?
1131: Warr hath determin'd us, and foild with loss
1132: Irreparable; tearms of peace yet none
1133: Voutsaf't or sought; for what peace will be giv'n
1134: To us enslav'd, but custody severe,
1136: Inflicted? and what peace can we return,
1137: But to our power hostility and hate,
1138: Untam'd reluctance, and revenge though slow,
1139: Yet ever plotting how the Conquerour least
1140: May reap his conquest, and may least rejoyce
1141: In doing what we most in suffering feel?
1142: Nor will occasion want, nor shall we need
1144: Heav'n, whose high walls fear no assault or Siege,
1145: Or ambush from the Deep.  What if we find
1146: Some easier enterprize?  There is a place
1147: (If ancient and prophetic fame in Heav'n
1148: Err not) another World, the happy seat
1149: Of som new Race call'd *Man*, about this time
1150: To be created like to us, though less
1151: In power and excellence, but favour'd more
1152: Of him who rules above; so was his will
1153: Pronounc'd among the Gods, and by an Oath,
1154: That shook Heav'ns whol circumference, confirm'd.
1155: Thither let us bend all our thoughts, to learn
1156: What creatures there inhabit, of what mould,
1157: Or substance, how endu'd, and what thir Power,
1158: And where thir weakness, how attempted best,
1159: By force or suttlety: Though Heav'n be shut,
1160: And Heav'ns high Arbitrator sit secure
1161: In his own strength, this place may lye expos'd
1162: The utmost border of his Kingdom, left
1163: To their defence who hold it: here perhaps
1164: Som advantagious act may be achiev'd
1165: By sudden onset, either with Hell fire
1166: To waste his whole Creation, or possess
1167: All as our own, and drive as we were driven,
1168: The punie habitants, or if not drive,
1169: Seduce them to our Party, that thir God
1170: May prove thir foe, and with repenting hand
1171: Abolish his own works.  This would surpass
1172: Common revenge, and interrupt his joy
1173: In our Confusion, and our Joy upraise
1174: In his disturbance; when his darling Sons
1175: Hurl'd headlong to partake with us, shall curse
1176: Thir frail Originals, and faded bliss,
1177: Faded so soon.  Advise if this be worth
1178: Attempting, or to sit in darkness here
1180: Pleaded his devilish Counsel, first devis'd
1181: By *Satan*, and in part propos'd: for whence,
1182: But from the Author of all ill could Spring
1183: So deep a malice, to confound the race
1184: Of mankind in one root, and Earth with Hell
1185: To mingle and involve, done all to spite
1186: The great Creatour?  But thir spite still serves
1187: His glory to augment.  The bold design
1188: Pleas'd highly those infernal States, and joy
1189: Sparkl'd in all thir eyes; with full assent
1190: They vote: whereat his speech he thus renews.
1191: ¶Well have ye judg'd, well ended long debate,
1192: Synod of Gods, and like to what ye are,
1193: Great things resolv'd; which from the lowest deep
1194: Will once more lift us up, in spight of Fate,
1195: Neerer our ancient Seat; perhaps in view
1196: Of those bright confines, whence with neighbouring Arms
1197: And opportune excursion we may chance
1198: Re-enter Heav'n; or else in some milde Zone
1199: Dwell not unvisited of Heav'ns fair Light
1200: Secure, and at the brightning Orient beam
1201: Purge off this gloom; the soft delicious Air,
1202: To heal the scarr of these corrosive Fires
1203: Shall breath her balme.  But first whom shall we send
1204: In search of this new world, whom shall we find
1205: Sufficient? who shall tempt with wandring feet
1207: And through the palpable obscure find out
1208: His uncouth way, or spread his aerie flight
1210: Over the vast abrupt, ere he arrive
1211: The happy Ile; what strength, what art can then
1212: Suffice, or what evasion bear him safe
1213: Through the strict Senteries and Stations thick
1214: Of Angels watching round?  Here he had need
1215: All circumspection, and we now no less
1216: Choice in our suffrage; for on whom we send,
1217: The weight of all and our last hope relies.
1218: ¶This said, he sat; and expectation held
1219: His look suspence, awaiting who appeer'd
1220: To second, or oppose, or undertake
1221: The perilous attempt: but all sat mute,
1222: Pondering the danger with deep thoughts; & each
1223: In others count'nance red his own dismay
1224: Astonisht: none among the choice and prime
1225: Of those Heav'n-warring Champions could be found
1226: So hardie as to proffer or accept
1227: Alone the dreadful voyage; till at last
1229: Above his fellows, with Monarchal pride
1230: Conscious of highest worth, unmov'd thus spake.
1232: With reason hath deep silence and demurr
1233: Seis'd us, though undismaid: long is the way
1234: And hard, that out of Hell leads up to Light;
1235: Our prison strong, this huge convex of Fire,
1236: Outrageous to devour, immures us round
1237: Ninefold, and gates of burning Adamant
1238: Barr'd over us prohibit all egress.
1239: These past, if any pass, the void profound
1240: Of unessential Night receives him next
1241: Wide gaping, and with utter loss of being
1242: Threatens him, plung'd in that abortive gulf.
1243: If thence he scape into what ever world,
1244: Or unknown Region, what remains him less
1245: Then unknown dangers and as hard escape.
1246: But I should ill become this Throne, O Peers,
1248: With splendor, arm'd with power, if aught propos'd
1249: And judg'd of public moment, in the shape
1250: Of difficulty or danger could deterre
1251: Me from attempting.  Wherefore do I assume
1252: These Royalties, and not refuse to Reign,
1253: Refusing to accept as great a share
1254: Of hazard as of honour, due alike
1255: To him who Reigns, and so much to him due
1256: Of hazard more, as he above the rest
1257: High honourd sits?  Go therfore mighty powers,
1258: Terror of Heav'n, though fall'n; intend at home,
1259: While here shall be our home, what best may ease
1260: The present misery, and render Hell
1261: More tollerable; if there be cure or charm
1262: To respite or deceive, or slack the pain
1263: Of this ill Mansion: intermit no watch
1264: Against a wakeful Foe, while I abroad
1265: Through all the coasts of dark destruction seek
1266: Deliverance for us all: this enterprize
1267: None shall partake with me.  Thus saying rose
1268: The Monarch, and prevented all reply,
1269: Prudent, least from his resolution rais'd
1270: Others among the chief might offer now
1271: (Certain to be refus'd) what erst they feard;
1272: And so refus'd might in opinion stand
1273: His rivals, winning cheap the high repute
1274: Which he through hazard huge must earn.  But they
1275: Dreaded not more th' adventure then his voice
1276: Forbidding; and at once with him they rose;
1277: Thir rising all at once was as the sound
1278: Of Thunder heard remote.  Towards him they bend
1279: With awful reverence prone; and as a God
1280: Extoll him equal to the highest in Heav'n:
1281: Nor fail'd they to express how much they prais'd,
1282: That for the general safety he despis'd
1283: His own: for neither do the Spirits damn'd
1284: Loose all thir vertue; least bad men should boast
1285: Thir specious deeds on earth, which glory excites,
1286: Or close ambition varnisht o're with zeal.
1287: Thus they thir doubtful consultations dark
1288: Ended rejoycing in thir matchless Chief:
1289: As when from mountain tops the dusky clouds
1290: Ascending, while the North wind sleeps, o'respread
1291: Heav'ns chearful face, the lowring Element
1292: Scowls ore the dark'nd lantskip Snow, or showre;
1293: If chance the radiant Sun with farewell sweet
1294: Extend his ev'ning beam, the fields revive,
1295: The birds thir notes renew, and bleating herds
1296: Attest thir joy, that hill and valley rings.
1297: O shame to men!  Devil with Devil damn'd
1298: Firm concord holds, men onely disagree
1299: Of Creatures rational, though under hope
1300: Of heavenly Grace: and God proclaiming peace,
1301: Yet live in hatred, enmitie, and strife
1302: Among themselves, and levie cruel warres,
1303: Wasting the Earth, each other to destroy:
1304: As if (which might induce us to accord)
1305: Man had not hellish foes anow besides,
1306: That day and night for his destruction waite.
1308: In order came the grand infernal Peers,
1309: Midst came thir mighty Paramount, and seemd
1310: Alone th' Antagonist of Heav'n, nor less
1311: Then Hells dread Emperour with pomp Supream,
1312: And God-like imitated State; him round
1313: A Globe of fierie Seraphim inclos'd
1314: With bright imblazonrie, and horrent Arms.
1315: Then of thir Session ended they bid cry
1316: With Trumpets regal sound the great result:
1317: Toward the four winds four speedy Cherubim
1318: Put to thir mouths the sounding Alchymie
1319: By Haralds voice explain'd: the hollow Abyss
1320: Heard farr and wide, and all the host of Hell
1321: With deafning shout, return'd them loud acclaim.
1322: Thence more at ease thir minds and somwhat rais'd
1323: By false presumptuous hope, the ranged powers
1324: Disband, and wandring, each his several way
1325: Pursues, as inclination or sad choice
1326: Leads him perplext, where he may likeliest find
1327: Truce to his restless thoughts, and entertain
1328: The irksome hours, till his great Chief return.
1329: Part on the Plain, or in the Air sublime
1330: Upon the wing, or in swift race contend,
1331: As at th' Olympian Games or *Pythian* fields;
1332: Part curb thir fierie Steeds, or shun the Goal
1333: With rapid wheels, or fronted Brigads form.
1334: As when to warn proud Cities warr appears
1335: Wag'd in the troubl'd Skie, and Armies rush
1336: To Battel in the Clouds, before each Van
1337: Pric forth the Aerie Knights, and couch thir spears
1338: Till thickest Legions close; with feats of Arms
1339: From either end of Heav'n the welkin burns.
1340: Others with vast *Typhoean* rage more fell
1341: Rend up both Rocks and Hills, and ride the Air
1342: In whirlwind; Hell scarce holds the wilde uproar.
1344: With conquest, felt th' envenom'd robe, and tore
1345: Through pain up by the roots *Thessalian* Pines,
1346: And *Lichas* from the top of *Oeta* threw
1347: Into th' *Euboic* Sea.  Others more milde,
1348: Retreated in a silent valley, sing
1349: With notes Angelical to many a Harp
1350: Thir own Heroic deeds and hapless fall
1351: By doom of Battel; and complain that Fate
1352: Free Vertue should enthrall to Force or Chance.
1353: Thir song was partial, but the harmony
1354: (What could it less when Spirits immortal sing?)
1355: Suspended Hell, and took with ravishment
1356: The thronging audience.  In discourse more sweet
1357: (For Eloquence the Soul, Song charms the Sense,)
1358: Others apart sat on a Hill retir'd,
1359: In thoughts more elevate, and reason'd high
1360: Of Providence, Foreknowledge, Will, and Fate,
1361: Fixt Fate, free will, foreknowledge absolute,
1362: And found no end, in wandring mazes lost.
1363: Of good and evil much they argu'd then,
1365: Passion and Apathie, and glory and shame,
1366: Vain wisdom all, and false Philosophie:
1367: Yet with a pleasing sorcerie could charm
1368: Pain for a while or anguish, and excite
1369: Fallacious hope, or arm th' obdured brest
1370: With stubborn patience as with triple steel.
1371: Another part in Squadrons and gross Bands,
1372: On bold adventure to discover wide
1373: That dismal world, if any Clime perhaps
1374: Might yeild them easier habitation, bend
1375: Four ways thir flying March, along the Banks
1376: Of four infernal Rivers that disgorge
1377: Into the burning Lake thir baleful streams;
1378: Abhorred *Styx* the flood of deadly hate,
1379: Sad *Acheron* of sorrow, black and deep;
1381: Heard on the ruful stream; fierce *Phlegeton*
1382: Whose waves of torrent fire inflame with rage.
1383: Farr off from these a slow and silent stream,
1385: Her watrie Labyrinth, whereof who drinks,
1386: Forthwith his former state and being forgets,
1387: Forgets both joy and grief, pleasure and pain.
1388: Beyond this flood a frozen Continent
1389: Lies dark and wilde, beat with perpetual storms
1390: Of Whirlwind and dire Hail, which on firm land
1391: Thaws not, but gathers heap, and ruin seems
1392: Of ancient pile; all else deep snow and ice,
1393: A gulf profound as that *Serbonian* Bog
1395: Where Armies whole have sunk: the parching Air
1396: Burns frore, and cold performs th' effect of Fire.
1398: At certain revolutions all the damn'd
1399: Are brought: and feel by turns the bitter change
1400: Of fierce extreams, extreams by change more fierce,
1401: From Beds of raging Fire to starve in Ice
1402: Thir soft Ethereal warmth, and there to pine
1404: Periods of time, thence hurried back to fire.
1406: Both to and fro, thir sorrow to augment,
1407: And wish and struggle, as they pass, to reach
1408: The tempting stream, with one small drop to loose
1409: In sweet forgetfulness all pain and woe,
1410: All in one moment, and so neer the brink;
1411: But fate withstands, and to oppose th' attempt
1413: The Ford, and of it self the water flies
1414: All taste of living wight, as once it fled
1415: The lip of *Tantalus*.  Thus roving on
1416: In confus'd march forlorn, th' adventrous Bands
1417: With shuddring horror pale, and eyes agast
1418: View'd first thir lamentable lot, and found
1419: No rest: through many a dark and drearie Vaile
1420: They pass'd, and many a Region dolorous,
1421: O're many a Frozen, many a Fierie Alpe,
1422: Rocks, Caves, Lakes, Fens, Bogs, Dens, and shades of death,
1423: A Universe of death, which God by curse
1424: Created evil, for evil only good,
1425: Where all life dies, death lives, and nature breeds,
1426: Perverse, all monstrous, all prodigious things,
1428: Then Fables yet have feign'd, or fear conceiv'd,
1430: ¶Mean while the Adversary of God and Man,
1431: *Satan* with thoughts inflam'd of highest design,
1432: Puts on swift wings, and toward the Gates of Hell
1433: Explores his solitary flight; som times
1434: He scours the right hand coast, som times the left,
1435: Now shaves with level wing the Deep, then soares
1436: Up to the fiery concave touring high.
1437: As when farr off at Sea a Fleet descri'd
1438: Hangs in the Clouds, by *Aequinoctial* Winds
1439: Close sailing from *Bengala*, or the Iles
1441: Thir spicie Drugs: they on the trading Flood
1442: Through the wide *Ethiopian* to the Cape
1443: Ply stemming nightly toward the Pole.  So seem'd
1444: Farr off the flying Fiend: at last appeer
1445: Hell bounds high reaching to the horrid Roof,
1446: And thrice threefold the Gates; three folds were Brass
1447: Three Iron, three of Adamantine Rock,
1449: Yet unconsum'd.  Before the Gates there sat
1450: On either side a formidable shape;
1451: The one seem'd Woman to the waste, and fair,
1452: But ended foul in many a scaly fould
1453: Voluminous and vast, a Serpent arm'd
1454: With mortal sting: about her middle round
1455: A cry of Hell Hounds never ceasing bark'd
1456: With wide *Cerberean* mouths full loud, and rung
1457: A hideous Peal: yet, when they list, would creep,
1458: If aught disturb'd thir noyse, into her woomb,
1459: And kennel there, yet there still bark'd and howl'd
1460: Within unseen.  Farr less abhorrd then these
1461: Vex'd *Scylla* bathing in the Sea that parts
1463: Nor uglier follow the Night-Hag, when call'd
1464: In secret, riding through the Air she comes
1465: Lur'd with the smell of infant blood, to dance
1466: With *Lapland* Witches, while the labouring Moon
1467: Eclipses at thir charms.  The other shape,
1468: If shape it might be call'd that shape had none
1469: Distinguishable in member, joynt, or limb,
1470: Or substance might be call'd that shadow seem'd,
1471: For each seem'd either; black it stood as Night,
1472: Fierce as ten Furies, terrible as Hell,
1473: And shook a dreadful Dart; what seem'd his head
1474: The likeness of a Kingly Crown had on.
1475: *Satan* was now at hand, and from his seat
1476: The Monster moving onward came as fast,
1477: With horrid strides, Hell trembled as he strode.
1478: Th' undaunted Fiend what this might be admir'd,
1479: Admir'd, not fear'd; God and his Son except,
1480: Created thing naught vallu'd he nor shun'd;
1481: And with disdainful look thus first began.
1482: ¶Whence and what art thou, execrable shape,
1483: That dar'st, though grim and terrible, advance
1484: Thy miscreated Front athwart my way
1485: To yonder Gates? through them I mean to pass,
1486: That be assur'd, without leave askt of thee:
1487: Retire, or taste thy folly, and learn by proof,
1488: Hell-born, not to contend with Spirits of Heav'n.
1489: ¶To whom the Goblin full of wrauth reply'd,
1490: Art thou that Traitor Angel, art thou hee,
1491: Who first broke peace in Heav'n and Faith, till then
1492: Unbrok'n, and in proud rebellious Arms
1493: Drew after him the third part of Heav'ns Sons
1494: Conjur'd against the highest, for which both Thou
1495: And they outcast from God, are here condemn'd
1496: To waste Eternal daies in woe and pain?
1497: And reck'n'st thou thy self with Spirits of Heav'n,
1498: Hell-doomd, and breath'st defiance here and scorn,
1499: Where I reign King, and to enrage thee more,
1500: Thy King and Lord?  Back to thy punishment,
1501: False fugitive, and to thy speed add wings,
1502: Least with a whip of Scorpions I pursue
1503: Thy lingring, or with one stroke of this Dart
1504: Strange horror seise thee, and pangs unfelt before.
1505: ¶So spake the grieslie terrour, and in shape,
1506: So speaking and so threatning, grew ten fold
1507: More dreadful and deform: on th' other side
1509: Unterrifi'd, and like a Comet burn'd,
1510: That fires the length of *Ophiucus* huge
1511: In th' Artick Sky, and from his horrid hair
1512: Shakes Pestilence and Warr.  Each at the Head
1513: Level'd his deadly aime; thir fatall hands
1514: No second stroke intend, and such a frown
1515: Each cast at th' other, as when two black Clouds
1516: With Heav'ns Artillery fraught, come rattling on
1517: Over the *Caspian*, then stand front to front
1518: Hov'ring a space, till Winds the signal blow
1519: To joyn thir dark Encounter in mid air:
1520: So frownd the mighty Combatants, that Hell
1521: Grew darker at thir frown, so matcht they stood;
1522: For never but once more was either like
1523: To meet so great a foe: and now great deeds
1524: Had been achiev'd, whereof all Hell had rung,
1525: Had not the Snakie Sorceress that sat
1526: Fast by Hell Gate, and kept the fatal Key,
1527: Ris'n, and with hideous outcry rush'd between.
1528: ¶O Father, what intends thy hand, she cry'd,
1529: Against thy only Son?  What fury O Son,
1530: Possesses thee to bend that mortal Dart
1531: Against thy Fathers head? and know'st for whom;
1532: For him who sits above and laughs the while
1533: At thee ordain'd his drudge, to execute
1534: What e're his wrath, which he calls Justice, bids,
1535: His wrath which one day will destroy ye both.
1536: ¶She spake, and at her words the hellish Pest
1537: Forbore, then these to her *Satan* return'd:
1538: ¶So strange thy outcry, and thy words so strange
1539: Thou interposest, that my sudden hand
1540: Prevented spares to tell thee yet by deeds
1541: What it intends; till first I know of thee,
1542: What thing thou art, thus double-form'd, and why
1543: In this infernal Vaile first met thou call'st
1544: Me Father, and that Fantasm call'st my Son?
1545: I know thee not, nor ever saw till now
1546: Sight more detestable then him and thee.
1547: ¶T' whom thus the Portress of Hell Gate reply'd;
1548: Hast thou forgot me then, and do I seem
1549: Now in thine eye so foul, once deemd so fair
1550: In Heav'n, when at th' Assembly, and in sight
1551: Of all the Seraphim with thee combin'd
1552: In bold conspiracy against Heav'ns King,
1553: All on a sudden miserable pain
1554: Surpris'd thee, dim thine eyes, and dizzie swumm
1555: In darkness, while thy head flames thick and fast
1556: Threw forth, till on the left side op'ning wide,
1557: Likest to thee in shape and count'nance bright,
1558: Then shining heav'nly fair, a Goddess arm'd
1559: Out of thy head I sprung: amazement seis'd
1560: All th' Host of Heav'n; back they recoild affraid
1561: At first, and call'd me *Sin*, and for a Sign
1562: Portentous held me; but familiar grown,
1563: I pleas'd, and with attractive graces won
1564: The most averse, thee chiefly, who full oft
1565: Thy self in me thy perfect image viewing
1566: Becam'st enamour'd, and such joy thou took'st
1567: With me in secret, that my womb conceiv'd
1568: A growing burden.  Mean while Warr arose,
1569: And fields were fought in Heav'n; wherein remaind
1570: (For what could else) to our Almighty Foe
1571: Cleer Victory, to our part loss and rout
1572: Through all the Empyrean: down they fell
1573: Driv'n headlong from the Pitch of Heaven, down
1574: Into this Deep, and in the general fall
1575: I also; at which time this powerful Key
1576: Into my hand was giv'n, with charge to keep
1577: These Gates for ever shut, which none can pass
1578: Without my op'ning.  Pensive here I sat
1579: Alone, but long I sat not, till my womb
1580: Pregnant by thee, and now excessive grown
1581: Prodigious motion felt and rueful throes.
1582: At last this odious offspring whom thou seest
1583: Thine own begotten, breaking violent way
1584: Tore through my entrails, that with fear and pain
1585: Distorted, all my nether shape thus grew
1586: Transform'd: but he my inbred enemie
1587: Forth issu'd, brandishing his fatal Dart
1588: Made to destroy: I fled, and cry'd out *Death*;
1589: Hell trembl'd at the hideous Name, and sigh'd
1590: From all her Caves, and back resounded *Death*.
1591: I fled, but he pursu'd (though more, it seems,
1592: Inflam'd with lust then rage) and swifter far,
1593: Me overtook his mother all dismaid,
1594: And in embraces forcible and foule
1595: Ingendring with me, of that rape begot
1596: These yelling Monsters that with ceasless cry
1597: Surround me, as thou sawst, hourly conceiv'd
1598: And hourly born, with sorrow infinite
1599: To me, for when they list into the womb
1600: That bred them they return, and howle and gnaw
1601: My Bowels, their repast; then bursting forth
1602: Afresh with conscious terrours vex me round,
1603: That rest or intermission none I find.
1604: Before mine eyes in opposition sits
1605: Grim *Death* my Son and foe, who sets them on,
1606: And me his Parent would full soon devour
1607: For want of other prey, but that he knows
1608: His end with mine involvd; and knows that I
1609: Should prove a bitter Morsel, and his bane,
1610: When ever that shall be; so Fate pronounc'd.
1611: But thou O Father, I forewarn thee, shun
1612: His deadly arrow; neither vainly hope
1613: To be invulnerable in those bright Arms,
1614: Though temper'd heav'nly, for that mortal dint,
1615: Save he who reigns above, none can resist.
1616: ¶She finish'd, and the suttle Fiend his lore
1617: Soon learnd, now milder, and thus answerd smooth.
1618: Dear Daughter, since thou claim'st me for thy Sire,
1619: And my fair Son here showst me, the dear pledge
1620: Of dalliance had with thee in Heav'n, and joys
1621: Then sweet, now sad to mention, through dire change
1622: Befalln us unforeseen, unthought of, know
1623: I come no enemie, but to set free
1624: From out this dark and dismal house of pain,
1625: Both him and thee, and all the heav'nly Host
1626: Of Spirits that in our just pretenses arm'd
1627: Fell with us from on high: from them I go
1628: This uncouth errand sole, and one for all
1629: My self expose, with lonely steps to tread
1630: Th' unfounded deep, & through the void immense
1631: To search with wandring quest a place foretold
1632: Should be, and, by concurring signs, ere now
1633: Created vast and round, a place of bliss
1634: In the Pourlieues of Heav'n, and therein plac't
1635: A race of upstart Creatures, to supply
1636: Perhaps our vacant room, though more remov'd,
1637: Least Heav'n surcharg'd with potent multitude
1638: Might hap to move new broiles: Be this or aught
1639: Then this more secret now design'd, I haste
1640: To know, and this once known, shall soon return,
1641: And bring ye to the place where Thou and Death
1642: Shall dwell at ease, and up and down unseen
1643: Wing silently the buxom Air, imbalm'd
1644: With odours; there ye shall be fed and fill'd
1645: Immeasurably, all things shall be your prey.
1646: He ceas'd, for both seemd highly pleasd, and Death
1647: Grinnd horrible a gastly smile, to hear
1648: His famine should be fill'd, and blest his mawe
1649: Destin'd to that good hour: no less rejoyc'd
1650: His mother bad, and thus bespake her Sire.
1651: ¶The key of this infernal Pit by due,
1652: And by command of Heav'ns all-powerful King
1653: I keep, by him forbidden to unlock
1654: These Adamantine Gates; against all force
1655: Death ready stands to interpose his dart,
1656: Fearless to be o'rematcht by living might.
1657: But what ow I to his commands above
1658: Who hates me, and hath hither thrust me down
1660: To sit in hateful Office here confin'd,
1662: Here in perpetual agonie and pain,
1663: With terrors and with clamors compasst round
1664: Of mine own brood, that on my bowels feed:
1665: Thou art my Father, thou my Author, thou
1666: My being gav'st me; whom should I obey
1667: But thee, whom follow? thou wilt bring me soon
1668: To that new world of light and bliss, among
1669: The Gods who live at ease, where I shall Reign
1670: At thy right hand voluptuous, as beseems
1671: Thy daughter and thy darling, without end.
1672: ¶Thus saying, from her side the fatal Key,
1673: Sad instrument of all our woe, she took;
1674: And towards the Gate rouling her bestial train,
1675: Forthwith the huge Porcullis high up drew,
1676: Which but her self not all the *Stygian* powers
1677: Could once have mov'd; then in the key-hole turns
1678: Th' intricate wards, and every Bolt and Bar
1679: Of massie Iron or sollid Rock with ease
1680: Unfast'ns: on a sudden op'n flie
1681: With impetuous recoile and jarring sound
1682: Th' infernal dores, and on thir hinges great
1683: Harsh Thunder, that the lowest bottom shook
1684: Of *Erebus*.  She op'nd, but to shut
1685: Excel'd her power; the Gates wide op'n stood,
1686: That with extended wings a Bannerd Host
1687: Under spread Ensigns marching might pass through
1688: With Horse and Chariots rankt in loose array;
1689: So wide they stood, and like a Furnace mouth
1690: Cast forth redounding smoak and ruddy flame.
1691: Before thir eyes in sudden view appear
1692: The secrets of the hoarie deep, a dark
1694: Without dimension, where length, breadth, and highth,
1695: And time and place are lost; where eldest Night
1698: Of endless warrs and by confusion stand.
1699: For hot, cold, moist, and dry, four Champions fierce
1700: Strive here for Maistrie, and to Battel bring
1701: Thir embryon Atoms; they around the flag
1702: Of each his faction, in thir several Clanns,
1703: Light-arm'd or heavy, sharp, smooth, swift or slow,
1704: Swarm populous, unnumber'd as the Sands
1706: Levied to side with warring Winds, and poise
1707: Thir lighter wings.  To whom these most adhere,
1708: Hee rules a moment; *Chaos* Umpire sits,
1709: And by decision more imbroiles the fray
1710: By which he Reigns: next him high Arbiter
1711: *Chance* governs all.  Into this wilde Abyss,
1712: The Womb of nature and perhaps her Grave,
1713: Of neither Sea, nor Shore, nor Air, nor Fire,
1714: But all these in thir pregnant causes mixt
1715: Confus'dly, and which thus must ever fight,
1716: Unless th' Almighty Maker them ordain
1717: His dark materials to create more Worlds,
1718: Into this wilde Abyss the warie fiend
1719: Stood on the brink of Hell and look'd a while,
1720: Pondering his Voyage; for no narrow frith
1721: He had to cross.  Nor was his eare less peal'd
1722: With noises loud and ruinous (to compare
1723: Great things with small) then when *Bellona* storms,
1724: With all her battering Engines bent to rase
1725: Som Capital City, or less then if this frame
1726: Of Heav'n were falling, and these Elements
1727: In mutinie had from her Axle torn
1728: The stedfast Earth.  At last his Sail-broad Vannes
1729: He spreads for flight, and in the surging smoak
1730: Uplifted spurns the ground, thence many a League
1731: As in a cloudy Chair ascending rides
1732: Audacious, but that seat soon failing, meets
1734: Fluttring his pennons vain plumb down he drops
1735: Ten thousand fadom deep, and to this hour
1736: Down had been falling, had not by ill chance
1737: The strong rebuff of som tumultuous cloud
1738: Instinct with Fire and Nitre hurried him
1739: As many miles aloft: that furie stay'd,
1740: Quencht in a Boggie *Syrtris*, neither Sea,
1741: Nor good dry Land: nigh founderd on he fares,
1742: Treading the crude consistence, half on foot,
1743: Half flying; behoves him now both Oare and Saile.
1744: As when a Gryfon through the Wilderness
1745: With winged course ore Hill or moarie Dale,
1747: Had from his wakeful custody purloind
1748: The guarded Gold: So eagerly the fiend
1749: Ore bog or steep, through strait, rough, dense, or rare,
1750: With head, hands, wings, or feet pursues his way,
1751: And swims or sinks, or wades, or creeps, or flyes:
1752: At length a universal hubbub wilde
1753: Of stunning sounds and voices all confus'd
1754: Born through the hollow dark assaults his eare
1755: With loudest vehemence: thither he plyes,
