1756: Undaunted to meet there what ever power
1757: Or Spirit of the nethermost Abyss
1758: Might in that noise reside, of whom to ask
1759: Which way the neerest coast of darkness lyes
1760: Bordering on light; when strait behold the Throne
1761: Of *Chaos*, and his dark Pavilion spread
1762: Wide on the wasteful Deep; with him Enthron'd
1763: Sat Sable-vested Night, eldest of things,
1764: The consort of his Reign; and by them stood
1767: And Tumult and Confusion all imbroild,
1768: And Discord with a thousand various mouths.
1769: ¶T' whom *Satan* turning boldly, thus.  Ye Powers
1770: And Spirits of this nethermost Abyss,
1771: *Chaos* and *Ancient Night*, I come no Spie,
1772: With purpose to explore or to disturb
1773: The secrets of your Realm, but by constraint
1774: Wandring this darksome desart, as my way
1775: Lies through your spacious Empire up to light,
1776: Alone, and without guide, half lost, I seek
1777: What readiest path leads where your gloomie bounds
1778: Confine with Heav'n; or if som other place
1779: From your Dominion won, th' Ethereal King
1781: I travel this profound, direct my course;
1782: Directed, no mean recompence it brings
1783: To your behoof, if I that Region lost,
1785: To her original darkness and your sway
1786: (Which is my present journey) and once more
1787: Erect the Standerd there of *Ancient Night*;
1788: Yours be th' advantage all, mine the revenge.
1789: ¶Thus *Satan*; and him thus the Anarch old
1790: With faultring speech and visage incompos'd
1791: Answer'd.  I know thee, stranger, who thou art,
1792: That mighty leading Angel, who of late
1793: Made head against Heav'ns King, though overthrown.
1794: I saw and heard, for such a numerous host
1795: Fled not in silence through the frighted deep
1796: With ruin upon ruin, rout on rout,
1797: Confusion worse confounded; and Heav'n Gates
1798: Pourd out by millions her victorious Bands
1799: Pursuing.  I upon my Frontieres here
1800: Keep residence; if all I can will serve,
1801: That little which is left so to defend
1802: Encroacht on still through our intestine broiles
1803: Weakning the Scepter of old Night: first Hell
1804: Your dungeon stretching far and wide beneath;
1805: Now lately Heaven and Earth, another World
1806: Hung ore my Realm, link'd in a golden Chain
1807: To that side Heav'n from whence your Legions fell:
1808: If that way be your walk, you have not farr;
1809: So much the neerer danger; goe and speed;
1810: Havock and spoil and ruin are my gain.
1811: ¶He ceas'd; and *Satan* staid not to reply,
1812: But glad that now his Sea should find a shore,
1813: With fresh alacritie and force renew'd
1814: Springs upward like a Pyramid of fire
1815: Into the wilde expanse, and through the shock
1816: Of fighting Elements, on all sides round
1817: Environ'd wins his way; harder beset
1818: And more endanger'd, then when *Argo* pass'd
1820: Or when *Ulysses* on the Larbord shunnd
1821: *Charybdis*, and by th' other whirlpool steard.
1822: So he with difficulty and labour hard
1823: Mov'd on, with difficulty and labour hee;
1824: But hee once past, soon after when man fell,
1825: Strange alteration!  Sin and Death amain
1826: Following his track, such was the will of Heav'n,
1827: Pav'd after him a broad and beat'n way
1828: Over the dark Abyss, whose boiling Gulf
1829: Tamely endur'd a Bridge of wondrous length
1830: From Hell continu'd reaching th' utmost Orbe
1831: Of this frail World; by which the Spirits perverse
1832: With easie intercourse pass to and fro
1833: To tempt or punish mortals, except whom
1834: God and good Angels guard by special grace.
1835: But now at last the sacred influence
1836: Of light appears, and from the walls of Heav'n
1837: Shoots farr into the bosom of dim Night
1838: A glimmering dawn; here Nature first begins
1839: Her fardest verge, and *Chaos* to retire
1840: As from her outmost works a brok'n foe
1841: With tumult less and with less hostile din,
1842: That *Satan* with less toil, and now with ease
1843: Wafts on the calmer wave by dubious light
1844: And like a weather-beaten Vessel holds
1845: Gladly the Port, though Shrouds and Tackle torn;
1846: Or in the emptier waste, resembling Air,
1847: Weighs his spread wings, at leasure to behold
1848: Farr off th' Empyreal Heav'n, extended wide
1849: In circuit, undetermind square or round,
1850: With Opal Towrs and Battlements adorn'd
1851: Of living Saphire, once his native Seat;
1852: And fast by hanging in a golden Chain
1853: This pendant world, in bigness as a Starr
1854: Of smallest Magnitude close by the Moon.
1855: Thither full fraught with mischievous revenge,
1856: Accurst, and in a cursed hour he hies.
1859: ¶Hail holy light, ofspring of Heav'n first-born,
1860: Or of th' Eternal Coeternal beam
1861: May I express thee unblam'd? since God is light,
1862: And never but in unapproached light
1863: Dwelt from Eternitie, dwelt then in thee,
1864: Bright effluence of bright essence increate.
1865: Or hear'st thou rather pure Ethereal stream,
1866: Whose Fountain who shall tell? before the Sun,
1867: Before the Heavens thou wert, and at the voice
1868: Of God, as with a Mantle didst invest
1869: The rising world of waters dark and deep,
1870: Won from the void and formless infinite.
1871: Thee I re-visit now with bolder wing,
1872: Escap't the *Stygian* Pool, though long detain'd
1873: In that obscure sojourn, while in my flight
1874: Through utter and through middle darkness borne
1875: With other notes then to th' *Orphean* Lyre
1877: Taught by the heav'nly Muse to venture down
1878: The dark descent, and up to reascend,
1879: Though hard and rare: thee I revisit safe,
1880: And feel thy sovran vital Lamp; but thou
1881: Revisit'st not these eyes, that rowle in vain
1882: To find thy piercing ray, and find no dawn;
1883: So thick a drop serene hath quencht thir Orbs,
1884: Or dim suffusion veild.  Yet not the more
1885: Cease I to wander where the Muses haunt
1886: Cleer Spring, or shadie Grove, or Sunnie Hill,
1887: Smit with the love of sacred song; but chief
1888: Thee *Sion* and the flowrie Brooks beneath
1889: That wash thy hallowd feet, and warbling flow,
1890: Nightly I visit: nor somtimes forget
1891: Those other two equal'd with me in Fate,
1892: So were I equal'd with them in renown,
1895: Then feed on thoughts, that voluntarie move
1896: Harmonious numbers; as the wakeful Bird
1897: Sings darkling, and in shadiest Covert hid
1898: Tunes her nocturnal Note.  Thus with the Year
1899: Seasons return, but not to me returns
1900: Day, or the sweet approach of Ev'n or Morn,
1901: Or sight of vernal bloom, or Summers Rose,
1902: Or flocks, or herds, or human face divine;
1903: But cloud in stead, and ever-during dark
1904: Surrounds me, from the chearful waies of men
1905: Cut off, and for the book of knowledg fair
1907: Of Natures works to mee expung'd and ras'd,
1908: And wisdome at one entrance quite shut out.
1909: So much the rather thou Celestial light
1910: Shine inward, and the mind through all her powers
1911: Irradiate, there plant eyes, all mist from thence
1912: Purge and disperse, that I may see and tell
1913: Of things invisible to mortal sight.
1914: ¶Now had the Almighty Father from above,
1915: From the pure Empyrean where he sits
1916: High Thron'd above all highth, bent down his eye,
1917: His own works and their works at once to view:
1918: About him all the Sanctities of Heaven
1919: Stood thick as Starrs, and from his sight receiv'd
1920: Beatitude past utterance; on his right
1921: The radiant image of his Glory sat,
1922: His onely Son; On Earth he first beheld
1923: Our two first Parents, yet the onely two
1924: Of mankind, in the happie Garden plac't,
1925: Reaping immortal fruits of joy and love,
1927: In blissful solitude; he then survey'd
1928: Hell and the Gulf between, and *Satan* there
1929: Coasting the wall of Heav'n on this side Night
1930: In the dun Air sublime, and ready now
1931: To stoop with wearied wings, and willing feet
1932: On the bare outside of this World, that seem'd
1934: Uncertain which, in Ocean or in Air.
1935: Him God beholding from his prospect high,
1936: Wherein past, present, future he beholds,
1937: Thus to his onely Son foreseeing spake.
1938: ¶Onely begotten Son, seest thou what rage
1939: Transports our adversarie, whom no bounds
1940: Prescrib'd, no barrs of Hell, nor all the chains
1941: Heapt on him there, nor yet the main Abyss
1942: Wide interrupt can hold; so bent he seems
1943: On desperat revenge, that shall redound
1944: Upon his own rebellious head.  And now
1945: Through all restraint broke loose he wings his way
1946: Not farr off Heav'n, in the Precincts of light,
1947: Directly towards the new created World,
1948: And Man there plac't, with purpose to assay
1949: If him by force he can destroy, or worse,
1950: By som false guile pervert; and shall pervert;
1951: For man will heark'n to his glozing lyes,
1952: And easily transgress the sole Command,
1953: Sole pledge of his obedience: So will fall
1954: Hee and his faithless Progenie: whose fault?
1955: Whose but his own? ingrate, he had of mee
1956: All he could have; I made him just and right,
1957: Sufficient to have stood, though free to fall.
1958: Such I created all th' Ethereal Powers
1959: And Spirits, both them who stood & them who faild;
1960: Freely they stood who stood, and fell who fell.
1961: Not free, what proof could they have givn sincere
1962: Of true allegiance, constant Faith or Love,
1963: Where onely what they needs must do, appeard,
1964: Not what they would? what praise could they receive?
1965: What pleasure I from such obedience paid,
1966: When Will and Reason (Reason also is choice)
1967: Useless and vain, of freedom both despoild,
1968: Made passive both, had servd necessitie,
1969: Not mee.  They therefore as to right belongd,
1970: So were created, nor can justly accuse
1971: Thir maker, or thir making, or thir Fate;
1973: Thir will, dispos'd by absolute Decree
1974: Or high foreknowledge; they themselves decreed
1975: Thir own revolt, not I: if I foreknew,
1976: Foreknowledge had no influence on their fault,
1977: Which had no less prov'd certain unforeknown.
1978: So without least impulse or shadow of Fate,
1979: Or aught by me immutablie foreseen,
1980: They trespass, Authors to themselves in all
1981: Both what they judge and what they choose; for so
1982: I formd them free, and free they must remain,
1983: Till they enthrall themselves: I else must change
1984: Thir nature, and revoke the high Decree
1986: Thir freedom, they themselves ordain'd thir fall.
1987: The first sort by thir own suggestion fell,
1989: By the other first: Man therefore shall find grace,
1990: The other none: in Mercy and Justice both,
1991: Through Heav'n and Earth, so shall my glorie excel,
1992: But Mercy first and last shall brightest shine.
1993: ¶Thus while God spake, ambrosial fragrance fill'd
1994: All Heav'n, and in the blessed Spirits elect
1995: Sense of new joy ineffable diffus'd:
1996: Beyond compare the Son of God was seen
1997: Most glorious, in him all his Father shon
1998: Substantially express'd, and in his face
2000: Love without end, and without measure Grace,
2001: Which uttering thus he to his Father spake.
2002: ¶O Father, gracious was that word which clos'd
2003: Thy sovran sentence, that Man should find grace;
2004: For which both Heav'n and Earth shall high extoll
2005: Thy praises, with th' innumerable sound
2006: Of Hymns and sacred Songs, wherewith thy Throne
2007: Encompass'd shall resound thee ever blest.
2008: For should Man finally be lost, should Man
2009: Thy creature late so lov'd, thy youngest Son
2010: Fall circumvented thus by fraud, though joynd
2011: With his own folly? that be from thee farr,
2012: That farr be from thee, Father, who art Judge
2013: Of all things made, and judgest onely right.
2014: Or shall the Adversarie thus obtain
2015: His end, and frustrate thine, shall he fulfill
2016: His malice, and thy goodness bring to naught,
2017: Or proud return though to his heavier doom,
2018: Yet with revenge accomplish't and to Hell
2019: Draw after him the whole Race of mankind,
2020: By him corrupted? or wilt thou thy self
2022: For him, what for thy glorie thou hast made?
2023: So should thy goodness and thy greatness both
2024: Be questiond and blaspheam'd without defence.
2025: ¶To whom the great Creatour thus reply'd.
2026: O Son, in whom my Soul hath chief delight,
2027: Son of my bosom, Son who art alone
2028: My word, my wisdom, and effectual might,
2029: All hast thou spok'n as my thoughts are, all
2030: As my Eternal purpose hath decreed:
2031: Man shall not quite be lost, but sav'd who will,
2032: Yet not of will in him, but grace in me
2033: Freely voutsaft; once more I will renew
2034: His lapsed powers, though forfeit and enthrall'd
2035: By sin to foul exorbitant desires;
2036: Upheld by me, yet once more he shall stand
2037: On even ground against his mortal foe,
2038: By me upheld, that he may know how frail
2039: His fall'n condition is, and to me ow
2040: All his deliv'rance, and to none but me.
2041: Some I have chosen of peculiar grace
2042: Elect above the rest; so is my will:
2043: The rest shall hear me call, and oft be warnd
2044: Thir sinful state, and to appease betimes
2045: Th' incensed Deitie, while offerd grace
2046: Invites; for I will cleer thir senses dark,
2047: What may suffice, and soft'n stonie hearts
2048: To pray, repent, and bring obedience due.
2049: To prayer, repentance, and obedience due,
2050: Though but endevord with sincere intent,
2051: Mine eare shall not be slow, mine eye not shut.
2052: And I will place within them as a guide
2053: My Umpire *Conscience*, whom if they will hear,
2054: Light after light well us'd they shall attain,
2055: And to the end persisting, safe arrive.
2056: This my long sufferance and my day of grace
2057: They who neglect and scorn, shall never taste;
2058: But hard be hard'nd, blind be blinded more,
2059: That they may stumble on, and deeper fall;
2060: And none but such from mercy I exclude.
2061: But yet all is not don; Man disobeying,
2062: Disloyal breaks his fealtie, and sinns
2063: Against the high Supremacie of Heav'n,
2064: Affecting God-head, and so loosing all,
2065: To expiate his Treason hath naught left,
2066: But to destruction sacred and devote,
2067: He with his whole posteritie must die,
2068: Die hee or Justice must; unless for him
2069: Som other able, and as willing, pay
2070: The rigid satisfaction, death for death.
2071: Say Heav'nly Powers, where shall we find such love,
2072: Which of ye will be mortal to redeem
2073: Mans mortal crime, and just th' unjust to save,
2074: Dwels in all Heaven charitie so deare?
2075: ¶He ask'd, but all the Heav'nly Quire stood mute,
2076: And silence was in Heav'n: on mans behalf
2078: Much less that durst upon his own head draw
2079: The deadly forfeiture, and ransom set.
2080: And now without redemption all mankind
2081: Must have bin lost, adjudg'd to Death and Hell
2082: By doom severe, had not the Son of God,
2083: In whom the fulness dwels of love divine,
2085: ¶Father, thy word is past, man shall find grace;
2086: And shall grace not find means, that finds her way,
2087: The speediest of thy winged messengers,
2088: To visit all thy creatures, and to all
2090: Happie for man, so coming; he her aide
2091: Can never seek, once dead in sins and lost;
2092: Attonement for himself or offering meet,
2093: Indebted and undon, hath none to bring:
2094: Behold mee then, mee for him, life for life
2095: I offer, on mee let thine anger fall;
2096: Account mee man; I for his sake will leave
2097: Thy bosom, and this glorie next to thee
2098: Freely put off, and for him lastly die
2099: Well pleas'd, on me let Death wreck all his rage;
2100: Under his gloomie power I shall not long
2101: Lie vanquisht; thou hast givn me to possess
2102: Life in my self for ever, by thee I live,
2103: Though now to Death I yeild, and am his due
2104: All that of me can die, yet that debt paid,
2105: Thou wilt not leave me in the loathsom grave
2106: His prey, nor suffer my unspotted Soule
2107: For ever with corruption there to dwell;
2108: But I shall rise Victorious, and subdue
2109: My Vanquisher, spoild of his vanted spoile;
2110: Death his deaths wound shall then receive, & stoop
2111: Inglorious, of his mortall sting disarm'd.
2112: I through the ample Air in Triumph high
2113: Shall lead Hell Captive maugre Hell, and show
2114: The powers of darkness bound.  Thou at the sight
2115: Pleas'd, out of Heaven shalt look down and smile,
2116: While by thee rais'd I ruin all my Foes,
2117: Death last, and with his Carcass glut the Grave:
2118: Then with the multitude of my redeemd
2119: Shall enter Heaven long absent, and returne,
2120: Father, to see thy face, wherein no cloud
2121: Of anger shall remain, but peace assur'd,
2122: And reconcilement; wrauth shall be no more
2123: Thenceforth, but in thy presence Joy entire.
2124: ¶His words here ended, but his meek aspect
2125: Silent yet spake, and breath'd immortal love
2126: To mortal men, above which only shon
2128: Glad to be offer'd, he attends the will
2129: Of his great Father.  Admiration seis'd
2130: All Heav'n, what this might mean, & whither tend
2131: Wondring; but soon th' Almighty thus reply'd:
2132: ¶O thou in Heav'n and Earth the only peace
2133: Found out for mankind under wrauth, O thou
2134: My sole complacence! well thou know'st how dear,
2135: To me are all my works, nor Man the least
2136: Though last created, that for him I spare
2137: Thee from my bosom and right hand, to save,
2138: By loosing thee a while, the whole Race lost.
2139: Thou therefore whom thou only canst redeeme,
2140: Thir Nature also to thy Nature joyne;
2141: And be thy self Man among men on Earth,
2142: Made flesh, when time shall be, of Virgin seed,
2143: By wondrous birth: Be thou in *Adams* room
2144: The Head of all mankind, though *Adams* Son.
2145: As in him perish all men, so in thee
2146: As from a second root shall be restor'd,
2147: As many as are restor'd, without thee none.
2148: His crime makes guiltie all his Sons, thy merit
2149: Imputed shall absolve them who renounce
2150: Thir own both righteous and unrighteous deeds,
2151: And live in thee transplanted, and from thee
2152: Receive new life.  So Man, as is most just,
2153: Shall satisfie for Man, be judg'd and die,
2154: And dying rise, and rising with him raise
2155: His Brethren, ransomd with his own dear life.
2156: So Heav'nly love shal outdoo Hellish hate,
2157: Giving to death, and dying to redeeme,
2158: So dearly to redeem what Hellish hate
2159: So easily destroy'd, and still destroyes
2160: In those who, when they may, accept not grace.
2161: Nor shalt thou by descending to assume
2162: Mans Nature, less'n or degrade thine owne.
2163: Because thou hast, though Thron'd in highest bliss
2164: Equal to God, and equally enjoying
2165: God-like fruition, quitted all to save
2166: A World from utter loss, and hast been found
2167: By Merit more then Birthright Son of God,
2168: Found worthiest to be so by being Good,
2169: Farr more then Great or High; because in thee
2170: Love hath abounded more then Glory abounds,
2172: With thee thy Manhood also to this Throne;
2173: Here shalt thou sit incarnate, here shalt Reigne
2174: Both God and Man, Son both of God and Man,
2176: I give thee, reign for ever, and assume
2177: Thy Merits; under thee as Head Supream
2178: Thrones, Princedoms, Powers, Dominions I reduce:
2179: All knees to thee shall bow, of them that bide
2180: In Heaven, or Earth, or under Earth in Hell;
2181: When thou attended gloriously from Heav'n
2182: Shalt in the Skie appeer, and from thee send
2184: Thy dread Tribunal: forthwith from all Windes
2185: The living, and forthwith the cited dead
2186: Of all past Ages to the general Doom
2187: Shall hast'n, such a peal shall rouse thir sleep.
2188: Then all thy Saints assembl'd, thou shalt judge
2189: Bad men and Angels, they arraignd shall sink
2190: Beneath thy Sentence; Hell, her numbers full,
2191: Thenceforth shall be for ever shut.  Mean while
2192: The World shall burn, and from her ashes spring
2193: New Heav'n and Earth, wherein the just shall dwell
2194: And after all thir tribulations long
2195: See golden days, fruitful of golden deeds,
2196: With Joy and Love triumphing, and fair Truth.
2197: Then thou thy regal Scepter shalt lay by,
2198: For regal Scepter then no more shall need,
2199: God shall be All in All.  But all ye Gods,
2200: Adore him, who to compass all this dies,
2201: Adore the Son, and honour him as mee.
2202: ¶No sooner had th' Almighty ceas't, but all
2203: The multitude of Angels with a shout
2204: Loud as from numbers without number, sweet
2205: As from blest voices, uttering joy, Heav'n rung
2206: With Jubilee, and loud Hosanna's fill'd
2208: Towards either Throne they bow, & to the ground
2209: With solemn adoration down they cast
2210: Thir Crowns inwove with Amarant and Gold,
2211: Immortal Amarant, a Flour which once
2212: In Paradise, fast by the Tree of Life
2213: Began to bloom, but soon for mans offence
2214: To Heav'n remov'd where first it grew, there grows,
2215: And flours aloft shading the Fount of Life,
2216: And where the river of Bliss through midst of Heavn
2217: Rowls o're *Elisian* Flours her Amber stream;
2218: With these that never fade the Spirits Elect
2219: Bind thir resplendent locks inwreath'd with beams,
2220: Now in loose Garlands thick thrown off, the bright
2221: Pavement that like a Sea of Jasper shon
2223: Then Crown'd again thir gold'n Harps they took,
2224: Harps ever tun'd, that glittering by their side
2225: Like Quivers hung, and with Praeamble sweet
2227: Thir sacred Song, and waken raptures high;
2228: No voice exempt, no voice but well could joine
2229: Melodious part, such concord is in Heav'n.
2232: Eternal King; thee Author of all being,
2233: Fountain of Light, thy self invisible
2234: Amidst the glorious brightness where thou sit'st
2235: Thron'd inaccessible, but when thou shad'st
2236: The full blaze of thy beams, and through a cloud
2237: Drawn round about thee like a radiant Shrine,
2238: Dark with excessive bright thy skirts appeer,
2239: Yet dazle Heav'n, that brightest Seraphim
2240: Approach not, but with both wings veil thir eyes.
2241: Thee next they sang of all Creation first,
2243: In whose conspicuous count'nance, without cloud
2244: Made visible, th' Almighty Father shines,
2245: Whom else no Creature can behold; on thee
2246: Impresst the effulgence of his Glorie abides,
2247: Transfus'd on thee his ample Spirit rests.
2248: Hee Heav'n of Heavens and all the Powers therein
2249: By thee created, and by thee threw down
2250: Th' aspiring Dominations: thou that day
2251: Thy Fathers dreadful Thunder didst not spare,
2252: Nor stop thy flaming Chariot wheels, that shook
2253: Heav'ns everlasting Frame, while o're the necks
2254: Thou drov'st of warring Angels disarraid.
2255: Back from pursuit thy Powers with loud acclaime
2256: Thee only extold, Son of thy Fathers might,
2257: To execute fierce vengeance on his foes,
2258: Not so on Man; him through their malice fall'n,
2259: Father of Mercie and Grace, thou didst not doome
2260: So strictly, but much more to pitie encline:
2261: No sooner did thy dear and onely Son
2262: Perceive thee purpos'd not to doom frail Man
2263: So strictly, but much more to pitie enclin'd,
2264: He to appease thy wrauth, and end the strife
2265: Of Mercy and Justice in thy face discern'd,
2266: Regardless of the Bliss wherein hee sat
2267: Second to thee, offerd himself to die
2268: For mans offence.  O unexampl'd love,
2269: Love no where to be found less then Divine!
2270: Hail Son of God, Saviour of Men, thy Name
2271: Shall be the copious matter of my Song
2272: Henceforth, and never shall my Harp thy praise
2273: Forget, nor from thy Fathers praise disjoine.
2274: ¶Thus they in Heav'n, above the starry Sphear,
2275: Thir happie hours in joy and hymning spent.
2276: Mean while upon the firm opacous Globe
2277: Of this round World, whose first convex divides
2279: From *Chaos* and th' inroad of Darkness old,
2280: *Satan* alighted walks: a Globe farr off
2281: It seem'd, now seems a boundless Continent
2282: Dark, waste, and wild, under the frown of Night
2285: Save on that side which from the wall of Heav'n
2286: Though distant farr som small reflection gaines
2287: Of glimmering air less vext with tempest loud:
2288: Here walk'd the Fiend at large in spacious field.
2289: As when a Vultur on *Imaus* bred,
2290: Whose snowie ridge the roving *Tartar* bounds,
2291: Dislodging from a Region scarce of prey
2292: To gorge the flesh of Lambs or yeanling Kids
2293: On Hills where Flocks are fed, flies toward the Springs
2295: But in his way lights on the barren plaines
2297: With Sails and Wind thir canie Waggons light:
2298: So on this windie Sea of Land, the Fiend
2299: Walk'd up and down alone bent on his prey,
2300: Alone, for other Creature in this place
2301: Living or liveless to be found was none,
2302: None yet, but store hereafter from the earth
2303: Up hither like Aereal vapours flew
2304: Of all things transitorie and vain, when Sin
2305: With vanity had filld the works of men:
2306: Both all things vain, and all who in vain things
2307: Built thir fond hopes of Glorie or lasting fame,
2308: Or happiness in this or th' other life;
2309: All who have thir reward on Earth, the fruits
2310: Of painful Superstition and blind Zeal,
2311: Naught seeking but the praise of men, here find
2312: Fit retribution, emptie as thir deeds;
2313: All th' unaccomplisht works of Natures hand,
2315: Dissolvd on earth, fleet hither, and in vain,
2317: Not in the neighbouring Moon, as some have dreamd;
2318: Those argent Fields more likely habitants,
2319: Translated Saints, or middle Spirits hold
2320: Betwixt th' Angelical and Human kinde:
2321: Hither of ill-joynd Sons and Daughters born
2322: First from the ancient World those Giants came
2323: With many a vain exploit, though then renownd:
2324: The builders next of *Babel* on the Plain
2325: Of *Sennaar*, and still with vain designe
2326: New *Babels*, had they wherewithall, would build:
2327: Others came single; hee who to be deemd
2328: A God, leap'd fondly into *Aetna* flames,
2332: Embryo's and Idiots, Eremits and Friers
2333: White, Black and Grey, with all thir trumperie.
2334: Here Pilgrims roam, that stray'd so farr to seek
2335: In *Golgotha* him dead, who lives in Heav'n;
2336: And they who to be sure of Paradise
2337: Dying put on the weeds of *Dominic*,
2338: Or in *Franciscan* think to pass disguis'd;
2339: They pass the Planets seven, and pass the fixt,
2340: And that Crystalline Sphear whose ballance weighs
2341: The Trepidation talkt, and that first mov'd;
2342: And now Saint *Peter* at Heav'ns Wicket seems
2343: To wait them with his Keys, and now at foot
2344: Of Heav'ns ascent they lift thir Feet, when loe
2345: A violent cross wind from either Coast
2346: Blows them transverse ten thousand Leagues awry
2347: Into the devious Air; then might ye see
2348: Cowles, Hoods and Habits with thir wearers tost
2349: And flutterd into Raggs, then Reliques, Beads,
2351: The sport of Winds: all these upwhirld aloft
2352: Fly o're the backside of the World farr off
2353: Into a *Limbo* large and broad, since calld
2354: The Paradise of Fools, to few unknown
2355: Long after, now unpeopl'd, and untrod;
2356: All this dark Globe the Fiend found as he pass'd,
2357: And long he wanderd, till at last a gleame
2358: Of dawning light turnd thither-ward in haste
2359: His travell'd steps; farr distant hee descries
2361: Up to the wall of Heaven a Structure high,
2362: At top whereof, but farr more rich appeerd
2363: The work as of a Kingly Palace Gate
2364: With Frontispice of Diamond and Gold
2365: Imbellisht, thick with sparkling orient Gemmes
2366: The Portal shon, inimitable on Earth
2367: By Model, or by shading Pencil drawn.
2368: The Stairs were such as whereon *Jacob* saw
2370: Of Guardians bright, when he from *Esau* fled
2372: Dreaming by night under the open Skie,
2373: And waking cri'd, This is the Gate of Heav'n.
2374: Each Stair mysteriously was meant, nor stood
2375: There alwaies, but drawn up to Heav'n somtimes
2376: Viewless, and underneath a bright Sea flow'd
2377: Of Jasper, or of liquid Pearle, whereon
2378: Who after came from Earth, sayling arriv'd,
2379: Wafted by Angels, or flew o're the Lake
2380: Rapt in a Chariot drawn by fiery Steeds.
2381: The Stairs were then let down, whether to dare
2382: The Fiend by easie ascent, or aggravate
2383: His sad exclusion from the dores of Bliss.
2384: Direct against which op'nd from beneath,
2385: Just o're the blissful seat of Paradise,
2386: A passage down to th' Earth, a passage wide,
2387: Wider by farr then that of after-times
2388: Over Mount *Sion*, and, though that were large,
2389: Over the *Promis'd Land* to God so dear,
2390: By which, to visit oft those happy Tribes,
2391: On high behests his Angels to and fro
2392: Pass'd frequent, and his eye with choice regard
2396: So wide the op'ning seemd, where bounds were set
2397: To darkness, such as bound the Ocean wave.
2398: *Satan* from hence now on the lower stair
2399: That scal'd by steps of Gold to Heav'n Gate
2400: Looks down with wonder at the sudden view
2401: Of all this World at once.  As when a Scout
2402: Through dark and desart wayes with peril gone
2403: All night; at last by break of chearful dawne
2404: Obtains the brow of some high-climbing Hill,
2405: Which to his eye discovers unaware
2406: The goodly prospect of some forein land
2408: With glistering Spires and Pinnacles adornd,
2409: Which now the Rising Sun guilds with his beams.
2410: Such wonder seis'd, though after Heaven seen,
2411: The Spirit maligne, but much more envy seis'd
2412: At sight of all this World beheld so faire.
2413: Round he surveys, and well might, where he stood
2414: So high above the circling Canopie
2415: Of Nights extended shade; from Eastern Point
2416: Of *Libra* to the fleecie Starr that bears
2418: Beyond th' *Horizon*; then from Pole to Pole
2419: He views in bredth, and without longer pause
2420: Down right into the Worlds first Region throws
2421: His flight precipitant, and windes with ease
2422: Through the pure marble Air his oblique way
2424: Stars distant, but nigh hand seemd other Worlds,
2425: Or other Worlds they seemd, or happy Iles,
2426: Like those *Hesperian* Gardens fam'd of old,
2427: Fortunate Fields, and Groves and flourie Vales,
2428: Thrice happy Iles, but who dwelt happy there
2429: He stayd not to enquire: above them all
2430: The golden Sun in splendor likest Heaven
2431: Allur'd his eye: Thither his course he bends
2432: Through the calm Firmament; but up or downe
2433: By center, or eccentric, hard to tell,
2434: Or Longitude, where the great Luminarie
2436: That from his Lordly eye keep distance due,
2437: Dispenses Light from farr; they as they move
2438: Thir Starry dance in numbers that compute
2439: Days, months, and years, towards his all-chearing Lamp
2440: Turn swift their various motions, or are turnd
2441: By his Magnetic beam, that gently warms
2442: The Univers, and to each inward part
2444: Shoots invisible vertue even to the deep:
2445: So wondrously was set his Station bright.
2446: There lands the Fiend, a spot like which perhaps
2447: Astronomer in the Sun's lucent Orbe
2448: Through his glaz'd Optic Tube yet never saw.
2449: The place he found beyond expression bright,
2450: Compar'd with aught on Earth, Medal or Stone;
2451: Not all parts like, but all alike informd
2452: With radiant light, as glowing Iron with fire;
2453: If mettal, part seemd Gold, part Silver cleer;
2454: If stone, Carbuncle most or Chrysolite,
2455: Rubie or Topaz, to the Twelve that shon
2456: In *Aarons* Brest-plate, and a stone besides
2457: Imagind rather oft then elsewhere seen,
2458: That stone, or like to that which here below
2459: Philosophers in vain so long have sought,
2460: In vain, though by thir powerful Art they binde
2462: In various shapes old *Proteus* from the Sea,
2463: Draind through a Limbec to his Native forme.
2464: What wonder then if fields and regions here
2465: Breathe forth *Elixir* pure, and Rivers run
2466: Potable Gold, when with one vertuous touch
2467: Th' Arch-chimic Sun so farr from us remote
2469: Here in the dark so many precious things
2470: Of colour glorious and effect so rare?
2471: Here matter new to gaze the Devil met
2472: Undazl'd, farr and wide his eye commands,
2473: For sight no obstacle found here, nor shade,
2474: But all Sun-shine, as when his Beams at Noon
2475: Culminate from th' *Aequator*, as they now
2476: Shot upward still direct, whence no way round
2477: Shadow from body opaque can fall, and the Aire,
2478: No where so cleer, sharp'nd his visual ray
2479: To objects distant farr, whereby he soon
2480: Saw within kenn a glorious Angel stand,
2481: The same whom *John* saw also in the Sun:
2482: His back was turnd, but not his brightness hid;
2483: Of beaming sunnie Raies, a golden tiar
2484: Circl'd his Head, nor less his Locks behind
2485: Illustrious on his Shoulders fledge with wings
2486: Lay waving round; on som great charge imploy'd
2487: Hee seemd, or fixt in cogitation deep.
2488: Glad was the Spirit impure as now in hope
2489: To find who might direct his wandring flight
2490: To Paradise the happie seat of Man,
2491: His journies end and our beginning woe.
2492: But first he casts to change his proper shape,
2493: Which else might work him danger or delay:
2494: And now a stripling Cherube he appeers,
2495: Not of the prime, yet such as in his face
2496: Youth smil'd Celestial, and to every Limb
2497: Sutable grace diffus'd, so well he feignd;
2498: Under a Coronet his flowing haire
2499: In curles on either cheek plaid, wings he wore
2500: Of many a colourd plume sprinkl'd with Gold,
2501: His habit fit for speed succinct, and held
2502: Before his decent steps a Silver wand.
2503: He drew not nigh unheard, the Angel bright,
2504: Ere he drew nigh, his radiant visage turnd,
2505: Admonisht by his eare, and strait was known
2506: Th' Arch-Angel *Uriel*, one of the seav'n
2507: Who in Gods presence, neerest to his Throne
2508: Stand ready at command, and are his Eyes
2509: That run through all the Heav'ns, or down to th' Earth
2510: Bear his swift errands over moist and dry,
2511: O're Sea and Land: him *Satan* thus accostes;
2512: ¶*Uriel*, for thou of those seav'n Spirits that stand
2513: In sight of God's high Throne, gloriously bright,
2514: The first art wont his great authentic will
2515: Interpreter through highest Heav'n to bring,
2516: Where all his Sons thy Embassie attend;
2517: And here art likeliest by supream decree
2518: Like honour to obtain, and as his Eye
2519: To visit oft this new Creation round;
2520: Unspeakable desire to see, and know
2521: All these his wondrous works, but chiefly Man,
2522: His chief delight and favour, him for whom
2523: All these his works so wondrous he ordaind,
2524: Hath brought me from the Quires of Cherubim
2525: Alone thus wandring.  Brightest Seraph tell
2526: In which of all these shining Orbes hath Man
2527: His fixed seat, or fixed seat hath none,
2528: But all these shining Orbes his choice to dwell;
2529: That I may find him, and with secret gaze,
2531: On whom the great Creator hath bestowd
2532: Worlds, and on whom hath all these graces powrd;
2533: That both in him and all things, as is meet,
2534: The Universal Maker we may praise;
2535: Who justly hath drivn out his Rebell Foes
2536: To deepest Hell, and to repair that loss
2537: Created this new happie Race of Men
2538: To serve him better: wise are all his wayes.
2540: For neither Man nor Angel can discern
2541: Hypocrisie, the only evil that walks
2543: By his permissive will, through Heav'n and Earth:
2544: And oft though wisdom wake, suspicion sleeps
2545: At wisdoms Gate, and to simplicitie
2546: Resigns her charge, while goodness thinks no ill
2547: Where no ill seems: Which now for once beguil'd
2548: *Uriel*, though Regent of the Sun, and held
2549: The sharpest sighted Spirit of all in Heav'n;
2550: Who to the fraudulent Impostor foule
2551: In his uprightness answer thus returnd.
2552: Faire Angel, thy desire which tends to know
2553: The works of God, thereby to glorifie
2554: The great Work-Maister, leads to no excess
2555: That reaches blame, but rather merits praise
2556: The more it seems excess, that led thee hither
2557: From thy Empyreal Mansion thus alone,
2558: To witness with thine eyes what some perhaps
2559: Contented with report heare onely in heav'n:
2560: For wonderful indeed are all his works,
2561: Pleasant to know, and worthiest to be all
2562: Had in remembrance alwayes with delight;
2563: But what created mind can comprehend
2564: Thir number, or the wisdom infinite
2565: That brought them forth, but hid thir causes deep.
2566: I saw when at his Word the formless Mass,
2567: This worlds material mould, came to a heap:
2568: Confusion heard his voice, and wilde uproar
2569: Stood rul'd, stood vast infinitude confin'd;
2570: Till at his second bidding darkness fled,
2571: Light shon, and order from disorder sprung:
2572: Swift to thir several Quarters hasted then
2573: The cumbrous Elements, Earth, Flood, Aire, Fire,
2574: And this Ethereal quintessence of Heav'n
2575: Flew upward, spirited with various forms,
2576: That rowld orbicular, and turnd to Starrs
2577: Numberless, as thou seest, and how they move;
2578: Each had his place appointed, each his course,
2579: The rest in circuit walles this Universe.
2580: Look downward on that Globe whose hither side
2581: With light from hence, though but reflected, shines;
2582: That place is Earth the seat of Man, that light
2583: His day, which else as th' other Hemisphere
2584: Night would invade, but there the neighbouring Moon
2585: (So call that opposite fair Starr) her aide
2586: Timely interposes, and her monthly round
2587: Still ending, still renewing, through mid Heav'n;
2588: With borrowd light her countenance triform
2589: Hence fills and empties to enlighten th' Earth,
2590: And in her pale dominion checks the night.
2591: That spot to which I point is *Paradise*,
2592: *Adams* abode, those loftie shades his Bowre.
2593: Thy way thou canst not miss, me mine requires.
2594: ¶Thus said, he turnd, and *Satan* bowing low,
2595: As to superior Spirits is wont in Heaven,
2596: Where honour due and reverence none neglects,
2597: Took leave, and toward the coast of Earth beneath,
2598: Down from th' Ecliptic, sped with hop'd success,
2599: Throws his steep flight with many an Aerie wheele,
2600: Nor staid, till on *Niphates* top he lights.
2603: ¶O For that warning voice, which he who saw
2604: Th' *Apocalyps*, heard cry in Heaven aloud,
2605: Then when the Dragon, put to second rout,
2606: Came furious down to be reveng'd on men,
2607: *Wo to the Inhabitants on Earth!* that now,
2608: While time was, our first Parents had bin warnd
2609: The coming of thir secret foe, and scap'd
2610: Haply so scap'd his mortal snare; for now
2611: *Satan*, now first inflam'd with rage, came down,
2612: The Tempter ere th' Accuser of man-kind,
2613: To wreck on innocent frail man his loss
2614: Of that first Battel, and his flight to Hell:
2615: Yet not rejoycing in his speed, though bold,
2616: Far off and fearless, nor with cause to boast,
2617: Begins his dire attempt, which nigh the birth
2618: Now rowling, boiles in his tumultuous brest,
2619: And like a devillish Engine back recoiles
2620: Upon himself; horror and doubt distract
2621: His troubl'd thoughts, and from the bottom stirr
2622: The Hell within him, for within him Hell
2623: He brings, and round about him, nor from Hell
2624: One step no more then from himself can fly
2625: By change of place: Now conscience wakes despair
2626: That slumberd, wakes the bitter memorie
2627: Of what he was, what is, and what must be
2628: Worse; of worse deeds worse sufferings must ensue.
2629: Sometimes towards *Eden* which now in his view
2630: Lay pleasant, his grievd look he fixes sad,
2631: Sometimes towards Heav'n and the full-blazing Sun,
2632: Which now sat high in his Meridian Towre:
2633: Then much revolving, thus in sighs began.
2634: ¶O thou that with surpassing Glory crownd,
2635: Look'st from thy sole Dominion like the God
2636: Of this new World; at whose sight all the Starrs
2637: Hide thir diminisht heads; to thee I call,
2638: But with no friendly voice, and add thy name
2639: O Sun, to tell thee how I hate thy beams
2640: That bring to my remembrance from what state
2641: I fell, how glorious once above thy Spheare;
2642: Till Pride and worse Ambition threw me down
2643: Warring in Heav'n against Heav'ns matchless King:
2644: Ah wherefore! he deservd no such return
2645: From me, whom he created what I was
2646: In that bright eminence, and with his good
2647: Upbraided none; nor was his service hard.
2648: What could be less then to afford him praise,
2649: The easiest recompence, and pay him thanks,
2650: How due! yet all his good prov'd ill in me,
2651: And wrought but malice; lifted up so high
2652: I sdeind subjection, and thought one step higher
2653: Would set me highest, and in a moment quit
2654: The debt immense of endless gratitude,
2655: So burthensome, still paying, still to ow;
2656: Forgetful what from him I still receivd,
2657: And understood not that a grateful mind
2658: By owing owes not, but still pays, at once
2659: Indebted and dischargd; what burden then?
2660: O had his powerful Destiny ordaind
2661: Me some inferiour Angel, I had stood
2662: Then happie; no unbounded hope had rais'd
2663: Ambition.  Yet why not? som other Power
2664: As great might have aspir'd, and me though mean
2665: Drawn to his part; but other Powers as great
2666: Fell not, but stand unshak'n, from within
2667: Or from without, to all temptations arm'd.
2668: Hadst thou the same free Will and Power to stand?
2669: Thou hadst: whom hast thou then or what to accuse,
2670: But Heav'ns free Love dealt equally to all?
2671: Be then his Love accurst, since love or hate,
2672: To me alike, it deals eternal woe.
2673: Nay curs'd be thou; since against his thy will
2674: Chose freely what it now so justly rues.
2675: Me miserable! which way shall I flie
2677: Which way I flie is Hell; my self am Hell;
2678: And in the lowest deep a lower deep
2679: Still threatning to devour me opens wide,
2680: To which the Hell I suffer seems a Heav'n.
2681: O then at last relent: is there no place
2682: Left for Repentance, none for Pardon left?
2683: None left but by submission; and that word
2684: *Disdain* forbids me, and my dread of shame
2685: Among the spirits beneath, whom I seduc'd
2686: With other promises and other vaunts
2687: Then to submit, boasting I could subdue
2688: Th' Omnipotent.  Ay me, they little know
2689: How dearly I abide that boast so vaine,
2690: Under what torments inwardly I groane;
2691: While they adore me on the Throne of Hell,
2692: With Diadem and Scepter high advanc'd
2693: The lower still I fall, onely Supream
2694: In miserie; such joy Ambition findes.
2695: But say I could repent and could obtaine
2696: By Act of Grace my former state; how soon
2697: Would highth recal high thoughts, how soon unsay
2698: What feign'd submission swore: ease would recant
2699: Vows made in pain, as violent and void.
2700: For never can true reconcilement grow
2701: Where wounds of deadly hate have peirc'd so deep:
2702: Which would but lead me to a worse relapse
2703: And heavier fall: so should I purchase deare
2704: Short intermission bought with double smart.
2705: This knows my punisher; therefore as farr
2706: From granting hee, as I from begging peace:
2707: All hope excluded thus, behold in stead
2708: Of us out-cast, exil'd, his new delight,
2709: Mankind created, and for him this World.
2710: So farwel Hope, and with Hope farwel Fear,
2711: Farwel Remorse: all Good to me is lost;
2712: Evil be thou my Good; by thee at least
2713: Divided Empire with Heav'ns King I hold
2714: By thee, and more then half perhaps will reigne;
2715: As Man ere long, and this new World shall know.
2716: ¶Thus while he spake, each passion dimm'd his face
2717: Thrice chang'd with pale, ire, envie and despair,
2718: Which marrd his borrow'd visage, and betraid
2719: Him counterfet, if any eye beheld.
2720: For heav'nly mindes from such distempers foule
2721: Are ever cleer.  Whereof hee soon aware,
2722: Each perturbation smooth'd with outward calme,
2723: Artificer of fraud; and was the first
2724: That practisd falshood under saintly shew,
2725: Deep malice to conceale, couch't with revenge:
2726: Yet not anough had practisd to deceive
2727: *Uriel* once warnd; whose eye pursu'd him down
2728: The way he went, and on th' *Assyrian* mount
2729: Saw him disfigur'd, more then could befall
2730: Spirit of happie sort: his gestures fierce
2731: He markd and mad demeanour, then alone,
2732: As he suppos'd, all unobserv'd, unseen.
2733: So on he fares, and to the border comes
2735: Now nearer, Crowns with her enclosure green,
2736: As with a rural mound the champain head
2737: Of a steep wilderness, whose hairie sides
2738: With thicket overgrown, grottesque and wilde,
2739: Access deni'd; and over head up grew
2741: Cedar, and Pine, and Firr, and branching Palm,
2742: A Silvan Scene, and as the ranks ascend
2743: Shade above shade, a woodie Theatre
2744: Of stateliest view.  Yet higher then thir tops
2745: The verdurous wall of Paradise up sprung:
2746: Which to our general Sire gave prospect large
2747: Into his neather Empire neighbouring round.
2748: And higher then that Wall a circling row
2749: Of goodliest Trees loaden with fairest Fruit,
2750: Blossoms and Fruits at once of golden hue
2751: Appeerd, with gay enameld colours mixt:
2752: On which the Sun more glad impress'd his beams
2753: Then in fair Evening Cloud, or humid Bow,
2754: When God hath showrd the earth; so lovely seemd
2755: That Lantskip: And of pure now purer aire
2756: Meets his approach, and to the heart inspires
2757: Vernal delight and joy, able to drive
2758: All sadness but despair: now gentle gales
2760: Native perfumes, and whisper whence they stole
2761: Those balmie spoiles.  As when to them who saile
2762: Beyond the *Cape of Hope*, and now are past
2763: *Mozambic*, off at Sea North-East windes blow
2765: Of *Arabie* the blest, with such delay
2766: Well pleas'd they slack thir course, and many a League
2767: Cheard with the grateful smell old Ocean smiles.
2768: So entertaind those odorous sweets the Fiend
2769: Who came thir bane, though with them better pleas'd
2771: That drove him, though enamourd, from the Spouse
2772: Of *Tobits* Son, and with a vengeance sent
2773: From *Media* post to *Aegypt*, there fast bound.
2774: ¶Now to th' ascent of that steep savage Hill
2775: *Satan* had journied on, pensive and slow;
2776: But further way found none, so thick entwin'd,
2777: As one continu'd brake, the undergrowth
2778: Of shrubs and tangling bushes had perplext
2779: All path of Man or Beast that past that way:
2780: One Gate there onely was, and that look'd East
2781: On th' other side: which when th' arch-fellon saw
2782: Due entrance he disdaind, and in contempt,
2783: At one slight bound high overleap'd all bound
2784: Of Hill or highest Wall, and sheer within
2785: Lights on his feet.  As when a prowling Wolfe,
2786: Whom hunger drives to seek new haunt for prey,
2787: Watching where Shepherds pen thir Flocks at eeve
2788: In hurdl'd Cotes amid the field secure,
2789: Leaps o're the fence with ease into the Fould:
2790: Or as a Thief bent to unhoord the cash
2791: Of some rich Burgher, whose substantial dores,
2792: Cross-barrd and bolted fast, fear no assault,
2793: In at the window climbes, or o're the tiles;
2794: So clomb this first grand Thief into Gods Fould:
2795: So since into his Church lewd Hirelings climbe.
2796: Thence up he flew, and on the Tree of Life,
2797: The middle Tree and highest there that grew,
2798: Sat like a Cormorant; yet not true Life
2799: Thereby regaind, but sat devising Death
2800: To them who liv'd; nor on the vertue thought
2801: Of that life-giving Plant, but only us'd
2802: For prospect, what well us'd had bin the pledge
2804: Any, but God alone, to value right
2805: The good before him, but perverts best things
2806: To worst abuse, or to thir meanest use.
2807: Beneath him with new wonder now he views
2808: To all delight of human sense expos'd
2809: In narrow room Natures whole wealth, yea more,
2810: A Heaven on Earth, for blissful Paradise
2811: Of God the Garden was, by him in the East
2813: From *Auran* Eastward to the Royal Towrs
2815: Or where the Sons of *Eden* long before
2816: Dwelt in *Telassar:* in this pleasant soile
2817: His farr more pleasant Garden God ordaind;
2818: Out of the fertil ground he caus'd to grow
2819: All Trees of noblest kind for sight, smell, taste;
2820: And all amid them stood the Tree of Life,
2822: Of vegetable Gold; and next to Life
2823: Our Death the Tree of Knowledge grew fast by,
2824: Knowledge of Good bought dear by knowing ill.
2825: Southward through *Eden* went a River large,
2826: Nor chang'd his course, but through the shaggie hill
2827: Pass'd underneath ingulft, for God had thrown
2828: That Mountain as his Garden mould high rais'd
2829: Upon the rapid current, which through veins
2830: Of porous Earth with kindly thirst up drawn,
2831: Rose a fresh Fountain, and with many a rill
2832: Waterd the Garden; thence united fell
2833: Down the steep glade, and met the neather Flood,
2834: Which from his darksom passage now appeers,
2835: And now divided into four main Streams,
2836: Runs divers, wandring many a famous Realme
2837: And Country whereof here needs no account,
2838: But rather to tell how, if Art could tell,
2839: How from that Saphire Fount the crisped Brooks,
2840: Rowling on Orient Pearl and sands of Gold,
2841: With mazie error under pendant shades
2842: Ran Nectar, visiting each plant, and fed
2843: Flours worthy of Paradise which not nice Art
2844: In Beds and curious Knots, but Nature boon
2845: Powrd forth profuse on Hill and Dale and Plaine,
2846: Both where the morning Sun first warmly smote
2847: The open field, and where the unpierc't shade
2848: Imbround the noontide Bowrs: Thus was this place,
2849: A happy rural seat of various view;
2850: Groves whose rich Trees wept odorous Gumms and Balme,
2851: Others whose fruit burnisht with Golden Rinde
2853: If true, here onely, and of delicious taste:
2854: Betwixt them Lawns, or level Downs, and Flocks
2855: Grasing the tender herb, were interpos'd,
2856: Or palmie hilloc, or the flourie lap
2857: Of som irriguous Valley spread her store,
2858: Flours of all hue, and without Thorn the Rose:
2859: Another side, umbrageous Grots and Caves
2860: Of coole recess, o're which the mantling Vine
2861: Layes forth her purple Grape, and gently creeps
2862: Luxuriant; mean while murmuring waters fall
2863: Down the slope hills, disperst, or in a Lake,
2864: That to the fringed Bank with Myrtle crownd,
2865: Her chrystall mirror holds, unite thir streams.
2866: The Birds thir quire apply; aires, vernal aires,
2867: Breathing the smell of field and grove, attune
2869: Knit with the *Graces* and the *Hours* in dance
2870: Led on th' Eternal Spring.  Not that faire field
2872: Her self a fairer Floure by gloomie *Dis*
2873: Was gatherd, which cost *Ceres* all that pain
2874: To seek her through the world; nor that sweet Grove
2878: Girt with the River *Triton*, where old *Cham*,
2882: Nor where *Abassin* Kings thir issue Guard,
2883: Mount *Amara*, though this by som suppos'd
2885: By *Nilus* head, enclos'd with shining Rock,
2886: A whole dayes journey high, but wide remote
2887: From this *Assyrian* Garden, where the Fiend
2888: Saw undelighted all delight, all kind
2889: Of living Creatures new to sight and strange:
2890: Two of far nobler shape erect and tall,
2891: Godlike erect, with native Honour clad
2892: In naked Majestie seemd Lords of all,
2893: And worthie seemd, for in thir looks Divine
2894: The image of thir glorious Maker shon,
2895: Truth, Wisdome, Sanctitude severe and pure,
2896: Severe, but in true filial freedom plac't;
2897: Whence true autoritie in men; though both
2898: Not equal, as thir sex not equal seemd;
2899: For contemplation hee and valour formd,
2900: For softness shee and sweet attractive Grace,
2901: Hee for God only, shee for God in him:
2902: His fair large Front and Eye sublime declar'd
2904: Round from his parted forelock manly hung
2905: Clustring, but not beneath his shoulders broad:
2906: Shee as a vail down to the slender waste
2908: Dissheveld, but in wanton ringlets wav'd
2909: As the Vine curles her tendrils, which impli'd
2910: Subjection, but requir'd with gentle sway,
2911: And by her yeilded, by him best receivd,
2912: Yeilded with coy submission, modest pride,
2914: Nor those mysterious parts were then conceald,
2915: Then was not guiltie shame, dishonest shame
2917: Sin-bred, how have ye troubl'd all mankind
2918: With shews instead, meer shews of seeming pure,
2919: And banisht from mans life his happiest life,
2921: So passd they naked on, nor shund the sight
2922: Of God or Angel, for they thought no ill:
2923: So hand in hand they passd, the lovliest pair
2924: That ever since in loves imbraces met,
2925: *Adam* the goodliest man of men since borne
2926: His Sons, the fairest of her Daughters *Eve*.
2927: Under a tuft of shade that on a green
2928: Stood whispering soft, by a fresh Fountain side
2929: They sat them down, and after no more toil
2930: Of thir sweet Gardning labour then suffic'd
2931: To recommend coole *Zephyr*, and made ease
2932: More easie, wholsom thirst and appetite
2933: More grateful, to thir Supper Fruits they fell,
2934: Nectarine Fruits which the compliant boughes
2935: Yeilded them, side-long as they sat recline
2936: On the soft downie Bank damaskt with flours:
2937: The savourie pulp they chew, and in the rinde
2938: Still as they thirsted scoop the brimming stream;
2939: Nor gentle purpose, nor endearing smiles
2940: Wanted, nor youthful dalliance as beseems
2941: Fair couple, linkt in happie nuptial League,
2942: Alone as they.  About them frisking playd
2943: All Beasts of th' Earth, since wilde, and of all chase
2944: In Wood or Wilderness, Forrest or Den;
2945: Sporting the Lion rampd, and in his paw
2946: Dandl'd the Kid; Bears, Tygers, Ounces, Pards
2947: Gambold before them, th' unwieldy Elephant
2948: To make them mirth us'd all his might, & wreathd
2949: His Lithe Proboscis; close the Serpent sly
2951: His breaded train, and of his fatal guile
2952: Gave proof unheeded; others on the grass
2953: Coucht, and now fild with pasture gazing sat,
2954: Or Bedward ruminating: for the Sun
2955: Declin'd was hasting now with prone carreer
2956: To th' Ocean Iles, and in th' ascending Scale
2957: Of Heav'n the Starrs that usher Evening rose:
2958: When *Satan* still in gaze, as first he stood,
2959: Scarce thus at length faild speech recoverd sad.
2960: ¶O Hell! what doe mine eyes with grief behold,
2961: Into our room of bliss thus high advanc't
2962: Creatures of other mould, earth-born perhaps,
2963: Not Spirits, yet to heav'nly Spirits bright
2964: Little inferior; whom my thoughts pursue
2965: With wonder, and could love, so lively shines
2966: In them Divine resemblance, and such grace
2967: The hand that formd them on thir shape hath pourd.
2968: Ah gentle pair, yee little think how nigh
2969: Your change approaches, when all these delights
2970: Will vanish and deliver ye to woe,
2971: More woe, the more your taste is now of joy;
2972: Happie, but for so happie ill secur'd
2973: Long to continue, and this high seat your Heav'n
2974: Ill fenc't for Heav'n to keep out such a foe
2975: As now is enterd; yet no purpos'd foe
2976: To you whom I could pittie thus forlorne
2977: Though I unpittied: League with you I seek,
2978: And mutual amitie so streight, so close,
2979: That I with you must dwell, or you with me
2980: Henceforth; my dwelling haply may not please
2981: Like this fair Paradise, your sense, yet such
2982: Accept your Makers work; he gave it me,
2983: Which I as freely give; Hell shall unfould,
2984: To entertain you two, her widest Gates,
2985: And send forth all her Kings; there will be room,
2986: Not like these narrow limits, to receive
2987: Your numerous ofspring; if no better place,
2988: Thank him who puts me loath to this revenge
2989: On you who wrong me not for him who wrongd.
2990: And should I at your harmless innocence
2991: Melt, as I doe, yet public reason just,
2992: Honour and Empire with revenge enlarg'd,
2993: By conquering this new World, compels me now
2994: To do what else though damnd I should abhorre.
2995: ¶So spake the Fiend, and with necessitie,
2996: The Tyrants plea, excus'd his devilish deeds.
2997: Then from his loftie stand on that high Tree
2998: Down he alights among the sportful Herd
2999: Of those fourfooted kindes, himself now one,
3000: Now other, as thir shape servd best his end
3001: Neerer to view his prey, and unespi'd
3002: To mark what of thir state he more might learn
3003: By word or action markt: about them round
3004: A Lion now he stalkes with fierie glare,
3005: Then as a Tiger, who by chance hath spi'd
3006: In some Purlieu two gentle Fawnes at play,
3007: Strait couches close, then rising changes oft
3008: His couchant watch, as one who chose his ground
3009: Whence rushing he might surest seise them both
3010: Grip't in each paw: when *Adam* first of men
3011: To first of women *Eve* thus moving speech,
3012: Turnd him all eare to heare new utterance flow.
3013: ¶Sole partner and sole part of all these joyes,
3014: Dearer thy self then all; needs must the Power
3015: That made us, and for us this ample World
3016: Be infinitly good, and of his good
3017: As liberal and free as infinite,
3018: That rais'd us from the dust and plac't us here
3019: In all this happiness, who at his hand
3020: Have nothing merited, nor can performe
3021: Aught whereof hee hath need, hee who requires
3022: From us no other service then to keep
3023: This one, this easie charge, of all the Trees
3024: In Paradise that beare delicious fruit
3025: So various, not to taste that onely Tree
3026: Of knowledge, planted by the Tree of Life,
3027: So neer grows Death to Life, what ere Death is,
3028: Som dreadful thing no doubt; for well thou knowst
3029: God hath pronounc't it death to taste that Tree,
3030: The only sign of our obedience left
3031: Among so many signes of power and rule
3032: Conferrd upon us, and Dominion giv'n
3033: Over all other Creatures that possesse
3034: Earth, Aire, and Sea.  Then let us not think hard
3036: Free leave so large to all things else, and choice
3038: But let us ever praise him, and extoll
3039: His bountie, following our delightful task
3040: To prune these growing Plants, & tend these Flours,
3041: Which were it toilsom, yet with thee were sweet.
3042: ¶To whom thus Eve repli'd.  O thou for whom
3043: And from whom I was formd flesh of thy flesh,
3044: And without whom am to no end, my Guide
3045: And Head, what thou hast said is just and right.
3046: For wee to him indeed all praises owe,
3047: And daily thanks, I chiefly who enjoy
3048: So farr the happier Lot, enjoying thee
3049: Preeminent by so much odds, while thou
3050: Like consort to thy self canst no where find.
3051: That day I oft remember, when from sleep
3052: I first awak't, and found my self repos'd
3053: Under a shade on flours, much wondring where
3054: And what I was, whence thither brought, and how.
3055: Not distant far from thence a murmuring sound
3056: Of waters issu'd from a Cave and spread
3057: Into a liquid Plain, then stood unmov'd
3058: Pure as th' expanse of Heav'n; I thither went
3059: With unexperienc't thought, and laid me downe
3060: On the green bank, to look into the cleer
3061: Smooth Lake, that to me seemd another Skie.
3062: As I bent down to look, just opposite,
3063: A Shape within the watry gleam appeerd
3064: Bending to look on me, I started back,
3065: It started back, but pleasd I soon returnd,
3066: Pleas'd it returnd as soon with answering looks
3067: Of sympathie and love, there I had fixt
3068: Mine eyes till now, and pin'd with vain desire,
3069: Had not a voice thus warnd me, What thou seest,
3070: What there thou seest fair Creature is thy self,
3071: With thee it came and goes: but follow me,
3072: And I will bring thee where no shadow staies
3073: Thy coming, and thy soft imbraces, hee
3074: Whose image thou art, him thou shall enjoy
3075: Inseparablie thine, to him shalt beare
3076: Multitudes like thy self, and thence be call'd
3077: Mother of human Race: what could I doe,
3078: But follow strait, invisibly thus led?
3079: Till I espi'd thee, fair indeed and tall,
3080: Under a Platan, yet methought less faire,
3081: Less winning soft, less amiablie milde,
3082: Then that smooth watry image; back I turnd,
3083: Thou following cryd'st aloud, Return fair *Eve*,
3084: Whom fli'st thou? whom thou fli'st, of him thou art,
3085: His flesh, his bone; to give thee being I lent
3086: Out of my side to thee, neerest my heart
3087: Substantial Life, to have thee by my side
3089: Part of my Soul I seek thee, and thee claim
3090: My other half: with that thy gentle hand
3091: Seisd mine, I yeilded, and from that time see
3092: How beauty is excelld by manly grace
3093: And wisdom, which alone is truly fair.
3094: ¶So spake our general Mother, and with eyes
3096: And meek surrender, half imbracing leand
3097: On our first Father, half her swelling Breast
3098: Naked met his under the flowing Gold
3099: Of her loose tresses hid: he in delight
3100: Both of her Beauty and submissive Charms
3102: On *Juno* smiles, when he impregns the Clouds
3103: That shed *May* Flowers; and press'd her Matron lip
3104: With kisses pure: aside the Devil turnd
3105: For envie, yet with jealous leer maligne
3106: Ey'd them askance, and to himself thus plaind.
3107: ¶Sight hateful, sight tormenting! thus these two
3109: The happier *Eden*, shall enjoy thir fill
3110: Of bliss on bliss, while I to Hell am thrust,
3111: Where neither joy nor love, but fierce desire,
3112: Among our other torments not the least,
3113: Still unfulfill'd with pain of longing pines;
3114: Yet let me not forget what I have gain'd
3115: From thir own mouths; all is not theirs it seems:
3116: One fatal Tree there stands of Knowledge call'd,
3117: Forbidden them to taste: Knowledge forbidd'n?
3118: Suspicious, reasonless.  Why should thir Lord
3119: Envie them that? can it be sin to know,
3120: Can it be death? and do they onely stand
3121: By Ignorance, is that thir happie state,
3122: The proof of thir obedience and thir faith?
3123: O fair foundation laid whereon to build
3124: Thir ruine!  Hence I will excite thir minds
3125: With more desire to know, and to reject
3127: To keep them low whom knowledge might exalt
3128: Equal with Gods; aspiring to be such,
3129: They taste and die: what likelier can ensue?
3130: But first with narrow search I must walk round
3131: This Garden, and no corner leave unspi'd;
3132: A chance but chance may lead where I may meet
3133: Some wandring Spirit of Heav'n, by Fountain side,
3134: Or in thick shade retir'd, from him to draw
3135: What further would be learnt.  Live while ye may,
3136: Yet happie pair; enjoy, till I return,
3137: Short pleasures, for long woes are to succeed.
3138: ¶So saying, his proud step he scornful turn'd,
3139: But with sly circumspection, and began
3140: Through wood, through waste, o're hil, o're dale his roam.
3141: Mean while in utmost Longitude, where Heav'n
3142: With Earth and Ocean meets, the setting Sun
3143: Slowly descended, and with right aspect
3144: Against the eastern Gate of Paradise
3145: Leveld his eevning Rayes: it was a Rock
3146: Of Alablaster, pil'd up to the Clouds,
3147: Conspicuous farr, winding with one ascent
3148: Accessible from Earth, one entrance high;
3149: The rest was craggie cliff, that overhung
3150: Still as it rose, impossible to climbe.
3152: Chief of th' Angelic Guards, awaiting night;
3154: Th' unarmed Youth of Heav'n, but nigh at hand
3155: Celestial Armourie, Shields, Helmes, and Speares
3156: Hung high with Diamond flaming, and with Gold.
3157: Thither came *Uriel*, gliding through the Eeven
3158: On a Sun beam, swift as a shooting Starr
3159: In *Autumn* thwarts the night, when vapors fir'd
3160: Impress the Air, and shews the Mariner
3161: From what point of his Compass to beware
3162: Impetuous winds: he thus began in haste.
3163: ¶*Gabriel*, to thee thy cours by Lot hath giv'n
3164: Charge and strict watch that to this happie place
3165: No evil thing approach or enter in;
3166: This day at highth of Noon came to my Spheare
3167: A Spirit, zealous, as he seem'd, to know
3168: More of th' Almighties works, and chiefly Man
3169: Gods latest Image: I describ'd his way
3170: Bent all on speed, and markt his Aerie Gate;
3171: But in the Mount that lies from *Eden* North,
3172: Where he first lighted, soon discernd his looks
3173: Alien from Heav'n, with passions foul obscur'd:
3174: Mine eye pursu'd him still, but under shade
3175: Lost sight of him; one of the banisht crew
3176: I fear, hath ventur'd from the deep, to raise
3177: New troubles; him thy care must be to find.
3178: ¶To whom the winged Warriour thus returnd:
3179: *Uriel*, no wonder if thy perfet sight,
3180: Amid the Suns bright circle where thou sitst,
3181: See farr and wide: in at this Gate none pass
3182: The vigilance here plac't, but such as come
3183: Well known from Heav'n; and since Meridian hour
3184: No Creature thence: if Spirit of other sort,
3185: So minded, have oreleapt these earthie bounds
3186: On purpose, hard thou knowst it to exclude
3188: But if within the circuit of these walks
3189: In whatsoever shape he lurk, of whom
3190: Thou telst, by morrow dawning I shall know.
3191: ¶So promis'd hee, and *Uriel* to his charge
3192: Returnd on that bright beam, whose point now raisd
3193: Bore him slope downward to the Sun now fall'n
3194: Beneath th' *Azores*; whither the prime Orb,
3195: Incredible how swift, had thither rowl'd
3196: Diurnal, or this less volubil Earth
3197: By shorter flight to th' East, had left him there
3198: Arraying with reflected Purple and Gold
3199: The Clouds that on his Western Throne attend:
3200: Now came still Eevning on, and Twilight gray
3201: Had in her sober Liverie all things clad;
3202: Silence accompanied, for Beast and Bird,
3203: They to thir grassie Couch, these to thir Nests
3204: Were slunk, all but the wakeful Nightingale;
3205: She all night long her amorous descant sung;
3206: Silence was pleas'd: now glow'd the Firmament
3208: The starrie Host, rode brightest, till the Moon
3209: Rising in clouded Majestie, at length
3210: Apparent Queen unvaild her peerless light,
3211: And o're the dark her Silver Mantle threw.
3212: ¶When *Adam* thus to *Eve*: Fair Consort, th' hour
3213: Of night, and all things now retir'd to rest
3214: Mind us of like repose, since God hath set
3215: Labour and rest, as day and night to men
3216: Successive, and the timely dew of sleep
3217: Now falling with soft slumbrous weight inclines
3218: Our eye-lids; other Creatures all day long
3219: Rove idle unimploid, and less need rest;
3220: Man hath his daily work of body or mind
3222: And the regard of Heav'n on all his waies;
3224: And of thir doings God takes no account.
3225: Tomorrow ere fresh Morning streak the East
3226: With first approach of light, we must be ris'n,
3227: And at our pleasant labour, to reform
3228: Yon flourie Arbors, yonder Allies green,
3229: Our walks at noon, with branches overgrown,
3230: That mock our scant manuring, and require
3231: More hands then ours to lop thir wanton growth:
3232: Those Blossoms also, and those dropping Gumms,
3233: That lie bestrowne unsightly and unsmooth,
3234: Ask riddance, if we mean to tread with ease;
3235: Mean while, as Nature wills, Night bids us rest.
3236: ¶To whom thus *Eve* with perfet beauty adornd.
3237: My Author and Disposer, what thou bidst
3238: Unargu'd I obey; so God ordains,
3239: God is thy Law, thou mine: to know no more
3240: Is womans happiest knowledge and her praise.
3241: With thee conversing I forget all time,
3242: All seasons and thir change, all please alike.
3243: Sweet is the breath of morn, her rising sweet,
3244: With charm of earliest Birds; pleasant the Sun
3245: When first on this delightful Land he spreads
3246: His orient Beams, on herb, tree, fruit, and flour,
3247: Glistring with dew; fragrant the fertil earth
3248: After soft showers; and sweet the coming on
3249: Of grateful Eevning milde, then silent Night
3250: With this her solemn Bird and this fair Moon,
3251: And these the Gemms of Heav'n, her starrie train:
3252: But neither breath of Morn when she ascends
3253: With charm of earliest Birds, nor rising Sun
3254: On this delightful land, nor herb, fruit, floure,
3255: Glistring with dew, nor fragrance after showers,
3256: Nor grateful Evening mild, nor silent Night
3257: With this her solemn Bird, nor walk by Moon,
3258: Or glittering Starr-light without thee is sweet.
3259: But wherfore all night long shine these, for whom
3260: This glorious sight, when sleep hath shut all eyes?
3262: Daughter of God and Man, accomplisht *Eve*,
3263: Those have thir course to finish, round the Earth,
3264: By morrow Eevning, and from Land to Land
3265: In order, though to Nations yet unborn,
3266: Ministring light prepar'd, they set and rise;
3267: Least total darkness should by Night regaine
3268: Her old possession, and extinguish life
3269: In Nature and all things, which these soft fires
3270: Not only enlighten, but with kindly heate
3271: Of various influence foment and warme,
3272: Temper or nourish, or in part shed down
3273: Thir stellar vertue on all kinds that grow
3274: On Earth, made hereby apter to receive
3275: Perfection from the Suns more potent Ray.
3276: These then, though unbeheld in deep of night,
3277: Shine not in vain, nor think, though men were none,
3278: That heav'n would want spectators, God want praise;
3279: Millions of spiritual Creatures walk the Earth
3280: Unseen, both when we wake, and when we sleep:
3281: All these with ceasless praise his works behold
3282: Both day and night: how often from the steep
3283: Of echoing Hill or Thicket have we heard
3284: Celestial voices to the midnight air,
3285: Sole, or responsive each to others note
3286: Singing thir great Creator: oft in bands
3287: While they keep watch, or nightly rounding walk
3288: With Heav'nly touch of instrumental sounds
3289: In full harmonic number joind, thir songs
3290: Divide the night, and lift our thoughts to Heaven.
3291: ¶Thus talking hand in hand alone they pass'd
3292: On to thir blissful Bower; it was a place
3293: Chos'n by the sovran Planter, when he fram'd
3294: All things to mans delightful use; the roofe
3295: Of thickest covert was inwoven shade
3296: Laurel and Mirtle, and what higher grew
3297: Of firm and fragrant leaf; on either side
3299: Fenc'd up the verdant wall; each beauteous flour,
3301: Rear'd high thir flourisht heads between, and wrought
3303: Crocus, and Hyacinth with rich inlay
3304: Broiderd the ground, more colour'd then with stone
3305: Of costliest Emblem: other Creature here
3306: Beast, Bird, Insect, or Worm durst enter none;
3307: Such was thir awe of man.  In shadier Bower
3308: More sacred and sequesterd, though but feignd,
3310: Nor *Faunus* haunted.  Here in close recess
3311: With Flowers, Garlands, and sweet-smelling Herbs
3312: Espoused *Eve* deckt first her Nuptial Bed,
3313: And heav'nly Quires the Hymenaean sung,
3314: What day the genial Angel to our Sire
3315: Brought her in naked beauty more adorn'd,
3316: More lovely then *Pandora*, whom the Gods
3317: Endowd with all thir gifts, and O too like
3318: In sad event, when to the unwiser Son
3320: Mankind with her faire looks, to be aveng'd
3321: On him who had stole *Joves* authentic fire.
3322: ¶Thus at thir shadie Lodge arriv'd, both stood,
3323: Both turnd, and under op'n Skie ador'd
3324: The God that made both Skie, Air, Earth & Heav'n
3325: Which they beheld, the Moons resplendent Globe
3326: And starrie Pole: Thou also mad'st the Night,
3327: Maker Omnipotent, and thou the Day,
3328: Which we in our appointed work imployd
3329: Have finisht happie in our mutual help
3330: And mutual love, the Crown of all our bliss
3331: Ordain'd by thee, and this delicious place
3332: For us too large, where thy abundance wants
3333: Partakers, and uncropt falls to the ground.
3334: But thou hast promis'd from us two a Race
3335: To fill the Earth, who shall with us extoll
3336: Thy goodness infinite, both when we wake,
3337: And when we seek, as now, thy gift of sleep.
3340: Which God likes best, into thir inmost bower
3341: Handed they went; and eas'd the putting off
3342: These troublesom disguises which wee wear,
3343: Strait side by side were laid, nor turnd I weene
3344: *Adam* from his fair Spouse, nor *Eve* the Rites
3347: Of puritie and place and innocence,
3348: Defaming as impure what God declares
3349: Pure, and commands to som, leaves free to all.
3350: Our Maker bids increase, who bids abstain
3351: But our Destroyer, foe to God and Man?
3352: Haile wedded Love, mysterious Law, true source
3354: In Paradise of all things common else.
3355: By thee adulterous lust was driv'n from men
3356: Among the bestial herds to raunge, by thee
3357: Founded in Reason, Loyal, Just, and Pure,
3358: Relations dear, and all the Charities
3359: Of Father, Son, and Brother first were known.
3360: Farr be it, that I should write thee sin or blame,
3361: Or think thee unbefitting holiest place,
3363: Whose Bed is undefil'd and chast pronounc't,
3364: Present, or past, as Saints and Patriarchs us'd.
3365: Here Love his golden shafts imploies, here lights
3366: His constant Lamp, and waves his purple wings,
3367: Reigns here and revels; not in the bought smile
3369: Casual fruition, nor in Court Amours
3370: Mixt Dance, or wanton Mask, or Midnight Bal,
3371: Or Serenate, which the starv'd Lover sings
3372: To his proud fair, best quitted with disdain.
3373: These lulld by Nightingales imbraceing slept,
3374: And on thir naked limbs the flourie roof
3375: Showrd Roses, which the Morn repair'd.  Sleep on,
3376: Blest pair; and O yet happiest if ye seek
3377: No happier state, and know to know no more.
3378: ¶Now had night measur'd with her shaddowie Cone
3379: Half way up Hill this vast Sublunar Vault,
3380: And from thir Ivorie Port the Cherubim
3381: Forth issuing at th' accustomd hour stood armd
3382: To thir night watches in warlike Parade,
3383: When *Gabriel* to his next in power thus spake.
3384: ¶*Uzziel*, half these draw off, and coast the South
3385: With strictest watch; these other wheel the North,
3386: Our circuit meets full West.  As flame they part
3387: Half wheeling to the Shield, half to the Spear.
3388: From these, two strong and suttle Spirits he calld
3389: That neer him stood, and gave them thus in charge.
3391: Search through this Garden, leav unsearcht no nook,
3392: But chiefly where those two fair Creatures Lodge,
3393: Now laid perhaps asleep secure of harme.
3394: This Eevning from the Sun's decline arriv'd
3395: Who tells of som infernal Spirit seen
3396: Hitherward bent (who could have thought?) escap'd
3397: The barrs of Hell, on errand bad no doubt:
3398: Such where ye find, seise fast, and hither bring.
3399: ¶So saying, on he led his radiant Files,
3400: Daz'ling the Moon; these to the Bower direct
3401: In search of whom they sought: him there they found
3402: Squat like a Toad, close at the eare of *Eve*;
3403: Assaying by his Devilish art to reach
3404: The Organs of her Fancie, and with them forge
3405: Illusions as he list, Phantasms and Dreams,
3406: Or if, inspiring venom, he might taint
3407: Th' animal Spirits that from pure blood arise
3408: Like gentle breaths from Rivers pure, thence raise
3410: Vain hopes, vain aimes, inordinate desires
3411: Blown up with high conceits ingendring pride.
3412: Him thus intent *Ithuriel* with his Spear
3413: Touch'd lightly; for no falshood can endure
3414: Touch of Celestial temper, but returns
3415: Of force to its own likeness: up he starts
3416: Discoverd and surpriz'd.  As when a spark
3417: Lights on a heap of nitrous Powder, laid
3418: Fit for the Tun som Magazin to store
3419: Against a rumord Warr, the Smuttie graine
3420: With sudden blaze diffus'd, inflames the Aire:
3421: So started up in his own shape the Fiend.
3422: Back stept those two fair Angels half amaz'd
3423: So sudden to behold the grieslie King;
3424: Yet thus, unmovd with fear, accost him soon.
3425: ¶Which of those rebell Spirits adjudg'd to Hell
3426: Com'st thou, escap'd thy prison, and transform'd,
3427: Why satst thou like an enemie in waite
3428: Here watching at the head of these that sleep?
3429: ¶Know ye not then said *Satan*, filld with scorn,
3430: Know ye not me? ye knew me once no mate
3431: For you, there sitting where ye durst not soare;
3432: Not to know mee argues your selves unknown,
3433: The lowest of your throng; or if ye know,
3434: Why ask ye, and superfluous begin
3435: Your message, like to end as much in vain?
3436: To whom thus *Zephon*, answering scorn with scorn.
3437: Think not, revolted Spirit, thy shape the same,
3438: Or undiminisht brightness, to be known
3439: As when thou stoodst in Heav'n upright and pure;
3440: That Glorie then, when thou no more wast good,
3441: Departed from thee, and thou resembl'st now
3442: Thy sin and place of doom obscure and foule.
3443: But come, for thou, be sure, shalt give account
3444: To him who sent us, whose charge is to keep
3445: This place inviolable, and these from harm.
3446: ¶So spake the Cherube, and his grave rebuke
3447: Severe in youthful beautie, added grace
3449: And felt how awful goodness is, and saw
3450: Vertue in her shape how lovly, saw, and pin'd
3451: His loss; but chiefly to find here observd
3452: His lustre visibly impar'd; yet seemd
3453: Undaunted.  If I must contend, said he,
3454: Best with the best, the Sender not the sent,
3455: Or all at once; more glorie will be wonn,
3456: Or less be lost.  Thy fear, said *Zephon* bold,
3457: Will save us trial what the least can doe
3458: Single against thee wicked, and thence weak.
3459: ¶The Fiend repli'd not, overcome with rage;
3460: But like a proud Steed reind, went hautie on,
3461: Chaumping his iron curb: to strive or flie
3462: He held it vain; awe from above had quelld
3463: His heart, not else dismai'd.  Now drew they nigh
3464: The western point, where those half-rounding guards
3465: Just met, & closing stood in squadron joind
3466: Awaiting next command.  To whom thir Chief
3467: *Gabriel* from the Front thus calld aloud.
3468: ¶O friends, I hear the tread of nimble feet
3469: Hasting this way, and now by glimps discerne
3471: And with them comes a third of Regal port,
3472: But faded splendor wan; who by his gate
3473: And fierce demeanour seems the Prince of Hell,
3474: Not likely to part hence without contest;
3475: Stand firm, for in his look defiance lours.
3476: ¶He scarce had ended, when those two approachd
3477: And brief related whom they brought, wher found,
3478: How busied, in what form and posture coucht.
3479: ¶To whom with stern regard thus *Gabriel* spake.
3480: Why hast thou, *Satan*, broke the bounds prescrib'd
3481: To thy transgressions, and disturbd the charge
