3482: Of others, who approve not to transgress
3483: By thy example, but have power and right
3484: To question thy bold entrance on this place;
3485: Imploi'd it seems to violate sleep, and those
3486: Whose dwelling God hath planted here in bliss?
3488: *Gabriel*, thou hadst in Heav'n th' esteem of wise,
3489: And such I held thee; but this question askt
3490: Puts me in doubt.  Lives ther who loves his pain?
3491: Who would not, finding way, break loose from Hell,
3492: Though thither doomd?  Thou wouldst thy self, no doubt,
3493: And boldly venture to whatever place
3494: Farthest from pain, where thou mightst hope to change
3496: Dole with delight, which in this place I sought;
3497: To thee no reason; who knowst only good,
3498: But evil hast not tri'd: and wilt object
3499: His will who bound us? let him surer barr
3500: His Iron Gates, if he intends our stay
3501: In that dark durance: thus much what was askt.
3502: The rest is true, they found me where they say;
3503: But that implies not violence or harme.
3504: ¶Thus hee in scorn.  The warlike Angel mov'd,
3506: O loss of one in Heav'n to judge of wise,
3508: And now returns him from his prison scap't,
3509: Gravely in doubt whether to hold them wise
3510: Or not, who ask what boldness brought him hither
3511: Unlicenc't from his bounds in Hell prescrib'd;
3512: So wise he judges it to fly from pain
3513: However, and to scape his punishment.
3514: So judge thou still, presumptuous, till the wrauth,
3515: Which thou incurr'st by flying, meet thy flight
3516: Seavenfold, and scourge that wisdom back to Hell,
3517: Which taught thee yet no better, that no pain
3519: But wherefore thou alone? wherefore with thee
3520: Came not all Hell broke loose? is pain to them
3521: Less pain, less to be fled, or thou then they
3522: Less hardie to endure? courageous Chief,
3523: The first in flight from pain, had'st thou alleg'd
3524: To thy deserted host this cause of flight,
3525: Thou surely hadst not come sole fugitive.
3526: ¶To which the Fiend thus answerd frowning stern.
3527: Not that I less endure, or shrink from pain,
3528: Insulting Angel, well thou knowst I stood
3529: Thy fiercest, when in Battel to thy aide
3530: The blasting volied Thunder made all speed
3531: And seconded thy else not dreaded Spear.
3532: But still thy words at random, as before,
3534: From hard assaies and ill successes past
3535: A faithful Leader, not to hazard all
3536: Through wayes of danger by himself untri'd.
3537: I therefore, I alone first undertook
3538: To wing the desolate Abyss, and spie
3539: This new created World, whereof in Hell
3540: Fame is not silent, here in hope to find
3541: Better abode, and my afflicted Powers
3542: To settle here on Earth, or in mid Aire;
3543: Though for possession put to try once more
3544: What thou and thy gay Legions dare against;
3545: Whose easier business were to serve thir Lord
3546: High up in Heav'n, with songs to hymne his Throne,
3547: And practis'd distances to cringe, not fight.
3548: ¶To whom the warriour Angel soon repli'd.
3549: To say and strait unsay, pretending first
3550: Wise to flie pain, professing next the Spie,
3551: Argues no Leader, but a lyar trac't,
3552: *Satan*, and couldst thou faithful add?  O name,
3553: O sacred name of faithfulness profan'd!
3554: Faithful to whom? to thy rebellious crew?
3555: Armie of Fiends, fit body to fit head;
3556: Was this your discipline and faith ingag'd,
3558: Allegeance to th' acknowledg'd Power supream?
3559: And thou sly hypocrite, who now wouldst seem
3560: Patron of liberty, who more then thou
3561: Once fawn'd, and cring'd, and servilly ador'd
3562: Heav'ns awful Monarch? wherefore but in hope
3563: To dispossess him, and thy self to reigne?
3564: But mark what I arreede thee now, avant;
3565: Flie thither whence thou fledst: if from this houre
3566: Within these hallowd limits thou appeer,
3567: Back to th' infernal pit I drag thee chaind,
3568: And Seale thee so, as henceforth not to scorne
3569: The facil gates of hell too slightly barrd.
3570: ¶So threatn'd hee, but *Satan* to no threats
3571: Gave heed, but waxing more in rage repli'd.
3572: ¶Then when I am thy captive talk of chaines,
3573: Proud limitarie Cherube, but ere then
3574: Farr heavier load thy self expect to feel
3575: From my prevailing arme, though Heavens King
3576: Ride on thy wings, and thou with thy Compeers,
3577: Us'd to the yoak, draw'st his triumphant wheels
3578: In progress through the rode of Heav'n Star-pav'd.
3579: ¶While thus he spake, th' Angelic Squadron bright
3580: Turnd fierie red, sharpning in mooned hornes
3581: Thir Phalanx, and began to hemm him round
3582: With ported Spears, as thick as when a field
3583: Of *Ceres* ripe for harvest waving bends
3584: Her bearded Grove of ears, which way the wind
3585: Swayes them; the careful Plowman doubting stands
3586: Least on the threshing floore his hopeful sheaves
3587: Prove chaff.  On th' other side *Satan* allarm'd
3588: Collecting all his might dilated stood,
3590: His stature reacht the Skie, and on his Crest
3591: Sat horror Plum'd; nor wanted in his graspe
3592: What seemd both Spear and Shield: now dreadful deeds
3593: Might have ensu'd, nor onely Paradise
3594: In this commotion, but the Starrie Cope
3595: Of Heav'n perhaps, or all the Elements
3596: At least had gon to rack, disturbd and torne
3597: With violence of this conflict, had not soon
3598: Th' Eternal to prevent such horrid fray
3599: Hung forth in Heav'n his golden Scales, yet seen
3601: Wherein all things created first he weighd,
3602: The pendulous round Earth with ballanc't Aire
3603: In counterpoise, now ponders all events,
3604: Battels and Realms: in these he put two weights
3605: The sequel each of parting and of fight;
3606: The latter quick up flew, and kickt the beam;
3607: Which *Gabriel* spying, thus bespake the Fiend.
3608: ¶*Satan*, I know thy strength, and thou knowst mine,
3609: Neither our own but giv'n; what follie then
3610: To boast what Arms can doe, since thine no more
3611: Then Heav'n permits, nor mine, though doubld now
3612: To trample thee as mire: for proof look up,
3613: And read thy Lot in yon celestial Sign
3614: Where thou art weigh'd, & shown how light, how weak,
3615: If thou resist.  The Fiend lookt up and knew
3616: His mounted scale aloft: nor more; but fled
3617: Murmuring, and with him fled the shades of night.
3620: ¶Now Morn her rosie steps in th' Eastern Clime
3621: Advancing, sow'd the Earth with Orient Pearle,
3622: When *Adam* wak't, so customd, for his sleep
3623: Was Aerie light, from pure digestion bred,
3624: And temperat vapors bland, which th' only sound
3625: Of leaves and fuming rills, *Aurora's* fan,
3626: Lightly dispers'd, and the shrill Matin Song
3627: Of Birds on every bough; so much the more
3628: His wonder was to find unwak'nd *Eve*
3629: With Tresses discompos'd, and glowing Cheek,
3630: As through unquiet rest: he on his side
3631: Leaning half-rais'd, with looks of cordial Love
3632: Hung over her enamour'd, and beheld
3633: Beautie, which whether waking or asleep,
3634: Shot forth peculiar Graces; then with voice
3636: Her hand soft touching, whisperd thus.  Awake
3637: My fairest, my espous'd, my latest found,
3638: Heav'ns last best gift, my ever new delight,
3639: Awake, the morning shines, and the fresh field
3640: Calls us, we lose the prime, to mark how spring
3641: Our tended Plants, how blows the Citron Grove,
3642: What drops the Myrrhe, & what the balmie Reed,
3643: How Nature paints her colours, how the Bee
3644: Sits on the Bloom extracting liquid sweet.
3645: ¶Such whispering wak'd her, but with startl'd eye
3646: On *Adam*, whom imbracing, thus she spake.
3647: ¶O Sole in whom my thoughts find all repose,
3648: My Glorie, my Perfection, glad I see
3649: Thy face, and Morn return'd, for I this Night,
3650: Such night till this I never pass'd, have dream'd,
3651: If dream'd, not as I oft am wont, of thee,
3652: Works of day pass't, or morrows next designe,
3653: But of offence and trouble, which my mind
3654: Knew never till this irksom night; methought
3655: Close at mine ear one call'd me forth to walk
3656: With gentle voice, I thought it thine; it said,
3657: Why sleepst thou *Eve*? now is the pleasant time,
3658: The cool, the silent, save where silence yields
3659: To the night-warbling Bird, that now awake
3660: Tunes sweetest his love-labor'd song; now reignes
3661: Full Orb'd the Moon, and with more pleasing light
3662: Shadowie sets off the face of things; in vain,
3663: If none regard; Heav'n wakes with all his eyes,
3664: Whom to behold but thee, Natures desire,
3665: In whose sight all things joy, with ravishment
3666: Attracted by thy beauty still to gaze.
3667: I rose as at thy call, but found thee not;
3668: To find thee I directed then my walk;
3669: And on, methought, alone I pass'd through ways
3670: That brought me on a sudden to the Tree
3671: Of interdicted Knowledge: fair it seem'd,
3672: Much fairer to my Fancie then by day:
3673: And as I wondring lookt, beside it stood
3674: One shap'd & wing'd like one of those from Heav'n
3675: By us oft seen; his dewie locks distill'd
3676: Ambrosia; on that Tree he also gaz'd;
3677: And O fair Plant, said he, with fruit surcharg'd,
3678: Deigns none to ease thy load and taste thy sweet,
3679: Nor God, nor Man; is Knowledge so despis'd?
3680: Or envie, or what reserve forbids to taste?
3681: Forbid who will, none shall from me withhold
3682: Longer thy offerd good, why else set here?
3683: This said he paus'd not, but with ventrous Arme
3684: He pluckt, he tasted; mee damp horror chil'd
3685: At such bold words voucht with a deed so bold:
3686: But he thus overjoy'd, O Fruit Divine,
3687: Sweet of thy self, but much more sweet thus cropt,
3688: Forbidd'n here, it seems, as onely fit
3689: For Gods, yet able to make Gods of Men:
3690: And why not Gods of Men, since good, the more
3692: The Author not impair'd, but honourd more?
3694: Partake thou also; happie though thou art,
3695: Happier thou mayst be, worthier canst not be:
3696: Taste this, and be henceforth among the Gods
3697: Thy self a Goddess, not to Earth confind,
3698: But somtimes in the Air, as wee, somtimes
3699: Ascend to Heav'n, by merit thine, and see
3700: What life the Gods live there, and such live thou.
3701: So saying, he drew nigh, and to me held,
3702: Even to my mouth of that same fruit held part
3703: Which he had pluckt; the pleasant savourie smell
3704: So quick'nd appetite, that I, methought,
3705: Could not but taste.  Forthwith up to the Clouds
3706: With him I flew, and underneath beheld
3707: The Earth outstretcht immense, a prospect wide
3708: And various: wondring at my flight and change
3710: My Guide was gon, and I, me thought, sunk down,
3711: And fell asleep; but O how glad I wak'd
3712: To find this but a dream!  Thus *Eve* her Night
3714: ¶Best Image of my self and dearer half,
3715: The trouble of thy thoughts this night in sleep
3716: Affects me equally; nor can I like
3717: This uncouth dream, of evil sprung I fear;
3718: Yet evil whence? in thee can harbour none,
3719: Created pure.  But know that in the Soule
3720: Are many lesser Faculties that serve
3721: Reason as chief; among these Fansie next
3722: Her office holds; of all external things,
3723: Which the five watchful Senses represent,
3725: Which Reason joyning or disjoyning, frames
3726: All what we affirm or what deny, and call
3727: Our knowledge or opinion; then retires
3728: Into her private Cell when Nature rests.
3729: Oft in her absence mimic Fansie wakes
3730: To imitate her; but misjoyning shapes,
3731: Wilde work produces oft, and most in dreams,
3732: Ill matching words and deeds long past or late.
3733: Som such resemblances methinks I find
3734: Of our last Eevnings talk, in this thy dream,
3735: But with addition strange; yet be not sad.
3736: Evil into the mind of God or Man
3737: May come and go, so unapprov'd, and leave
3738: No spot or blame behind: Which gives me hope
3739: That what in sleep thou didst abhorr to dream,
3740: Waking thou never wilt consent to do.
3741: Be not disheart'nd then, nor cloud those looks
3742: That wont to be more chearful and serene
3743: Then when fair Morning first smiles on the World,
3744: And let us to our fresh imployments rise
3745: Among the Groves, the Fountains, and the Flours
3746: That open now thir choicest bosom'd smells
3747: Reservd from night, and kept for thee in store.
3748: ¶So cheard he his fair Spouse, and she was cheard,
3749: But silently a gentle tear let fall
3750: From either eye, and wip'd them with her haire;
3751: Two other precious drops that ready stood,
3752: Each in thir chrystal sluce, hee ere they fell
3753: Kiss'd as the gracious signs of sweet remorse
3754: And pious awe, that feard to have offended.
3755: ¶So all was cleard, and to the Field they haste.
3756: But first from under shadie arborous roof,
3757: Soon as they forth were come to open sight
3758: Of day-spring, and the Sun, who scarce up risen
3759: With wheels yet hov'ring o're the Ocean brim,
3760: Shot paralel to the earth his dewie ray,
3761: Discovering in wide Lantskip all the East
3763: Lowly they bow'd adoring, and began
3764: Thir Orisons, each Morning duly paid
3765: In various style, for neither various style
3766: Nor holy rapture wanted they to praise
3767: Thir Maker, in fit strains pronounc't or sung
3769: Flowd from thir lips, in Prose or numerous Verse,
3770: More tuneable then needed Lute or Harp
3771: To add more sweetness, and they thus began.
3772: ¶These are thy glorious works, Parent of good,
3774: Thus wondrous fair; thy self how wondrous then!
3775: Unspeakable, who sitst above these Heavens
3776: To us invisible or dimly seen
3777: In these thy lowest works, yet these declare
3778: Thy goodness beyond thought, and Power Divine:
3779: Speak yee who best can tell, ye Sons of light,
3780: Angels, for yee behold him, and with songs
3781: And choral symphonies, Day without Night,
3782: Circle his Throne rejoycing, yee in Heav'n,
3783: On Earth joyn all yee Creatures to extoll
3784: Him first, him last, him midst, and without end.
3785: Fairest of Starrs, last in the train of Night,
3786: If better thou belong not to the dawn,
3787: Sure pledge of day, that crownst the smiling Morn
3788: With thy bright Circlet, praise him in thy Spheare
3789: While day arises, that sweet hour of Prime.
3790: Thou Sun, of this great World both Eye and Soule,
3791: Acknowledge him thy Greater, sound his praise
3792: In thy eternal course, both when thou climb'st,
3793: And when high Noon hast gaind, & when thou fallst.
3794: Moon, that now meetst the orient Sun, now fli'st
3795: With the fixt Starrs, fixt in thir Orb that flies,
3796: And yee five other wandring Fires that move
3797: In mystic Dance not without Song, resound
3798: His praise, who out of Darkness call'd up Light.
3799: Aire, and ye Elements the eldest birth
3800: Of Natures Womb, that in quaternion run
3802: And nourish all things, let your ceasless change
3803: Varie to our great Maker still new praise.
3804: Ye Mists and Exhalations that now rise
3805: From Hill or steaming Lake, duskie or grey,
3806: Till the Sun paint your fleecie skirts with Gold,
3807: In honour to the Worlds great Author rise,
3808: Whether to deck with Clouds the uncolourd skie,
3809: Or wet the thirstie Earth with falling showers,
3810: Rising or falling still advance his praise.
3811: His praise ye Winds, that from four Quarters blow,
3812: Breath soft or loud; and wave your tops, ye Pines,
3813: With every Plant, in sign of Worship wave.
3814: Fountains and yee, that warble, as ye flow,
3815: Melodious murmurs, warbling tune his praise.
3816: Joyn voices all ye living Souls, ye Birds,
3817: That singing up to Heaven Gate ascend,
3818: Bear on your wings and in your notes his praise;
3819: Yee that in Waters glide, and yee that walk
3820: The Earth, and stately tread, or lowly creep;
3821: Witness if I be silent, Morn or Eeven,
3822: To Hill, or Valley, Fountain, or fresh shade
3823: Made vocal by my Song, and taught his praise.
3824: Hail universal Lord, be bounteous still
3825: To give us onely good; and if the night
3826: Have gathered aught of evil or conceald,
3827: Disperse it, as now light dispels the dark.
3828: ¶So pray'd they innocent, and to thir thoughts
3829: Firm peace recoverd soon and wonted calm.
3830: On to thir mornings rural work they haste
3831: Among sweet dewes and flours; where any row
3832: Of Fruit-trees overwoodie reachd too farr
3833: Thir pamperd boughes, and needed hands to check
3834: Fruitless imbraces: or they led the Vine
3835: To wed her Elm; she spous'd about him twines
3836: Her mariageable arms, and with her brings
3837: Her dowr th' adopted Clusters, to adorn
3838: His barren leaves.  Them thus imploid beheld
3839: With pittie Heav'ns high King, and to him call'd
3842: His marriage with the seaventimes-wedded Maid.
3843: ¶*Raphael*, said hee, thou hear'st what stir on Earth
3844: *Satan* from Hell scap't through the darksom Gulf
3845: Hath raisd in Paradise, and how disturbd
3846: This night the human pair, how he designes
3847: In them at once to ruin all mankind.
3848: Go therefore, half this day as friend with friend
3849: Converse with *Adam*, in what Bowre or shade
3850: Thou find'st him from the heat of Noon retir'd,
3851: To respit his day-labour with repast,
3852: Or with repose; and such discourse bring on,
3853: As may advise him of his happie state,
3854: Happiness in his power left free to will,
3855: Left to his own free Will, his Will though free,
3856: Yet mutable; whence warne him to beware
3857: He swerve not too secure: tell him withall
3858: His danger, and from whom, what enemie
3859: Late falln himself from Heav'n, is plotting now
3860: The fall of others from like state of bliss;
3861: By violence, no, for that shall be withstood,
3862: But by deceit and lies; this let him know,
3865: ¶So spake th' Eternal Father, and fulfilld
3866: All Justice: nor delaid the winged Saint
3867: After his charge receivd, but from among
3868: Thousand Celestial Ardors, where he stood
3869: Vaild with his gorgeous wings, up springing light
3870: Flew through the midst of Heav'n; th' angelic Quires
3871: On each hand parting, to his speed gave way
3872: Through all th' Empyreal road; till at the Gate
3873: Of Heav'n arriv'd, the gate self-opend wide
3874: On golden Hinges turning, as by work
3875: Divine the sov'ran Architect had fram'd.
3876: From hence, no cloud, or, to obstruct his sight,
3877: Starr interpos'd, however small he sees,
3878: Not unconform to other shining Globes,
3879: Earth and the Gard'n of God, with Cedars crownd
3880: Above all Hills.  As when by night the Glass
3882: Imagind Lands and Regions in the Moon:
3885: A cloudy spot.  Down thither prone in flight
3886: He speeds, and through the vast Ethereal Skie
3887: Sailes between worlds & worlds, with steddie wing
3888: Now on the polar windes, then with quick Fann
3889: Winnows the buxom Air; till within soare
3890: Of Towring Eagles, to all the Fowles he seems
3891: A *Phoenix*, gaz'd by all, as that sole Bird
3892: When to enshrine his reliques in the Sun's
3893: Bright Temple, to *Aegyptian Theb's* he flies.
3894: At once on th' Eastern cliff of Paradise
3895: He lights, and to his proper shape returns
3896: A Seraph wingd; six wings he wore, to shade
3897: His lineaments Divine; the pair that clad
3898: Each shoulder broad, came mantling o're his brest
3899: With regal Ornament; the middle pair
3900: Girt like a Starrie Zone his waste, and round
3901: Skirted his loines and thighes with downie Gold
3902: And colours dipt in Heav'n; the third his feet
3903: Shaddowd from either heele with featherd maile
3904: Skie-tinctur'd grain.  Like *Maia's* son he stood,
3905: And shook his Plumes, that Heav'nly fragrance filld
3906: The circuit wide.  Strait knew him all the bands
3907: Of Angels under watch; and to his state,
3908: And to his message high in honour rise;
3909: For on som message high they guessd him bound.
3910: Thir glittering Tents he passd, and now is come
3911: Into the blissful field, through Groves of Myrrhe,
3912: And flouring Odours, Cassia, Nard, and Balme;
3913: A Wilderness of sweets; for Nature here
3914: Wantond as in her prime, and plaid at will
3915: Her Virgin Fancies, pouring forth more sweet,
3916: Wilde above rule or art; enormous bliss.
3917: Him through the spicie Forrest onward com
3918: *Adam* discernd, as in the dore he sat
3919: Of his coole Bowre, while now the mounted Sun
3920: Shot down direct his fervid Raies, to warme
3921: Earths inmost womb, more warmth then *Adam* need;
3922: And *Eve* within, due at her hour prepar'd
3923: For dinner savourie fruits, of taste to please
3924: True appetite, and not disrelish thirst
3925: Of nectarous draughts between, from milkie stream,
3926: Berrie or Grape: to whom thus *Adam* call'd.
3927: ¶Haste hither *Eve*, and worth thy sight behold
3928: Eastward among those Trees, what glorious shape
3929: Comes this way moving; seems another Morn
3930: Ris'n on mid-noon; som great behest from Heav'n
3931: To us perhaps he brings, and will voutsafe
3932: This day to be our Guest.  But goe with speed,
3933: And what thy stores contain, bring forth and poure
3934: Abundance, fit to honour and receive
3935: Our Heav'nly stranger; well we may afford
3936: Our givers thir own gifts, and large bestow
3937: From large bestowd, where Nature multiplies
3938: Her fertil growth, and by disburd'ning grows
3939: More fruitful, which instructs us not to spare.
3941: Of God inspir'd, small store will serve, where store,
3942: All seasons, ripe for use hangs on the stalk;
3943: Save what by frugal storing firmness gains
3944: To nourish, and superfluous moist consumes:
3945: But I will haste and from each bough and break,
3946: Each Plant & juciest Gourd will pluck such choice
3947: To entertain our Angel guest, as hee
3948: Beholding shall confess that here on Earth
3949: God hath dispenst his bounties as in Heav'n.
3950: ¶So saying, with dispatchful looks in haste
3951: She turns, on hospitable thoughts intent
3952: What choice to chuse for delicacie best,
3953: What order, so contriv'd as not to mix
3954: Tastes, not well joynd, inelegant, but bring
3955: Taste after taste upheld with kindliest change,
3956: Bestirs her then, and from each tender stalk
3958: In *India* East or West, or middle shoare
3959: In *Pontus* or the *Punic* Coast, or where
3960: *Alcinous* reign'd, fruit of all kindes, in coate,
3961: Rough, or smooth rin'd, or bearded husk, or shell
3962: She gathers, Tribute large, and on the board
3963: Heaps with unsparing hand; for drink the Grape
3964: She crushes, inoffensive moust, and meathes
3965: From many a berrie, and from sweet kernels prest
3966: She tempers dulcet creams, nor these to hold
3967: Wants her fit vessels pure, then strews the ground
3968: With Rose and Odours from the shrub unfum'd.
3969: Mean while our Primitive great Sire, to meet
3970: His god-like Guest, walks forth, without more train
3971: Accompani'd then with his own compleat
3972: Perfections, in himself was all his state,
3973: More solemn then the tedious pomp that waits
3974: On Princes, when thir rich Retinue long
3975: Of Horses led, and Grooms besmeard with Gold
3976: Dazles the croud, and sets them all agape.
3977: Neerer his presence *Adam* though not awd,
3978: Yet with submiss approach and reverence meek,
3979: As to a superior Nature, bowing low,
3980: ¶Thus said.  Native of Heav'n, for other place
3981: None can then Heav'n such glorious shape contain;
3982: Since by descending from the Thrones above,
3983: Those happie places thou hast deignd a while
3984: To want, and honour these, voutsafe with us
3985: Two onely, who yet by sov'ran gift possess
3986: This spacious ground, in yonder shadie Bowre
3987: To rest, and what the Garden choicest bears
3988: To sit and taste, till this meridian heat
3989: Be over, and the Sun more coole decline.
3990: ¶Whom thus the Angelic Vertue answerd milde.
3991: *Adam*, I therefore came, nor art thou such
3992: Created, or such place hast here to dwell,
3993: As may not oft invite, though Spirits of Heav'n
3994: To visit thee; lead on then where thy Bowre
3995: Oreshades; for these mid-hours, till Eevning rise
3996: I have at will.  So to the Silvan Lodge
3997: They came, that like *Pomona's* Arbour smil'd
3998: With flourets deck't and fragrant smells; but *Eve*
3999: Undeckt, save with her self more lovely fair
4000: Then Wood-Nymph, or the fairest Goddess feign'd
4001: Of three that in Mount *Ida* naked strove,
4002: Stood to entertain her guest from Heav'n; no vaile
4003: Shee needed, Vertue-proof, no thought infirme
4004: Alterd her cheek.  On whom the Angel *Haile*
4007: ¶Haile Mother of Mankind, whose fruitful Womb
4008: Shall fill the World more numerous with thy Sons
4009: Then with these various fruits the Trees of God
4010: Have heap'd this Table.  Rais'd of grassie terf
4011: Thir Table was, and mossie seats had round,
4012: And on her ample Square from side to side
4014: Danc'd hand in hand.  A while discourse they hold;
4015: No fear lest Dinner coole; when thus began
4016: Our Authour.  Heav'nly stranger, please to taste
4017: These bounties which our Nourisher, from whom
4018: All perfet good unmeasur'd out, descends,
4019: To us for food and for delight hath caus'd
4020: The Earth to yeild; unsavourie food perhaps
4021: To spiritual Natures; only this I know,
4022: That one Celestial Father gives to all.
4023: ¶To whom the Angel.  Therefore what he gives
4024: (Whose praise be ever sung) to man in part
4025: Spiritual, may of purest Spirits be found
4026: No ingrateful food: and food alike those pure
4028: As doth your Rational; and both contain
4030: Of sense, whereby they hear, see, smell, touch, taste,
4033: For know, whatever was created, needs
4034: To be sustaind and fed; of Elements
4035: The grosser feeds the purer, earth the sea,
4036: Earth and the Sea feed Air, the Air those Fires
4037: Ethereal, and as lowest first the Moon;
4038: Whence in her visage round those spots, unpurg'd
4039: Vapours not yet into her substance turnd.
4040: Nor doth the Moon no nourishment exhale
4041: From her moist Continent to higher Orbes.
4042: The Sun that light imparts to all, receives
4044: In humid exhalations, and at Even
4045: Sups with the Ocean: though in Heav'n the Trees
4046: Of life ambrosial frutage bear, and vines
4047: Yeild Nectar, though from off the boughs each Morn
4048: We brush mellifluous Dewes, and find the ground
4049: Cover'd with pearly grain: yet God hath here
4050: Varied his bounty so with new delights,
4051: As may compare with Heaven; and to taste
4052: Think not I shall be nice.  So down they sat,
4053: And to thir viands fell, nor seemingly
4054: The Angel, nor in mist, the common gloss
4055: Of Theologians, but with keen dispatch
4056: Of real hunger, and concoctive heate
4058: Through Spirits with ease; nor wonder; if by fire
4059: Of sooty coal the Empiric Alchimist
4060: Can turn, or holds it possible to turn
4061: Metals of drossiest Ore to perfet Gold
4062: As from the Mine.  Mean while at Table *Eve*
4063: Ministerd naked, and thir flowing cups
4064: With pleasant liquors crown'd: O innocence
4066: Then had the Sons of God excuse to have bin
4067: Enamour'd at that sight; but in those hearts
4069: Was understood, the injur'd Lovers Hell.
4070: ¶Thus when with meats & drinks they had suffic'd,
4071: Not burd'nd Nature, sudden mind arose
4072: In *Adam*, not to let th' occasion pass
4073: Given him by this great Conference to know
4074: Of things above his World, and of thir being
4075: Who dwell in Heav'n, whose excellence he saw
4076: Transcend his own so farr, whose radiant forms
4077: Divine effulgence, whose high Power so far
4078: Exceeded human, and his wary speech
4079: Thus to th' Empyreal Minister he fram'd.
4080: ¶Inhabitant with God, now know I well
4081: Thy favour, in this honour done to man,
4082: Under whose lowly roof thou hast voutsaf't
4083: To enter, and these earthly fruits to taste,
4084: Food not of Angels, yet accepted so,
4085: As that more willingly thou couldst not seem
4086: At Heav'ns high feasts to have fed: yet what compare?
4088: O *Adam*, one Almightie is, from whom
4089: All things proceed, and up to him return,
4090: If not deprav'd from good, created all
4091: Such to perfection, one first matter all,
4092: Indu'd with various forms, various degrees
4093: Of substance, and in things that live, of life;
4094: But more refin'd, more spiritous, and pure,
4095: As neerer to him plac't or neerer tending
4096: Each in thir several active Sphears assignd,
4097: Till body up to spirit work, in bounds
4098: Proportiond to each kind.  So from the root
4099: Springs lighter the green stalk, from thence the leaves
4100: More aerie, last the bright consummate floure
4101: Spirits odorous breathes: flours and thir fruit
4102: Mans nourishment, by gradual scale sublim'd
4103: To vital Spirits aspire, to animal,
4104: To intellectual, give both life and sense,
4105: Fansie and understanding, whence the soule
4106: Reason receives, and reason is her being,
4108: Is oftest yours, the latter most is ours,
4109: Differing but in degree, of kind the same.
4110: Wonder not then, what God for you saw good
4111: If I refuse not, but convert, as you,
4112: To proper substance; time may come when men
4113: With Angels may participate, and find
4114: No inconvenient Diet, nor too light Fare:
4115: And from these corporal nutriments perhaps
4116: Your bodies may at last turn all to Spirit
4117: Improv'd by tract of time, and wingd ascend
4118: Ethereal, as wee, or may at choice
4119: Here or in Heav'nly Paradises dwell;
4120: If ye be found obedient, and retain
4122: Whose progenie you are.  Mean while enjoy
4123: Your fill what happiness this happie state
4125: ¶To whom the Patriarch of mankind repli'd.
4127: Well hast thou taught the way that might direct
4128: Our knowledge, and the scale of Nature set
4131: By steps we may ascend to God.  But say,
4132: What meant that caution joind, *If ye be found
4133: obedient?* can wee want obedience then
4134: To him, or possibly his love desert
4135: Who formd us from the dust, and plac'd us here
4136: Full to the utmost measure of what bliss
4137: Human desires can seek or apprehend?
4138: ¶To whom the Angel.  Son of Heav'n and Earth,
4139: Attend: That thou art happie, owe to God;
4140: That thou continu'st such, owe to thy self,
4141: That is, to thy obedience; therein stand.
4142: This was that caution giv'n thee; be advis'd.
4143: God made thee perfet, not immutable;
4144: And good he made thee, but to persevere
4145: He left it in thy power, ordaind thy will
4146: By nature free, not over-rul'd by Fate
4149: Not our necessitated, such with him
4150: Findes no acceptance, nor can find, for how
4151: Can hearts, not free, be tri'd whether they serve
4152: Willing or no, who will but what they must
4153: By Destinie, and can no other choose?
4154: My self and all th' Angelic Host that stand
4155: In sight of God enthron'd, our happie state
4156: Hold, as you yours, while our obedience holds;
4157: On other surety none; freely we serve.
4158: Because wee freely love, as in our will
4159: To love or not; in this we stand or fall:
4160: And som are fall'n, to disobedience fall'n,
4161: And so from Heav'n to deepest Hell; O fall
4162: From what high state of bliss into what woe!
4163: ¶To whom our great Progenitor.  Thy words
4164: Attentive, and with more delighted eare
4165: Divine instructer, I have heard, then when
4166: Cherubic Songs by night from neighbouring Hills
4167: Aereal Music send: nor knew I not
4168: To be both will and deed created free;
4169: Yet that we never shall forget to love
4170: Our maker, and obey him whose command
4171: Single, is yet so just, my constant thoughts
4172: Assur'd me and still assure: though what thou tellst
4173: Hath past in Heav'n, som doubt within me move,
4174: But more desire to hear, if thou consent,
4175: The full relation, which must needs be strange,
4176: Worthy of Sacred silence to be heard;
4177: And we have yet large day, for scarce the Sun
4178: Hath finisht half his journey, and scarce begins
4179: His other half in the great Zone of Heav'n.
4181: After short pause assenting, thus began.
4182: ¶High matter thou injoinst me, O prime of men,
4183: Sad task and hard, for how shall I relate
4184: To human sense th' invisible exploits
4185: Of warring Spirits; how without remorse
4186: The ruin of so many glorious once
4187: And perfet while they stood; how last unfould
4188: The secrets of another world, perhaps
4189: Not lawful to reveal? yet for thy good
4190: This is dispenc't, and what surmounts the reach
4191: Of human sense, I shall delineate so,
4192: By lik'ning spiritual to corporal forms,
4193: As may express them best, though what if Earth
4194: Be but the shaddow of Heav'n, and things therein
4195: Each to other like, more then on earth is thought?
4196: ¶As yet this world was not, and *Chaos* wilde
4197: Reignd where these Heav'ns now rowl, where Earth now rests
4198: Upon her Center pois'd, when on a day
4200: To motion, measures all things durable
4201: By present, past, and future) on such day
4202: As Heav'ns great Year brings forth, th' Empyreal Host
4203: Of Angels by Imperial summons call'd,
4205: Forthwith from all the ends of Heav'n appeerd
4206: Under thir Hierarchs in orders bright
4207: Ten thousand thousand Ensignes high advanc'd,
4208: Standards, and Gonfalons twixt Van and Reare
4209: Streame in the Aire, and for distinction serve
4210: Of Hierarchies, of Orders, and Degrees;
4211: Or in thir glittering Tissues bear imblaz'd
4212: Holy Memorials, acts of Zeale and Love
4213: Recorded eminent.  Thus when in Orbes
4215: Orb within Orb, the Father infinite,
4216: By whom in bliss imbosom'd sat the Son,
4217: Amidst as from a flaming Mount, whoseop
4218: Brightness had made invisible, thus spake.
4219: ¶Hear all ye Angels, Progenie of Light,
4221: Hear my Decree, which unrevok't shall stand.
4222: This day I have begot whom I declare
4223: My onely Son, and on this holy Hill
4224: Him have anointed, whom ye now behold
4225: At my right hand; your Head I him appoint;
4226: And by my Self have sworn to him shall bow
4227: All knees in Heav'n, and shall confess him Lord:
4228: Under his great Vice-gerent Reign abide
4230: For ever happie: him who disobeyes
4231: Mee disobeyes, breaks union, and that day
4232: Cast out from God and blessed vision, falls
4233: Into utter darkness, deep ingulft, his place
4235: ¶So spake th' Omnipotent, and with his words
4236: All seemd well pleas'd, all seem'd, but were not all.
4237: That day, as other solem dayes, they spent
4238: In song and dance about the sacred Hill,
4239: Mystical dance, which yonder starrie Spheare
4240: Of Planets and of fixt in all her Wheeles
4243: Then most, when most irregular they seem:
4244: And in thir motions harmonie Divine
4245: So smooths her charming tones, that Gods own ear
4247: (For we have also our Eevning and our Morn,
4248: We ours for change delectable, not need)
4249: Forthwith from dance to sweet repast they turn
4250: Desirous, all in Circles as they stood,
4251: Tables are set, and on a sudden pil'd
4252: With Angels Food, and rubied Nectar flows:
4253: In Pearl, in Diamond, and massie Gold,
4254: Fruit of delicious Vines, the growth of Heav'n.
4255: They eat, they drink, and with refection sweet
4256: Are fill'd, before th' all bounteous King, who showrd
4257: With copious hand, rejoycing in thir joy.
4258: Now when ambrosial Night with Clouds exhal'd
4259: From that high mount of God, whence light & shade
4260: Spring both, the face of brightest Heav'n had changd
4261: To grateful Twilight (for Night comes not there
4262: In darker veile) and roseat Dews dispos'd
4263: All but the unsleeping eyes of God to rest,
4264: Wide over all the Plain, and wider farr
4265: Then all this globous Earth in Plain outspred,
4266: (Such are the Courts of God) Th' Angelic throng
4267: Disperst in Bands and Files thir Camp extend
4268: By living Streams among the Trees of Life,
4271: Fannd with coole Winds, save those who in thir course
4272: Melodious Hymns about the sovran Throne
4273: Alternate all night long: but not so wak'd
4274: *Satan*, so call him now, his former name
4275: Is heard no more Heav'n; he of the first,
4276: If not the first Arch-Angel, great in Power,
4277: In favour and praeeminence, yet fraught
4278: With envie against the Son of God, that day
4279: Honourd by his great Father, and proclaimd
4281: Through pride that sight, and thought himself impaird.
4283: Soon as midnight brought on the duskie houre
4284: Friendliest to sleep and silence, he resolv'd
4285: With all his Legions to dislodge, and leave
4288: Awak'ning, thus to him in secret spake.
4289: ¶Sleepst thou Companion dear, what sleep can close
4290: Thy eye-lids? and remembrest what Decree
4291: Of yesterday, so late hath past the lips
4292: Of Heav'ns Almightie.  Thou to me thy thoughts
4293: Wast wont, I mine to thee was wont to impart;
4294: Both waking we were one; how then can now
4295: Thy sleep dissent? new Laws thou seest impos'd;
4296: New Laws from him who reigns, new minds may raise
4297: In us who serve, new Counsels, to debate
4298: What doubtful may ensue, more in this place
4299: To utter is not safe.  Assemble thou
4300: Of all those Myriads which we lead the chief;
4301: Tell them that by command, ere yet dim Night
4302: Her shadowie Cloud withdraws, I am to haste,
4303: And all who under me thir Banners wave,
4304: Homeward with flying march where we possess
4305: The Quarters of the North, there to prepare
4306: Fit entertainment to receive our King
4307: The great *Messiah*, and his new commands,
4308: Who speedily through all the Hierarchies
4309: Intends to pass triumphant, and give Laws.
4310: ¶So spake the false Arch-Angel, and infus'd
4311: Bad influence into th' unwarie brest
4312: Of his Associate; hee together calls,
4313: Or several one by one, the Regent Powers,
4314: Under him Regent, tells, as he was taught,
4315: That the most High commanding, now ere Night,
4316: Now ere dim Night had disincumberd Heav'n,
4317: The great Hierarchal Standard was to move;
4318: Tells the suggested cause, and casts between
4319: Ambiguous words and jealousies, to sound
4320: Or taint integritie; but all obey'd
4321: The wonted signal, and superior voice
4322: Of thir great Potentate; for great indeed
4323: His name, and high was his degree in Heav'n;
4324: His count'nance, as the Morning Starr that guides
4325: The starrie flock, allur'd them, and with lyes
4326: Drew after him the third part of Heav'ns Host:
4327: Mean while th' Eternal eye, whose sight discernes
4328: Abstrusest thoughts, from forth his holy Mount
4329: And from within the golden Lamps that burne
4330: Nightly before him, saw without thir light
4331: Rebellion rising, saw in whom, how spred
4332: Among the sons of Morn, what multitudes
4333: Were banded to oppose his high Decree;
4334: And smiling to his onely Son thus said.
4335: ¶Son, thou in whom my glory I behold
4336: In full resplendence, Heir of all my might,
4337: Neerly it now concernes us to be sure
4338: Of our Omnipotence, and with what Arms
4339: We mean to hold what anciently we claim
4340: Of Deitie or Empire, such a foe
4341: Is rising, who intends to erect his Throne
4342: Equal to ours, throughout the spacious North;
4343: Nor so content, hath in his thought to trie
4344: In battel, what our Power is, or our right.
4345: Let us advise, and to this hazard draw
4346: With speed what force is left, and all imploy
4347: In our defence, lest unawares we lose
4348: This our high place, our Sanctuarie, our Hill.
4349: ¶To whom the Son with calm aspect and cleer
4351: Made answer.  Mightie Father, thou thy foes
4352: Justly hast in derision, and secure
4353: Laugh'st at thir vain designes and tumults vain,
4354: Matter to mee of Glory, whom thir hate
4355: Illustrates, when they see all Regal Power
4356: Giv'n me to quell thir pride, and in event
4357: Know whether I be dextrous to subdue
4358: Thy Rebels, or be found the worst in Heav'n.
4359: ¶So spake the Son, but *Satan* with his Powers
4360: Farr was advanc't on winged speed, an Host
4361: Innumerable as the Starrs of Night,
4362: Or Starrs of Morning, Dew-drops, which the Sun
4363: Impearls on every leaf and every flouer.
4364: Regions they pass'd, the mightie Regencies
4365: Of Seraphim and Potentates and Thrones
4366: In thir triple Degrees, Regions to which
4367: All thy Dominion, *Adam*, is no more
4368: Then what this Garden is to all the Earth,
4369: And all the Sea, from one entire globose
4370: Stretcht into Longitude; which having pass'd
4371: At length into the limits of the North
4372: They came, and *Satan* to his Royal seat
4373: High on a Hill, far blazing, as a Mount
4374: Rais'd on a Mount, with Pyramids and Towrs
4375: From Diamond Quarries hew'n, & Rocks of Gold,
4377: That Structure in the Dialect of men
4378: Interpreted) which not long after, hee
4380: In imitation of that Mount whereon
4381: *Messiah* was declar'd in sight of Heav'n,
4382: The Mountain of the Congregation call'd;
4383: For thither he assembl'd all his Train,
4385: About the great reception of thir King,
4386: Thither to come, and with calumnious Art
4387: Of counterfeted truth thus held thir ears.
4389: If these magnific Titles yet remain
4390: Not meerly titular, since by Decree
4391: Another now hath to himself ingross't
4392: All Power, and us eclipst under the name
4393: Of King anointed, for whom all this haste
4394: Of midnight march, and hurried meeting here,
4395: This onely to consult how we may best
4396: With what may be devis'd of honours new
4397: Receive him coming to receive from us
4399: Too much to one, but double how endur'd,
4400: To one and to his image now proclaim'd?
4401: But what if better counsels might erect
4402: Our minds and teach us to cast off this Yoke?
4403: Will ye submit your necks, and chuse to bend
4404: The supple knee? ye will not, if I trust
4405: To know ye right, or if ye know your selves
4406: Natives and Sons of Heav'n possest before
4407: By none, and if not equal all, yet free,
4408: Equally free; for Orders and Degrees
4409: Jarr not with liberty, but well consist.
4410: Who can in reason then or right assume
4411: Monarchie over such as live by right
4412: His equals, if in power and splendor less,
4413: In freedome equal? or can introduce
4414: Law and Edict on us, who without law
4415: Erre not, much less for this to be our Lord,
4416: And look for adoration to th' abuse
4417: Of those Imperial Titles which assert
4418: Our being ordain'd to govern, not to serve?
4419: ¶Thus farr his bold discourse without controule
4420: Had audience, when among the Seraphim
4421: *Abdiel*, then whom none with more zeale ador'd
4422: The Deitie, and divine commands obei'd,
4423: Stood up, and in a flame of zeale severe
4424: The current of his fury thus oppos'd.
4426: Words which no eare ever to hear in Heav'n
4427: Expected, least of all from thee, ingrate
4428: In place thy self so high above thy Peeres.
4429: Canst thou with impious obloquie condemne
4430: The just Decree of God, pronounc't and sworn,
4431: That to his only Son by right endu'd
4432: With Regal Scepter, every Soule in Heav'n
4433: Shall bend the knee, and in that honour due
4434: Confess him rightful King? unjust thou saist
4435: Flatly unjust, to binde with Laws the free,
4436: And equal over equals to let Reigne,
4437: One over all with unsucceeded power.
4438: Shalt thou give Law to God, shalt thou dispute
4439: With him the points of libertie, who made
4440: Thee what thou art, & formd the Pow'rs of Heav'n
4441: Such as he pleasd, and circumscrib'd thir being?
4442: Yet by experience taught we know how good,
4443: And of our good, and of our dignitie
4444: How provident he is, how farr from thought
4445: To make us less, bent rather to exalt
4446: Our happie state under one Head more neer
4447: United.  But to grant it thee unjust,
4448: That equal over equals Monarch Reigne:
4449: Thy self though great & glorious dost thou count,
4450: Or all Angelic Nature joind in one,
4451: Equal to him begotten Son, by whom
4452: As by his Word the mighty Father made
4453: All things, ev'n thee, and all the Spirits of Heav'n
4454: By him created in thir bright degrees,
4455: Crownd them with Glory, & to thir Glory nam'd
4457: Essential Powers, nor by his Reign obscur'd,
4458: But more illustrious made, since he the Head
4459: One of our number thus reduc't becomes,
4460: His Laws our Laws, all honour to him done
4461: Returns our own.  Cease then this impious rage,
4462: And tempt not these; but hast'n to appease
4463: Th' incensed Father, and th' incensed Son,
4464: While Pardon may be found in time besought.
4465: ¶So spake the fervent Angel, but his zeale
4466: None seconded, as out of season judg'd,
4467: Or singular and rash, whereat rejoic'd
4468: Th' Apostat, and more haughty thus repli'd.
4469: That we were formd then saist thou? & the work
4470: Of secondarie hands, by task transferd
4471: From Father to his Son? strange point and new!
4472: Doctrin which we would know whence learnt: who saw
4473: When this creation was? rememberst thou
4474: Thy making, while the Maker gave thee being?
4475: We know no time when we were not as now;
4476: Know none before us, self-begot, self-rais'd
4477: By our own quick'ning power, when fatal course
4478: Had circl'd his full Orbe, the birth mature
4479: Of this our native Heav'n, Ethereal Sons.
4480: Our puissance is our own, our own right hand
4481: Shall teach us highest deeds, by proof to try
4482: Who is our equal: then thou shalt behold
4484: Address, and to begirt th' Almighty Throne
4486: These tidings carrie to th' anointed King;
4487: And fly, ere evil intercept thy flight.
4488: ¶He said, and as the sound of waters deep
4489: Hoarce murmur echo'd to his words applause
4490: Through the infinite Host, nor less for that
4491: The flaming Seraph fearless, though alone
4492: Encompass'd round with foes, thus answerd bold.
4493: ¶O alienate from God, O spirit accurst,
4494: Forsak'n of all good; I see thy fall
4495: Determind, and thy hapless crew involv'd
4496: In this perfidious fraud, contagion spred
4497: Both of thy crime and punishment: henceforth
4498: No more be troubl'd how to quit the yoke
4500: Will not be now voutsaf't, other Decrees
4501: Against thee are gon forth without recall;
4502: That Golden Scepter which thou didst reject
4503: Is now an Iron Rod to bruise and breake
4504: Thy disobedience.  Well thou didst advise,
4505: Yet not for thy advise or threats I fly
4506: These wicked Tents devoted, least the wrauth
4508: Distinguish not: for soon expect to feel
4509: His Thunder on thy head, devouring fire.
4510: Then who created thee lamenting learne,
4511: When who can uncreate thee thou shalt know.
4513: Among the faithless, faithful only hee;
4516: His Loyaltie he kept, his Love, his Zeale;
4517: Nor number, nor example with him wrought
4518: To swerve from truth, or change his constant mind
4519: Though single.  From amidst them forth he passd,
4520: Long way through hostile scorn, which he susteind
4521: Superior, nor of violence fear'd aught;
4522: And with retorted scorn his back he turn'd
4523: On those proud Towrs to swift destruction doom'd.
4527: Through Heav'ns wide Champain held his way, till Morn,
4528: Wak't by the circling Hours, with rosie hand
4529: Unbarr'd the gates of Light.  There is a Cave
4530: Within the Mount of God, fast by his Throne,
4531: Where light and darkness in perpetual round
4532: Lodge and dislodge by turns, which makes through Heav'n
4533: Grateful vicissitude, like Day and Night;
4534: Light issues forth, and at the other dore
4535: Obsequious darkness enters, till her houre
4536: To veile the Heav'n, though darkness there might well
4537: Seem twilight here; and now went forth the Morn
4538: Such as in highest Heav'n, arrayd in Gold
4539: Empyreal, from before her vanisht Night,
4540: Shot through with orient Beams: when all the Plain
4541: Coverd with thick embatteld Squadrons bright,
4542: Chariots and flaming Armes, and fierie Steeds
4543: Reflecting blaze on blaze, first met his view:
4544: Warr he perceav'd, warr in procinct, and found
4545: Already known what he for news had thought
4546: To have reported: gladly then he mixt
4547: Among those friendly Powers who him receav'd
4548: With joy and acclamations loud, that one
4549: That of so many Myriads fall'n, yet one
4550: Returnd not lost: On to the sacred hill
4551: They led him high applauded, and present
4552: Before the seat supream; from whence a voice
4553: From midst a Golden Cloud thus milde was heard.
4554: ¶Servant of God, well done, well hast thou fought
4555: The better fight, who single hast maintaind
4557: Of Truth, in word mightier then they in Armes;
4558: And for the testimonie of Truth hast born
4559: Universal reproach, far worse to beare
4560: Then violence: for this was all thy care
4561: To stand approv'd in sight of God, though Worlds
4562: Judg'd thee perverse: the easier conquest now
4563: Remains thee, aided by this host of friends,
4564: Back on thy foes more glorious to return
4565: Then scornd thou didst depart, and to subdue
4566: By force, who reason for thir Law refuse,
4567: Right reason for thir Law, and for thir King
4568: *Messiah*, who by right of merit Reigns.
4570: And thou in Military prowess next
4571: *Gabriel*, lead forth to Battel these my Sons
4572: Invincible, lead forth my armed Saints
4573: By Thousands and by Millions rang'd for fight;
4574: Equal in number to that Godless crew
4575: Rebellious, them with Fire and hostile Arms
4576: Fearless assault, and to the brow of Heav'n
4577: Pursuing drive them out from God and bliss,
4578: Into thir place of punishment, the Gulf
4580: His fiery *Chaos* to receave thir fall.
4581: ¶So spake the Sovran voice, and Clouds began
4582: To darken all the Hill, and smoak to rowl
4583: In duskie wreathes, reluctant flames, the signe
4584: Of wrauth awak't: nor with less dread the loud
4585: Ethereal Trumpet from on high gan blow:
4586: At which command the Powers Militant,
4587: That stood for Heav'n, in mighty Quadrate joyn'd
4589: In silence thir bright Legions, to the sound
4592: Under thir God-like Leaders, in the Cause
4593: Of God and his *Messiah*.  On they move
4595: Nor streit'ning Vale, nor Wood, nor Stream divides
4596: Thir perfet ranks; for high above the ground
4597: Thir march was, and the passive Air upbore
4598: Thir nimble tread; as when the total kind
4599: Of Birds in orderly array on wing
4601: Thir names of thee; so over many a tract
4602: Of Heav'n they march'd, and many a Province wide
4603: Tenfold the length of this terrene: at last
4604: Farr in th' Horizon to the North appeer'd
4605: From skirt to skirt a fierie Region, stretcht
4606: In battailous aspect, and neerer view
4608: Of rigid Spears, and Helmets throng'd, and Shields
4610: The banded Powers of *Satan* hasting on
4611: With furious expedition; for they weend
4612: That self same day by fight, or by surprize
4613: To win the Mount of God, and on his Throne
4614: To set the envier of his State, the proud
4615: Aspirer, but thir thoughts prov'd fond and vain
4616: In the mid way: though strange to us it seemd
4617: At first, that Angel should with Angel warr,
4618: And in fierce hosting meet, who wont to meet
4619: So oft in Festivals of joy and love
4620: Unanimous, as sons of one great Sire
4621: Hymning th' Eternal Father: but the shout
4622: Of Battel now began, and rushing sound
4623: Of onset ended soon each milder thought.
4624: High in the midst exalted as a God
4625: Th' Apostat in his Sun-bright Chariot sate
4627: With Flaming Cherubim, and golden Shields;
4628: Then lighted from his gorgeous Throne, for now
4629: 'Twixt Host and Host but narrow space was left,
4630: A dreadful interval, and Front to Front
4632: Of hideous length: before the cloudie Van,
4633: On the rough edge of battel ere it joyn'd,
4634: *Satan* with vast and haughtie strides advanc't,
4635: Came towring, armd in Adamant and Gold;
4636: *Abdiel* that sight endur'd not, where he stood
4637: Among the mightiest, bent on highest deeds,
4638: And thus his own undaunted heart explores.
4639: ¶O Heav'n! that such resemblance of the Highest
4640: Should yet remain, where faith and realtie
4641: Remain not; wherfore should not strength & might
4642: There fail where Vertue fails, or weakest prove
4643: Where boldest; though to sight unconquerable?
4644: His puissance, trusting in th' Almightie's aide,
4645: I mean to try, whose Reason I have tri'd
4646: Unsound and false; nor is it aught but just,
4647: That he who in debate of Truth hath won,
4648: Should win in Arms, in both disputes alike
4649: Victor; though brutish that contest and foule,
4650: When Reason hath to deal with force, yet so
4651: Most reason is that Reason overcome.
4652: ¶So pondering, and from his armed Peers
4653: Forth stepping opposite, half way he met
4654: His daring foe, at this prevention more
4655: Incens't, and thus securely him defi'd.
4656: ¶Proud, art thou met? thy hope was to have reacht
4657: The highth of thy aspiring unoppos'd,
4658: The Throne of God unguarded, and his side
4659: Abandond at the terror of thy Power
4660: Or potent tongue; fool, not to think how vain
4661: Against th' Omnipotent to rise in Arms;
4662: Who out of smallest things could without end
4663: Have rais'd incessant Armies to defeat
4664: Thy folly; or with solitarie hand
4665: Reaching beyond all limit, at one blow
4666: Unaided could have finisht thee, and whelmd
4667: Thy Legions under darkness; but thou seest
4668: All are not of thy Train; there be who Faith
4669: Prefer, and Pietie to God, though then
4670: To thee not visible, when I alone
4671: Seemd in thy World erroneous to dissent
4672: From all: my Sect thou seest, now learn too late
4673: How few somtimes may know, when thousands err.
4674: ¶Whom the grand foe with scornful eye askance
4675: Thus answerd.  Ill for thee, but in wisht houre
4676: Of my revenge, first sought for thou returnst
4677: From flight, seditious Angel, to receave
4678: Thy merited reward, the first assay
4679: Of this right hand provok't, since first that tongue
4681: A third part of the Gods, in Synod met
4682: Thir Deities to assert, who while they feel
4683: Vigour Divine within them, can allow
4684: Omnipotence to none.  But well thou comst
4685: Before thy fellows, ambitious to win
4686: From me som Plume, that thy success may show
4687: Destruction to the rest: this pause between
4688: (Unanswerd least thou boast) to let thee know;
4689: At first I thought that Libertie and Heav'n
4690: To heav'nly Soules had bin all one; but now
4691: I see that most through sloth had rather serve,
4692: Ministring Spirits, traind up in Feast and Song;
4693: Such hast thou arm'd, the Minstrelsie of Heav'n,
4695: As both thir deeds compar'd this day shall prove.
4696: ¶To whom in brief thus *Abdiel* stern repli'd.
4697: Apostat, still thou errst, nor end wilt find
4698: Of erring, from the path of truth remote:
4699: Unjustly thou deprav'st it with the name
4700: Of *Servitude* to serve whom God ordains,
4701: Or Nature; God and Nature bid the same,
4702: When he who rules is worthiest, and excells
4703: Them whom he governs.  This is servitude,
4704: To serve th' unwise, or him who hath rebelld
4705: Against his worthier, as thine now serve thee,
4706: Thy self not free, but to thy self enthrall'd;
4707: Yet leudly dar'st our ministring upbraid.
4708: Reign thou in Hell thy Kingdom, let mee serve
4709: In Heav'n God ever blessed, and his Divine
4710: Behests obey, worthiest to be obey'd,
4711: Yet Chains in Hell, not Realms expect: mean while
4712: From mee returnd, as erst thou saidst, from flight,
4713: This greeting on thy impious Crest receive.
4714: ¶So saying, a noble stroke he lifted high,
4715: Which hung not, but so swift with tempest fell
4716: On the proud Crest of *Satan*, that no sight,
4717: Nor motion of swift thought, less could his Shield
4718: Such ruin intercept: ten paces huge
4719: He back recoild; the tenth on bended knee
4720: His massie Spear upstaid; as if on Earth
4721: Winds under ground or waters forcing way
4722: Sidelong, had push't a Mountain from his seat
4723: Half sunk with all his Pines.  Amazement seis'd
4724: The Rebel Thrones, but greater rage to see
4725: Thus foil'd thir mightiest, ours joy filld, and shout,
4726: Presage of Victorie and fierce desire
4728: Th' Arch-Angel trumpet; through the vast of Heav'n
4729: It sounded, and the faithful Armies rung
4730: *Hosanna* to the Highest: nor stood at gaze
4731: The adverse Legions, nor less hideous joyn'd
4732: The horrid shock: now storming furie rose,
4733: And clamour such as heard in Heav'n till now
4734: Was never, Arms on Armour clashing bray'd
4735: Horrible discord, and the madding Wheeles
4736: Of brazen Chariots rag'd; dire was the noise
4737: Of conflict; over head the dismal hiss
4738: Of fiery Darts in flaming volies flew,
4739: And flying vaulted either Host with fire.
4741: Both Battels maine, with ruinous assault
4743: Resounded, and had Earth bin then, all Earth
4744: Had to her Center shook.  What wonder? when
4745: Millions of fierce encountring Angels fought
4746: On either side, the least of whom could weild
4747: These Elements, and arm him with the force
4748: Of all thir Regions: how much more of Power
4749: Armie against Armie numberless to raise
4751: Though not destroy, thir happie Native seat;
4752: Had not th' Eternal King Omnipotent
4753: From his strong hold of Heav'n high over-rul'd
4754: And limited thir might; though numberd such
4755: As each divided Legion might have seemd
4756: A numerous Host, in strength each armed hand
4757: A Legion; led in fight, yet Leader seemd
4758: Each Warriour single as in Chief, expert
4759: When to advance, or stand, or turn the sway
4760: Of Battel, open when, and when to close
4761: The ridges of grim Warr; no thought of flight,
4762: None of retreat, no unbecoming deed
4763: That argu'd fear; each on himself reli'd,
4764: As onely in his arm the moment lay
4765: Of victorie; deeds of eternal fame
4766: Were don, but infinite: for wide was spred
4767: That Warr and various; somtimes on firm ground
4768: A standing fight, then soaring on main wing
4769: Tormented all the Air; all Air seemd then
4770: Conflicting Fire: long time in eeven scale
4771: The Battel hung; till *Satan*, who that day
4772: Prodigious power had shewn, and met in Armes
4773: No equal, raunging through the dire attack
4774: Of fighting Seraphim confus'd, at length
4775: Saw where the Sword of *Michael* smote, and fell'd
4776: Squadrons at once, with huge two-handed sway
4777: Brandisht aloft the horrid edge came down
4778: Wide wasting; such destruction to withstand
4779: He hasted, and oppos'd the rockie Orb
4780: Of tenfold Adamant, his ample Shield
4781: A vast circumference: At his approach
4782: The great Arch-Angel from his warlike toile
4783: Surceas'd, and glad as hoping here to end
4784: Intestine War in Heav'n, the arch foe subdu'd
4785: Or Captive drag'd in Chains, with hostile frown
4786: And visage all enflam'd first thus began.
4787: ¶Author of evil, unknown till thy revolt,
4788: Unnam'd in Heav'n, now plenteous, as thou seest
4789: These Acts of hateful strife, hateful to all,
4790: Though heaviest by just measure on thy self
4791: And thy adherents: how hast thou disturb'd
4792: Heav'ns blessed peace, and into Nature brought
4794: Of thy Rebellion? how hast thou instill'd
4795: Thy malice into thousands, once upright
4796: And faithful, now prov'd false.  But think not here
4797: To trouble Holy Rest; Heav'n casts thee out
4798: From all her Confines.  Heav'n the seat of bliss
4799: Brooks not the works of violence and Warr.
4800: Hence then, and evil go with thee along
4801: Thy ofspring, to the place of evil, Hell,
4802: Thou and thy wicked crew; there mingle broiles,
4803: Ere this avenging Sword begin thy doome,
4804: Or som more sudden vengeance wing'd from God
4806: ¶So spake the Prince of Angels; to whom thus
4807: The Adversarie.  Nor think thou with wind
4808: Of airie threats to aw whom yet with deeds
4809: Thou canst not.  Hast thou turnd the least of these
4810: To flight, or if to fall, but that they rise
4811: Unvanquisht, easier to transact with mee
4812: That thou shouldst hope, imperious, & with threats
4813: To chase me hence? erre not that so shall end
4814: The strife which thou call'st evil, but wee style
4815: The strife of Glorie: which we mean to win,
4816: Or turn this Heav'n it self into the Hell
4817: Thou fablest, here however to dwell free,
4818: If not to reign: mean while thy utmost force,
4819: And join him nam'd *Almightie* to thy aid,
4820: I flie not, but have sought thee farr and nigh.
4821: ¶They ended parle, and both addrest for fight
4822: Unspeakable; for who, though with the tongue
4823: Of Angels, can relate, or to what things
4824: Liken on Earth conspicuous, that may lift
4826: Of Godlike Power: for likest Gods they seemd,
4827: Stood they or mov'd, in stature, motion, arms
4828: Fit to decide the Empire of great Heav'n.
4829: Now wav'd thir fierie Swords, and in the Aire
4830: Made horrid Circles; two broad Suns thir Shields
4832: In horror; from each hand with speed retir'd
4833: Where erst was thickest fight, th' Angelic throng,
4834: And left large field, unsafe within the wind
4835: Of such commotion, such as to set forth
4836: Great things by small, If Natures concord broke,
4837: Among the Constellations warr were sprung,
4838: Two Planets rushing from aspect maligne
4839: Of fiercest opposition in mid Skie,
4840: Should combat, and thir jarring Sphears confound.
4841: Together both with next to Almightie Arme,
4842: Uplifted imminent one stroke they aim'd
4843: That might determine, and not need repeate,
4844: As not of power, at once; nor odds appeerd
4845: In might or swift prevention; but the sword
4846: Of *Michael* from the Armorie of God
4847: Was giv'n him temperd so, that neither keen
4848: Nor solid might resist that edge: it met
4849: The sword of *Satan* with steep force to smite
4850: Descending, and in half cut sheere, nor staid,
4851: But with swift wheele reverse, deep entring shar'd
4852: All his right side; then *Satan* first knew pain,
4853: And writh'd him to and fro convolv'd; so sore
4854: The griding sword with discontinuous wound
4855: Pass'd through him, but th' Ethereal substance clos'd
4856: Not long divisible, and from the gash
4857: A stream of Nectarous humor issuing flow'd
4858: Sanguin, such as Celestial Spirits may bleed,
4859: And all his Armour staind ere while so bright.
4860: Forthwith on all sides to his aide was run
4861: By Angels many and strong, who interpos'd
4862: Defence, while others bore him on thir Shields
4863: Back to his Chariot; where it stood retir'd
4864: From off the files of warr; there they him laid
4865: Gnashing for anguish and despite and shame
4866: To find himself not matchless, and his pride
4867: Humbl'd by such rebuke, so farr beneath
4868: His confidence to equal God in power.
4869: Yet soon he heal'd; for Spirits that live throughout
4870: Vital in every part, not as frail man
4871: In Entrailes, Heart or Head, Liver or Reines,
4873: Nor in thir liquid texture mortal wound
4874: Receive, no more then can the fluid Aire:
4875: All Heart they live, all Head, all Eye, all Eare,
4876: All Intellect, all Sense, and as they please,
4877: They Limb themselves, and colour, shape or size
4878: Assume, as likes them best, condense or rare.
4879: ¶Mean while in other parts like deeds deservd
4880: Memorial, where the might of *Gabriel* fought,
4881: And with fierce Ensignes pierc'd the deep array
4882: Of *Moloc* furious King, who him defi'd,
4883: And at his Chariot wheeles to drag him bound
4884: Threatn'd, nor from the Holie One of Heav'n
4885: Refrein'd his tongue blasphemous; but anon
4886: Down clov'n to the waste, with shatterd Armes
4887: And uncouth paine fled bellowing.  On each wing
4889: Though huge, and in a Rock of Diamond Armd,
4891: Two potent Thrones, that to be less then Gods
4892: Disdain'd, but meaner thoughts learnd in thir flight,
4893: Mangl'd with gastly wounds through Plate and Maile.
4895: The Atheist crew, but with redoubl'd blow
4898: I might relate of thousands, and thir names
4899: Eternize here on Earth; but those elect
4900: Angels contented with thir fame in Heav'n
4901: Seek not the praise of men: the other sort
4902: In might though wondrous and in Acts of Warr,
4903: Nor of Renown less eager, yet by doome
4904: Canceld from Heav'n and sacred memorie,
4905: Nameless in dark oblivion let them dwell.
4906: For strength from Truth divided and from Just,
4908: And ignominie, yet to glorie aspires
4909: Vain glorious, and through infamie seeks fame:
4910: Therfore Eternal silence be thir doome.
4911: ¶And now thir mightiest quelld, the battel swerv'd,
4912: With many an inrode gor'd; deformed rout
4913: Enter'd, and foul disorder; all the ground
4914: With shiverd armour strow'n, and on a heap
4916: And fierie foaming Steeds; what stood, recoyld
4917: Orewearied, through the faint Satanic Host
4918: Defensive scarse, or with pale fear surpris'd,
4919: Then first with fear surpris'd and sense of paine
4920: Fled ignominious, to such evil brought
4921: By sinne of disobedience, till that hour
4922: Not liable to fear or flight or paine.
4924: In Cubic Phalanx firm advanc't entire,
4927: Gave them above thir foes, not to have sinnd,
4928: Not to have disobei'd; in fight they stood
4930: By wound, though from thir place by violence mov'd.
4931: ¶Now Night her course began, and over Heav'n
4933: And silence on the odious dinn of Warr:
4934: Under her Cloudie covert both retir'd,
4935: Victor and Vanquisht: on the foughten field
4937: Encamping, plac'd in Guard thir Watches round,
4938: Cherubic waving fires: on th' other part
4940: Far in the dark dislodg'd, and void of rest,
4941: His Potentates to Councel call'd by night;
4942: And in the midst thus undismai'd began.
4943: ¶O now in danger tri'd, now known in Armes
4944: Not to be overpowerd, Companions deare,
4945: Found worthy not of Libertie alone,
4946: Too mean pretense, but what we more affect,
4948: Who have sustaind one day in doubtful fight,
4949: (And if one day, why not Eternal dayes?)
4950: What Heavens Lord had powerfullest to send
4951: Against us from about his Throne, and judg'd
4952: Sufficient to subdue us to his will,
4953: But proves not so: then fallible, it seems,
4954: Of future we may deem him, though till now
4955: Omniscient thought.  True is, less firmly arm'd,
4956: Some disadvantage we endur'd and paine,
4957: Till now not known, but known as soon contemnd,
4958: Since now we find this our Empyreal forme
4960: Imperishable, and though peirc'd with wound,
4961: Soon closing, and by native vigour heal'd.
4962: Of evil then so small as easie think
4963: The remedie; perhaps more valid Armes,
4964: Weapons more violent, when next we meet,
4965: May serve to better us, and worse our foes,
4966: Or equal what between us made the odds,
4967: In Nature none: if other hidden cause
4968: Left them Superiour, while we can preserve
4969: Unhurt our mindes, and understanding sound,
4970: Due search and consultation will disclose.
4971: ¶He sat; and in th' assembly next upstood
4973: As one he stood escap't from cruel fight,
4974: Sore toild, his riv'n Armes to havoc hewn,
4975: And cloudie in aspect thus answering spake.
4976: Deliverer from new Lords, leader to free
4977: Enjoyment of our right as Gods; yet hard
4978: For Gods, and too unequal work we find
4979: Against unequal armes to fight in paine,
4980: Against unpaind, impassive; from which evil
4981: Ruin must needs ensue; for what availes
4982: Valour or strength, though matchless, quelld with pain
4983: Which all subdues, and makes remiss the hands
4984: Of Mightiest.  Sense of pleasure we may well
4985: Spare out of life perhaps, and not repine,
4986: But live content, which is the calmest life:
4987: But pain is perfet miserie, the worst
4989: All patience.  He who therefore can invent
4990: With what more forcible we may offend
4991: Our yet unwounded Enemies, or arme
4992: Our selves with like defence, to mee deserves
4993: No less then for deliverance what we owe.
4995: Not uninvented that, which thou aright
4996: Beleivst so main to our success, I bring;
4997: Which of us who beholds the bright surface
4998: Of this Ethereous mould whereon we stand,
4999: This continent of spacious Heav'n, adornd
5000: With Plant, Fruit, Flour Ambrosial, Gemms & Gold,
5002: These things, as not to mind from whence they grow
5003: Deep under ground, materials dark and crude,
5004: Of spiritous and fierie spume, till toucht
5005: With Heav'ns ray, and temperd they shoot forth
5006: So beauteous, op'ning to the ambient light.
5007: These in thir dark Nativitie the Deep
5008: Shall yeild us, pregnant with infernal flame,
5009: Which into hallow Engins long and round
5010: Thick-rammd, at th' other bore with touch of fire
5011: Dilated and infuriate shall send forth
5012: From far with thundring noise among our foes
5013: Such implements of mischief as shall dash
5014: To pieces, and orewhelm whatever stands
5015: Adverse, that they shall fear we have disarmd
5016: The Thunderer of his only dreaded bolt.
5017: Nor long shall be our labour, yet ere dawne,
5018: Effect shall end our wish.  Mean while revive;
5019: Abandon fear; to strength and counsel joind
5020: Think nothing hard, much less to be despaird.
5021: He ended, and his words thir drooping chere
5022: Enlightn'd, and thir languisht hope reviv'd.
5023: Th' invention all admir'd, and each, how hee
5024: To be th' inventer miss'd, so easie it seemd
5025: Once found, which yet unfound most would have thought
5026: Impossible: yet haply of thy Race
5027: In future dayes, if Malice should abound,
5028: Some one intent on mischief, or inspir'd
5030: Like instrument to plague the Sons of men
5031: For sin, on warr and mutual slaughter bent.
5032: Forthwith from Councel to the work they flew,
5034: Were ready, in a moment up they turnd
5035: Wide the Celestial soile, and saw beneath
5036: Th' originals of Nature in thir crude
5038: They found, they mingl'd, and with suttle Art,
5040: To blackest grain, and into store conveyd:
5041: Part hidd'n veins diggd up (nor hath this Earth
5042: Entrails unlike) of Mineral and Stone,
5043: Whereof to found thir Engins and thir Balls
5044: Of missive ruin; part incentive reed
5045: Provide, pernicious with one touch to fire.
5046: So all ere day spring, under conscious Night
5047: Secret they finish'd, and in order set,
5049: Now when fair Morn Orient in Heav'n appeerd
5050: Up rose the Victor Angels, and to Arms
5051: The matin Trumpet Sung: in Arms they stood
5053: Soon banded; others from the dawning Hills
5054: Lookd round, and Scouts each Coast light-armed scoure,
5055: Each quarter, to descrie the distant foe,
5056: Where lodg'd, or whither fled, or if for fight,
5057: In motion or in alt: him soon they met
5058: Under spred Ensignes moving nigh, in slow
5059: But firm Battalion; back with speediest Sail
5061: Came flying, and in mid Aire aloud thus cri'd.
5062: ¶Arme, Warriours, Arme for fight, the foe at hand,
5063: Whom fled we thought, will save us long pursuit
5064: This day, fear not his flight; so thick a Cloud
5065: He comes, and settl'd in his face I see
5066: Sad resolution and secure: let each
5067: His Adamantine coat gird well, and each
5068: Fit well his Helme, gripe fast his orbed Shield,
5069: Born eevn or high, for this day will pour down,
5070: If I conjecture aught, no drizling showr,
5071: But ratling storm of Arrows barbd with fire.
5072: So warnd he them aware themselves, and soon
5073: In order, quit of all impediment;
5074: Instant without disturb they took Allarm,
5075: And onward move Embattelld; when behold
5076: Not distant far with heavie pace the Foe
5077: Approaching gross and huge; in hollow Cube
5079: On every side with shaddowing Squadrons Deep,
5080: To hide the fraud.  At interview both stood
5081: A while, but suddenly at head appeerd
5082: *Satan*: And thus was heard Commanding loud.
5083: ¶Vangard, to Right and Left the Front unfould;
5084: That all may see who hate us, how we seek
5085: Peace and composure, and with open brest
5086: Stand readie to receive them, if they like
5087: Our overture, and turn not back perverse;
5088: But that I doubt, however witness Heaven,
5089: Heav'n witness thou anon, while we discharge
5090: Freely our part: yee who appointed stand
5091: Do as you have in charge, and briefly touch
5092: What we propound, and loud that all may hear.
5093: ¶So scoffing in ambiguous words, he scarce
5094: Had ended; when to Right and Left the Front
5095: Divided, and to either Flank retir'd.
5096: Which to our eyes discoverd new and strange,
5097: A triple-mounted row of Pillars laid
5098: On Wheels (for like to Pillars most they seem'd
5099: Or hollow'd bodies made of Oak or Firr
5100: With branches lopt, in Wood or Mountain fell'd)
5101: Brass, Iron, Stonie mould, had not thir mouthes
5102: With hideous orifice gap't on us wide,
5103: Portending hollow truce; at each behind
5104: A Seraph stood, and in his hand a Reed
5105: Stood waving tipt with fire; while we suspense,
5106: Collected stood within our thoughts amus'd,
5107: Not long, for sudden all at once thir Reeds
5108: Put forth, and to a narrow vent appli'd
5109: With nicest touch.  Immediate in a flame,
5110: But soon obscur'd with smoak, all Heav'n appeerd,
5111: From those deep-throated Engins belcht, whose roar
5112: Emboweld with outragious noise the Air,
5113: And all her entrails tore, disgorging foule
5114: Thir devillish glut, chaind Thunderbolts and Hail
5115: Of Iron Globes, which on the Victor Host
5116: Level'd, with such impetuous furie smote,
5117: That whom they hit, none on thir feet might stand,
5118: Though standing else as Rocks, but down they fell
5119: By thousands, Angel on Arch-Angel rowl'd;
5120: The sooner for thir Arms, unarm'd they might
5121: Have easily as Spirits evaded swift
5122: By quick contraction or remove; but now
5123: Foule dissipation follow'd and forc't rout;
5124: Nor serv'd it to relax thir serried files.
5125: What should they do? if on they rusht, repulse
5127: Doubl'd, would render them yet more despis'd,
5128: And to thir foes a laughter; for in view
5129: Stood rankt of Seraphim another row
5130: In posture to displode thir second tire
5131: Of Thunder: back defeated to return
5132: They worse abhorr'd.  *Satan* beheld thir plight,
5133: And to his Mates thus in derision call'd.
5134: ¶O Friends, why come not on these Victors proud?
5135: Ere while they fierce were coming, and when wee,
5136: To entertain them fair with open Front
5137: And Brest, (what could we more?) propounded terms
5138: Of composition, strait they chang'd thir minds,
5139: Flew off, and into strange vagaries fell,
5140: As they would dance, yet for a dance they seemd
5142: For joy of offerd peace: but I suppose
5143: If our proposals once again were heard
5144: We should compel them to a quick result.
5145: ¶To whom thus *Belial* in like gamesom mood.
5146: Leader, the terms we sent were terms of weight,
5147: Of hard contents, and full of force urg'd home,
5148: Such as we might perceive amus'd them all,
5149: And stumbl'd many, who receives them right,
5150: Had need from head to foot well understand;
5151: Not understood, this gift they have besides,
5152: They shew us when our foes walk not upright.
5153: ¶So they among themselves in pleasant veine
5154: Stood scoffing, highthn'd in thir thoughts beyond
5155: All doubt of Victorie, eternal might
5156: To match with thir inventions they presum'd
5157: So easie, and of his Thunder made a scorn,
5158: And all his Host derided, while they stood
5159: A while in trouble; but they stood not long,
5160: Rage prompted them at length, & found them arms
5161: Against such hellish mischief fit to oppose.
5163: Which God hath in his mighty Angels plac'd)
5164: Thir Arms away they threw, and to the Hills
5165: (For Earth hath this variety from Heav'n
5166: Of pleasure situate in Hill and Dale)
5167: Light as the Lightning glimps they ran, they flew,
5168: From thir foundations loosning to and fro
5169: They pluckt the seated Hills with all thir load,
5170: Rocks, Waters, Woods, and by the shaggie tops
5171: Up lifting bore them in thir hands: Amaze,
5172: Be sure, and terrour seis'd the rebel Host,
5173: When coming towards them so dread they saw
5174: The bottom of the Mountains upward turn'd,
5175: Till on those cursed Engins triple-row
5176: They saw them whelmd, and all thir confidence
5177: Under the weight of Mountains buried deep,
5178: Themselves invaded next, and on thir heads
5179: Main Promontories flung, which in the Air
5180: Came shadowing, and opprest whole Legions arm'd,
5181: Thir armor help'd thir harm, crush't in and brus'd
5182: Into thir substance pent, which wrought them pain
5183: Implacable, and many a dolorous groan,
5184: Long strugling underneath, ere they could wind
5185: Out of such prison, though Spirits of purest light,
5186: Purest at first, now gross by sinning grown.
5187: The rest in imitation to like Armes
5188: Betook them, and the neighbouring Hills uptore;
5189: So Hills amid the Air encounterd Hills
5190: Hurl'd to and fro with jaculation dire,
5191: That under ground they fought in dismal shade;
5192: Infernal noise; Warr seem'd a civil Game
5193: To this uproar; horrid confusion heapt
5194: Upon confusion rose: and now all Heav'n
5195: Had gone to wrack, with ruin overspred,
5196: Had not th' Almightie Father where he sits
5197: Shrin'd in his Sanctuarie of Heav'n secure,
5198: Consulting on the sum of things, foreseen
5199: This tumult, and permitted all, advis'd:
5200: That his great purpose he might so fulfill,
5201: To honour his Anointed Son aveng'd
5202: Upon his enemies, and to declare
5203: All power on him transferr'd: whence to his Son
5204: Th' Assessor of his Throne he thus began.
5206: Son in whose face invisible is beheld
5207: Visibly, what by Deitie I am,
5208: And in whose hand what by Decree I doe,
5209: Second Omnipotence, two dayes are past,
5210: Two dayes, as we compute the dayes of Heav'n,
5211: Since *Michael* and his Powers went forth to tame
5212: These disobedient; sore hath been thir fight,
5213: As likeliest was, when two such Foes met arm'd;
5214: For to themselves I left them, and thou knowst,
5215: Equal in their Creation they were form'd,
5216: Save what sin hath impaird, which yet hath wrought
5217: Insensibly, for I suspend thir doom;
5218: Whence in perpetual fight they needs must last
5219: Endless, and no solution will be found:
5220: Warr wearied hath perform'd what Warr can do,
5221: And to disorder'd rage let loose the reines,
5222: With Mountains as with Weapons arm'd, which makes
5223: Wild work in Heav'n, and dangerous to the maine.
5224: Two dayes are therefore past, the third is thine;
5225: For thee I have ordain'd it, and thus farr
5226: Have sufferd, that the Glorie may be thine
5227: Of ending this great Warr, since none but Thou
5228: Can end it.  Into thee such Vertue and Grace
5229: Immense I have transfus'd, that all may know
5230: In Heav'n and Hell thy Power above compare,
5231: And this perverse Commotion governd thus,
5232: To manifest thee worthiest to be Heir
