5233: Of all things, to be Heir and to be King
5234: By Sacred Unction, thy deserved right.
5235: Go then thou Mightiest in thy Fathers might,
5236: Ascend my Chariot, guide the rapid Wheeles
5237: That shake Heav'ns basis, bring forth all my Warr,
5238: My Bow and Thunder, my Almightie Arms
5239: Gird on, and Sword upon thy puissant Thigh;
5240: Pursue these sons of Darkness, drive them out
5241: From all Heav'ns bounds into the utter Deep:
5242: There let them learn, as likes them, to despise
5244: ¶He said, and on his Son with Rayes direct
5245: Shon full, he all his Father full exprest
5247: And thus the filial Godhead answering spake.
5248: ¶O Father, O Supream of heav'nly Thrones,
5249: First, Highest, Holiest, Best, thou alwayes seekst
5250: To glorifie thy Son, I alwayes thee,
5251: As is most just; this I my Glorie account,
5252: My exaltation, and my whole delight,
5253: That thou in me well pleas'd, declarst thy will
5254: Fulfill'd, which to fulfil is all my bliss.
5255: Scepter and Power, thy giving, I assume,
5256: And gladlier shall resign, when in the end
5257: Thou shalt be All in All, and I in thee
5258: For ever, and in mee all whom thou lov'st:
5259: But whom thou hat'st, I hate, and can put on
5260: Thy terrors, as I put thy mildness on,
5261: Image of thee in all things; and shall soon,
5262: Armd with thy might, rid heav'n of these rebell'd,
5263: To thir prepar'd ill Mansion driven down
5264: To chains of Darkness, and th' undying Worm,
5265: That from thy just obedience could revolt,
5266: Whom to obey is happiness entire.
5267: Then shall thy Saints unmixt, and from th' impure
5268: Farr separate, circling thy holy Mount
5270: Hymns of high praise, and I among them chief.
5271: So said, he o're his Scepter bowing, rose
5272: From the right hand of Glorie where he sate,
5273: And the third sacred Morn began to shine
5274: Dawning through Heav'n: forth rush'd with whirlwind sound
5276: Flashing thick flames, Wheele within Wheele undrawn,
5277: It self instinct with Spirit, but convoyd
5278: By four Cherubic shapes, four Faces each
5279: Had wondrous, as with Starrs thir bodies all
5280: And Wings were set with Eyes, with Eyes the Wheels
5281: Of Beril, and careering Fires between;
5282: Over thir heads a chrystal Firmament,
5283: Whereon a Saphir Throne, inlaid with pure
5284: Amber, and colours of the showrie Arch.
5285: Hee in Celestial Panoplie all armd
5287: Ascended, at his right hand Victorie
5288: Sate Eagle-wing'd, beside him hung his Bow
5289: And Quiver with three-bolted Thunder stor'd,
5290: And from about him fierce Effusion rowld
5291: Of smoak and bickering flame, and sparkles dire;
5292: Attended with ten thousand thousand Saints,
5293: He onward came, farr off his coming shon,
5294: And twentie thousand (I thir number heard)
5295: Chariots of God, half on each hand were seen:
5296: Hee on the wings of Cherub rode sublime
5297: On the Crystallin Skie, in Saphir Thron'd.
5298: Illustrious farr and wide, but by his own
5299: First seen, them unexpected joy surpriz'd,
5300: When the great Ensign of *Messiah* blaz'd
5301: Aloft by Angels born, his Sign in Heav'n:
5303: His Armie, circumfus'd on either Wing,
5304: Under thir Head imbodied all in one.
5305: Before him Power Divine his way prepar'd;
5306: At his command the uprooted Hills retir'd
5307: Each to his place, they heard his voice and went
5308: Obsequious, Heav'n his wonted face renewd,
5309: And with fresh Flourets Hill and Valley smil'd.
5310: This saw his hapless Foes, but stood obdur'd,
5311: And to rebellious fight rallied thir Powers
5313: In heav'nly Spirits could such perverseness dwell?
5314: But to convince the proud what Signs availe,
5315: Or Wonders move th' obdurate to relent?
5316: They hard'nd more by what might most reclame,
5317: Grieving to see his Glorie, at the sight
5318: Took envie, and aspiring to his highth,
5319: Stood reimbattell'd fierce, by force or fraud
5320: Weening to prosper, and at length prevaile
5321: Against God and *Messiah*, or to fall
5322: In universal ruin last, and now
5323: To final Battel drew, disdaining flight,
5324: Or faint retreat; when the great Son of God
5325: To all his Host on either hand thus spake.
5326: ¶Stand still in bright array ye Saints, here stand
5327: Ye Angels arm'd, this day from Battel rest;
5328: Faithful hath been your Warfare, and of God
5329: Accepted, fearless in his righteous Cause,
5330: And as ye have receivd, so have ye don
5331: Invincibly; but of this cursed crew
5332: The punishment to other hand belongs,
5333: Vengeance is his, or whose he sole appoints;
5334: Number to this dayes work is not ordain'd
5335: Nor multitude, stand onely and behold
5336: Gods indignation on these Godless pourd
5337: By mee; not you but mee they have despis'd,
5338: Yet envied; against mee is all thir rage,
5339: Because the Father, t' whom in Heav'n supream
5340: Kingdom and Power and Glorie appertains,
5341: Hath honourd me according to his will.
5342: Therefore to mee thir doom he hath assig'n'd;
5343: That they may have thir wish, to trie with mee
5344: In Battel which the stronger proves, they all,
5345: Or I alone against them, since by strength
5346: They measure all, of other excellence
5347: Not emulous, nor care who them excells;
5348: Nor other strife with them do I voutsafe.
5349: ¶So spake the Son, and into terrour chang'd
5350: His count'nance too severe to be beheld
5351: And full of wrauth bent on his Enemies.
5352: At once the Four spred out thir Starrie wings
5353: With dreadful shade contiguous, and the Orbes
5354: Of his fierce Chariot rowld, as with the sound
5355: Of torrent Floods, or of a numerous Host.
5356: Hee on his impious Foes right onward drove,
5357: Gloomie as Night; under his burning Wheeles
5359: All but the Throne it self of God.  Full soon
5360: Among them he arriv'd; in his right hand
5361: Grasping ten thousand Thunders, which he sent
5362: Before him, such as in thir Soules infix'd
5363: Plagues; they astonisht all resistance lost,
5364: All courage; down thir idle weapons drop'd;
5365: O're Shields and Helmes, and helmed heads he rode
5366: Of Thrones and mighty Seraphim prostrate,
5367: That wish'd the Mountains now might be again
5368: Thrown on them as a shelter from his ire.
5369: Nor less on either side tempestuous fell
5370: His arrows, from the fourfold-visag'd Foure,
5371: Distinct with eyes, and from the living Wheels,
5372: Distinct alike with multitude of eyes,
5373: One Spirit in them rul'd, and every eye
5374: Glar'd lightning, and shot forth pernicious fire
5375: Among th' accurst, that witherd all thir strength,
5376: And of thir wonted vigour left them draind,
5378: Yet half his strength he put not forth, but check'd
5379: His Thunder in mid Volie, for he meant
5380: Not to destroy, but root them out of Heav'n:
5381: The overthrown he rais'd, and as a Heard
5382: Of Goats or timerous flock together throngd
5383: Drove them before him Thunder-struck, pursu'd
5384: With terrors and with furies to the bounds
5385: And Chrystall wall of Heav'n, which op'ning wide,
5386: Rowld inward, and a spacious Gap disclos'd
5387: Into the wastful Deep; the monstrous sight
5388: Strook them with horror backward, but far worse
5389: Urg'd them behind; headlong themselvs they threw
5390: Down from the verge of Heav'n, Eternal wrauth
5391: Burnt after them to the bottomless pit.
5392: ¶Hell heard th' unsufferable noise, Hell saw
5393: Heav'n ruining from Heav'n and would have fled
5394: Affrighted; but strict Fate had cast too deep
5395: Her dark foundations, and too fast had bound.
5396: Nine dayes they fell; confounded *Chaos* roard,
5397: And felt tenfold confusion in thir fall
5398: Through his wilde Anarchie, so huge a rout
5399: Incumberd him with ruin: Hell at last
5400: Yawning receavd them whole, and on them clos'd,
5401: Hell thir fit habitation fraught with fire
5402: Unquenchable, the house of woe and paine.
5403: Disburd'nd Heav'n rejoic'd, and soon repaird
5404: Her mural breach, returning whence it rowld.
5405: Sole Victor from th' expulsion of his Foes
5407: To meet him all his Saints, who silent stood
5408: Eye witnesses of his Almightie Acts,
5409: With Jubilie advanc'd; and as they went,
5410: Shaded with branching Palme, each order bright,
5411: Sung Triumph, and him sung Victorious King,
5412: Son, Heire, and Lord, to him Dominion giv'n,
5413: Worthiest to Reign: he celebrated rode
5414: Triumphant through mid Heav'n, into the Courts
5415: And Temple of his mightie Father Thron'd
5416: On high; who into Glorie him receav'd,
5417: Where now he sits at the right hand of bliss.
5418: ¶Thus measuring things in Heav'n by things on Earth
5419: At thy request, and that thou maist beware
5420: By what is past, to thee I have reveal'd
5421: What might have else to human Race bin hid;
5422: The discord which befel, and Warr in Heav'n
5423: Among th' Angelic Powers, and the deep fall
5424: Of those too high aspiring, who rebelld
5425: With *Satan*, hee who envies now thy state,
5426: Who now is plotting how he may seduce
5427: Thee also from obedience, that with him
5428: Bereavd of happiness thou maist partake
5430: Which would be all his solace and revenge,
5431: As a despite don against the most High,
5432: Thee once to gaine Companion of his woe.
5433: But list'n not to his Temptations, warne
5434: Thy weaker; let it profit thee to have heard
5436: Of disobedience; firm they might have stood,
5437: Yet fell; remember, and fear to transgress.
5441: If rightly thou art call'd, whose Voice divine
5442: Following, above th' *Olympian* Hill I soare,
5444: The meaning, not the Name I call: for thou
5445: Nor of the Muses nine, nor on the top
5446: Of old *Olympus* dwell'st, but Heav'nlie borne,
5447: Before the Hills appeerd, or Fountain flow'd,
5448: Thou with Eternal wisdom didst converse,
5449: Wisdom thy Sister, and with her didst play
5450: In presence of th' Almightie Father, pleas'd
5451: With thy Celestial Song.  Up led by thee
5452: Into the Heav'n of Heav'ns I have presum'd,
5453: An Earthlie Guest, and drawn Empyreal Aire,
5454: Thy tempring; with like safetie guided down
5455: Return me to my Native Element:
5456: Least from this flying Steed unrein'd, (as once
5458: Dismounted, on th' *Aleian* Field I fall
5459: Erroneous, there to wander and forlorne.
5460: Half yet remaines unsung, but narrower bound
5462: Standing on Earth, not rapt above the Pole,
5463: More safe I Sing with mortal voice, unchang'd
5464: To hoarce or mute, though fall'n on evil dayes,
5465: On evil dayes though fall'n, and evil tongues;
5466: In darkness, and with dangers compast rouud,
5467: And solitude; yet not alone, while thou
5468: Visit'st my slumbers Nightly, or when Morn
5469: Purples the East: still govern thou my Song,
5470: *Urania*, and fit audience find, though few.
5471: But drive farr off the barbarous dissonance
5472: Of *Bacchus* and his Revellers, the Race
5473: Of that wilde Rout that tore the *Thracian* Bard
5474: In *Rhodope*, where Woods and Rocks had Eares
5475: To rapture, till the savage clamor dround
5476: Both Harp and Voice; nor could the Muse defend
5477: Her Son.  So fail not thou, who thee implores:
5478: For thou art Heav'nlie, shee an empty dreame.
5482: Apostasie, by what befell in Heaven
5483: To those Apostates, least the like befall
5484: In Paradise to *Adam* or his Race,
5485: Charg'd not to touch the interdicted Tree,
5486: If they transgress, and slight that sole command,
5487: So easily obeyd amid the choice
5488: Of all tasts else to please thir appetite,
5489: Though wandring.  He with his consorted *Eve*
5490: The storie heard attentive, and was fill'd
5491: With admiration, and deep Muse to heare
5492: Of things so high and strange, things to thir thought
5493: So unimaginable as hate in Heav'n,
5494: And Warr so neer the Peace of God in bliss
5495: With such confusion: but the evil soon
5496: Driv'n back redounded as a flood on those
5497: From whom it sprung, impossible to mix
5499: The doubts that in his heart arose: and now
5500: Led on, yet sinless, with desire to know
5501: What neerer might concern him, how this World
5502: Of Heav'n and Earth conspicuous first began,
5503: When, and whereof created, for what cause,
5504: What within *Eden* or without was done
5505: Before his memorie, as one whose drouth
5506: Yet scarce allay'd still eyes the current streame,
5507: Whose liquid murmur heard new thirst excites,
5508: Proceeded thus to ask his Heav'nly Guest.
5509: ¶Great things, and full of wonder in our eares,
5510: Farr differing from this World, thou hast reveal'd
5512: Down from the Empyrean to forewarne
5513: Us timely of what might else have bin our loss,
5514: Unknown, which human knowledg could not reach:
5515: For which to the infinitly Good we owe
5517: Receave with solemne purpose to observe
5518: Immutably his sovran will, the end
5519: Of what we are.  But since thou hast voutsaf't
5520: Gently for our instruction to impart
5521: Things above Earthly thought, which yet concernd
5522: Our knowing, as to highest wisdom seemd,
5523: Deign to descend now lower, and relate
5524: What may no less perhaps availe us known,
5525: How first began this Heav'n which we behold
5526: Distant so high, with moving Fires adornd
5527: Innumerable, and this which yeelds or fills
5528: All space, the ambient Aire wide interfus'd
5529: Imbracing round this florid Earth, what cause
5530: Mov'd the Creator in his holy Rest
5531: Through all Eternitie so late to build
5532: In *Chaos*, and the work begun, how soon
5533: Absolv'd, if unforbid thou maist unfould
5534: What wee, not to explore the secrets aske
5535: Of his Eternal Empire, but the more
5536: To magnifie his works, the more we know.
5537: And the great Light of Day yet wants to run
5538: Much of his Race though steep, suspens in Heav'n
5539: Held by thy voice, thy potent voice he heares,
5540: And longer will delay to heare thee tell
5541: His Generation, and the rising Birth
5542: Of Nature from the unapparent Deep:
5543: Or if the Starr of Eevning and the Moon
5544: Haste to thy audience, Night with her will bring
5545: Silence, and Sleep listning to thee will watch,
5546: Or we can bid his absence, till thy Song
5547: End, and dismiss thee ere the Morning shine.
5549: ¶And thus the Godlike Angel answerd milde.
5550: This also thy request with caution askt
5551: Obtaine: though to recount Almightie works
5552: What words or tongue of Seraph can suffice,
5553: Or heart of man suffice to comprehend?
5554: Yet what thou canst attain, which best may serve
5555: To glorifie the Maker, and inferr
5556: Thee also happier, shall not be withheld
5557: Thy hearing, such Commission from above
5558: I have receav'd, to answer thy desire
5559: Of knowledge within bounds; beyond abstain
5560: To ask, nor let thine own inventions hope
5561: Things not reveal'd, which th' invisible King,
5562: Onely Omniscient, hath supprest in Night,
5563: To none communicable in Earth or Heaven:
5564: Anough is left besides to search and know.
5565: But Knowledge is as food, and needs no less
5566: Her Temperance over Appetite, to know
5567: In measure what the mind may well contain,
5568: Oppresses else with Surfet, and soon turns
5569: Wisdom to Folly, as Nourishment to Winde.
5571: (So call him, brighter once amidst the Host
5572: Of Angels, then that Starr the Starrs among)
5573: Fell with his flaming Legions through the Deep
5574: Into his place, and the great Son returnd
5575: Victorious with his Saints, th' Omnipotent
5576: Eternal Father from his Throne beheld
5577: Thir multitude, and to his Son thus spake.
5578: ¶At least our envious Foe hath fail'd, who thought
5579: All like himself rebellious, by whose aid
5580: This inaccessible high strength, the seat
5582: He trusted to have seis'd, and into fraud
5583: Drew many, whom thir place knows here no more;
5584: Yet farr the greater part have kept, I see,
5585: Thir station, Heav'n yet populous retaines
5586: Number sufficient to possess her Realmes
5587: Though wide, and this high Temple to frequent
5588: With Ministeries due and solemn Rites:
5589: But least his heart exalt him in the harme
5590: Already done, to have dispeopl'd Heav'n,
5591: My damage fondly deem'd, I can repaire
5592: That detriment, if such it be to lose
5593: Self-lost, and in a moment will create
5594: Another World, out of one man a Race
5595: Of men innumerable, there to dwell,
5596: Not here, till by degrees of merit rais'd
5597: They open to themselves at length the way
5598: Up hither, under long obedience tri'd,
5599: And Earth be chang'd to Heavn, & Heav'n to Earth,
5600: One Kingdom, Joy and Union without end.
5601: Mean while inhabit laxe, ye Powers of Heav'n,
5602: And thou my Word, begotten Son, by thee
5603: This I perform, speak thou, and be it don:
5604: My overshadowing Spirit and might with thee
5605: I send along, ride forth, and bid the Deep
5606: Within appointed bounds be Heav'n and Earth,
5607: Boundless the Deep, because I am who fill
5609: Though I uncircumscrib'd my self retire,
5610: And put not forth my goodness, which is free
5611: To act or not, Necessitie and Chance
5612: Approach not mee, and what I will is Fate.
5613: ¶So spake th' Almightie, and to what he spake
5614: His Word, the Filial Godhead, gave effect.
5615: Immediate are the Acts of God, more swift
5616: Then time or motion, but to human ears
5617: Cannot without process of speech be told,
5618: So told as earthly notion can receave.
5619: Great triumph and rejoycing was in Heav'n
5620: When such was heard declar'd the Almightie's will;
5621: Glorie they sung to the most High, good will
5622: To future men, and in thir dwellings peace:
5623: Glorie to him whose just avenging ire
5624: Had driven out th' ungodly from his sight
5625: And th' habitations of the just; to him
5626: Glorie and praise, whose wisdom had ordain'd
5627: Good out of evil to create, in stead
5628: Of Spirits maligne a better Race to bring
5629: Into thir vacant room, and thence diffuse
5630: His good to Worlds and Ages infinite.
5631: So sang the Hierarchies: Mean while the Son
5632: On his great Expedition now appeer'd,
5633: Girt with Omnipotence, with Radiance crown'd
5634: Of Majestie Divine, Sapience and Love
5635: Immense, and all his Father in him shon.
5636: About his Chariot numberless were pour'd
5637: Cherub and Seraph, Potentates and Thrones,
5638: And Vertues, winged Spirits, and Chariots wing'd,
5639: From the Armoury of God, where stand of old
5640: Myriads between two brazen Mountains lodg'd
5641: Against a solemn day, harnest at hand,
5642: Celestial Equipage; and now came forth
5643: Spontaneous, for within them Spirit livd,
5644: Attendant on thir Lord: Heav'n op'nd wide
5645: Her ever during Gates, Harmonious sound
5646: On golden Hinges moving, to let forth
5647: The King of Glorie in his powerful Word
5648: And Spirit coming to create new Worlds.
5649: On heav'nly ground they stood, and from the shore
5650: They view'd the vast immeasurable Abyss
5651: Outrageous as a Sea, dark, wasteful, wilde,
5652: Up from the bottom turn'd by furious windes
5653: And surging waves, as Mountains to assault
5654: Heav'ns highth, and with the Center mix the Pole.
5655: ¶Silence, ye troubl'd waves, and thou Deep, peace,
5656: Said then th' Omnific Word, your discord end:
5657: ¶Nor staid, but on the Wings of Cherubim
5659: Farr into *Chaos*, and the World unborn;
5660: For *Chaos* heard his voice: him all his Traine
5661: Follow'd in bright procession to behold
5662: Creation, and the wonders of his might.
5663: Then staid the fervid Wheeles, and in his hand
5664: He took the golden Compasses, prepar'd
5665: In Gods Eternal store, to circumscribe
5666: This Universe, and all created things:
5667: One foot he center'd, and the other turn'd
5668: Round through the vast profunditie obscure,
5669: And said, thus farr extend, thus farr thy bounds,
5670: This be thy just Circumference, O World.
5671: Thus God the Heav'n created, thus the Earth,
5672: Matter unform'd and void: Darkness profound
5673: Cover'd th' Abyss: but on the watrie calme
5674: His brooding wings the Spirit of God outspred,
5675: And vital vertue infus'd, and vital warmth
5676: Throughout the fluid Mass, but downward purg'd
5677: The black tartareous cold infernal dregs
5678: Adverse to life: then founded, then conglob'd
5679: Like things to like, the rest to several place
5680: Disparted, and between spun out the Air,
5681: And Earth self-ballanc't on her Center hung.
5682: ¶Let ther be Light, said God, and forthwith Light
5683: Ethereal, first of things, quintessence pure
5684: Sprung from the Deep, and from her Native East
5685: To journie through the airie gloom began,
5686: Sphear'd in a radiant Cloud, for yet the Sun
5687: Was not; shee in a cloudie Tabernacle
5688: Sojourn'd the while.  God saw the Light was good;
5689: And light from darkness by the Hemisphere
5690: Divided: Light the Day, and Darkness Night
5691: He nam'd.  Thus was the first Day Eev'n and Morn:
5693: By the Celestial Quires, when Orient Light
5694: Exhaling first from Darkness they beheld;
5695: Birth-day of Heav'n and Earth; with joy and shout
5696: The hollow Universal Orb they fill'd,
5697: And touch't thir Golden Harps, & hymning prais'd
5698: God and his works, Creatour him they sung,
5699: Both when first Eevning was, and when first Morn.
5700: ¶Again, God said, let ther be Firmament
5701: Amid the Waters, and let it divide
5702: The Waters from the Waters: and God made
5703: The Firmament, expanse of liquid, pure,
5705: In circuit to the uttermost convex
5706: Of this great Round: partition firm and sure,
5707: The Waters underneath from those above
5708: Dividing: for as Earth, so hee the World
5709: Built on circumfluous Waters calme, in wide
5710: Crystallin Ocean, and the loud misrule
5711: Of *Chaos* farr remov'd, least fierce extreames
5712: Contiguous might distemper the whole frame:
5713: And Heav'n he nam'd the Firmament: So Eev'n
5714: And Morning *Chorus* sung the second Day.
5715: ¶The Earth was form'd, but in the Womb as yet
5717: Appeer'd not: over all the face of Earth
5718: Main Ocean flow'd, not idle, but with warme
5719: Prolific humour soft'ning all her Globe,
5720: Fermented the great Mother to conceave,
5721: Satiate with genial moisture, when God said
5722: Be gather'd now ye Waters under Heav'n
5723: Into one place, and let dry Land appeer.
5725: Emergent, and thir broad bare backs upheave
5726: Into the Clouds, thir tops ascend the Skie:
5727: So high as heav'd the tumid Hills, so low
5728: Down sunk a hollow bottom broad and deep,
5729: Capacious bed of Waters: thither they
5731: As drops on dust conglobing from the drie;
5732: Part rise in crystal Wall, or ridge direct,
5733: For haste; such flight the great command impress'd
5734: On the swift flouds: as Armies at the call
5735: Of Trumpet (for of Armies thou hast heard)
5736: Troop to thir Standard, so the watrie throng,
5737: Wave rowling after Wave, where way they found,
5738: If steep, with torrent rapture, if through Plaine,
5739: Soft-ebbing; nor withstood them Rock or Hill,
5740: But they, or under ground, or circuit wide
5741: With Serpent errour wandring, found thir way,
5742: And on the washie Oose deep Channels wore;
5743: Easie, e're God had bid the ground be drie,
5744: All but within those banks, where Rivers now
5745: Stream, and perpetual draw thir humid traine.
5746: The dry Land, Earth, and the great receptacle
5747: Of congregated Waters he call'd Seas:
5748: And saw that it was good, and said, Let th' Earth
5749: Put forth the verdant Grass, Herb yeilding Seed,
5750: And Fruit Tree yeilding Fruit after her kind;
5751: Whose Seed is in her self upon the Earth.
5752: He scarce had said, when the bare Earth, till then
5754: Brought forth the tender Grass, whose verdure clad
5755: Her Universal Face with pleasant green,
5756: Then Herbs of every leaf, that sudden flour'd
5757: Op'ning thir various colours, and made gay
5758: Her bosom smelling sweet: and these scarce blown,
5759: Forth flourish't thick the clustring Vine, forth crept
5760: The smelling Gourd, up stood the cornie Reed
5761: Embattell'd in her field: add the humble Shrub,
5762: And Bush with frizl'd hair implicit: last
5763: Rose as in Dance the stately Trees, and spred
5764: Thir branches hung with copious Fruit; or gemm'd
5765: Thir Blossoms: with high Woods the Hills were crownd,
5766: With tufts the vallies & each fountain side,
5767: With borders long the Rivers.  That Earth now
5768: Seemd like to Heav'n, a seat where Gods might dwell,
5769: Or wander with delight, and love to haunt
5770: Her sacred shades: though God had yet not rain'd
5771: Upon the Earth, and man to till the ground
5772: None was, but from the Earth a dewie Mist
5773: Went up and waterd all the ground, and each
5774: Plant of the field, which e're it was in the Earth
5775: God made, and every Herb, before it grew
5776: On the green stemm; God saw that it was good:
5777: So Eev'n and Morn recorded the Third Day.
5778: ¶Again th' Almightie spake: Let there be Lights
5779: High in th' expanse of Heaven to divide
5780: The Day from Night; and let them be for Signes,
5781: For Seasons, and for Dayes, and circling Years,
5782: And let them be for Lights as I ordaine
5783: Thir Office in the Firmament of Heav'n
5784: To give Light on the Earth; and it was so.
5785: And God made two great Lights, great for thir use
5786: To Man, the greater to have rule by Day,
5787: The less by Night alterne: and made the Starrs,
5788: And set them in the Firmament of Heav'n
5789: To illuminate the Earth, and rule the Day
5790: In thir vicissitude, and rule the Night,
5791: And Light from Darkness to divide.  God saw,
5792: Surveying his great Work, that it was good:
5793: For of Celestial Bodies first the Sun
5794: A mightie Spheare he fram'd, unlightsom first,
5795: Though of Ethereal Mould: then form'd the Moon
5796: Globose, and everie magnitude of Starrs,
5797: And sowd with Starrs the Heav'n thick as a field:
5798: Of Light by farr the greater part he took,
5799: Transplanted from her cloudie Shrine, and plac'd
5800: In the Suns Orb, made porous to receive
5801: And drink the liquid Light, firm to retaine
5802: Her gather'd beams, great Palace now of Light.
5803: Hither as to thir Fountain other Starrs
5804: Repairing, in thir gold'n Urns draw Light,
5805: And hence the Morning Planet guilds his horns;
5806: By tincture or reflection they augment
5807: Thir small peculiar, though from human sight
5808: So farr remote, with diminution seen.
5809: First in his East the glorious Lamp was seen,
5810: Regent of Day, and all th' Horizon round
5811: Invested with bright Rayes, jocond to run
5812: His Longitude through Heav'ns high rode: the gray
5813: Dawn, and the *Pleiades* before him danc'd
5814: Shedding sweet influence: less bright the Moon,
5815: But opposite in leveld West was set
5816: His mirror, with full face borrowing her Light
5817: From him, for other light she needed none
5818: In that aspect, and still that distance keepes
5819: Till night, then in the East her turn she shines,
5820: Revolvd on Heav'ns great Axle, and her Reign
5821: With thousand lesser Lights dividual holds,
5822: With thousand thousand Starres, that then appeer'd
5823: Spangling the Hemisphere: then first adornd
5824: With thir bright Luminaries that Set and Rose,
5825: Glad Eevning & glad Morn crownd the fourth day.
5826: ¶And God said, let the Waters generate
5827: Reptil with Spawn abundant, living Soule:
5828: And let Fowle flie above the Earth, with wings
5829: Displayd on the op'n Firmament of Heav'n.
5830: And God created the great Whales, and each
5831: Soul living, each that crept, which plenteously
5832: The waters generated by thir kindes,
5833: And every Bird of wing after his kinde;
5834: And saw that it was good, and bless'd them, saying,
5835: Be fruitful, multiply, and in the Seas
5836: And Lakes and running Streams the waters fill;
5837: And let the Fowle be multiply'd on the Earth.
5838: Forthwith the Sounds and Seas, each Creek & Bay
5839: With Frie innumerable swarme, and Shoales
5840: Of Fish that with thir Finns and shining Scales
5841: Glide under the green Wave, in Sculles that oft
5842: Bank the mid Sea: part single or with mate
5843: Graze the Sea weed thir pasture, & through Groves
5844: Of Coral stray, or sporting with quick glance
5845: Show to the Sun thir wav'd coats dropt with Gold,
5846: Or in thir Pearlie shells at ease, attend
5847: Moist nutriment, or under Rocks thir food
5848: In jointed Armour watch: on smooth the Seale,
5849: And bended Dolphins play: part huge of bulk
5850: Wallowing unweildie, enormous in thir Gate
5852: Hugest of living Creatures, on the Deep
5853: Stretcht like a Promontorie sleeps or swimmes,
5854: And seems a moving Land, and at his Gilles
5855: Draws in, and at his Trunck spouts out a Sea.
5856: Mean while the tepid Caves, and Fens and shoares
5857: Thir Brood as numerous hatch, from the Egg that soon
5858: Bursting with kindly rupture forth disclos'd
5859: Thir callow young, but featherd soon and fledge
5860: They summ'd thir Penns, and soaring th' air sublime
5861: With clang despis'd the ground, under a cloud
5862: In prospect; there the Eagle and the Stork
5863: On Cliffs and Cedar tops thir Eyries build:
5864: Part loosly wing the Region, part more wise
5865: In common, rang'd in figure wedge thir way,
5866: Intelligent of seasons, and set forth
5867: Thir Aierie Caravan high over Sea's
5868: Flying, and over Lands with mutual wing
5869: Easing thir flight; so stears the prudent Crane
5870: Her annual Voiage, born on Windes; the Aire
5871: Floats, as they pass, fann'd with unnumber'd plumes:
5872: From Branch to Branch the smaller Birds with song
5873: Solac'd the Woods, and spred thir painted wings
5874: Till Ev'n, nor then the solemn Nightingal
5875: Ceas'd warbling, but all night tun'd her soft layes:
5876: Others on Silver Lakes and Rivers Bath'd
5877: Thir downie Brest; the Swan with Arched neck
5878: Between her white wings mantling proudly, Rowes
5879: Her state with Oarie feet: yet oft they quit
5880: The Dank, and rising on stiff Pennons, towre
5881: The mid Aereal Skie: Others on ground
5882: Walk'd firm; the crested Cock whose clarion sounds
5883: The silent hours, and th' other whose gay Traine
5884: Adorns him, colour'd with the Florid hue
5885: Of Rainbows and Starrie Eyes.  The Waters thus
5886: With Fish replenisht, and the Aire with Fowle,
5887: Ev'ning and Morn solemniz'd the Fift day.
5888: ¶The Sixt, and of Creation last arose
5889: With Eevning Harps and Mattin, when God said,
5890: Let th' Earth bring forth Fowle living in her kinde,
5891: Cattel and Creeping things, and Beast of the Earth,
5892: Each in their kinde.  The Earth obey'd, and strait
5893: Op'ning her fertil Woomb teem'd at a Birth
5895: Limb'd and full grown: out of the ground up-rose
5896: As from his Laire the wilde Beast where he wonns
5897: In Forrest wilde, in Thicket, Brake, or Den;
5898: Among the Trees in Pairs they rose, they walk'd:
5899: The Cattel in the Fields and Meddowes green:
5900: Those rare and solitarie, these in flocks
5901: Pasturing at once, and in broad Herds upsprung:
5902: The grassie Clods now Calv'd, now half appeer'd
5903: The Tawnie Lion, pawing to get free
5904: His hinder parts, then springs as broke from Bonds,
5905: And Rampant shakes his Brinded main; the Ounce,
5906: The Libbard, and the Tyger, as the Moale
5907: Rising, the crumbl'd Earth above them threw
5908: In Hillocks; the swift Stag from under ground
5909: Bore up his branching head: scarse from his mould
5911: His vastness: Fleec't the Flocks and bleating rose,
5912: As Plants: ambiguous between Sea and Land
5913: The River Horse and scalie Crocodile.
5914: At once came forth whatever creeps the ground,
5915: Insect or Worme; those wav'd thir limber fans
5916: For wings, and smallest Lineaments exact
5917: In all the Liveries dect of Summers pride
5918: With spots of Gold and Purple, azure and green:
5919: These as a line thir long dimension drew,
5920: Streaking the ground with sinuous trace; not all
5921: Minims of Nature; some of Serpent kinde
5922: Wondrous in length and corpulence involv'd
5923: Thir Snakie foulds, and added wings.  First crept
5925: Of future, in small room large heart enclos'd,
5927: Hereafter, join'd in her popular Tribes
5929: The Femal Bee that feeds her Husband Drone
5930: Deliciously, and builds her waxen Cells
5931: With Honey stor'd: the rest are numberless,
5932: And thou thir Natures know'st, and gav'st them Names,
5933: Needlest to thee repeaed; nor unknown
5934: The Serpent suttl'st Beast of all the field,
5935: Of huge extent somtimes, with brazen Eyes
5936: And hairie Main terrific, though to thee
5937: Not noxious, but obedient at thy call.
5938: Now Heav'n in all her Glorie shon, and rowld
5939: Her motions, as the great first-Movers hand
5940: First wheeld thir course; Earth in her rich attire
5941: Consummate lovly smil'd; Aire, Water, Earth,
5942: By Fowl, Fish, Beast, was flown, was swum, was walkt
5943: Frequent; and of the Sixt day yet remain'd;
5944: There wanted yet the Master work, the end
5945: Of all yet don; a Creature who not prone
5946: And Brute as other Creatures, but endu'd
5947: With Sanctitie of Reason, might erect
5948: His Stature, and upright with Front serene
5949: Govern the rest, self-knowing, and from thence
5951: But grateful to acknowledge whence his good
5952: Descends, thither with heart and voice and eyes
5954: And worship God Supream, who made him chief
5955: Of all his works: therefore the Omnipotent
5956: Eternal Father (For where is not hee
5957: Present) thus to his Son audibly spake.
5958: ¶Let us make now Man in our image, Man
5959: In our similitude, and let them rule
5960: Over the Fish and Fowle of Sea and Aire,
5961: Beast of the Field, and over all the Earth,
5962: And every creeping thing that creeps the ground.
5963: This said, he formd thee, *Adam*, thee O Man
5964: Dust of the ground, and in thy nostrils breath'd
5965: The breath of Life; in his own Image hee
5966: Created thee, in the Image of God
5967: Express, and thou becam'st a living Soul.
5968: Male he created thee, but thy consort
5969: Femal for Race; then bless'd Mankinde, and said,
5970: Be fruitful, multiplie, and fill the Earth,
5971: Subdue it, and throughout Dominion hold
5972: Over Fish of the Sea, and Fowle of the Aire,
5973: And every living thing that moves on the Earth.
5974: Wherever thus created, for no place
5975: Is yet distinct by name, thence, as thou know'st
5976: He brought thee into this delicious Grove,
5977: This Garden, planted with the Trees of God,
5978: Delectable both to behold and taste;
5979: And freely all thir pleasant fruit for food
5980: Gave thee, all sorts are here that all th' Earth yeelds,
5981: Varietie without end; but of the Tree
5982: Which tasted works knowledge of Good and Evil,
5983: Thou mai'st not; in the day thou eat'st, thou di'st;
5984: Death is the penaltie impos'd, beware,
5985: And govern well thy appetite, least sin
5986: Surprise thee, and her black attendant Death.
5987: Here finish'd hee, and all that he had made
5988: View'd, and behold all was entirely good;
5989: So Ev'n and Morn accomplish'd the Sixt day:
5990: Yet not till the Creator from his work
5992: Up to the Heav'n of Heav'ns his high abode,
5993: Thence to behold this new created World
5994: Th' addition of his Empire, how it shew'd
5995: In prospect from his Throne, how good, how faire,
5996: Answering his great Idea.  Up he rode
5997: Followd with acclamation and the sound
5998: Symphonious of ten thousand Harpes that tun'd
5999: Angelic harmonies: the Earth, the Aire
6001: The Heav'ns and all the Constellations rung,
6002: The Planets in thir stations list'ning stood,
6003: While the bright Pomp ascended jubilant.
6004: Open, ye everlasting Gates, they sung,
6005: Open, ye Heav'ns, your living dores; let in
6006: The great Creator from his work returnd
6007: Magnificent, his Six days work, a World;
6008: Open, and henceforth oft; for God will deigne
6009: To visit oft the dwellings of just Men
6011: Thither will send his winged Messengers
6012: On errands of supernal Grace.  So sung
6013: The glorious Train ascending: He through Heav'n,
6014: That open'd wide her blazing Portals, led
6015: To Gods Eternal house direct the way,
6016: A broad and ample rode, whose dust is Gold
6017: And pavement Starrs, as Starrs to thee appeer,
6018: Seen in the Galaxie, that Milkie way
6019: Which nightly as a circling Zone thou seest
6020: Pouderd with Starrs.  And now on Earth the Seaventh
6021: Eev'ning arose in *Eden*, for the Sun
6022: Was set, and twilight from the East came on,
6023: Forerunning Night; when at the holy mount
6024: Of Heav'ns high-seated top, th' Impereal Throne
6025: Of Godhead, fixt for ever firm and sure,
6026: The Filial Power arriv'd, and sate him down
6027: With his great Father (for he also went
6029: Hath Omnipresence) and the work ordain'd,
6030: Author and end of all things, and from work
6031: Now resting, bless'd and hallowd the Seav'nth day,
6032: As resting on that day from all his work,
6033: But not in silence holy kept; the Harp
6034: Had work and rested not, the solemn Pipe,
6035: And Dulcimer, all Organs of sweet stop,
6036: All sounds on Fret by String or Golden Wire
6037: Temper'd soft Tunings, intermixt with Voice
6038: Choral or Unison: of incense Clouds
6039: Fuming from Golden Censers hid the Mount.
6040: Creation and the Six dayes acts they sung,
6042: Thy power; what thought can measure thee or tongue
6043: Relate thee; greater now in thy return
6044: Then from the Giant Angels; thee that day
6045: Thy Thunders magnifi'd; but to create
6046: Is greater then created to destroy.
6047: Who can impair thee, mighty King, or bound
6048: Thy Empire? easily the proud attempt
6049: Of Spirits apostat and thir Counsels vaine
6050: Thou hast repeld, while impiously they thought
6051: Thee to diminish, and from thee withdraw
6052: The number of thy worshippers.  Who seekes
6053: To lessen thee, against his purpose serves
6054: To manifest the more thy might: his evil
6055: Thou usest, and from thence creat'st more good.
6056: Witness this new-made World, another Heav'n
6057: From Heaven Gate not farr, founded in view
6058: On the cleer *Hyaline*, the Glassie Sea;
6059: Of amplitude almost immense, with Starr's
6060: Numerous, and every Starr perhaps a World
6061: Of destind habitation; but thou know'st
6062: Thir seasons: among these the seat of men,
6063: Earth with her nether Ocean circumfus'd,
6064: Thir pleasant dwelling place.  Thrice happie men,
6065: And sons of men, whom God hath thus advanc't,
6066: Created in his Image, there to dwell
6067: And worship him, and in reward to rule
6068: Over his Works, on Earth, in Sea, or Air,
6069: And multiply a Race of Worshippers
6070: Holy and just: thrice happie if they know
6072: ¶So sung they, and the Empyrean rung,
6074: And thy request think now fulfill'd, that ask'd
6075: How first this World and face of things began,
6076: And what before thy memorie was don
6078: Informd by thee might know; if else thou seekst
6079: Aught, not surpassing human measure, say.
6081: What thanks sufficient, or what recompence
6082: Equal have I to render thee, Divine
6083: Hystorian, who thus largely hast allayd
6084: The thirst I had of knowledge, and voutsaf't
6086: Things else by me unsearchable, now heard
6087: With wonder, but delight, and, as is due,
6088: With glorie attributed to the high
6089: Creator; some thing yet of doubt remaines,
6090: Which onely thy solution can resolve.
6091: When I behold this goodly Frame, this World
6092: Of Heav'n and Earth consisting, and compute,
6093: Thir magnitudes, this Earth a spot, a graine,
6094: An Atom, with the Firmament compar'd
6095: And all her numberd Starrs, that seem to rowle
6097: Thir distance argues and thir swift return
6099: Round this opacous Earth, this punctual spot,
6100: One day and night; in all thir vast survey
6101: Useless besides, reasoning I oft admire,
6102: How Nature wise and frugal could commit
6104: So many nobler Bodies to create,
6105: Greater so manifold to this one use,
6106: For aught appeers, and on thir Orbs impose
6107: Such restless revolution day by day
6109: That better might with farr less compass move,
6110: Serv'd by more noble then her self, attaines
6111: Her end without least motion, and receaves,
6112: As Tribute such a sumless journey brought
6113: Of incorporeal speed, her warmth and light;
6114: Speed, to describe whose swiftness Number failes.
6115: ¶So spake our Sire, and by his count'nance seemd
6116: Entring on studious thoughts abstruse, which *Eve*
6117: Perceaving where she sat retir'd in sight,
6118: With lowliness Majestic from her seat,
6119: And Grace that won who saw to wish her stay,
6120: Rose, and went forth among her Fruits and Flours,
6121: To visit how they prosper'd, bud and bloom,
6122: Her Nurserie; they at her coming sprung
6123: And toucht by her fair tendance gladlier grew.
6124: Yet went she not, as not with such discourse
6125: Delighted, or not capable her eare
6126: Of what was high: such pleasure she reserv'd,
6128: Her Husband the Relater she preferr'd
6129: Before the Angel, and of him to ask
6130: Chose rather; hee, she knew would intermix
6131: Grateful digressions, and solve high dispute
6132: With conjugal Caresses, from his Lip
6133: Not Words alone pleas'd her.  O when meet now
6134: Such pairs, in Love and mutual Honour joyn'd?
6135: With Goddess-like demeanour forth she went;
6136: Not unattended, for on her as Queen
6137: A pomp of winning Graces waited still,
6138: And from about her shot Darts of desire
6139: Into all Eyes to wish her still in sight.
6142: ¶To ask or search I blame thee not, for Heav'n
6143: Is as the Book of God before thee set,
6144: Wherein to read his wondrous Works, and learne
6145: His Seasons, Hours, or Days, or Months, or Yeares:
6146: This to attain, whether Heav'n move or Earth,
6147: Imports not, if thou reck'n right, the rest
6148: From Man or Angel the great Architect
6149: Did wisely to conceal, and not divulge
6150: His secrets to be scann'd by them who ought
6151: Rather admire; or if they list to try
6152: Conjecture, he his Fabric of the Heav'ns
6153: Hath left to thir disputes, perhaps to move
6154: His laughter at thir quaint Opinions wide
6155: Hereafter, when they come to model Heav'n
6156: And calculate the Starrs, how they will weild
6157: The mightie frame, how build, unbuild, contrive
6158: To save appeerances, how gird the Sphear
6159: With Centric and Eccentric scribl'd o're,
6160: Cycle and Epicycle, Orb in Orb:
6161: Alreadie by thy reasoning this I guess,
6162: Who art to lead thy ofspring, and supposest
6163: That Bodies bright and greater should not serve
6164: The less not bright, nor Heav'n such journies run,
6165: Earth sitting still, when she alone receaves
6166: The benefit: consider first, that Great
6167: Or Bright inferrs not Excellence: the Earth
6168: Though, in comparison of Heav'n, so small,
6169: Nor glistering, may of solid good containe
6170: More plenty then the Sun that barren shines,
6171: Whose vertue on it self workes no effect,
6172: But in the fruitful Earth; there first receavd
6173: His beams, unactive else, thir vigor find.
6174: Yet not to Earth are those bright Luminaries
6175: Officious, but to thee Earths habitant.
6176: And for the Heav'ns wide Circuit, let it speak
6177: The Makers high magnificence, who built
6178: So spacious, and his Line stretcht out so farr;
6179: That Man may know he dwells not in his own;
6180: An Edifice too large for him to fill,
6181: Lodg'd in a small partition, and the rest
6182: Ordain'd for uses to his Lord best known.
6183: The swiftness of those Circles attribute,
6185: That to corporeal substances could adde
6186: Speed almost Spiritual; mee thou thinkst not slow,
6187: Who since the Morning hour set out from Heav'n
6188: Where God resides, and ere mid-day arriv'd
6190: By Numbers that have name.  But this I urge,
6191: Admitting Motion in the Heav'ns, to shew
6192: Invalid that which thee to doubt it mov'd;
6193: Not that I so affirm, though so it seem
6194: To thee who hast thy dwelling here on Earth.
6195: God to remove his wayes from human sense,
6196: Plac'd Heav'n from Earth so farr, that earthly sight,
6197: If it presume, might erre in things too high,
6198: And no advantage gaine.  What if the Sun
6199: Be Center to the World, and other Starrs
6200: By his attractive vertue and thir own
6201: Incited, dance about him various rounds?
6202: Thir wandring course now high, now low, then hid,
6204: In six thou seest, and what if sev'nth to these
6205: The Planet Earth, so stedfast though she seem,
6207: Which else to several Sphears thou must ascribe,
6209: Or save the Sun his labour, and that swift
6211: Invisible else above all Starrs, the Wheele
6212: Of Day and Night; which needs not thy beleefe,
6213: If Earth industrious of her self fetch Day
6214: Travelling East, and with her part averse
6215: From the Suns beam meet Night, her other part
6216: Still luminous by his ray.  What if that light
6217: Sent from her through the wide transpicuous aire,
6218: To the terrestrial Moon be as a Starr
6219: Enlightning her by Day, as she by Night
6220: This Earth? reciprocal, if Land be there,
6221: Feilds and Inhabitants: Her spots thou seest
6222: As Clouds, and Clouds may rain, and Rain produce
6223: Fruits in her soft'nd Soile, for some to eate
6224: Allotted there; and other Suns perhaps
6225: With thir attendant Moons thou wilt descrie
6227: Which two great Sexes animate the World,
6228: Stor'd in each Orb perhaps with some that live.
6229: For such vast room in Nature unpossest
6230: By living Soule, desert and desolate,
6231: Onely to shine, yet scarce to contribute
6232: Each Orb a glimps of Light, conveyd so farr
6233: Down to this habitable, which returnes
6234: Light back to them, is obvious to dispute.
6235: But whether thus these things, or whether not,
6236: Whether the Sun predominant in Heav'n
6237: Rise on the Earth, or Earth rise on the Sun,
6238: Hee from the East his flaming rode begin,
6239: Or Shee from West her silent course advance
6240: With inoffensive pace that spinning sleeps
6241: On her soft Axle, while she paces Eev'n,
6242: And bears thee soft with the smooth Air along,
6243: Sollicit not thy thoughts with matters hid,
6244: Leave them to God above, him serve and feare;
6245: Of other Creatures, as him pleases best,
6246: Wherever plac't, let him dispose: joy thou
6247: In what he gives to thee, this Paradise
6248: And thy faire *Eve*; Heav'n is for thee too high
6249: To know what passes there; be lowlie wise:
6250: Think onely what concernes thee and thy being;
6251: Dream not of other Worlds, what Creatures there
6252: Live, in what state, condition or degree,
6253: Contented that thus farr hath been reveal'd
6254: Not of Earth onely but of highest Heav'n.
6255: ¶To whom thus *Adam* cleerd of doubt, repli'd.
6256: How fully hast thou satisfi'd mee, pure
6258: And freed from intricacies, taught to live,
6259: The easiest way, nor with perplexing thoughts
6260: To interrupt the sweet of Life, from which
6261: God hath bid dwell farr off all anxious cares,
6262: And not molest us, unless we our selves
6263: Seek them with wandring thoughts, and notions vaine.
6264: But apt the Mind or Fancie is to roave
6265: Uncheckt, and of her roaving is no end;
6266: Till warn'd, or by experience taught, she learne,
6267: That not to know at large of things remote
6268: From use, obscure and suttle, but to know
6269: That which before us lies in daily life,
6270: Is the prime Wisdom, what is more, is fume,
6272: And renders us in things that most concerne
6273: Unpractis'd, unprepar'd, and still to seek.
6274: Therefore from this high pitch let us descend
6275: A lower flight, and speak of things at hand
6276: Useful, whence haply mention may arise
6277: Of somthing not unseasonable to ask
6278: By sufferance, and thy wonted favour deign'd.
6279: Thee I have heard relating what was don
6280: Ere my remembrance: now hear mee relate
6281: My Storie, which perhaps thou hast not heard;
6282: And Day is yet not spent; till then thou seest
6283: How suttly to detaine thee I devise,
6284: Inviting thee to hear while I relate,
6285: Fond, were it not in hope of thy reply:
6286: For while I sit with thee, I seem in Heav'n,
6287: And sweeter thy discourse is to my eare
6288: Then Fruits of Palm-tree pleasantest to thirst
6289: And hunger both, from labour, at the houre
6290: Of sweet repast; they satiate, and soon fill,
6291: Though pleasant, but thy words with Grace Divine
6292: Imbu'd, bring to thir sweetness no satietie.
6294: Nor are thy lips ungraceful, Sire of men,
6295: Nor tongue ineloquent; for God on thee
6296: Abundantly his gifts hath also pour'd,
6297: Inward and outward both, his image faire:
6298: Speaking or mute all comliness and grace
6299: Attends thee, and each word, each motion formes.
6300: Nor less think wee in Heav'n of thee on Earth
6301: Then of our fellow servant, and inquire
6302: Gladly into the wayes of God with Man:
6303: For God we see hath honour'd thee, and set
6304: On Man his equal Love: say therefore on;
6305: For I that Day was absent, as befell,
6306: Bound on a voyage uncouth and obscure,
6307: Farr on excursion toward the Gates of Hell;
6308: Squar'd in full Legion (such command we had)
6309: To see that none thence issu'd forth a spie,
6310: Or enemie, while God was in his work,
6311: Least hee incenst at such eruption bold,
6312: Destruction with Creation might have mixt.
6313: Not that they durst without his leave attempt,
6314: But us he sends upon his high behests
6315: For state, as Sovran King, and to enure
6316: Our prompt obedience.  Fast we found, fast shut
6317: The dismal Gates, and barricado'd strong;
6318: But long ere our approaching heard within
6319: Noise, other then the sound of Dance or Song,
6320: Torment, and lowd lament, and furious rage.
6321: Glad we return'd up to the coasts of Light
6322: Ere Sabbath Eev'ning: so we had in charge.
6323: But thy relation now; for I attend,
6324: Pleas'd with thy words no less then thou with mine.
6325: ¶So spake the Godlike Power, and thus our Sire.
6326: For Man to tell how human Life began
6327: Is hard; for who himself beginning knew?
6328: Desire with thee still longer to converse
6329: Induc'd me.  As new wak't from soundest sleep
6330: Soft on the flourie herb I found me laid
6331: In Balmie Sweat, which with his Beames the Sun
6332: Soon dri'd, and on the reaking moisture fed.
6333: Strait toward Heav'n my wondring Eyes I turnd,
6334: And gaz'd a while the ample Skie, till rais'd
6335: By quick instinctive motion up I sprung,
6337: Stood on my feet; about me round I saw
6338: Hill, Dale, and shadie Woods, and sunnie Plaines,
6339: And liquid Lapse of murmuring Streams; by these,
6340: Creatures that livd, and movd, and walk'd, or flew,
6341: Birds on the branches warbling; all things smil'd,
6342: With fragrance and with joy my heart oreflow'd.
6343: My self I then perus'd, and Limb by Limb
6344: Survey'd, and sometimes went, and sometimes ran
6345: With supple joints, as lively vigour led:
6346: But who I was, or where, or from what cause,
6347: Knew not; to speak I tri'd, and forthwith spake,
6348: My Tongue obey'd and readily could name
6349: What e're I saw.  Thou Sun, said I, faire Light,
6350: And thou enlight'nd Earth, so fresh and gay,
6351: Ye Hills and Dales, ye Rivers, Woods, and Plaines,
6352: And ye that live and move, fair Creatures, tell,
6353: Tell, if ye saw, how came I thus, how here?
6354: Not of my self; by some great Maker then,
6355: In goodness and in power praeeminent;
6356: Tell me, how may I know him, how adore,
6357: From whom I have that thus I move and live,
6358: And feel that I am happier then I know.
6359: While thus I call'd, and stray'd I knew not whither,
6360: From where I first drew Aire, and first beheld
6361: This happie Light, when answer none return'd,
6362: On a green shadie Bank profuse of Flours
6363: Pensive I sate me down; there gentle sleep
6364: First found me, and with soft oppression seis'd
6365: My droused sense, untroubl'd, though I thought
6366: I then was passing to my former state
6368: When suddenly stood at my Head a dream,
6370: My Fancy to believe I yet had being,
6371: And livd: One came, methought, of shape Divine,
6372: And said, thy Mansion wants thee, *Adam*, rise,
6373: First Man, of Men innumerable ordain'd
6374: First Father, call'd by thee I come thy Guide
6375: To the Garden of bliss, thy seat prepar'd.
6376: So saying, by the hand he took me rais'd,
6377: And over Fields and Waters, as in Aire
6378: Smooth sliding without step, last led me up
6379: A woodie Mountain; whose high top was plaine,
6380: A Circuit wide, enclos'd, with goodliest Trees
6381: Planted, with Walks, and Bowers, that what I saw
6382: Of Earth before scarse pleasant seemd.  Each Tree
6383: Load'n with fairest Fruit, that hung to the Eye
6384: Tempting, stirr'd in me sudden appetite
6385: To pluck and eate; whereat I wak'd, and found
6386: Before mine Eyes all real, as the dream
6387: Had lively shadowd: Here had new begun
6388: My wandring, had not hee who was my Guide
6389: Up hither, from among the Trees appeer'd,
6390: Presence Divine.  Rejoycing, but with aw
6391: In adoration at his feet I fell
6392: Submiss: he rear'd me, & Whom thou soughtst I am,
6393: Said mildely, Author of all this thou seest
6394: Above, or round about thee or beneath.
6395: This Paradise I give thee, count it thine
6396: To Till and keep, and of the Fruit to eate:
6397: Of every Tree that in the Garden growes
6398: Eate freely with glad heart; fear here no dearth:
6399: But of the Tree whose operation brings
6400: Knowledg of good and ill, which I have set
6401: The Pledge of thy Obedience and thy Faith,
6402: Amid the Garden by the Tree of Life,
6403: Remember what I warne thee, shun to taste,
6404: And shun the bitter consequence: for know,
6405: The day thou eat'st thereof, my sole command
6407: From that day mortal, and this happie State
6408: Shalt loose, expell'd from hence into a World
6409: Of woe and sorrow.  Sternly he pronounc'd
6411: Yet dreadful in mine eare, though in my choice
6412: Not to incur; but soon his cleer aspect
6413: Return'd and gratious purpose thus renew'd.
6414: Not onely these fair bounds, but all the Earth
6415: To thee and to thy Race I give; as Lords
6416: Possess it, and all things that therein live,
6417: Or live in Sea, or Aire, Beast, Fish, and Fowle.
6418: In signe whereof each Bird and Beast behold
6419: After thir kindes; I bring them to receave
6420: From thee thir Names, and pay thee fealtie
6421: With low subjection; understand the same
6422: Of Fish within thir watry residence,
6423: Not hither summond, since they cannot change
6424: Thir Element to draw the thinner Aire.
6425: As thus he spake, each Bird and Beast behold
6426: Approaching two and two, These cowring low
6427: With blandishment, each Bird stoop'd on his wing.
6428: I nam'd them, as they pass'd, and understood
6429: Thir Nature, with such knowledg God endu'd
6430: My sudden apprehension: but in these
6431: I found not what me thought I wanted still;
6432: And to the Heav'nly vision thus presum'd.
6433: ¶O by what Name, for thou above all these,
6434: Above mankinde, or aught then mankinde higher,
6435: Surpassest farr my naming, how may I
6436: Adore thee, Author of this Universe,
6437: And all this good to man, for whose well being
6438: So amply, and with hands so liberal
6439: Thou hast provided all things: but with mee
6440: I see not who partakes.  In solitude
6441: What happiness, who can enjoy alone,
6442: Or all enjoying, what contentment find?
6443: Thus I presumptuous; and the vision bright,
6444: As with a smile more bright'nd, thus repli'd.
6445: ¶What call'st thou solitude, is not the Earth
6446: With various living creatures, and the Aire
6447: Replenisht, and all these at thy command
6448: To come and play before thee, know'st thou not
6449: Thir language and thir wayes, they also know,
6450: And reason not contemptibly; with these
6451: Find pastime, and beare rule; thy Realm is large.
6452: So spake the Universal Lord, and seem'd
6453: So ordering.  I with leave of speech implor'd,
6455: ¶Let not my words offend thee, Heav'nly Power,
6456: My Maker, be propitious while I speak.
6457: Hast thou not made me here thy substitute,
6458: And these inferiour farr beneath me set?
6460: Can sort, what harmonie or true delight?
6461: Which must be mutual, in proportion due
6462: Giv'n and receiv'd; but in disparitie
6463: The one intense, the other still remiss
6464: Cannot well suite with either, but soon prove
6465: Tedious alike: Of fellowship I speak
6466: Such as I seek, fit to participate
6467: All rational delight, wherein the brute
6468: Cannot be human consort; they rejoyce
6469: Each with thir kinde, Lion with Lioness;
6470: So fitly them in pairs thou hast combin'd;
6471: Much less can Bird with Beast, or Fish with Fowle
6472: So well converse, nor with the Ox the Ape;
6473: Wors then can Man with Beast, and least of all.
6475: A nice and suttle happiness I see
6476: Thou to thy self proposest, in the choice
6477: Of thy Associates, *Adam*, and wilt taste
6478: No pleasure, though in pleasure, solitarie.
6479: What thinkst thou then of mee, and this my State,
6480: Seem I to thee sufficiently possest
6481: Of happiness, or not? who am alone
6482: From all Eternitie, for none I know
6483: Second to mee or like, equal much less.
6484: How have I then with whom to hold converse
6485: Save with the Creatures which I made, and those
6487: Beneath what other Creatures are to thee?
6488: ¶He ceas'd, I lowly answer'd.  To attaine
6489: The highth and depth of thy Eternal wayes
6490: All human thoughts come short, Supream of things;
6491: Thou in thy self art perfet, and in thee
6492: Is no deficience found; not so is Man,
6493: But in degree, the cause of his desire
6494: By conversation with his like to help,
6495: Or solace his defects.  No need that thou
6497: And through all numbers absolute, though One;
6498: But Man by number is to manifest
6500: Like of his like, his Image multipli'd,
6503: Thou in thy secresie although alone,
6504: Best with thy self accompanied, seek'st not
6506: Canst raise thy Creature to what highth thou wilt
6508: I by conversing cannot these erect
6509: From prone, nor in thir wayes complacence find.
6510: Thus I embold'nd spake, and freedom us'd
6511: Permissive, and acceptance found, which gain'd
6512: This answer from the gratious voice Divine.
6513: ¶Thus farr to try thee, *Adam*, I was pleas'd,
6514: And finde thee knowing not of Beasts alone,
6515: Which thou hast rightly nam'd, but of thy self,
6516: Expressing well the spirit within thee free,
6517: My Image, not imparted to the Brute,
6518: Whose fellowship therefore unmeet for thee
6519: Good reason was thou freely shouldst dislike,
6520: And be so minded still; I, ere thou spak'st,
6521: Knew it not good for Man to be alone,
6522: And no such companie as then thou saw'st
6523: Intended thee, for trial onely brought,
6524: To see how thou could'st judge of fit and meet:
6525: What next I bring shall please thee, be assur'd,
6526: Thy likeness, thy fit help, thy other self,
6527: Thy wish, exactly to thy hearts desire.
6528: ¶Hee ended, or I heard no more, for now
6529: My earthly by his Heav'nly overpowerd,
6530: Which it had long stood under, streind to the highth
6532: As with an object that excels the sense,
6533: Dazl'd and spent, sunk down, and sought repair
6534: Of sleep, which instantly fell on me, call'd
6535: By Nature as in aide, and clos'd mine eyes.
6536: Mine eyes he clos'd, but op'n left the Cell
6537: Of Fancie my internal sight, by which
6538: Abstract as in a transe methought I saw,
6539: Though sleeping, where I lay, and saw the shape
6540: Still glorious before whom awake I stood;
6541: Who stooping op'nd my left side, and took
6542: From thence a Rib, with cordial spirits warme,
6543: And Life-blood streaming fresh; wide was the wound,
6544: But suddenly with flesh fill'd up & heal'd:
6545: The Rib he formd and fashond with his hands;
6546: Under his forming hands a Creature grew,
6547: Manlike, but different sex, so lovly faire,
6548: That what seemd fair in all the World, seemd now
6549: Mean, or in her summd up, in her containd
6550: And in her looks, which from that time infus'd
6551: Sweetness into my heart, unfelt before,
6552: And into all things from her Aire inspir'd
6553: The spirit of love and amorous delight.
6554: She disappeerd, and left me dark, I wak'd
6555: To find her, or for ever to deplore
6556: Her loss, and other pleasures all abjure:
6557: When out of hope, behold her, not farr off,
6558: Such as I saw her in my dream, adornd
6559: With what all Earth or Heaven could bestow
6560: To make her amiable: On she came,
6561: Led by her Heav'nly Maker, though unseen,
6562: And guided by his voice, nor uninformd
6563: Of nuptial Sanctitie and marriage Rites:
6564: Grace was in all her steps, Heav'n in her Eye,
6565: In every gesture dignitie and love.
6566: I overjoyd could not forbear aloud.
6567: ¶This turn hath made amends; thou hast fulfill'd
6568: Thy words, Creator bounteous and benigne,
6569: Giver of all things faire, but fairest this
6570: Of all thy gifts, nor enviest.  I now see
6571: Bone of my Bone, Flesh of my Flesh, my Self
6572: Before me; Woman is her Name, of Man
6573: Extracted; for this cause he shall forgoe
6574: Father and Mother, and to his Wife adhere;
6575: And they shall be one Flesh, one Heart, one Soule.
6576: ¶She heard me thus, and though divinely brought,
6578: Her vertue and the conscience of her worth,
6579: That would be woo'd, and not unsought be won,
6580: Not obvious, not obtrusive, but retir'd,
6581: The more desirable, or to say all,
6582: Nature her self, though pure of sinful thought,
6583: Wrought in her so, that seeing me, she turn'd;
6584: I follow'd her, she what was Honour knew,
6586: My pleaded reason.  To the Nuptial Bowre
6587: I led her blushing like the Morn: all Heav'n,
6588: And happie Constellations on that houre
6589: Shed thir selectest influence; the Earth
6590: Gave sign of gratulation, and each Hill;
6591: Joyous the Birds; fresh Gales and gentle Aires
6592: Whisper'd it to the Woods, and from thir wings
6593: Flung Rose, flung Odours from the spicie Shrub,
6594: Disporting, till the amorous Bird of Night
6595: Sung Spousal, and bid haste the Eevning Starr
6596: On his Hill top, to light the bridal Lamp.
6597: Thus I have told thee all my State, and brought
6598: My Storie to the sum of earthly bliss
6599: Which I enjoy, and must confess to find
6600: In all things else delight indeed, but such
6601: As us'd or not, works in the mind no change,
6603: I mean of Taste, Sight, Smell, Herbs, Fruits, & Flours,
6604: Walks, and the melodie of Birds; but here
6606: Transported touch; here passion first I felt,
6607: Commotion strange, in all enjoyments else
6608: Superiour and unmov'd, here onely weake
6609: Against the charm of Beauties powerful glance.
6610: Or Nature faild in mee, and left some part
6611: Not proof enough such Object to sustain,
6612: Or from my side subducting, took perhaps
6613: More then enough; at least on her bestow'd
6614: Too much of Ornament, in outward shew
6616: For well I understand in the prime end
6617: Of Nature her th' inferiour, in the mind
6618: And inward Faculties, which most excell,
6619: In outward also her resembling less
6620: His Image who made both, and less expressing
6621: The character of that Dominion giv'n
6622: O're other Creatures; yet when I approach
6623: Her loveliness, so absolute she seems
6624: And in her self compleat, so well to know
6625: Her own, that what she wills to do or say,
6627: All higher knowledge in her presence falls
6628: Degraded, Wisdom in discourse with her
6629: Looses discount'nanc't, and like folly shewes;
6630: Authoritie and Reason on her waite,
6631: As one intended first, not after made
6633: Greatness of mind and nobleness thir seat
6634: Build in her loveliest, and create an awe
6635: About her, as a guard Angelic plac't.
6636: To whom the Angel with contracted brow.
6637: ¶Accuse not Nature, she hath don her part;
6638: Do thou but thine, and be not diffident
6639: Of Wisdom, she deserts thee not, if thou
6640: Dismiss not her, when most thou needst her nigh,
6642: Less excellent, as thou thy self perceav'st.
6643: For what admir'st thou, what transports thee so,
6644: An outside? fair no doubt, and worthy well
6645: Thy cherishing, thy honouring, and thy love,
6646: Not thy subjection: weigh with her thy self;
6647: Then value: Oft times nothing profits more
6648: Then self-esteem, grounded on just and right
6649: Well manag'd; of that skill the more thou know'st,
6650: The more she will acknowledge thee her Head,
6651: And to realities yeild all her shows;
6652: Made so adorn for thy delight the more,
6653: So awful, that with honour thou maist love
6654: Thy mate, who sees when thou art seen least wise.
6655: But if the sense of touch whereby mankind
6656: Is propagated seem such dear delight
6657: Beyond all other, think the same voutsaf't
6658: To Cattel and each Beast; which would not be
6659: To them made common & divulg'd, if aught
6660: Therein enjoy'd were worthy to subdue
6661: The Soule of Man, or passion in him move.
6662: What higher in her societie thou findst
6664: In loving thou dost well, in passion not,
6665: Wherein true Love consists not; love refines
6666: The thoughts, and heart enlarges, hath his seat
6667: In Reason, and is judicious, is the scale
6668: By which to heav'nly Love thou maist ascend,
6669: Not sunk in carnal pleasure, for which cause
6670: Among the Beasts no Mate for thee was found.
6672: Neither her out-side formd so fair, nor aught
6673: In procreation common to all kindes
6674: (Though higher of the genial Bed by far,
6675: And with mysterious reverence I deem)
6676: So much delights me, as those graceful acts,
6677: Those thousand decencies that daily flow
6678: From all her words and actions, mixt with Love
6679: And sweet compliance, which declare unfeign'd
6680: Union of Mind, or in us both one Soule;
6681: Harmonie to behold in wedded pair
6682: More grateful then harmonious sound to the eare.
6683: Yet these subject not; I to thee disclose
6684: What inward thence I feel, not therefore foild,
6685: Who meet with various objects, from the sense
6687: Approve the best, and follow what I approve.
6688: To love thou blam'st me not, for love thou saist
6689: Leads up to Heav'n, is both the way and guide;
6690: Bear with me then, if lawful what I ask;
6691: Love not the heav'nly Spirits, and how thir Love
6692: Express they, by looks onely, or do they mix
6694: ¶To whom the Angel with a smile that glow'd
6695: Celestial rosie red, Loves proper hue,
6696: Answer'd.  Let it suffice thee that thou know'st
6697: Us happie, and without Love no happiness.
6698: Whatever pure thou in the body enjoy'st
6699: (And pure thou wert created) we enjoy
6700: In eminence, and obstacle find none
6701: Of membrane, joynt, or limb, exclusive barrs:
6702: Easier then Air with Air, if Spirits embrace,
6703: Total they mix, Union of Pure with Pure
6705: As Flesh to mix with Flesh, or Soul with Soul.
6706: But I can now no more; the parting Sun
6707: Beyond the Earths green Cape and verdant Isles
6709: Be strong, live happie, and love, but first of all
6710: Him whom to love is to obey, and keep
6711: His great command; take heed least Passion sway
6712: Thy Judgement to do aught, which else free Will
6713: Would not admit; thine and of all thy Sons
6714: The weal or woe in thee is plac't; beware.
6715: I in thy persevering shall rejoyce,
6716: And all the Blest: stand fast; to stand or fall
6717: Free in thine own Arbitrement it lies.
6718: Perfet within, no outward aid require;
6719: And all temptation to transgress repel.
6721: Follow'd with benediction.  Since to part,
6723: Sent from whose sovran goodness I adore.
6724: Gentle to me and affable hath been
6725: Thy condescension, and shall be honour'd ever
6726: With grateful Memorie: thou to mankind
6727: Be good and friendly still, and oft return.
6728: ¶So parted they, the Angel up to Heav'n
6729: From the thick shade, and *Adam* to his Bowre.
6732: ¶No more of talk where God or Angel Guest
6733: With Man, as with his Friend, familiar us'd
6734: To sit indulgent, and with him partake
6735: Rural repast, permitting him the while
6736: Venial discourse unblam'd: I now must change
6737: Those Notes to Tragic; foul distrust, and breach
6738: Disloyal on the part of Man, revolt
6739: And disobedience: On the part of Heav'n
6741: Anger and just rebuke, and judgement giv'n,
6742: That brought into this World a world of woe,
6743: Sinne and her shadow Death, and Miserie
6744: Deaths Harbinger: Sad task, yet argument
6745: Not less but more Heroic then the wrauth
6746: Of stern *Achilles* on his Foe pursu'd
6747: Thrice Fugitive about *Troy* Wall; or rage
6749: Or *Neptun's* ire or *Juno's*, that so long
6751: If answerable style I can obtaine
6752: Of my Celestial Patroness, who deignes
6754: And dictates to me slumbring, or inspires
6756: Since first this subject for Heroic Song
6757: Pleas'd me long choosing, and beginning late;
6758: Not sedulous by Nature to indite
6760: Heroic deem'd, chief maistrie to dissect
6761: With long and tedious havoc fabl'd Knights
6762: In Battels feign'd; the better fortitude
6764: Unsung; or to describe Races and Games,
6767: Bases and tinsel Trappings, gorgious Knights
6768: At Joust and Torneament; then marshal'd Feast
6769: Serv'd up in Hall with Sewers, and Seneshals;
6770: The skill of Artifice or Office mean,
6771: Not that which justly gives Heroic name
6772: To Person or to Poem.  Mee of these
6773: Nor skilld nor studious, higher Argument
6774: Remaines, sufficient of it self to raise
6775: That name, unless an age too late, or cold
6776: Climat, or Years damp my intended wing
6777: Deprest, and much they may, if all be mine,
6778: Not Hers who brings it nightly to my Ear.
6779: ¶The Sun was sunk, and after him the Starr
6780: Of *Hesperus*, whose Office is to bring
6781: Twilight upon the Earth, short Arbiter
6782: Twixt Day and Night, and now from end to end
6783: Nights Hemisphere had veild the Horizon round:
6784: When *Satan* who late fled before the threats
6786: In meditated fraud and malice, bent
6787: On mans destruction, maugre what might hap
6788: Of heavier on himself, fearless return'd.
6789: By Night he fled, and at Midnight return'd
6790: From compassing the Earth, cautious of day,
6791: Since *Uriel* Regent of the Sun descri'd
6792: His entrance, and forewarnd the Cherubim
6793: That kept thir watch; thence full of anguish driv'n,
6794: The space of seven continu'd Nights he rode
6795: With darkness, thrice the Equinoctial Line
6796: He circl'd, four times cross'd the Carr of Night
6797: From Pole to Pole, traversing each Colure;
6798: On the eighth return'd, and on the Coast averse
6799: From entrance or Cherubic Watch, by stealth
6800: Found unsuspected way.  There was a place,
6801: Now not, though Sin, not Time, first wraught the change,
6802: Where *Tigris* at the foot of Paradise
6803: Into a Gulf shot under ground, till part
6804: Rose up a Fountain by the Tree of Life;
6805: In with the River sunk, and with it rose
6806: Satan involv'd in rising Mist, then sought
6807: Where to lie hid; Sea he had searcht and Land
6810: Downward as farr Antartic; and in length
6811: West from *Orantes* to the Ocean barr'd
6812: At *Darien*, thence to the Land where flowes
6813: *Ganges* and *Indus:* thus the Orb he roam'd
6814: With narrow search; and with inspection deep
6815: Consider'd every Creature, which of all
6816: Most opportune might serve his Wiles, and found
6817: The Serpent suttlest Beast of all the Field.
6819: Of thoughts revolv'd, his final sentence chose
6820: Fit Vessel, fittest Imp of fraud, in whom
6821: To enter, and his dark suggestions hide
6822: From sharpest sight: for in the wilie Snake,
6823: Whatever sleights none would suspicious mark,
6824: As from his wit and native suttletie
6825: Proceeding, which in other Beasts observ'd
6826: Doubt might beget of Diabolic pow'r
6827: Active within beyond the sense of brute.
6828: Thus he resolv'd, but first from inward griefe
6829: His bursting passion into plaints thus pour'd:
6830: ¶O Earth, how like to Heav'n, if not preferrd
6831: More justly, Seat worthier of Gods, as built
6832: With second thoughts, reforming what was old!
6833: For what God after better worse would build?
6834: Terrestrial Heav'n, danc't round by other Heav'ns
6835: That shine, yet bear thir bright officious Lamps,
6836: Light above Light, for thee alone, as seems,
6837: In thee concentring all thir precious beams
6838: Of sacred influence: As God in Heav'n
6839: Is Center, yet extends to all, so thou
6840: Centring receav'st from all those Orbs; in thee,
6841: Not in themselves, all thir known vertue appeers
6842: Productive in Herb, Plant, and nobler birth
6843: Of Creatures animate with gradual life
6844: Of Growth, Sense, Reason, all summ'd up in Man.
6845: With what delight could I have walkt thee round
6846: If I could joy in aught, sweet interchange
6847: Of Hill and Vallie, Rivers, Woods and Plaines,
6848: Now Land, now Sea, & Shores with Forrest crownd,
6849: Rocks, Dens, and Caves; but I in none of these
6850: Find place or refuge; and the more I see
6851: Pleasures about me, so much more I feel
6852: Torment within me, as from the hateful siege
6853: Of contraries; all good to me becomes
6854: Bane, and in Heav'n much worse would be my state.
6855: But neither here seek I, no nor in Heav'n
6856: To dwell, unless by maistring Heav'ns Supreame;
6857: Nor hope to be my self less miserable
6858: By what I seek, but others to make such
6859: As I though thereby worse to me redound:
6860: For onely in destroying I finde ease
6861: To my relentless thoughts; and him destroyd,
6862: Or won to what may work his utter loss,
6863: For whom all this was made, all this will soon
6864: Follow, as to him linkt in weal or woe,
6865: In wo then; that destruction wide may range:
6866: To mee shall be the glorie sole among
6867: The infernal Powers, in one day to have marr'd
6868: What he *Almightie* styl'd, six Nights and Days
6869: Continu'd making, and who knows how long
6870: Before had bin contriving, though perhaps
6871: Not longer then since I in one Night freed
6873: Th' Angelic Name, and thinner left the throng
6874: Of his adorers: hee to be aveng'd,
6875: And to repaire his numbers thus impair'd,
6876: Whether such vertue spent of old now faild
6877: More Angels to Create, if they at least
6878: Are his Created or to spite us more,
6879: Determin'd to advance into our room
6880: A Creature form'd of Earth, and him endow,
6882: With Heav'nly spoils, our spoils: What he decreed
6883: He effected; Man he made, and for him built
6884: Magnificent this World, and Earth his seat,
6885: Him Lord pronounc'd, and, O indignitie!
6886: Subjected to his service Angel wings,
6887: And flaming Ministers to watch and tend
6888: Thir earthlie Charge: Of these the vigilance
6889: I dread, and to elude, thus wrapt in mist
6890: Of midnight vapor glide obscure, and prie
6891: In every Bush and Brake, where hap may finde
6892: The Serpent sleeping, in whose mazie foulds
6893: To hide me, and the dark intent I bring.
6894: O foul descent! that I who erst contended
6895: With Gods to sit the highest, am now constraind
6896: Into a Beast, and mixt with bestial slime,
6897: This essence to incarnate and imbrute,
6898: That to the hight of Deitie aspir'd;
6899: But what will not Ambition and Revenge
6900: Descend to? who aspires must down as low
6901: As high he soard, obnoxious first or last
6902: To basest things.  Revenge, at first though sweet,
6903: Bitter ere long back on it self recoiles;
6904: Let it; I reck not, so it light well aim'd,
6905: Since higher I fall short, on him who next
6906: Provokes my envie, this new Favorite
6907: Of Heav'n, this Man of Clay, Son of despite,
6908: Whom us the more to spite his Maker rais'd
6909: From dust: spite then with spite is best repaid.
6910: ¶So saying, through each Thicket Danck or Drie,
6911: Like a black mist low creeping, he held on
6912: His midnight search, where soonest he might finde
6913: The Serpent: him fast sleeping soon he found
6914: In Labyrinth of many a round self-rowl'd,
6915: His head the midst, well stor'd with suttle wiles:
6916: Not yet in horrid Shade or dismal Den,
6917: Not nocent yet, but on the grassie Herbe
6918: Fearless unfeard he slept: in at his Mouth
6919: The Devil enterd, and his brutal sense,
6920: In heart or head, possessing soon inspir'd
6921: With act intelligential; but his sleep
6922: Disturbd not, waiting close th' approach of Morn.
6923: Now whenas sacred Light began to dawne
6924: In *Eden* on the humid Flours, that breathd
6925: Thir morning Incense, when all things that breath,
6926: From th' Earths great Altar send up silent praise
6927: To the Creator, and his Nostrils fill
6928: With gratefull Smell, forth came the human pair
6929: And joynd thir vocal Worship to the Quire
6930: Of Creatures wanting voice, that done, partake
6931: The season, prime for sweetest Sents and Aires:
6932: Then commune how that day they best may ply
6933: Thir growing work: for much thir work outgrew
6934: The hands dispatch of two Gardning so wide.
6935: And *Eve* first to her Husband thus began.
6936: ¶*Adam*, well may we labour still to dress
6937: This Garden, still to tend Plant, Herb and Flour.
6938: Our pleasant task enjoyn'd, but till more hands
6939: Aid us, the work under our labour grows,
6940: Luxurious by restraint; what we by day
6941: Lop overgrown, or prune, or prop, or bind,
6942: One night or two with wanton growth derides
6943: Tending to wilde.  Thou therefore now advise
6944: Or hear what to my mind first thoughts present,
6945: Let us divide our labours, thou where choice
6946: Leads thee, or where most needs, whether to wind
6947: The Woodbine round this Arbour, or direct
6948: The clasping Ivie where to climb, while I
6949: In yonder Spring of Roses intermixt
6950: With Myrtle, find what to redress till Noon:
6951: For while so near each other thus all day
6952: Our task we choose, what wonder if no near
6953: Looks intervene and smiles, or object new
6954: Casual discourse draw on, which intermits
6955: Our dayes work brought to little, though begun
6956: Early, and th' hour of Supper comes unearn'd.
6958: Sole *Eve*, Associate sole, to me beyond
6959: Compare above all living Creatures deare,
6960: Well hast thou motion'd, wel thy thoughts imployd
6961: How we might best fulfill the work which here
6962: God hath assign'd us, nor of me shalt pass
6963: Unprais'd: for nothing lovelier can be found
6964: In woman, then to studie houshold good,
6965: And good workes in her Husband to promote.
6966: Yet not so strictly hath our Lord impos'd
6967: Labour, as to debarr us when we need
6968: Refreshment, whether food, or talk between,
6969: Food of the mind, or this sweet intercourse
6970: Of looks and smiles, for smiles from Reason flow,
6971: To brute deni'd, and are of Love the food,
6972: Love not the lowest end of human life.
6973: For not to irksom toile, but to delight
6974: He made us, and delight to Reason joyn'd.
6975: These paths and Bowers doubt not but our joynt
