6976: Will keep from Wilderness with ease, as wide
6977: As we need walk, till younger hands ere long
6978: Assist us: But if much converse perhaps
6979: Thee satiate, to short absence I could yeild.
6980: For solitude somtimes is best societie,
6981: And short retirement urges sweet returne.
6982: But other doubt possesses me, least harm
6983: Befall thee sever'd from me; for thou knowst
6984: What hath bin warn'd us, what malicious Foe
6985: Envying our happiness, and of his own
6986: Despairing, seeks to work us woe and shame
6987: By sly assault; and somwhere nigh at hand
6988: Watches, no doubt, with greedy hope to find
6989: His wish and best advantage, us asunder,
6990: Hopeless to circumvent us joynd, where each
6991: To other speedie aide might lend at need;
6992: Whether his first design be to withdraw
6993: Our fealtie from God, or to disturb
6994: Conjugal Love, then which perhaps no bliss
6995: Enjoy'd by us excites his envie more;
6996: Or this, or worse, leave not the faithful side
6997: That gave thee being, stil shades thee and protects.
6998: The Wife, where danger or dishonour lurks,
6999: Safest and seemliest by her Husband staies,
7000: Who guards her, or with her the worst endures.
7002: As one who loves, and some unkindness meets,
7003: With sweet austeer composure thus reply'd.
7004: ¶Ofspring of Heav'n and Earth, and all Earths Lord,
7005: That such an enemie we have, who seeks
7006: Our ruin, both by thee informd I learne,
7007: And from the parting Angel over-heard
7008: As in a shadie nook I stood behind,
7009: Just then returnd at shut of Evening Flours.
7010: But that thou shouldst my firmness therefore doubt
7011: To God or thee, because we have a foe
7012: May tempt it, I expected not to hear.
7013: His violence thou fearst not, being such,
7014: As wee, not capable of death or paine,
7015: Can either not receave, or can repell.
7016: His fraud is then thy fear, which plain inferrs
7017: Thy equal fear that my firm Faith and Love
7018: Can by his fraud be shak'n or seduc't;
7019: Thoughts, which how found they harbour in thy Brest,
7020: *Adam*, misthought of her to thee so dear?
7022: Daughter of God and Man, immortal *Eve*,
7023: For such thou art, from sin and blame entire:
7024: Not diffident of thee do I dissuade
7025: Thy absence from my sight, but to avoid
7026: Th' attempt it self, intended by our Foe.
7027: For hee who tempts, though in vain, at least asperses
7028: The tempted with dishonour foul, suppos'd
7029: Not incorruptible of Faith, not prooff
7030: Against temptation: thou thy self with scorne
7031: And anger wouldst resent the offer'd wrong,
7032: Though ineffectual found: misdeem not then,
7033: If such affront I labour to avert
7034: From thee alone, which on us both at once
7035: The Enemie, though bold, will hardly dare,
7036: Or daring, first on mee th' assault shall light.
7037: Nor thou his malice and false guile contemn;
7038: Suttle he needs must be, who could seduce
7039: Angels, nor think superfluous others aid.
7040: I from the influence of thy looks receave
7041: Access in every Vertue, in thy sight
7042: More wise, more watchful, stronger, if need were
7043: Of outward strength; while shame, thou looking on,
7044: Shame to be overcome or over-reacht
7045: Would utmost vigor raise, and rais'd unite.
7046: Why shouldst not thou like sense within thee feel
7047: When I am present, and thy trial choose
7048: With me, best witness of thy Vertue tri'd.
7050: And Matrimonial Love, but *Eve*, who thought
7051: Less attributed to her Faith sincere,
7052: Thus her reply with accent sweet renewd.
7053: ¶If this be our condition, thus to dwell
7054: In narrow circuit strait'nd by a Foe,
7055: Suttle or violent, we not endu'd
7056: Single with like defence, wherever met,
7057: How are we happie, still in fear of harm?
7058: But harm precedes not sin: onely our Foe
7059: Tempting affronts us with his foul esteem
7060: Of our integritie: his foul esteeme
7061: Sticks no dishonor on our Front, but turns
7062: Foul on himself; then wherfore shund or feard
7063: By us? who rather double honour gaine
7064: From his surmise prov'd false, finde peace within,
7065: Favour from Heav'n, our witness from th' event.
7066: And what is Faith, Love, Vertue unassaid
7068: Let us not then suspect our happie State
7069: Left so imperfet by the Maker wise,
7070: As not secure to single or combin'd.
7071: Fraile is our happiness, if this be so,
7074: O Woman, best are all things as the will
7075: Of God ordaind them, his creating hand
7077: Of all that he Created, much less Man,
7078: Or ought that might his happie State secure,
7079: Secure from outward force; within himself
7080: The danger lies, yet lies within his power:
7081: Against his will he can receave no harme.
7082: But God left free the Will, for what obeyes
7083: Reason, is free, and Reason he made right,
7084: But bid her well beware, and still erect,
7085: Least by some faire appeering good surpris'd
7086: She dictate false, and missinforme the Will
7087: To do what God expresly hath forbid.
7088: Not then mistrust, but tender love enjoynes,
7089: That I should mind thee oft, and mind thou me.
7090: Firm we subsist, yet possible to swerve,
7091: Since Reason not impossibly may meet
7092: Some specious object by the Foe subornd,
7094: Not keeping strictest watch, as she was warnd.
7095: Seek not temptation then, which to avoide
7096: Were better, and most likelie if from mee
7097: Thou sever not; Trial will come unsought.
7098: Wouldst thou approve thy constancie, approve
7099: First thy obedience; th' other who can know,
7100: Not seeing thee attempted, who attest?
7101: But if thou think, trial unsought may finde
7102: Us both securer then thus warnd thou seemst,
7103: Go; for thy stay, not free, absents thee more;
7104: Go in thy native innocence, relie
7105: On what thou hast of vertue, summon all,
7106: For God towards thee hath done his part, do thine.
7107: ¶So spake the Patriarch of Mankinde, but *Eve*
7108: Persisted, yet submiss, though last, repli'd.
7109: ¶With thy permission then, and thus forewarnd
7110: Chiefly by what thy own last reasoning words
7111: Touchd onely, that our trial, when least sought,
7112: May finde us both perhaps farr less prepar'd,
7113: The willinger I goe, nor much expect
7114: A Foe so proud will first the weaker seek;
7115: So bent, the more shall shame him his repulse.
7116: Thus saying, from her Husbands hand her hand
7117: Soft she withdrew, and like a Wood-Nymph light
7119: Betook her to the Groves, but *Delia's* self
7120: In gate surpass'd and Goddess-like deport,
7121: Though not as shee with Bow and Quiver armd,
7122: But with such Gardning Tools as Are yet rude,
7123: Guiltless of fire had formd, or Angels brought,
7125: Likest she seemd, *Pomona* when she fled
7128: Her long with ardent look his *Eye* pursu'd
7129: Delighted, but desiring more her stay.
7130: Oft he to her his charge of quick returne,
7131: Repeated, shee to him as oft engag'd
7132: To be returnd by Noon amid the Bowre,
7133: And all things in best order to invite
7135: O much deceav'd, much failing, hapless *Eve*,
7136: Of thy presum'd return! event perverse!
7137: Thou never from that houre in Paradise
7138: Foundst either sweet repast, or found repose;
7139: Such ambush hid among sweet Flours and Shades
7141: To intercept thy way, or send thee back
7142: Despoild of Innocence, of Faith, of Bliss.
7143: For now, and since first break of dawne the Fiend,
7144: Meer Serpent in appearance, forth was come,
7145: And on his Quest, where likeliest he might finde
7146: The onely two of Mankinde, but in them
7147: The whole included Race, his purposd prey.
7148: In Bowre and Field he sought, where any tuft
7149: Of Grove or Garden-Plot more pleasant lay,
7150: Thir tendance or Plantation for delight,
7151: By Fountain or by shadie Rivulet
7152: He sought them both, but wish'd his hap might find
7153: *Eve* separate, he wish'd, but not with hope
7154: Of what so seldom chanc'd, when to his wish,
7155: Beyond his hope, *Eve* separate he spies,
7156: Veild in a Cloud of Fragrance, where she stood,
7157: Half spi'd, so thick the Roses bushing round
7158: About her glowd, oft stooping to support
7159: Each Flour of slender stalk, whose head though gay
7160: Carnation, Purple, Azure, or spect with Gold,
7161: Hung drooping unsustaind, them she upstaies
7162: Gently with Mirtle band, mindless the while,
7163: Her self, though fairest unsupported Flour,
7164: From her best prop so farr, and storn so nigh.
7165: Neererhe drew, and many a walk travers'd
7166: Of stateliest Covert, Cedar, Pine, or Palme,
7167: Then voluble and bold, now hid, now seen
7169: Imborderd on each Bank, the hand of *Eve*:
7170: Spot more delicious then those Gardens feign'd
7173: Or that, not Mystic, where the Sapient King
7174: Held dalliance with his faire *Egyptian* Spouse.
7175: Much hee the Place admir'd, the Person more.
7176: As one who long in populous City pent,
7177: Where Houses thick and Sewers annoy the Aire,
7178: Forth issuing on a Summers Morn, to breathe
7179: Among the pleasant Villages and Farmes
7180: Adjoynd, from each thing met conceaves delight,
7181: The smell of Grain, or tedded Grass, or Kine,
7182: Or Dairie, each rural sight, each rural sound;
7183: If chance with Nymphlike step fair Virgin pass,
7184: What pleasing seemd, for her now pleases more,
7185: She most, and in her look summs all Delight.
7186: Such Pleasure took the Serpent to behold
7187: This Flourie Plat, the sweet recess of *Eve*
7188: Thus earlie, thus alone; her Heav'nly forme
7189: Angelic, but more soft, and Feminine,
7190: Her graceful Innocence, her every Aire
7191: Of gesture or lest action overawd
7192: His Malice, and with rapine sweet bereav'd
7193: His fierceness of the fierce intent it brought:
7194: That space the Evil one abstracted stood
7195: From his own evil, and for the time remaind
7197: Of guile, of hate, of envie, of revenge;
7198: But the hot Hell that alwayes in him burnes,
7199: Though in mid Heav'n, soon ended his delight,
7200: And tortures him now more, the more he sees
7201: Of pleasure not for him ordain'd: then soon
7202: Fierce hate he recollects, and all his thoughts
7204: ¶Thoughts, whither have he led me, with what sweet
7206: What hither brought us, hate, not love, nor hope
7207: Of Paradise for Hell, hope here to taste
7208: Of pleasure, but all pleasure to destroy,
7209: Save what is in destroying, other joy
7210: To me is lost.  Then let me not let pass
7211: Occasion which now smiles, behold alone
7212: The Woman, opportune to all attempts,
7213: Her Husband, for I view far round, not nigh,
7214: Whose higher intellectual more I shun,
7215: And strength, of courage hautie, and of limb
7216: Heroic built, though of terrestrial mould,
7217: Foe not informidable, exempt from wound,
7218: I not; so much hath Hell debas'd, and paine
7219: Infeebl'd me, to what I was in Heav'n.
7220: Shee fair, divinely fair, fit Love for Gods,
7221: Not terrible, though terrour be in Love
7222: And beautie, not approacht by stronger hate,
7223: Hate stronger, under shew of Love well feign'd,
7224: The way which to her ruin now I tend.
7225: ¶So spake the Enemie of Mankind, enclos'd
7226: In Serpent, Inmate bad, and toward *Eve*
7227: Address'd his way, not with indented wave,
7228: Prone on the ground, as since, but on his reare,
7229: Circular base of rising foulds, that tour'd
7230: Fould above fould a surging Maze, his Head
7231: Crested aloft, and Carbuncle his Eyes;
7232: With burnisht Neck of verdant Gold, erect
7233: Amidst his circling Spires, that on the grass
7234: Floted redundant: pleasing was his shape,
7235: And lovely, never since of Serpent kind
7236: Lovelier, not those that in *Illyria* chang'd
7240: Hee with *Olympias*, this with her who bore
7241: *Scipio* the highth of *Rome*.  With tract oblique
7242: At first, as one who sought access, but feard
7243: To interrupt, side-long he works his way.
7244: As when a Ship by skilful Stearsman wrought
7245: Nigh Rivers mouth or Foreland, where the Wind
7246: Veres oft, as oft so steers, and shifts her Saile;
7247: So varied hee, and of his tortuous Traine
7248: Curld many a wanton wreath in sight of *Eve*,
7249: To lure her Eye; shee busied heard the sound
7250: Of rusling Leaves, but minded not, as us'd
7251: To such disport before her through the Field,
7252: From every Beast, more duteous at her call,
7253: Then at *Circean* call the Herd disguis'd.
7254: Hee boulder now, uncall'd before her stood;
7255: But as in gaze admiring: Oft he bowd
7256: His turret Crest, and sleek enamel'd Neck,
7257: Fawning, and lick'd the ground whereon she trod.
7258: His gentle dumb expression turnd at length
7259: The Eye of *Eve* to mark his play; he glad
7260: Of her attention gaind, with Serpent Tongue
7261: Organic, or impulse of vocal Air,
7264: Thou canst, who art sole Wonder, much less arm
7265: Thy looks, the Heav'n of mildness, with disdain,
7266: Displeas'd that I approach thee thus, and gaze
7267: Insatiate, I thus single; nor have feard
7268: Thy awful brow, more awful thus retir'd.
7269: Fairest resemblance of thy Maker faire,
7270: Thee all living things gaze on, all things thine
7271: By gift, and thy Celestial Beautie adore
7272: With ravishment beheld, there best beheld
7274: In this enclosure wild, these Beasts among,
7275: Beholders rude, and shallow to discerne
7276: Half what in thee is fair, one man except,
7277: Who sees thee? (and what is one?) who shouldst be seen
7278: A Goddess among Gods, ador'd and serv'd
7279: By Angels numberless, thy daily Train.
7280: ¶So gloz'd the Tempter, and his Proem tun'd;
7281: Into the Heart of *Eve* his words made way,
7282: Though at the voice much marveling; at length
7283: Not unamaz'd she thus in answer spake.
7284: What may this mean?  Language of Man pronounc't
7285: By Tongue of Brute, and human sense exprest?
7286: The first at lest of these I thought deni'd
7287: To Beasts, whom God on their Creation-Day
7288: Created mute to all articulat sound;
7289: The latter I demurre, for in thir looks
7290: Much reason, and in thir actions oft appeers.
7291: Thee, Serpent, suttlest beast of all the field
7292: I knew, but not with human voice endu'd;
7293: Redouble then this miracle, and say,
7294: How cam'st thou speakable of mute, and how
7295: To me so friendly grown above the rest
7296: Of brutal kind, that daily are in sight?
7297: Say, for such wonder claims attention due.
7298: ¶To whom the guileful Tempter thus reply'd.
7299: Empress of this fair World, resplendent *Eve*,
7300: Easie to mee it is to tell thee all
7301: What thou commandst, and right thou shouldst be obeyd:
7302: I was at first as other Beasts that graze
7303: The trodden Herb, of abject thoughts and low,
7304: As was my food, nor aught but food discern'd
7305: Or Sex, and apprehended nothing high:
7306: Till on a day roaving the field, I chanc'd
7307: A goodly Tree farr distant to behold
7308: Loaden with fruit of fairest colours mixt,
7309: Ruddie and Gold: I nearer drew to gaze;
7310: When from the boughes a savorie odour blow'n,
7311: Grateful to appetite, more pleas'd my sense
7312: Then smell of sweetest Fenel, or the Teats
7313: Of Ewe or Goat dropping with Milk at Eevn,
7314: Unsuckt of Lamb or Kid, that tend thir play.
7315: To satisfie the sharp desire I had
7316: Of tasting those fair Apples, I resolv'd
7317: Not to deferr; hunger and thirst at once,
7318: Powerful perswaders, quick'nd at the scent
7319: Of that alluring fruit, urg'd me so keene.
7320: About the Mossie Trunk I wound me soon,
7321: For high from ground the branches would require
7322: Thy utmost reach or *Adams*: Round the Tree
7323: All other Beasts that saw, with like desire
7324: Longing and envying stood, but could not reach.
7325: Amid the Tree now got, where plentie hung
7326: Tempting so nigh, to pluck and eat my fill
7327: I spar'd not, for such pleasure till that hour
7328: At Feed or Fountain never had I found.
7329: Sated at length, ere long I might perceave
7330: Strange alteration in me, to degree
7331: Of Reason in my inward Powers, and Speech
7332: Wanted not long, though to this shape retaind.
7333: Thenceforth to Speculations high or deep
7334: I turnd my thoughts, and with capacious mind
7335: Considerd all things visible in Heav'n,
7336: Or Earth, or Middle, all things fair and good;
7337: But all that fair and good in thy Divine
7338: Semblance, and in thy Beauties heav'nly Ray
7339: United I beheld; no Fair to thine
7341: Mee thus, though importune perhaps, to come
7342: And gaze, and worship thee of right declar'd
7344: ¶So talk'd the spirited sly Snake; and *Eve*
7345: Yet more amaz'd unwarie thus reply'd.
7347: The vertue of that Fruit, in thee first prov'd:
7348: But say, where grows the Tree, from hence how far?
7349: For many are the Trees of God that grow
7350: In Paradise, and various, yet unknown
7351: To us, in such abundance lies our choice,
7352: As leaves a greater store of Fruit untoucht,
7354: Grow up to thir provision, and more hands
7355: Help to disburden Nature of her Bearth.
7356: ¶To whom the wilie Adder, blithe and glad.
7357: Empress, the way is readie, and not long,
7358: Beyond a row of Myrtles, on a Flat,
7359: Fast by a Fountain, one small Thicket past
7360: Of blowing Myrrh and Balme; if thou accept
7361: My conduct, I can bring thee thither soon.
7362: ¶Lead then, said *Eve*.  Hee leading swiftly rowld
7363: In tangles, and make intricate seem strait,
7364: To mischief swift.  Hope elevates, and joy
7365: Bright'ns his Crest, as when a wandring Fire
7366: Compact of unctuous vapor, which the Night
7367: Condenses, and the cold invirons round,
7368: Kindl'd through agitation to a Flame,
7369: Which oft, they say, some evil Spirit attends,
7370: Hovering and blazing with delusive Light,
7371: Misleads th' amaz'd Night-wanderer from his way
7372: To Boggs and Mires, & oft through Pond or Poole,
7373: There swallow'd up and lost, from succour farr.
7374: So glister'd the dire Snake and into fraud
7375: Led *Eve* our credulous Mother, to the Tree
7376: Of prohibition, root of all our woe;
7377: Which when she saw, thus to her guide she spake.
7378: ¶Serpent, we might have spar'd our coming hither,
7379: Fruitless to me, though Fruit be here to excess,
7380: The credit of whose vertue rest with thee,
7381: Wondrous indeed, if cause of such effects.
7382: But of this Tree we may not taste nor touch;
7383: God so commanded, and left that Command
7384: Sole Daughter of his voice; the rest, we live
7385: Law to our selves, our Reason is our Law.
7387: Indeed? hath God then said that of the Fruit
7388: Of all these Garden Trees ye shall not eate,
7389: Yet Lords declar'd of all in Earth or Aire?
7390: ¶To whom thus *Eve* yet sinless.  Of the Fruit
7391: Of each Tree in the Garden we may eate,
7392: But of the Fruit of this fair Tree amidst
7393: The Garden, God hath said, Ye shall not eate
7394: Thereof, nor shall ye touch it, least ye die.
7395: ¶She scarse had said, though brief, when now more bold
7396: The Tempter, but with shew of Zeale and Love
7397: To Man, and indignation at his wrong,
7398: New part puts on, and as to passion mov'd,
7399: Fluctuats disturbd, yet comely, and in act
7400: Rais'd, as of som great matter to begin.
7401: As when of old som Orator renound
7403: Flourishd, since mute, to som great cause addrest,
7404: Stood in himself collected, while each part,
7405: Motion, each act won audience ere the tongue,
7406: Somtimes in highth began, as no delay
7407: Of Preface brooking through his Zeal of Right.
7408: So standing, moving, or to highth upgrown
7409: The Tempter all impassiond thus began.
7411: Mother of Science, Now I feel thy Power
7412: Within me cleere, not onely to discerne
7413: Things in thir Causes, but to trace the wayes
7414: Of highest Agents, deemd however wise.
7415: Queen of this Universe, doe not believe
7416: Those rigid threats of Death; ye shall not Die:
7417: How should ye? by the Fruit? it gives you Life
7418: To Knowledge?  By the Threatner, look on mee,
7419: Mee who have touch'd and tasted, yet both live,
7420: And life more perfet have attaind then Fate
7421: Meant mee, by ventring higher then my Lot.
7422: Shall that be shut to Man, which to the Beast
7423: Is open? or will God incense his ire
7424: For such a pretty Trespass, and not praise
7425: Rather your dauntless vertue, whom the pain
7426: Of Death denounc't, whatever thing Death be,
7427: Deterrd not from atchieving what might leade
7428: To happier life, knowledge of Good and Evil;
7429: Of good, how just? of evil, if what is evil
7430: Be real, why not known, since easier shunnd?
7431: God therefore cannot hurt ye, and be just;
7432: Not just, not God; not feard then, nor obeid:
7433: Your feare it self of Death removes the feare.
7434: Why then was this forbid?  Why but to awe,
7435: Why but to keep ye low and ignorant,
7436: His worshippers; he knows that in the day
7437: Ye Eate thereof, your Eyes that seem so cleere,
7438: Yet are but dim, shall perfetly be then
7439: Op'nd and cleerd, and ye shall be as Gods,
7440: Knowing both Good and Evil as they know.
7441: That ye should be as Gods, since I as Man,
7442: Internal Man, is but proportion meet,
7443: I of brute human, yee of human Gods.
7444: So ye shalt die perhaps, by putting off
7445: Human, to put on Gods, death to be wisht,
7446: Though threat'nd, which no worse then this can bring
7447: And what are Gods that Man may not become
7449: The Gods are first, and that advantage use
7450: On our belief, that all from them proceeds,
7451: I question it, for this fair Earth I see,
7452: Warm'd by the Sun, producing every kind,
7453: Them nothing: If they all things, who enclos'd
7454: Knowledge of Good and Evil in this Tree,
7455: That whoso eats thereof, forthwith attains
7456: Wisdom without their leave? and wherein lies
7457: Th' offence, that Man should thus attain to know?
7458: What can your knowledge hurt him, or this Tree
7459: Impart against his will if all be his?
7460: Or is it envie, and can envie dwell
7461: In heav'nly brests? these, these and many more
7462: Causes import your need of this fair Fruit.
7463: Goddess humane, reach then, and freely taste.
7464: ¶He ended, and his words replete with guile
7465: Into her heart too easie entrance won:
7466: Fixt on the Fruit she gaz'd, which to behold
7467: Might tempt alone, and in her ears the sound
7468: Yet rung of his perswasive words, impregn'd
7469: With Reason, to her seeming, and with Truth;
7470: Meanwhile the hour of Noon drew on, and wak'd
7471: An eager appetite, rais'd by the smell
7472: So savorie of that Fruit, which with desire,
7473: Inclinable now grown to touch or taste,
7474: Sollicited her longing eye; yet first
7475: Pausing a while, thus to her self she mus'd.
7476: ¶Great are thy Vertues, doubtless, best of Fruits,
7477: Though kept from Man, & worthy to be admir'd,
7478: Whose taste, too long forborn, at first assay
7479: Gave elocution to the mute, and taught
7480: The Tongue not made for Speech to speak thy praise:
7481: Thy praise hee also who forbids thy use,
7482: Conceales not from us, naming thee the Tree
7483: Of Knowledge, knowledge both of good and evil;
7484: Forbids us then to taste, but his forbidding
7485: Commends thee more, while it inferrs the good
7486: By thee communicated, and our want:
7487: For good unknown, sure is not had, or had
7488: And yet unknown, is as not had at all.
7489: In plain then, what forbids he but to know,
7490: Forbids us good, forbids us to be wise?
7491: Such prohibitions binde not.  But if Death
7492: Bind us with after-bands, what profits then
7493: Our inward freedom?  In the day we eate
7494: Of this fair Fruit, our doom is, we shall die.
7495: How dies the Serpent? hee hath eat'n and lives,
7496: And knows, and speaks, and reasons, and discernes,
7497: Irrational till then.  For us alone
7498: Was death invented? or to us deni'd
7499: This intellectual food, for beasts reserv'd?
7500: For Beasts it seems: yet that one Beast which first
7501: Hath tasted, envies not, but brings with joy
7502: The good befall'n him, Author unsuspect,
7503: Friendly to man, farr from deceit or guile.
7504: What fear I then, rather what know to feare
7505: Under this ignorance of Good and Evil,
7506: Of God or Death, of Law or Penaltie?
7507: Here grows the Cure of all, this Fruit Divine,
7508: Fair to the Eye, inviting to the Taste,
7509: Of vertue to make wise: what hinders then
7510: To reach, and feed at once both Bodie and Mind?
7511: ¶So saying, her rash hand in evil hour
7512: Forth reaching to the Fruit, she pluck'd, she eat:
7513: Earth felt the wound, and Nature from her seat
7514: Sighing through all her Works gave signs of woe,
7515: That all was lost.  Back to the Thicket slunk
7516: The guiltie Serpent, and well might, for *Eve*
7517: Intent now wholly on her taste, naught else
7518: Regarded, such delight till then, as seemd,
7519: In Fruit she never tasted, whether true
7520: Or fansied so, through expectation high
7521: Of knowledg, nor was God-head from her thought.
7523: And knew not eating Death: Satiate at length,
7524: And hight'nd as with Wine, jocond and boon,
7525: Thus to her self she pleasingly began.
7526: ¶O Sovran, vertuous, precious of all Trees
7529: And thy fair Fruit let hang, as to no end
7530: Created; but henceforth my early care,
7531: Not without Song, each Morning, and due praise
7532: Shall tend thee, and the fertil burden ease
7533: Of thy full branches offer'd free to all;
7534: Till dieted by thee I grow mature
7535: In knowledge, as the Gods who all things know;
7536: Though others envie what they cannot give;
7537: For had the gift bin theirs, it had not here
7538: Thus grown.  Experience, next to thee I owe,
7539: Best guide; not following thee, I had remaind
7540: In ignorance, thou op'nst Wisdoms way,
7541: And giv'st access, though secret she retire.
7542: And I perhaps am secret; Heav'n is high,
7543: High and remote to see from thence distinct
7544: Each thing on Earth; and other care perhaps
7545: May have diverted from continual watch
7546: Our great Forbidder, safe with all his Spies
7547: About him.  But to *Adam* in what sort
7548: Shall I appeer? shall I to him make known
7549: As yet my change, and give him to partake
7550: Full happiness with mee, or rather not,
7551: But keep the odds of Knowledge in my power
7552: Without Copartner? so to add what wants
7553: In Femal Sex, the more to draw his Love,
7554: And render me more equal, and perhaps
7556: Superior; for inferior who is free?
7557: This may be well: but what if God have seen,
7558: And Death ensue? then I shall be no more,
7560: Shall live with her enjoying, I extinct;
7561: A death to think.  Confirm'd then I resolve,
7562: *Adam* shall share with me in bliss or woe:
7563: So dear I love him, that with him all deaths
7564: I could endure; without him live no life.
7565: ¶So saying, from the Tree her step she turnd,
7566: But first low Reverence don, as to the power
7567: That dwelt within, whose presence had infus'd
7568: Into the plant sciential sap, deriv'd
7569: From Nectar, drink of Gods.  *Adam* the while
7570: Waiting desirous her return, had wove
7571: Of choicest Flours a Garland to adorne
7572: Her Tresses, and her rural labours crown
7573: As Reapers oft are wont thir Harvest Queen.
7574: Great joy he promis'd to his thoughts, and new
7575: Solace in her return, so long delay'd;
7576: Yet oft his heart, divine of somthing ill,
7577: Misgave him; hee the faultring measure felt;
7578: And forth to meet her went, the way she took
7579: That Morn when first they parted; by the Tree
7580: Of Knowledge he must pass, there he her met,
7581: Scarse from the Tree returning; in her hand
7582: A bough of fairest fruit that downie smil'd,
7583: New gatherd, and ambrosial smell diffus'd.
7584: To him she hasted, in her face excuse
7585: Came Prologue, and Apologie to prompt,
7586: Which with bland words at will she thus addrest.
7587: ¶Hast thou not wonderd, *Adam*, at my stay?
7588: Thee I have misst, and thought it long, depriv'd
7589: Thy presence, agonie of love till now
7590: Not felt, nor shall be twice, for never more
7591: Mean I to trie, what rash untri'd I sought,
7592: The paine of absence from thy sight.  But strange
7593: Hath bin the cause, and wonderful to heare:
7594: This Tree is not as we are told, a Tree
7595: Of danger tasted, nor to evil unknown
7596: Op'ning the way, but of Divine effect
7597: To open Eyes, and make them Gods who taste;
7598: And hath bin tasted such; the Serpent wise,
7599: Or not restraind as wee, or not obeying,
7600: Hath eat'n of the fruit, and is become,
7601: Not dead, as we are threatn'd, but thenceforth
7602: Endu'd with human voice and human sense,
7603: Reasoning to admiration, and with mee
7604: Perswasively hath so prevaild, that I
7605: Have also tasted, and have also found
7606: Th' effects to correspond, opener mine Eyes,
7607: Dimm erst, dilated Spirits, ampler Heart,
7608: And growing up to Godhead; which for thee
7609: Chiefly I sought, without thee can despise.
7610: For bliss, as thou hast part, to me is bliss,
7611: Tedious, unshar'd with thee, and odious soon.
7612: Thou therefore also taste, that equal Lot
7613: May joyne us, equal Joy, as equal Love;
7614: Least thou not tasting, different degree
7615: Disjoyne us, and I then too late renounce
7616: Deitie for thee, when Fate will not permit.
7617: ¶Thus *Eve* with Countnance blithe her storie told;
7618: But in her Cheek distemper flushing glowd.
7619: On th' other side, *Adam*, soon as he heard
7620: The fatal Trespass don by *Eve*, amaz'd,
7621: Astonied stood and Blank, while horror chill
7622: Ran through his veins, and all his joynts relax'd;
7623: From his slack hand the Garland wreath'd for *Eve*
7624: Down drop'd, and all the faded Roses shed:
7625: Speechless he stood and pale, till thus at length
7626: First to himself he inward silence broke.
7627: ¶O fairest of Creation, last and best
7628: Of all Gods Works, Creature in whom excell'd
7629: Whatever can to fight or thought be found,
7630: Holy, divine, good, amiable, or sweet!
7631: How art thou lost, how on a sudden lost,
7632: Defac't, deflourd, and now to Death devote?
7633: Rather how hast thou yeelded to transgress
7634: The strict forbiddance, how to violate
7635: The sacred Fruit forbidd'n! som cursed fraud
7636: Of Enemie hath beguil'd thee, yet unknown,
7637: And mee with thee hath ruind, for with thee
7638: Certain my resolution is to Die;
7639: How can I live without thee, how forgoe
7640: Thy sweet Converse and Love so dearly joyn'd,
7641: To live again in these wilde Woods forlorn?
7642: Should God create another *Eve*, and I
7643: Another Rib afford, yet loss of thee
7644: Would never from my heart; no no, I feel
7645: The Link of Nature draw me: Flesh of Flesh,
7646: Bone of my Bone thou art, and from thy State
7647: Mine never shall be parted, bliss or woe.
7648: ¶So having said, as one from sad dismay
7651: Thus in calme mood his Words to *Eve* he turnd.
7653: And peril great provok't, who thus hast dar'd
7654: Had it bin onely coveting to Eye
7655: That sacred Fruit, sacred to abstinence,
7656: Much more to taste it under banne to touch.
7657: But past who can recall, or don undoe?
7658: Not God omnipotent, for Fate, yet so
7659: Perhaps thou shalt not Die, perhaps the Fact
7660: Is not so hainous now, foretasted Fruit,
7661: Profan'd first by the Serpent, by him first
7662: Made common and unhallowd: ere one tastes;
7663: Nor yet on him found deadly; he yet lives,
7664: Lives, as thou saidst, and gaines to live as Man
7665: Higher degree of Life, inducement strong
7666: To us, as likely tasting to attaine
7668: But to be Gods, or Angels Demi-gods.
7669: Nor can I think that God, Creator wise,
7670: Though threatning, will in earnest so destroy
7671: Us his prime Creatures, dignifi'd so high,
7672: Set over all his Works, which in our Fall,
7673: For us created, needs with us must faile,
7674: Dependent made; so God shall uncreate,
7675: Be frustrate, do, undo, and labour loose,
7676: Not well conceav'd of God, who though his Power
7677: Creation could repeate, yet would be loath
7678: Us to abolish, least the Adversary
7679: Triumph and say; Fickle their State whom God
7680: Most Favors, who can please him long?  Mee first
7681: He ruind, now Mankind; whom will he next?
7682: Matter of scorne, not to be given the Foe.
7683: However I with thee have fixt my Lot,
7684: Certain to undergoe like doom, if Death
7685: Consort with thee, Death is to mee as Life;
7686: So forcible within my heart I feel
7687: The Bond of Nature draw me to my owne,
7688: My own in thee, for what thou art is mine;
7689: Our State cannot be severd, we are one,
7690: One Flesh; to loose thee were to loose my self.
7692: O glorious trial of exceeding Love,
7694: Ingaging me to emulate, but short
7695: Of thy perfection, how shall I attaine,
7696: *Adam*, from whose deare side I boast me sprung,
7697: And gladly of our Union heare thee speak,
7698: One Heart, one Soul in both; whereof good prooff
7699: This day affords, declaring thee resolvd,
7700: Rather then Death or aught then Death more dread
7701: Shall separate us, linkt in Love so deare,
7702: To undergoe with mee one Guilt, one Crime,
7703: If any be, of tasting this fair Fruit,
7704: Whose vertue, for of good still good proceeds,
7705: Direct, or by occasion hath presented
7706: This happie trial of thy Love, which else
7707: So eminently never had bin known.
7708: Were it I thought Death menac't would ensue
7709: This my attempt, I would sustain alone
7710: The worst, and not perswade thee, rather die
7711: Deserted, then oblige thee with a fact
7712: Pernicious to thy Peace, chiefly assur'd
7713: Remarkably so late of thy so true,
7714: So faithful Love unequald; but I feel
7715: Farr otherwise th' event, not Death, but Life
7716: Augmented, op'nd Eyes, new Hopes, new Joyes,
7717: Taste so Divine, that what of sweet before
7718: Hath toucht my sense, flat seems to this, and harsh.
7720: And fear of Death deliver to the Windes.
7721: ¶So saying, she embrac'd him, and for joy
7722: Tenderly wept, much won that he his Love
7723: Had so enobl'd, as of choice to incurr
7724: Divine displeasure for her sake, or Death.
7726: Such recompence best merits) from the bough
7727: She gave him of that fair enticing Fruit
7728: With liberal hand: he scrupl'd not to eat
7729: Against his better knowledge, not deceav'd,
7730: But fondly overcome with Femal charm.
7731: Earth trembl'd from her entrails, as again
7732: In pangs, and Nature gave a second groan,
7733: Skie lowr'd, and muttering Thunder, som sad drops
7734: Wept at compleating of the mortal Sin
7736: Eating his fill, nor *Eve* to iterate
7737: Her former trespass fear'd, the more to soothe
7738: Him with her lov'd societie, that now
7739: As with new Wine intoxicated both
7740: They swim in mirth, and fansie that they feel
7742: Wherewith to scorn the Earth: but that false Fruit
7745: Began to cast lascivious Eyes, she him
7746: As wantonly repaid; in Lust they burne:
7748: ¶*Eve*, now I see thou art exact of taste,
7749: And elegant, of Sapience no small part,
7750: Since to each meaning savour we apply,
7751: And Palate call judicious; I the praise
7752: Yeild thee, so well this day thou hast purvey'd.
7753: Much pleasure we have lost, while we abstain'd
7754: From this delightful Fruit, nor known till now
7755: True relish, tasting; if such pleasure be
7756: In things to us forbidden, it might be wish'd,
7757: For this one Tree had bin forbidden ten.
7758: But come, so well refresh't, now let us play,
7759: As meet is, after such delicious Fare;
7760: For never did thy Beautie since the day
7761: I saw thee first and wedded thee, adorn'd
7762: With all perfections, so enflame my sense
7763: With ardor to enjoy thee, fairer now
7764: Then ever, bountie of this vertuous Tree.
7765: ¶So said he, and forbore not glance or toy
7767: Of *Eve*, whose Eye darted contagious Fire.
7768: Her hand he seis'd, and to a shadie bank,
7769: Thick overhead with verdant roof imbowr'd
7770: He led her nothing loath; Flours were the Couch,
7772: And Hyacinth, Earths freshest softest lap.
7773: There they thir fill of Love and Loves disport
7774: Took largely, of thir mutual guilt the Seale,
7775: The solace of thir sin, till dewie sleep
7776: Oppress'd them, wearied with thir amorous play.
7777: Soon as the force of that fallacious Fruit,
7779: About thir spirits had plaid, and inmost powers
7780: Made erre, was now exhal'd, and grosser sleep
7781: Bred of unkindly fumes, with conscious dreams
7782: Encumberd, now had left them, up they rose
7783: As from unrest, and each the other viewing,
7784: Soon found thir Eyes how op'nd, and thir minds
7785: How dark'nd; innocence, that as a veile
7786: Had shadow'd them from knowing ill, was gon,
7788: And honour from about them, naked left
7789: To guiltie shame hee cover'd, but his Robe
7790: Uncover'd more.  So rose the *Danite* strong
7793: Shorn of his strength, They destitute and bare
7794: Of all thir vertue: silent, and in face
7795: Confounded long they sate, as struck'n mute,
7796: Till *Adam*, though not less then *Eve* abasht,
7797: At length gave utterance to these words constraind.
7798: ¶O *Eve*, in evil hour thou didst give care
7799: To that false Worm, of whomsoever taught
7800: To counterfet Mans voice, true in our Fall,
7801: False in our promis'd Rising; since our Eyes
7802: Op'nd we find indeed, and find we know
7803: Both Good and Evil, Good lost and Evil got,
7804: Bad Fruit of Knowledge, if this be to know,
7805: Which leaves us naked thus, of Honour void,
7806: Of Innocence, of Faith, of Puritie,
7807: Our wonted Ornaments now soild and staind,
7808: And in our Faces evident the signes
7809: Of foul concupiscence; whence evil store;
7810: Even shame, the last of evils; of the first
7811: Be sure then.  How shall I behold the face
7812: Henceforth of God or Angel, earst with joy
7813: And rapture so oft beheld? those heav'nly shapes
7814: Will dazle now this earthly, with thir blaze
7815: Insufferably bright.  O might I here
7816: In solitude live savage, in some glad
7818: To Starr or Sun-light, spread thir umbrage broad,
7819: And brown as Evening: Cover me ye Pines,
7821: Hide me, where I may never see them more.
7822: But let us now, as in bad plight, devise
7823: What best may for the present serve to hide
7824: The Parts of each from other, that seem most
7825: To shame obnoxious, and unseemliest seen,
7826: Some Tree whose broad smooth Leaves together sowd,
7827: And girded on our loyns, may cover round
7828: Those middle parts, that this new commer, Shame,
7829: There sit not, and reproach us as unclean.
7830: ¶So counsel'd hee, and both together went
7831: Into the thickest Wood, there soon they chose
7832: The Figtree, not that kind for Fruit renown'd,
7833: But such as at this day to *Indians* known
7835: Braunching so broad and long, that in the ground
7836: The bended Twigs take root, and Daughters grow
7837: About the Mother Tree, a Pillard shade
7838: High overarch't, and echoing Walks between;
7839: There oft the *Indian* Herdsman shunning heate
7840: Shelters in coole, and tends his pasturing Herds
7841: At Loopholes cut through thickest shade: Those Leaves
7843: And with what skill they had, together sowd,
7844: To gird thir waste, vain Covering if to hide
7845: Thir guilt and dreaded shame; O how unlike
7846: To that first naked Glorie.  Such of late
7848: With featherd Cincture, naked else and wilde
7849: Among the Trees on Iles and woodie Shores.
7850: Thus fenc't, and as they thought, thir shame in part
7851: Coverd, but not at rest or ease of Mind,
7852: They sate them down to weep, nor onely Teares
7853: Raind at thir Eyes, but high Winds worse within
7854: Began to rise, high Passions, Anger, Hate,
7855: Mistrust, Suspicion, Discord, and shook sore
7856: Thir inward State of Mind, calme Region once
7857: And full of Peace, now tost and turbulent:
7858: For Understanding rul'd not, and the Will
7859: Heard not her lore, both in subjection now
7860: To sensual Appetite, who from beneathe
7862: Superior sway: From thus distemperd brest,
7863: *Adam*, estrang'd in look and alterd stile,
7865: ¶Would thou hadst heark'nd to my words, & stai'd
7866: With me, as I besought thee, when that strange
7867: Desire of wandring this unhappie Morn,
7868: I know not whence possessd thee; we had then
7869: Remaind still happie, not as now, despoild
7870: Of all our good, sham'd, naked, miserable.
7871: Let none henceforth seek needless cause to approve
7872: The Faith they owe; when earnestly they seek
7873: Such proof, conclude, they then begin to faile.
7874: ¶To whom soon mov'd with touch of blame thus *Eve*.
7875: What words have past thy Lips, *Adam* severe,
7876: Imput'st thou that to my default, or will
7877: Of wandering, as thou call'st it, which who knows
7878: But might as ill have happ'nd thou being by,
7879: Or to thy self perhaps: hadst thou bin there,
7880: Or bere th' attempt, thou couldst not have discernd
7881: Fraud in the Serpent, speaking as he spake;
7882: No ground of enmitie between us known,
7883: Why hee should mean me ill, or seek to harme.
7884: Was I to have never parted from thy side?
7885: As good have grown there still a liveless Rib.
7886: Being as I am, why didst not thou the Head
7887: Command me absolutely not to go,
7888: Going into such danger as thou saidst?
7889: Too facil then thou didst not much gainsay,
7890: Nay, didst permit, approve, and fair dismiss.
7891: Hadst thou bin firm and fixt in thy dissent,
7892: Neither had I transgress'd, nor thou with mee.
7894: Is this the Love, is the recompence
7895: Of mine to thee, ingrateful *Eve*, exprest
7896: Immutable when thou wert lost, not I,
7897: Who might have liv'd and joyd immortal bliss,
7898: Yet willingly chose rather Death with thee:
7899: And am I now upbraided, as the cause
7900: Of thy transgressing? not enough severe,
7901: It seems, in thy restraint: what could I more?
7902: I warn'd thee, I admonish'd thee, foretold
7903: The danger, and the lurking Enemie
7904: That lay in wait; beyond this had bin force,
7905: And force upon free Will hath here no place.
7906: But confidence then bore thee on, secure
7907: Either to meet no danger, or to finde
7908: Matter of glorious trial; and perhaps
7909: I also err'd in overmuch admiring
7910: What seemd in thee so perfet, that I thought
7911: No evil durst attempt thee, but I rue
7912: That errour now, which is become my crime,
7913: And thou th' accuser.  Thus it shall befall
7914: Him who to worth in Women overtrusting
7915: Lets her Will rule; restraint she will not brook,
7916: And left to her self, if evil thence ensue,
7917: Shee first his weak indulgence will accuse.
7919: The fruitless hours, but neither self-condemning
7920: And of thir vain contest appeer'd no end.
7924: Of *Satan* done in Paradise, and how
7925: Hee in the Serpent had perverted *Eve*,
7926: Her Husband shee, to taste the fatall fruit,
7927: Was known in Heav'n; for what can scape the Eye
7928: Of God All-seeing, or deceave his Heart
7929: Omniscient, who in all things wise and just,
7930: Hinder'd not *Satan* to attempt the minde
7931: Of Man, with strength entire, and free Will arm'd,
7932: Complete to have discover'd and repulst
7933: Whatever wiles of Foe or seeming Friend.
7934: For still they knew, and ought to have still remember'd
7935: The high Injunction not to taste that Fruit,
7936: Whoever tempted; which they not obeying,
7937: Incurr'd, what could they less, the penaltie,
7938: And manifold in sin, deserv'd to fall.
7939: Up into Heav'n from Paradise in hast
7940: Th' Angelic Guards ascended, mute and sad
7941: For Man, for of his state by this they knew,
7942: Much wondring how the suttle Fiend had stoln
7943: Entrance unseen.  Soon as th' unwelcome news
7944: From Earth arriv'd at Heaven Gate, displeas'd
7945: All were who heard, dim sadness did not spare
7946: That time Celestial visages, yet mixt
7947: With pitie, violated not thir bliss.
7949: Th' ethereal People ran, to hear and know
7950: How all befell: they towards the Throne Supream
7951: Accountable made haste to make appear
7952: With righteous plea, thir utmost vigilance,
7953: And easily approv'd; when the most High
7954: Eternal Father from his secret Cloud,
7955: Amidst in Thunder utter'd thus his voice.
7957: From unsuccessful charge, be not dismaid,
7958: Nor troubl'd at these tidings from the Earth,
7959: Which your sincerest care could not prevent,
7960: Foretold so lately what would come to pass,
7961: When first this Tempter cross'd the Gulf from Hell.
7962: I told ye then he should prevail and speed
7963: On his bad Errand, Man should be seduc't
7964: And flatter'd out of all, believing lies
7965: Against his Maker; no Decree of mine
7967: Or touch with lightest moment of impulse
7968: His free Will, to her own inclining left
7969: In eevn scale.  But fall'n he is, and now
7970: What rests, but that the mortal Sentence pass
7971: On his transgression, Death denounc't that day,
7972: Which he presumes already vain and void,
7973: Because not yet inflicted, as he fear'd,
7974: By some immediate stroak; but soon shall find
7975: Forbearance no acquittance ere day end.
7976: Justice shall not return as bountie scorn'd.
7977: But whom send I to judge them? whom but thee
7978: Vicegerent Son, to thee I have transferr'd
7979: All Judgement, whether in Heav'n, or Earth; or Hell.
7980: Easie it may be seen that I intend
7981: Mercie collegue with Justice, sending thee
7982: Mans Friend, his Mediator, his design'd
7984: And destin'd Man himself to judge Man fall'n.
7985: ¶So spake the Father, and unfoulding bright
7986: Toward the right hand his Glorie, on the Son
7987: Blaz'd forth unclouded Deitie; he full
7989: Express'd, and thus divinely answer'd milde.
7991: Mine both in Heav'n and Earth to do thy will
7992: Supream, that thou in mee thy Son belov'd
7993: Mayst ever rest well pleas'd.  I go to judge
7994: On Earth these thy transgressors, but thou knowst,
7995: Whoever judg'd, the worst on mee must light,
7996: When time shall be, for so I undertook
7997: Before thee; and not repenting, this obtaine
7998: Of right, that I may mitigate thir doom
7999: On me deriv'd, yet I shall temper so
8000: Justice with Mercie, as may illustrate most
8001: Them fully satisfied, and thee appease.
8002: Attendance none shall need, nor Train, where none
8003: Are to behold the Judgement, but the judg'd,
8004: Those two; the third best absent is condemn'd,
8005: Convict by flight, and Rebel to all Law
8006: Conviction to the Serpent none belongs.
8007: ¶Thus saying, from his radiant Seat he rose
8008: Of high collateral glorie: him Thrones and Powers,
8010: Accompanied to Heaven Gate, from whence
8011: *Eden* and all the Coast in prospect lay.
8012: Down he descended strait; the speed of Gods
8013: Time counts not, though with swiftest minutes wing'd.
8014: Now was the Sun in Western cadence low
8015: From Noon, and gentle Aires due at thir hour
8016: To fan the Earth now wak'd, and usher in
8017: The Eevning coole when he from wrauth more coole
8018: Came the mild Judge and Intercessor both
8019: To sentence Man: the voice of God they heard
8020: Now walking in the Garden, by soft windes
8021: Brought to thir Ears, while day declin'd, they heard
8022: And from his presence hid themselves among
8023: The thickest Trees, both Man and Wife, till God
8025: ¶Where art thou *Adam*, wont with joy to meet
8026: My coming seen far off?  I miss thee here,
8027: Not pleas'd, thus entertaind with solitude,
8028: Where obvious dutie erewhile appear'd unsaught:
8029: Or come I less conspicuous, or what change
8030: Absents thee, or what chance detains?  Come forth.
8031: He came, and with him *Eve*, more loth, though first
8032: To offend, discount'nanc't both, and discompos'd;
8033: Love was not in thir looks, either to God
8034: Or to each other, but apparent guilt,
8035: And shame, and perturbation, and despaire,
8036: Anger, and obstinacie, and hate, and guile.
8037: Whence *Adam* faultring long, thus answer'd brief.
8038: ¶I heard thee in the Garden, and of thy voice
8039: Affraid, being naked, hid my self.  To whom
8040: The gracious Judge without revile repli'd.
8041: ¶My voice thou oft hast heard, and hast not fear'd,
8042: But still rejoyc't, how is it now become
8043: So dreadful to thee? that thou art naked, who
8044: Hath told thee? hast thou eaten of the Tree
8045: Whereof I gave thee charge thou shouldst not eat?
8047: O Heav'n! in evil strait this day I stand
8048: Before my Judge, either to undergoe
8049: My self the total Crime, or to accuse
8050: My other self, the partner of my life;
8051: Whose failing, while her Faith to me remaines,
8052: I should conceal, and not expose to blame
8053: By my complaint; but strict necessitie
8055: Least on my head both sin and punishment,
8057: Devolv'd; though should I hold my peace, yet thou
8058: Wouldst easily detect what I conceale.
8059: This Woman whom thou mad'st to be my help,
8060: And gav'st me as thy perfet gift, so good,
8061: So fit, so acceptable, so Divine,
8062: That from her hand I could suspect no ill,
8063: And what she did, whatever in it self,
8064: Her doing seem'd to justifie the deed;
8065: Shee gave me of the Tree, and I did eate.
8066: ¶To whom the sovran Presence thus repli'd.
8067: Was shee thy God, that her thou didst obey
8068: Before his voice, or was shee made thy guide,
8069: Superior, or but equal, that to her
8070: Thou did'st resigne thy Manhood, and the Place
8071: Wherein God set thee above her made of thee,
8072: And for thee, whose perfection farr excell'd
8073: Hers in all real dignitie: Adornd
8074: She was indeed, and lovely to attract
8075: Thy Love, not thy Subjection, and her Gifts
8076: Were such as under Government well seem'd,
8077: Unseemly to beare rule, which was thy part
8078: And person, had'st thou known thy self aright.
8079: ¶So having said, he thus to *Eve* in few:
8080: Say Woman, what is this which thou hast done?
8081: ¶To whom sad *Eve* with shame nigh overwhelm'd,
8082: Confessing soon, yet not before her Judge
8083: Bold or loquacious, thus abasht repli'd.
8084: ¶The Serpent me beguil'd and I did eate.
8085: ¶Which when the Lord God heard, without delay
8086: To Judgement he proceeded on th' accus'd
8087: Serpent though brute, unable to transferre
8088: The Guilt on him who made him instrument
8089: Of mischief, and polluted from the end
8090: Of his Creation; justly then accurst,
8091: As vitiated in Nature: more to know
8092: Concern'd not Man (since he no further knew)
8093: Nor alter'd his offence; yet God at last
8094: To Satan first in sin his doom apply'd,
8095: Though in mysterious terms, judg'd as then best:
8096: And on the Serpent thus his curse let fall.
8097: ¶Because thou hast done this, thou art accurst
8098: Above all Cattel, each Beast of the Field;
8099: Upon thy Belly groveling thou shalt goe,
8100: And dust shalt eat all the days of thy Life.
8101: Between Thee and the Woman I will put
8102: Enmitie, and between thine and her Seed;
8103: Her Seed shall bruise thy head, thou bruise his heel.
8106: Saw Satan fall like Lightning down from Heav'n,
8107: Prince of the Aire; then rising from his Grave
8109: In open shew, and with ascention bright
8110: Captivity led captive through the Aire,
8111: The Realme it self of Satan long usurpt,
8112: Whom he shall tread at last under our feet;
8113: Eevn hee who now foretold his fatal bruise,
8114: And to the Woman thus his Sentence turn'd.
8116: By thy Conception; Children thou shalt bring
8117: In sorrow forth, and to thy Husbands will
8118: Thine shall submit, hee over thee shall rule.
8120: Because thou hast heark'nd to the voice of thy Wife,
8121: And eaten of the Tree concerning which
8122: I charg'd thee, saying: Thou shalt not eate thereof,
8123: Curs'd is the ground for thy sake, thou in sorrow
8124: Shalt eate thereof all the days of thy Life;
8125: Thornes also and Thistles it shall bring thee forth
8126: Unbid, and thou shalt eate th' Herb of th' Field,
8127: In the sweat of thy Face shalt thou eate Bread,
8128: Till thou return unto the ground, for thou
8129: Out of the ground wast taken, know thy Birth,
8130: For dust thou art, and shalt to dust returne.
8131: ¶So judg'd he Man, both Judge and Saviour sent,
8132: And th' instant stroke of Death denounc't that day
8133: Remov'd farr off; then pittying how they stood
8134: Before him naked to the aire, that now
8135: Must suffer change, disdain'd not to begin
8136: Thenceforth the forme of servant to assume,
8137: As when he wash'd his servants feet, so now
8138: As Father of his Familie he clad
8139: Thir nakedness with Skins of Beasts, or slain,
8140: Or as the Snake with youthful Coate repaid;
8141: And thought not much to cloath his Enemies:
8142: Nor hee thir outward onely with the Skins
8143: Of Beasts, but inward nakedness, much more
8144: Opprobrious, with his Robe of righteousness,
8145: Araying cover'd from his Fathers sight.
8146: To him with swift ascent he up returnd,
8148: In glory as of old, to him appeas'd
8149: All, though all-knowing, what had past with Man
8151: Meanwhile ere thus was sin'd and judg'd on Earth,
8152: Within the Gates of Hell sate Sin and Death,
8153: In counterview within the Gates, that now
8154: Stood open wide, belching outrageous flame
8155: Farr into *Chaos*, since the Fiend pass'd through,
8156: Sin opening, who thus now to Death began.
8157: ¶O Son, why sit we here each other viewing
8158: Idlely, while Satan our great Author thrives
8159: In other Worlds, and happier Seat provides
8160: For us his ofspring deare?  It cannot be
8161: But that success attends him; if mishap,
8162: Ere this he had return'd, with fury driv'n
8163: By his Avenger, since no place like this
8164: Can fit his punishment, or their revenge.
8165: Methinks I feel new strength within me rise,
8166: Wings growing, and Dominion giv'n me large
8167: Beyond this Deep; whatever drawes me on,
8168: Or sympathie, or som connatural force
8169: Powerful at greatest distance to unite
8170: With secret amity things of like kinde
8171: By secretest conveyance.  Thou my Shade
8173: For Death from Sin no power can separate.
8174: But least the difficultie of passing back
8175: Stay his returne perhaps over this Gulfe
8177: Adventrous work, yet to thy power and mine
8178: Not unagreeable, to found a path
8179: Over this Maine from Hell to that new World
8180: Where Satan now prevailes, a Monument
8181: Of merit high to all th' infernal Host,
8182: Easing thir passage hence, for intercourse,
8183: Or transmigration, as thir lot shall lead.
8184: Nor can I miss the way, so strongly drawn
8185: By this new felt attraction and instinct.
8186: ¶Whom thus the meager Shadow answerd soon.
8187: Goe whither Fate and inclination strong
8188: Leads thee, I shall not lag behinde, nor erre
8189: The way, thou leading, such a sent I draw
8190: Of carnage, prey innumerable, and taste
8191: The savour of Death from all things there that live:
8192: Nor shall I to the work thou enterprisest
8193: Be wanting, but afford thee equal aid.
8194: ¶So saying, with delight he snuff'd the smell
8195: Of mortal change on Earth.  As when a flock
8196: Of ravenous Fowl, though many a League remote,
8197: Against the day of Battel, to a Field,
8198: Where Armies lie encampt, come flying, lur'd
8199: With sent of living Carcasses design'd
8200: For death, the following day, in bloodie fight.
8201: So sented the grim Feature, and upturn'd
8202: His Nostril wide into the murkie Air,
8203: Sagacious of his Quarrey from so farr.
8204: Then Both from out Hell Gates into the waste
8205: Wide Anarchie of *Chaos* damp and dark
8206: Flew divers, & with Power (thir Power was great)
8207: Hovering upon the Waters; what they met
8208: Solid or slimie, as in raging Sea
8209: Tost up and down, together crowded drove
8210: From each side shoaling towards the mouth of Hell.
8211: As when two Polar Winds blowing adverse
8213: Mountains of Ice, that stop th' imagin'd way
8216: Death with his Mace petrific, cold and dry,
8217: As with a Trident smote, and fix't as firm
8218: As *Delos* floating once; the rest his look
8219: Bound with *Gorgonian* rigor not to move,
8220: And with *Asphaltic* slime; broad as the Gate,
8221: Deep to the Roots of Hell the gather'd beach
8222: They fasten'd, and the Mole immense wraught on
8223: Over the foaming deep high Archt, a Bridge
8224: Of length prodigious joyning to the Wall
8225: Immoveable of this now fenceless world
8226: Forfeit to Death; from hence a passage broad,
8227: Smooth, easie, inoffensive down to Hell.
8228: So, if great things to small may be compar'd,
8231: Came to the Sea, and over *Hellespont*
8233: And scourg'd with many a stroak th' indignant waves.
8234: Now had they brought the work by wondrous Art
8235: Pontifical, a ridge of pendent Rock
8236: Over the vext Abyss, following the track
8237: Of *Satan*, to the selfsame place where hee
8238: First lighted from his Wing, and landed safe
8239: From out of *Chaos* to the outside bare
8240: Of this round World: with Pinns of Adamant
8241: And Chains they made all fast, too fast they made
8242: And durable; and now in little space
8243: The Confines met of Empyrean Heav'n
8244: And of this World, and on the left hand Hell
8245: With long reach interpos'd; three sev'ral wayes
8246: In sight, to each of these three places led.
8247: And now thir way to Earth they had descri'd,
8248: To Paradise first tending, when behold
8249: *Satan* in likeness of an Angel bright
8251: His *Zenith*, while the Sun in *Aries* rose:
8252: Disguis'd he came, but those his Children dear
8253: Thir Parent soon discern'd, though in disguise.
8255: Into the Wood fast by, and changing shape
8256: To observe the sequel, saw his guileful act
8258: Upon her Husband, saw thir shame that sought
8259: Vain covertures; but when he saw descend
8260: The Son of God to judge them, terrifi'd
8261: Hee fled, not hoping to escape, but shun
8262: The present, fearing guiltie what his wrauth
8263: Might suddenly inflict; that past, return'd
8264: By Night, and listning where the hapless Paire
8265: Sate in thir sad discourse, and various plaint,
8266: Thence gatherd his own doom, which understood
8267: Not instant, but of future time.  With joy
8268: And tidings fraught, to Hell he now return'd,
8269: And at the brink of *Chaos*, neer the foot
8270: Of this new wondrous Pontifice, unhop't
8271: Met who to meet him came, his Ofspring dear.
8272: Great joy was at thir meeting, and at sight
8273: Of that stupendious Bridge his joy encreas'd.
8274: Long hee admiring stood, till Sin, his faire
8275: Inchanting Daughter, thus the silence broke.
8276: ¶O Parent, these are thy magnific deeds,
8277: Thy Trophies, which thou view'st as not thine own,
8278: Thou art thir Author and prime Architect:
8279: For I no sooner in my Heart divin'd,
8280: My Heart, which by a secret harmonie
8281: Still moves with thine, joyn'd in connexion sweet,
8282: That thou on Earth hadst prosper'd, which thy looks
8283: Now also evidence, but straight I felt
8284: Though distant from thee Worlds between, yet felt
8285: That I must after thee with this thy Son;
8286: Such fatal consequence unites us three:
8287: Hell could no longer hold us in her bounds,
8289: Detain from following thy illustrious track.
8290: Thou hast atchiev'd our libertie, confin'd
8291: Within Hell Gates till now, thou us impow'rd
8292: To fortifie thus farr, and overlay
8293: With this portentous Bridge the dark Abyss.
8294: Thine now is all this World, thy vertue hath won
8295: What thy hands builded not, thy Wisdom gain'd
8296: With odds what Warr hath lost, and fully aveng'd
8297: Our foile in Heav'n; here thou shalt Monarch reign,
8298: There didst not; there let him still Victor sway,
8299: As Battel hath adjudg'd, from this new World
8300: Retiring, by his own doom alienated,
8301: And henceforth Monarchie with thee divide
8302: Of all things, parted by th' Empyreal bounds,
8303: His Quadrature, from thy Orbicular World,
8304: Or trie thee now more dang'rous to his Throne.
8305: ¶Whom thus the Prince of Darkness answerd glad.
8306: Fair Daughter, and thou Son and Grandchild both,
8307: High proof ye now have giv'n to be the Race
8308: Of *Satan* (for I glorie in the name,
8310: Amply have merited of me, of all
8311: Th' Infernal Empire, that so neer Heav'ns dore
8312: Triumphal with triumphal act have met,
8313: Mine with this glorious Work, & made one Realm
8314: Hell and this World, one Realm, one Continent
8315: Of easie thorough-fare.  Therefore while I
8316: Descend through Darkness, on your Rode with ease
8317: To my associate Powers, them to acquaint
8318: With these successes, and with them rejoyce,
8319: You two this way, among those numerous Orbs
8320: All yours, right down to Paradise descend;
8321: There dwell & Reign in bliss, thence on the Earth
8322: Dominion exercise and in the Aire,
8323: Chiefly on Man, sole Lord of all declar'd,
8324: Him first make sure your thrall, and lastly kill.
8325: My Substitutes I send ye, and Create
8326: Plenipotent on Earth, of matchless might
8327: Issuing from mee: on your joynt vigor now
8328: My hold of this new Kingdom all depends,
8329: Through Sin to Death expos'd by my exploit.
8330: If your joynt power prevaile, th' affaires of Hell
8331: No detriment need feare, goe and be strong.
8332: ¶So saying he dismiss'd them, they with speed
8333: Thir course through thickest Constellations held
8334: Spreading thir bane; the blasted Starrs lookt wan,
8336: Then sufferd.  Th' other way *Satan* went down
8337: The Causey to Hell Gate; on either side
8339: And with rebounding surge the barrs assaild,
8340: That scorn'd his indignation: through the Gate,
8342: And all about found desolate; for those
8343: Appointed to sit there, had left thir charge,
8344: Flown to the upper World; the rest were all
8345: Farr to the inland retir'd, about the walls
8348: Of that bright Starr to *Satan* paragond.
8349: There kept thir Watch the Legions, while the Grand
8350: In Council sate, sollicitous what chance
8351: Might intercept thir Emperour sent, so hee
8352: Departing gave command, and they observ'd.
8353: As when the *Tartar* from his *Russian* Foe
8355: Retires, or *Bactrian* Sophi from the hornes
8356: Of *Turkish* Crescent, leaves all waste beyond
8357: The Realme of *Aladule*, in his retreate
8358: To *Tauris* or *Casbeen*.  So these the late
8359: Heav'n-banisht Host, left desert utmost Hell
8360: Many a dark League, reduc't in careful Watch
8361: Round thir Metropolis, and now expecting
8362: Each hour their great adventurer from the search
8363: Of Forrein Worlds: he through the midst unmarkt,
8365: Of lowest order, past; and from the dore
8367: Ascended his high Throne, which under state
8368: Of richest texture spred, at th' upper end
8369: Was plac't in regal lustre.  Down a while
8370: He sate, and round about him saw unseen:
8371: At last as from a Cloud his fulgent head
8372: And shape Starr bright appeer'd, or brighter, clad
8373: With what permissive glory since his fall
8374: Was left him, or false glitter: All amaz'd
8375: At that so sudden blaze the *Stygian* throng
8376: Bent thir aspect, and whom they wish'd beheld,
8377: Thir mighty Chief returnd: loud was th' acclaime:
8378: Forth rush'd in haste the great consulting Peers,
8379: Rais'd from thir dark *Divan*, and with like joy
8380: Congratulant approach'd him, who with hand
8381: Silence, and with these words attention won.
8383: For in possession such, not onely of right,
8384: I call ye and declare ye now, returnd
8385: Successful beyond hope, to lead ye forth
8386: Triumphant out of this infernal Pit
8387: Abominable, accurst, the house of woe,
8388: And Dungeon of our Tyrant: Now possess,
8389: As Lords, a spacious World, to our native Heaven
8390: Little inferiour, by my adventure hard
8391: With peril great atchiev'd.  Long were to tell
8392: What I have don, what sufferd, with what paine
8393: Voyag'd the unreal, vast, unbounded deep
8395: By Sin and Death a broad way now is pav'd
8396: To expedite your glorious march; but I
8397: Toild out my uncouth passage, forc't to ride
8398: Th' untractable Abysse, plung'd in the womb
8400: That jealous of thir secrets fiercely oppos'd
8401: My journey strange, with clamorous uproare
8402: Protesting Fate supreame; thence how I found
8403: The new created World, which fame in Heav'n
8404: Long had foretold, a Fabrick wonderful
8406: Plac't in a Paradise, by our exile
8407: Made happie: Him by fraud I have seduc'd
8408: From his Creator, and the more to increase
8409: Your wonder, with an Apple; he thereat
8410: Offended, worth your laughter, hath giv'n up
8411: Both his beloved Man and all his World,
8412: To Sin and Death a prey, and so to us,
8413: Without our hazard, labour or allarme,
8414: To range in, and to dwell, and over Man
8415: To rule, as over all he should have rul'd.
8416: True is, mee also he hath judg'd, or rather
8417: Mee not, but the brute Serpent in whose shape
8418: Man I deceav'd: that which to mee belongs,
8419: Is enmity, which he will put between
8420: Mee and Mankinde; I am to bruise his heel;
8421: His Seed, when is not set, shall bruise my head:
8422: A World who would not purchase with a bruise,
8423: Or much more grievous pain?  Ye have th' account
8424: Of my performance: What remaines, ye Gods,
8425: But up and enter now into full bliss.
8426: ¶So having said, a while he stood, expecting
8427: Thir universal shout and high applause
8428: To fill his eare, when contrary he hears
8429: On all sides, from innumerable tongues
8430: A dismal universal hiss, the sound
8431: Of public scorn; he wonderd, but not long
8432: Had leasure, wondring at himself now more;
8433: His Visage drawn he felt to sharp and spare,
8434: His Armes clung to his Ribs, his Leggs entwining
8435: Each other, till supplanted down he fell
8436: A monstrous Serpent on his Belly prone,
8437: Reluctant, but in vaine, a greater power
8438: Now rul'd him, punisht in the shape he sin'd,
8439: According to his doom: he would have spoke,
8440: But hiss for hiss returnd with forked tongue
8441: To forked tongue, for now were all transform'd
8442: Alike, to Serpents all as accessories
8443: To his bold Riot: dreadful was the din
8444: Of hissing through the Hall, thick swarming now
8445: With complicated monsters, head and taile,
8448: And *Dipsas* (Not so thick swarm'd once the Soil
8449: Bedropt with blood of Gorgon, or the Isle
8450: *Ophiusa*) but still greatest hee the midst,
8451: Now Dragon grown, larger then whom the Sun
8452: Ingenderd in the *Pythian* Vale on slime,
8453: Huge *Python*, and his Power no less he seem'd
8454: Above the rest still to retain; they all
8455: Him follow'd issuing forth to th' open Field,
8456: Where all yet left of that revolted Rout
8457: Heav'n-fall'n, in station stood or just array,
8458: Sublime with expectation when to see
8459: In Triumph issuing forth thir glorious Chief;
8460: They saw, but other sight instead, a crowd
8461: Of ugly Serpents; horror on them fell,
8462: And horrid sympathie; for what they saw,
8463: They felt themselvs now changing; down thir arms,
8464: Down fell both Spear and Shield, down they as fast,
8465: And the dire hiss renew'd, and the dire form
8466: Catcht by Contagion, like in punishment,
8467: As in thir crime.  Thus was th' applause they meant,
8468: Turnd to exploding hiss, triumph to shame
8469: Cast on themselves from thir own mouths.  There stood
8470: A Grove hard by, sprung up with this thir change,
8471: His will who reigns above, to aggravate
8472: Thir penance, laden with fair Fruit, like that
8473: Which grew in Paradise, the bait of *Eve*
8474: Us'd by the Tempter: on that prospect strange
8475: Thir earnest eyes they fix'd, imagining
8476: For one forbidden Tree a multitude
8477: Now ris'n, to work them furder woe or shame;
8478: Yet parcht with scalding thurst and hunger fierce,
8479: Though to delude them sent, could not abstain,
8480: But on they rould in heaps, and up the Trees
8481: Climbing, sat thicker then the snakie locks
8483: The Frutage fair to sight, like that which grew
8484: Neer that bituminous Lake where *Sodom* flam'd;
8485: This more delusive, not the touch, but taste
8486: Deceav'd; they fondly thinking to allay
8487: Thir appetite with gust, instead of Fruit
8488: Chewd bitter Ashes, which th' offended taste
8489: With spattering noise rejected: oft they assayd,
8490: Hunger and thirst constraining, drugd as oft,
8491: With hatefullest disrelish writh'd thir jaws
8492: With foot and cinders fill'd; so oft they fell
8493: Into the same illusion, not as Man
8494: Whom they triumph'd once lapst.  Thus were they plagu'd
8495: And worn with Famin, long and ceasless hiss,
8496: Till thir lost shape, permitted, they resum'd,
8497: Yearly enjoynd, some say, to undergo
8498: This annual humbling certain number'd days,
8499: To dash thir pride, and joy for Man seduc't.
8501: Among the Heathen of thir purchase got,
8502: And Fabl'd how the Serpent, whom they calld
8504: Encroaching *Eve* perhaps, had first the rule
8507: Mean while in Paradise the hellish pair
8508: Too soon arriv'd, *Sin* there in power before,
8509: Once actual, now in body, and to dwell
8511: Close following pace for pace, not mounted yet
8512: On his pale Horse: to whom *Sin* thus began.
8514: What thinkst thou of our Empire now, though earnd
8515: With travail difficult, not better farr
8516: Then stil at Hels dark threshold to have sate watch,
8517: Unnam'd, undreaded, and thy self half starv'd?
8518: ¶Whom thus the Sin-born Monster answerd soon.
8519: To mee, who with eternal Famin pine,
8520: Alike is Hell, or Paradise, or Heaven,
8521: There best, where most with ravin I may meet;
8522: Which here, though plenteous, all too little seems
8523: To stuff this Maw, this vast unhide-bound Corps.
8524: ¶To whom th' incestuous Mother thus repli'd.
8525: Thou therefore on these Herbs, and Fruits, & Flours
8526: Feed first, on each Beast next, and Fish, and Fowle,
8527: No homely morsels, and whatever thing
8528: The Sithe of Time mowes down, devour unspar'd,
8529: Till I in Man residing through the Race,
8530: His thoughts, his looks, words, actions all infect,
8531: And season him thy last and sweetest prey.
8532: ¶This said, they both betook them several wayes,
8533: Both to destroy, or unimmortal make
8534: All kinds, and for destruction to mature
8535: Sooner or later; which th' Almightie seeing,
8536: From his transcendent Seat the Saints among,
8537: To those bright Orders utterd thus his voice.
8538: ¶See with what heat these Dogs of Hell advance
8539: To waste and havoc yonder World, which I
8540: So fair and good created, and had still
8541: Kept in that state, had not the folly of Man
8542: Let in these wastful Furies, who impute
8543: Folly to mee, so doth the Prince of Hell
8544: And his Adherents, that with so much ease
8545: I suffer them to enter and possess
8546: A place so heav'nly, and conniving seem
8548: That laugh, as if transported with some fit
8549: Of Passion, I to them had quitted all,
8550: At random yeilded up to their misrule;
8551: And know not that I call'd and drew them thither
8552: My Hell-hounds, to lick up the draff and filth
8553: Which mans polluting Sin with taint hath shed
8554: On what was pure, till cramm'd and gorg'd, nigh burst
8555: With suckt and glutted offal, at one fling
8556: Of thy victorious Arm, well-pleasing Son,
8557: Both *Sin*, and *Death*, and yawning *Grave* at last
8558: Through *Chaos* hurld, obstruct the mouth of Hell
8559: For ever, and seal up his ravenous Jawes.
8560: Then Heav'n and Earth renewd shall be made pure
8561: To sanctitie that shall receive no staine:
8562: Till then the Curse pronounc't on both precedes.
8563: ¶Hee ended, and the heav'nly Audience loud
8564: Sung *Halleluia*, as the sound of Seas,
8565: Through multitude that sung: Just are thy ways,
8566: Righteous are thy Decrees on all thy Works;
8567: Who can extenuate thee?  Next, to the Son,
8568: Destin'd restorer of Mankind, by whom
8569: New Heav'n and Earth shall to the Ages rise,
8570: Or down from Heav'n descend.  Such was thir song,
8571: While the Creator calling forth by name
8572: His mightie Angels gave them several charge,
8573: As sorted best with present things.  The Sun
8574: Had first his precept so to move, so shine,
8575: As might affect the Earth with cold and heat
8576: Scarce tollerable, and from the North to call
8577: Decrepit Winter, from the South to bring
8578: Solstitial summers heat.  To the blanc Moone
8579: Her office they prescrib'd, to th' other five
8582: Of noxious efficacie, and when to joyne
8583: In Synod unbenigne, and taught the fixt
8584: Thir influence malignant when to showre,
8585: Which of them rising with the Sun, or falling,
8586: Should prove tempestuous: To the Winds they set
8587: Thir corners, when with bluster to confound
8588: Sea, Aire, and Shoar, the Thunder when to rowle
8589: With terror through the dark Aereal Hall.
8590: Some say he bid his Angels turne ascanse
8591: The Poles of Earth twice ten degrees and more
8592: From the Suns Axle; they with labour push'd
8593: Oblique the Centric Globe: Som say the Sun
8594: Was bid turn Reines from th' Equinoctial Rode
8595: Like distant breadth to *Taurus* with the Seav'n
8597: Up to the *Tropic* Crab; thence down amaine
8599: As deep as *Capricorne*, to bring in change
8600: Of Seasons to each Clime; else had the Spring
8601: Perpetual smil'd on Earth with vernant Flours,
8602: Equal in Days and Nights, except to those
8603: Beyond the Polar Circles; to them Day
8604: Had unbenighted shon, while the low Sun
8605: To recompence his distance, in thir sight
8606: Had rounded still th' *Horizon*, and not known
8607: Or East or West, which had forbid the Snow
8608: From cold *Estotiland*, and South as farr
8610: The Sun, as from *Thyestean* Banquet, turn'd
8611: His course intended; else how had the World
8612: Inhabited, though sinless, more then now,
8613: Avoided pinching cold and scorching heate?
8614: These changes in the Heav'ns, though slow, produc'd
8615: Like change on Sea and Land, sideral blast,
8616: Vapour, and Mist, and Exhalation hot,
8617: Corrupt and Pestilent: Now from the North
8619: Bursting thir brazen Dungeon, armd with ice
8620: And snow and haile and stormie gust and flaw,
8622: And *Thrascias* rend the Woods and Seas upturn;
8623: With adverse blast up-turns them from the South
8625: From *Serraliona*; thwart of these as fierce
8626: Forth rush the *Levant* and the *Ponent* Windes
8629: Outrage from liveless things; but Discord first
8630: Daughter of Sin, among th' irrational,
8632: Beast now with Beast gan war, & Fowle with Fowle,
8633: And Fish with Fish; to graze the Herb all leaving,
8634: Devourd each other; nor stood much in awe
8635: Of Man, but fled him, or with count'nance grim
8636: Glar'd on him passing: these were from without
8638: Alreadie in part, though hid in gloomiest shade,
8639: To sorrow abandond, but worse felt within,
8640: And in a troubl'd Sea of passion tost,
8641: Thus to disburd'n sought with sad complaint.
8642: ¶O miserable of happie! is this the end
8643: Of this new glorious World, and mee so late
8644: The Glory of that Glory, who now becom
8645: Accurst of blessed, hide me from the face
8646: Of God, whom to behold was then my highth
8647: Of happiness: yet well, if here would end
8648: The miserie, I deserv'd it, and would beare
8649: My own deservings; but this will not serve;
8650: All that I eate or drink, or shall beget,
8651: Is propagated curse.  O voice once heard
8653: Now death to heare! for what can I encrease
8654: Or multiplie, but curses on my head?
8655: Who of all Ages to succeed, but feeling
8656: The evil on him brought by me, will curse
8657: My Head, Ill fare our Ancestor impure,
8658: For this we may thank *Adam*; but his thanks
8659: Shall be the execration; so besides
8660: Mine own that bide upon me, all from mee
8661: Shall with a fierce reflux on mee redound,
8662: On mee as on thir natural center light
8663: Heavie, though in thir place.  O fleeting joyes
8664: Of Paradise, deare bought with lasting woes!
8665: Did I request thee, Maker, from my Clay
8666: To mould me Man, did I sollicite thee
8667: From darkness to promote me, or here place
8668: In this delicious Garden? as my Will
8669: Concurd not to my being, it were but right
8670: And equal to reduce me to my dust,
8671: Desirous to resigne, and render back
8672: All I receav'd, unable to performe
8673: Thy terms too hard, by which I was to hold
8674: The good I sought not.  To the loss of that,
8675: Sufficient penaltie, why hast thou added
8676: The sense of endless woes? inexplicable
8677: Thy Justice seems; yet to say truth, too late,
8678: I thus contest; then should have been refusd
8679: Those terms whatever, when they were propos'd:
8680: Thou didst accept them; wilt thou enjoy the good,
8681: Then cavil the conditions? and though God
8682: Made thee without thy leave, what if thy Son
8684: Wherefore didst thou beget me? I sought it not:
8685: Wouldst thou admit for his contempt of thee
8686: That proud excuse? yet him not thy election,
8688: God made thee of choice his own, and of his own
8689: To serve him, thy reward was of his grace,
8690: Thy punishment then justly is at his Will.
8691: Be it so, for I submit, his doom is fair,
8692: That dust I am, and shall to dust returne:
8693: O welcom hour whenever! why delayes
8694: His hand to execute what his Decree
8695: Fixd on this day? why do I overlive,
8696: Why am I mockt with death, and length'nd out
8697: To deathless pain? how gladly would I meet
8698: Mortalitie my sentence, and be Earth
8699: Insensible, how glad would lay me down
8700: As in my Mothers lap? there I should rest
8701: And sleep secure; his dreadful voice no more
8702: Would Thunder in my ears, no fear of worse
8703: To mee and to my ofspring would torment me
8704: With cruel expectation.  Yet one doubt
8705: Pursues me still, least all I cannot die,
8706: Least that pure breath of Life, the Spirit of Man
8707: Which God inspir'd, cannot together perish
8708: With this corporeal Clod; then in the Grave,
8709: Or in some other dismal place, who knows
8710: But I shall die a living Death?  O thought
8711: Horrid, if true! yet why? it was but breath
8712: Of Life that sinn'd; what dies but what had life
8713: And sin? the Bodie properly hath neither.
8714: All of me then shall die: let this appease
8715: The doubt, since humane reach no further knows.
8716: For though the Lord of all be infinite,
8717: Is his wrauth also? be it, man is not so,
8718: But mortal doom'd.  How can he exercise
8719: Wrath without end on Man whom Death must end?
8720: Can he make deathless Death? that were to make
8721: Strange contradiction, which to God himself
8723: Of weakness, not of Power.  Will he, draw out,
8724: For angers sake, finite to infinite
8725: In punisht man, to satisfie his rigour
8726: Satisfi'd never; that were to extend
8727: His Sentence beyond dust and Natures Law,
8728: By which all Causes else according still
8729: To the reception of thir matter act,
8730: Not to th' extent of thir own Spheare.  But say
8731: That Death be not one stroak, as I suppos'd,
8733: From this day onward, which I feel begun
8734: Both in me, and without me, and so last
8735: To perpetuitie; Ay me, that fear
8736: Comes thundring back with dreadful revolution
