8737: On my defensless head; both Death and I
8738: Am found Eternal, and incorporate both,
8739: Nor I on my part single, in mee all
8741: That I must leave ye, Sons; O were I able
8742: To waste it all my self, and leave ye none!
8743: So disinherited how would ye bless
8744: Me now your Curse!  Ah, why should all mankind
8745: For one mans fault thus guiltless be condemn'd,
8746: If guiltless?  But from mee what can proceed,
8747: But all corrupt, both Mind and Will deprav'd,
8748: Not to do onely, but to will the same
8749: With me? how can they acquitted stand
8750: In sight of God?  Him after all Disputes
8751: Forc't I absolve: all my evasions vain
8752: And reasonings, though through Mazes, lead me still
8753: But to my own conviction: first and last
8754: On mee, mee onely, as the sourse and spring
8755: Of all corruption, all the blame lights due;
8756: So might the wrauth, Fond wish! couldst thou support
8757: That burden heavier then the Earth to bear,
8758: Then all the world much heavier, though divided
8759: With that bad Woman?  Thus what thou desir'st,
8760: And what thou fearst, alike destroyes all hope
8761: Of refuge, and concludes thee miserable
8762: Beyond all past example and future,
8763: To *Satan* onely like both crime and doom.
8764: O Conscience, into what Abyss of fears
8765: And horrors hast thou driv'n me; out of which
8766: I find no way, from deep to deeper plung'd!
8768: Through the still Night, now now, as ere man fell,
8769: Wholsom and cool, and mild, but with black Air
8770: Accompanied, with damps and dreadful gloom,
8771: Which to his evil Conscience represented
8772: All things with double terror: On the ground
8773: Outstretcht he lay, on the cold ground, and oft
8774: Curs'd his Creation, Death as oft accus'd
8776: The day of his offence.  Why comes not Death,
8777: Said hee, with one thrice acceptable stroke
8778: To end me?  Shall Truth fail to keep her word,
8779: Justice Divine not hast'n to be just?
8780: But Death comes not at call, Justice Divine
8781: Mends not her slowest pace for prayers or cries.
8782: O Woods, O Fountains, Hillocks, Dales and Bowrs,
8783: With other echo farr I taught your Shades
8784: To answer, and resound farr other Song.
8785: Whom thus afflicted when sad *Eve* beheld,
8786: Desolate where she sate, approaching nigh,
8787: Soft words to his fierce passion she assay'd:
8788: But her with stern regard he thus repell'd.
8789: ¶Out of my sight, thou Serpent, that name best
8790: Befits thee with him leagu'd, thy self as false
8791: And hateful; nothing wants, but that thy shape,
8792: Like his, and colour Serpentine may shew
8793: Thy inward fraud, to warn all Creatures from thee
8794: Henceforth; least that too heav'nly form, pretended
8795: To hellish falshood, snare them.  But for thee
8796: I had persisted happie, had not thy pride
8797: And wandring vanitie, when lest was safe,
8799: Not to be trusted, longing to be seen
8800: Though by the Devil himself, him overweening
8801: To over-reach, but with the Serpent meeting
8802: Fool'd and beguil'd, by him thou, I by thee,
8803: To trust thee from my side, imagin'd wise,
8804: Constant, mature, proof against all assaults,
8805: And understood not all was but a shew
8806: Rather then solid vertu, all but a Rib
8807: Crooked by nature, bent, as now appears,
8808: More to the part sinister from me drawn,
8809: Well if thrown out, as supernumerarie
8810: To my just number found.  O why did God,
8811: Creator wise, that peopl'd highest Heav'n
8812: With Spirits Masculine, create at last
8813: This noveltie on Earth, this fair defect
8814: Of Nature, and not fill the World at once
8815: With Men as Angels without Feminine,
8816: Or find some other way to generate
8817: Mankind? this mischief had not then befall'n,
8818: And more that shall befall, innumerable
8819: Disturbances on Earth through Femal snares,
8820: And straight conjunction with this Sex: for either
8821: He never shall find out fit Mate, but such
8822: As some misfortune brings him, or mistake,
8823: Or whom he wishes most shall seldom gain
8824: Through her perverseness, but shall see her gaind
8825: By a farr worse, or if she love, withheld
8826: By Parents, or his happiest choice too late
8827: Shall meet, alreadie linkt and Wedlock-bound
8828: To a fell Adversarie, his hate or shame:
8830: To humane life, and houshold peace confound.
8831: ¶He added not, and from her turn'd, but *Eve*
8832: Not so repulst, with Tears that ceas'd not flowing,
8833: And tresses all disorderd, at his feet
8834: Fell humble, and imbracing them, besaught
8835: His peace, and thus proceeded in her plaint.
8837: What love sincere, and reverence in my heart
8838: I beare thee, and unweeting have offended,
8840: I beg, and clasp thy knees; bereave me not,
8841: Whereon I live, thy gentle looks, thy aid,
8842: Thy counsel in this uttermost distress,
8843: My onely strength and stay: forlorn of thee,
8844: Whither shall I betake me, where subsist?
8845: While yet we live, scarse one short hour perhaps,
8846: Between us two let there be peace, both joyning,
8847: As joyn'd in injuries, one enmitie
8848: Against a Foe by doom express assign'd us,
8849: That cruel Serpent: On me exercise not
8850: Thy hatred for this miserie befall'n,
8851: On me already lost, mee then thy self
8852: More miserable; both have sin'd, but thou
8853: Against God onely, I against God and thee,
8854: And to the place of judgement will return,
8855: There with my cries importune Heaven, that all
8856: The sentence from thy head remov'd may light
8857: On me, sole cause to thee of all this woe,
8858: Mee mee onely just object of his ire.
8859: ¶She ended weeping, and her lowlie plight,
8860: Immoveable till peace obtain'd from fault
8863: Towards her, his life so late and sole delight,
8864: Now at his feet submissive in distress,
8865: Creature so faire his reconcilement seeking,
8866: His counsel whom she had displeas'd, his aide;
8867: As one disarm'd, his anger all he lost,
8868: And thus with peaceful words uprais'd her soon.
8870: So now of what thou knowst not, who desir'st
8871: The punishment all on thy self; alas,
8872: Beare thine own first, ill able to sustaine
8873: His full wrauth whose thou feelst as yet lest part,
8874: And my displeasure bearst so ill.  If Prayers
8875: Could alter high Decrees, I to that place
8876: Would speed before thee, and be louder heard,
8877: That on my head all might be visited,
8878: Thy frailtie and infirmer Sex forgiv'n,
8879: To me committed and by me expos'd.
8880: But rise, let us no more contend, nor blame
8881: Each other, blam'd enough elsewhere, but strive
8882: In offices of Love, how we may light'n
8883: Each others burden in our share of woe;
8884: Since this days Death denounc't, if ought I see,
8885: Will prove no sudden, but a slow-pac't evill,
8886: A long days dying to augment our paine,
8887: And to our Seed (O hapless Seed!) deriv'd.
8890: How little weight my words with thee can finde,
8891: Found so erroneous, thence by just event
8893: Restor'd by thee, vile as I am, to place
8894: Of new acceptance, hopeful to regaine
8895: Thy Love, the sole contentment of my heart,
8896: Living or dying from thee I will not hide
8897: What thoughts in my unquiet brest are ris'n,
8898: Tending to som relief of our extremes,
8899: Or end, though sharp and sad, yet tolerable,
8900: As in our evils, and of easier choice.
8901: If care of our descent perplex us most,
8902: Which must be born to certain woe, devourd
8903: By Death at last, and miserable it is
8904: To be to others cause of misery,
8905: Our own begotten, and of our Loines to bring
8906: Into this cursed World a woful Race,
8907: That after wretched Life must be at last
8908: Food for so foule a Monster, in thy power
8909: It lies, yet ere Conception to prevent
8910: The Race unblest, to being yet unbegot.
8912: So Death shall be deceav'd his glut, and with us two
8913: Be forc'd to satisfie his Rav'nous Maw.
8914: But if thou judge it hard and difficult,
8916: From Loves due Rites, Nuptial embraces sweet,
8917: And with desire to languish without hope,
8919: With like desire, which would be miserie
8920: And torment less then none of what we dread,
8921: Then both our selves and Seed at once to free
8922: From what we fear for both, let us make short,
8923: Let us seek Death, or hee not found, supply
8924: With our own hands his Office on our selves;
8925: Why stand we longer shivering under feares,
8926: That shew no end but Death, and have the power,
8927: Of many wayes to die the shortest choosing,
8930: Broke off the rest; so much of Death her thoughts
8931: Had entertaind, as di'd her Cheeks with pale.
8932: But *Adam* with such counsel nothing sway'd,
8933: To better hopes his more attentive minde
8934: Labouring had rais'd, and thus to *Eve* repli'd.
8935: ¶*Eve*, thy contempt of life and pleasure seems
8936: To argue in thee somthing more sublime
8937: And excellent then what thy minde contemnes;
8939: That excellence thought in thee, and implies,
8940: Not thy contempt, but anguish and regret
8941: For loss of life and pleasure overlov'd.
8942: Or if thou covet death, as utmost end
8943: Of miserie, so thinking to evade
8944: The penaltie pronounc't, doubt not but God
8945: Hath wiselier arm'd his vengeful ire then so
8946: To be forestall'd; much more I fear least Death
8947: So snatcht will not exempt us from the paine
8948: We are by doom to pay; rather such acts
8949: Of contumacie will provoke the highest
8950: To make death in us live: Then let us seek
8952: I have in view, calling to minde with heed
8953: Part of our Sentence, that thy Seed shall bruise
8954: The Serpents head; piteous amends, unless
8955: Be meant, whom I conjecture, our grand Foe
8956: *Satan*, who in the Serpent hath contriv'd
8957: Against us this deceit: to crush his head
8958: Would be revenge indeed; which will be lost
8959: By death brought on our selves, or childless days
8960: Resolv'd, as thou proposest; so our Foe
8961: Shall scape his punishment ordain'd, and wee
8962: Instead shall double ours upon our heads.
8963: No more be mention'd then of violence
8964: Against our selves, and wilful barrenness,
8965: That cuts us off from hope, and savours onely
8966: Rancor and pride, impatience and despite,
8967: Reluctance against God and his just yoke
8968: Laid on our Necks.  Remember with what mild
8969: And gracious temper he both heard and judg'd
8970: Without wrauth or reviling; wee expected
8972: Was meant by Death that day, when lo, to thee
8973: Pains onely in Child-bearing were foretold,
8974: And bringing forth, soon recompenc't with joy,
8975: Fruit of thy Womb: On mee the Curse aslope
8976: Glanc'd on the ground, with labour I must earne
8977: My bread; what harm?  Idleness had bin worse;
8978: My labour will sustain me; and least Cold
8979: Or Heat should injure us, his timely care
8980: Hath unbesaught provided, and his hands
8981: Cloath'd us unworthie, pitying while he judg'd;
8982: How much more, if we pray him, will his ear
8983: Be open, and his heart to pitie incline,
8984: And teach us further by what means to shun
8985: Th' inclement Seasons, Rain, Ice, Hail and Snow,
8986: Which now the Skie with various Face begins
8987: To shew us in this Mountain, while the Winds
8988: Blow moist and keen, shattering the graceful locks
8989: Of these fair spreading Trees; which bids us seek
8990: Som better shroud, som better warmth to cherish
8991: Our Limbs benumm'd, ere this diurnal Starr
8992: Leave cold the Night, how we his gather'd beams
8993: Reflected, may with matter sere foment,
8994: Or by collision of two bodies grinde
8995: The Air attrite to Fire, as late the Clouds
8996: Justling or pusht with Winds rude in thir shock
8997: Tine the slant Lightning, whose thwart flame driv'n down
8998: Kindles the gummie bark of Firr or Pine,
8999: And sends a comfortable heat from farr,
9000: Which might supplie the Sun: such Fire to use,
9001: And what may else be remedie or cure
9002: To evils which our own misdeeds have wrought,
9003: Hee will instruct us praying, and of Grace
9004: Beseeching him, so as we need not fear
9005: To pass commodiously this life, sustain'd
9006: By him with many comforts, till we end
9007: In dust, our final rest and native home.
9008: What better can we do, then to the place
9009: Repairing where he judg'd us, prostrate fall
9010: Before him reverent, and there confess
9011: Humbly our faults, and pardon beg, with tears
9012: Watering the ground, and with our sighs the Air
9013: Frequenting, sent from hearts contrite, in sign
9014: Of sorrow unfeign'd, and humiliation meek.
9015: Undoubtedly he will relent and turn
9016: From his displeasure; in whose look serene,
9017: When angry most he seem'd and most severe,
9018: What else but favor, grace, and mercie shon?
9020: Felt less remorse: they forthwith to the place
9021: Repairing where he judg'd them prostrate fell
9022: Before him reverent, and both confess'd
9023: Humbly thir faults, and pardon beg'd, with tears
9024: Watering the ground, and with thir sighs the Air
9025: Frequenting, sent from hearts contrite, in sign
9026: Of sorrow unfeign'd, and humiliation meek.
9029: ¶Thus they in lowliest plight repentant stood
9030: Praying, for from the Mercie-seat above
9032: The stonie from thir hearts, and made new flesh
9033: Regenerat grow instead, that sighs now breath'd
9034: Unutterable, which the Spirit of prayer
9035: Inspir'd, and wing'd for Heav'n with speedier flight
9036: Then loudest Oratorie: yet thir port
9037: Not of mean suiters, nor important less
9038: Seem'd thir Petition, then when th' ancient Pair
9039: In Fables old, less ancient yet then these,
9041: The Race of Mankind drownd, before the Shrine
9042: Of *Themis* stood devout.  To Heav'n thir prayers
9043: Flew up, nor missed the way, by envious windes
9044: Blow'n vagabond or frustrate: in they passd
9045: Dimentionless through Heav'nly dores; then clad
9046: With incense, where the Golden Altar fum'd,
9047: By thir great Intercessor, came in sight
9048: Before the Fathers Throne: Them the glad Son
9050: ¶See Father, what first fruits on Earth are sprung
9051: From thy implanted Grace in Man, these Sighs
9052: And Prayers, which in this Golden Censer, mixt
9053: With Incense, I thy Priest before thee bring,
9054: Fruits of more pleasing savour from thy seed
9055: Sow'n with contrition in his heart, then those
9056: Which his own hand manuring all the Trees
9057: Of Paradise could have produc't, ere fall'n
9058: From innocence.  Now therefore bend thine eare
9059: To supplication, heare his sighs though mute;
9060: Unskilful with what words to pray, let mee
9061: Interpret for him, mee his Advocate
9062: And propitiation, all his works on mee
9063: Good or not good ingraft, my Merit those
9064: Shall perfet, and for these my Death shall pay.
9065: Accept me, and in mee from these receave
9066: The smell of peace toward Mankinde, let him live
9067: Before thee reconcil'd, at least his days
9068: Numberd, though sad, till Death, his doom (which I
9069: To mitigate thus plead, not to reverse)
9070: To better life shall yeeld him, where with mee
9071: All my redeemd may dwell in joy and bliss,
9072: Made one with me as I with thee am one.
9073: ¶To whom the Father, without Cloud, serene.
9074: All thy request for Man, accepted Son,
9075: Obtain, all thy request was my Decree:
9076: But longer in that Paradise to dwell,
9077: The Law I gave to Nature him forbids:
9078: Those pure immortal Elements that know
9079: No gross, no unharmoneous mixture foule,
9080: Eject him tainted now, and purge him off
9081: As a distemper, gross to aire as gross,
9082: And mortal food, as may dispose him best
9083: For dissolution wrought by Sin, that first
9084: Distemperd all things, and of incorrupt
9085: Corrupted.  I at first with two fair gifts
9088: This other serv'd but to eternize woe;
9089: Till I provided Death; so Death becomes
9090: His final remedie, and after Life
9091: Tri'd in sharp tribulation, and refin'd
9092: By Faith and faithful works, to second Life,
9093: Wak't in the renovation of the just,
9094: Resignes him up with Heav'n and Earth renewd.
9095: But let us call to Synod all the Blest
9096: Through Heav'ns wide bounds; from them I will not hide
9097: My judgments, how with Mankind I proceed,
9098: As how with peccant Angels late they saw;
9099: And in thir state, though firm, stood more confirmd.
9100: ¶He ended, and the Son gave signal high
9101: To the bright Minister that watchd, hee blew
9102: His Trumpet, heard in *Oreb* since perhaps
9103: When God descended, and perhaps once more
9104: To sound at general Doom.  Th' Angelic blast
9105: Filld all the Regions: from thir blissful Bowrs
9107: By the waters of Life, where ere they sate
9108: In fellowships of joy: the Sons of Light
9109: Hasted, resorting to the Summons high,
9110: And took thir Seats; till from his Throne supream
9111: Th' Almighty thus pronounced his sovran Will.
9112: ¶O Sons, like one of us Man is become
9113: To know both Good and Evil, since his taste
9114: Of that defended Fruit; but let him boast
9115: His knowledge of Good lost, and Evil got,
9116: Happier, had it suffic'd him to have known
9117: Good by it self, and Evil not at all.
9118: He sorrows now, repents, and prayes contrite,
9119: My motions in him, longer then they move,
9120: His heart I know, how variable and vain
9121: Self-left.  Least therefore his now bolder hand
9122: Reach also of the Tree of Life, and eat,
9123: And live for ever, dream at least to live
9124: Forever, to remove him I decree,
9125: And send him from the Garden forth to Till
9126: The Ground whence he was taken, fitter soile.
9127: ¶*Michael*, this my behest have thou in charge,
9128: Take to thee from among the Cherubim
9129: Thy choice of flaming Warriours, least the Fiend
9130: Or in behalf of Man, or to invade
9131: Vacant possession som new trouble raise:
9132: Hast thee, and from the Paradise of God
9133: Without remorse drive out the sinful Pair,
9134: From hallowd ground th' unholie, and denounce
9135: To them and to thir Progenie from thence
9136: Perpetual banishment.  Yet least they faint
9137: At the sad Sentence rigorously urg'd,
9138: For I behold them soft'nd and with tears
9139: Bewailing thir excess, all terror hide.
9140: If patiently thy bidding they obey,
9142: To *Adam* what shall come in future dayes,
9143: As I shall thee enlighten, intermix
9144: My Cov'nant in the Womans seed renewd;
9145: So send them forth, though sorrowing, yet in peace:
9146: And on the East side of the Garden place,
9147: Where entrance up from *Eden* easiest climbes,
9148: Cherubic watch, and of a Sword the flame
9149: Wide waving, all approach farr off to fright,
9150: And guard all passage to the Tree of Life:
9152: To Spirits foule, and all my Trees thir prey,
9153: With whose stol'n Fruit Man once more to delude.
9154: ¶He ceas'd; and th' Archangelic Power prepar'd
9155: For swift descent, with him the Cohort bright
9156: Of watchful Cherubim; four faces each
9157: Had, like a double *Janus*, all thir shape
9158: Spangl'd with eyes more numerous then those
9159: Of *Argus*, and more wakeful then to drouze,
9160: Charm'd with *Arcadian* Pipe, the Pastoral Reed
9161: Of *Hermes*, or his opiate Rod.  Meanwhile
9162: To resalute the World with sacred Light
9163: *Leucothea* wak'd, and with fresh dews imbalmd
9164: The Earth, when *Adam* and first Matron *Eve*
9165: Had ended now thir Orisons, and found,
9166: Strength added from above, new hope to spring
9167: Out of despaire, joy, but with fear yet linkt;
9168: Which thus to *Eve* his welcome words renewd.
9169: ¶*Eve*, easily may Faith admit, that all
9170: The good which we enjoy, from Heav'n descends
9171: But that from us ought should ascend to Heav'n
9172: So prevalent as to concerne the mind
9173: Of God high blest, or to incline his will,
9174: Hard to belief may seem; yet this will Prayer,
9175: Or one short sigh of humane breath, up-borne
9176: Ev'n to the Seat of God.  For since I saught
9177: By Prayer th' offended Deitie to appease,
9178: Kneel'd and before him humbl'd all my heart,
9179: Methought I saw him placable and mild,
9180: Bending his eare; perswasion in me grew
9181: That I was heard with favour; peace returnd
9182: Home to my brest, and to my memorie
9183: His promise, that thy Seed shall bruise our Foe;
9184: Which then not minded in dismay, yet now
9185: Assures me that the bitterness of death
9186: Is past, and we shall live.  Whence Haile to thee,
9187: *Eve* rightly call'd, Mother of all Mankind,
9188: Mother of all things living, since by thee
9189: Man is to live, and all things live for Man.
9190: ¶To whom thus *Eve* with sad demeanour meek.
9191: Ill worthie I such title should belong
9192: To me transgressour, who for thee ordaind
9193: A help, became thy snare; to mee reproach
9194: Rather belongs, distrust and all dispraise:
9195: But infinite in pardon was my Judge,
9196: That I who first brought Death on all, am grac't
9197: The sourse of life; next favourable thou,
9198: Who highly thus to entitle me voutsaf't,
9199: Farr other name deserving.  But the Field
9200: To labour calls us now with sweat impos'd,
9201: Though after sleepless Night; for see the Morn,
9202: All unconcern'd with our unrest, begins
9203: Her rosie progress smiling; let us forth,
9204: I never from thy side henceforth to stray,
9205: Wherere our days work lies, though now enjoind
9206: Laborious, till day droop; while here we dwell,
9207: What can be toilsom in these pleasant Walkes?
9208: Here let us live, though in fall'n state, content.
9209: ¶So spake, so wish'd much-humbl'd *Eve*, but Fate
9210: Subscrib'd not; Nature first gave Signs, imprest
9211: On Bird, Beast, Aire, Aire suddenly eclips'd
9212: After short blush of Morn; nigh in her sight
9213: The Bird of *Jove*, stoopt from his aerie tour,
9214: Two Birds of gayest plume before him drove:
9215: Down from a Hill the Beast that reigns in Woods,
9216: First Hunter then, pursu'd a gentle brace,
9217: Goodliest of all the Forrest, Hart and Hinde;
9218: Direct to th' Eastern Gate was bent thir flight.
9219: *Adam* observ'd, and with his Eye the chase
9220: Pursuing, not unmov'd to *Eve* thus spake.
9221: ¶O *Eve*, some furder change awaits us nigh,
9222: Which Heav'n by these mute signs in Nature shews
9223: Forerunners of his purpose, or to warn
9224: Us haply too secure of our discharge
9225: From penaltie, because from death releast
9226: Some days; how long, and what till then our life,
9227: Who knows, or more then this, that we are dust,
9228: And thither must return and be no more.
9229: Why else this double object in our sight
9230: Of flight pursu'd in th' Air and ore the ground
9231: One way the self-same hour? why in the East
9232: Darkness ere Dayes mid-course, and Morning light
9233: More orient in yon Western Cloud that draws
9234: O're the blew Firmament a radiant white,
9235: And slow descends, with somthing heav'nly fraught.
9236: ¶He err'd not, for by this the heav'nly Bands
9237: Down from a Skie of Jasper lighted now
9238: In Paradise, and on a Hill made alt,
9239: A glorious Apparition, had not doubt
9240: And carnal fear that day dimm'd *Adams* eye.
9241: Not that more glorious, when the Angels met
9243: The field Pavilion'd with his Guardians bright;
9244: Nor that which on the flaming Mount appeerd
9245: In *Dothan*, cover'd with a Camp of Fire,
9246: Against the *Syrian* King, who to surprize
9247: One man, Assassin-like had levied Warr,
9249: In thir bright stand, there left his Powers to seise
9250: Possession of the Garden; hee alone,
9251: To finde where *Adam* shelterd, took his way,
9253: While the great Visitant approachd, thus spake.
9254: ¶*Eve*, now expect great tidings, which perhaps
9255: Of us will soon determin, or impose
9256: New Laws to be observ'd; for I descrie
9257: From yonder blazing Cloud that veils the Hill
9258: One of the heav'nly Host, and by his Gate
9259: None of the meanest, some great Potentate
9260: Or of the Thrones above, such Majestie
9261: Invests him coming; yet not terrible,
9262: That I should fear, nor sociably mild,
9263: As *Raphael*, that I should much confide,
9264: But solemn and sublime, whom not to offend,
9265: With reverence I must meet, and thou retire.
9266: He ended; and th' Arch-Angel soon drew nigh,
9267: Not in his shape Celestial, but as Man
9268: Clad to meet Man; over his lucid Armes
9269: A militarie Vest of purple flowd
9271: Of *Sarra*, worn by Kings and Hero's old
9272: In time of Truce; *Iris* had dipt the wooff;
9273: His starrie Helme unbuckl'd shew'd him prime
9274: In Manhood where Youth ended; by his side
9275: As in a glistering *Zodiac* hung the Sword,
9276: Satans dire dread, and in his hand the Spear.
9277: *Adam* bowd low, hee Kingly from his State
9278: Inclin'd not, but his coming thus declar'd.
9279: ¶*Adam*, Heav'ns high behest no Preface needs:
9280: Sufficient that thy Prayers are heard, and Death,
9281: Then due by sentence when thou didst transgress,
9282: Defeated of his seisure many dayes
9283: Giv'n thee of Grace, wherein thou may'st repent,
9284: And one bad act with many deeds well done
9285: Mayst cover: well may then thy Lord appeas'd
9286: Redeem thee quite from Deaths rapacious claimes;
9287: But longer in this Paradise to dwell
9288: Permits not; to remove thee I am come,
9289: And send thee from the Garden forth to till
9290: The ground whence thou wast tak'n, fitter Soile.
9291: ¶He added not, for *Adam* at the newes
9292: Heart-strook with chilling gripe of sorrow stood,
9293: That all his senses bound; *Eve*, who unseen
9294: Yet all had heard, with audible lament
9295: Discover'd soon the place of her retire.
9296: ¶O unexpected stroke, worse then of Death!
9297: Must I thus leave thee Paradise? thus leave
9298: Thee Native Soile, these happie Walks and Shades,
9299: Fit haunt of Gods? where I had hope to spend,
9300: Quiet though sad, the respit of that day
9301: That must be mortal to us both.  O flours,
9302: That never will in other Climate grow,
9303: My early visitation, and my last
9304: At Eev'n, which I bred up with tender hand
9305: From the first op'ning bud, and gave ye Names,
9306: Who now shall reare ye to the Sun, or ranke
9307: Your Tribes, and water from th' ambrosial Fount?
9308: Thee lastly nuptial Bowre, by mee adornd
9309: With what to sight or smell was sweet; from thee
9310: How shall I part, and whither wander down
9311: Into a lower World, to this obscure
9312: And wilde, how shall we breath in other Aire
9313: Less pure, accustomd to immortal Fruits?
9316: What justly thou hast lost; nor set thy heart,
9317: Thus over fond, on that which is not thine;
9318: Thy going is not lonely, with thee goes
9319: Thy Husband, him to follow thou art bound;
9320: Where he abides, think there thy native soile.
9321: ¶*Adam* by this from the cold sudden damp
9322: Recovering, and his scatterd spirits returnd,
9323: To *Michael* thus his humble words addressd.
9324: ¶Celestial, whether among the Thrones, or nam'd
9325: Of them the Highest, for such of shape may seem
9326: Prince above Princes, gently hast thou tould
9327: Thy message, which might else in telling wound,
9328: And in performing end us; what besides
9329: Of sorrow and dejection and despair
9330: Our frailtie can sustain, thy tidings bring,
9331: Departure from this happy place, our sweet
9333: Familiar to our eyes, all places else
9335: Nor knowing us nor known: and if by prayer
9336: Incessant I could hope to change the will
9337: Of him who all things can, I would not cease
9338: To wearie him with my assiduous cries:
9339: But prayer against his absolute Decree
9340: No more availes then breath against the winde,
9341: Blown stifling back on him that breaths it forth:
9342: Therefore to his great bidding I submit.
9343: This most afflicts me, that departing hence,
9344: As from his face I shall be hid, deprivd
9345: His blessed count'nance; here I could frequent,
9346: With worship, place by place where he voutsaf'd
9347: Presence Divine, and to my Sons relate;
9348: On this Mount he appeerd, under this Tree
9349: Stood visible, among these Pines his voice
9350: I heard, here with him at this Fountain talk'd:
9351: So many grateful Altars I would reare
9352: Of grassie Terfe, and pile up every Stone
9353: Of lustre from the brook, in memorie,
9354: Or monument to Ages, and thereon
9355: Offer sweet smelling Gumms & Fruits and Flours:
9356: In yonder nether World where shall I seek
9357: His bright appearances, or footstep trace?
9358: For though I fled him angrie, yet recall'd
9359: To life prolongd and promisd Race, I now
9360: Gladly behold though but his utmost skirts
9361: Of glory, and farr off his steps adore.
9363: *Adam*, thou know'st Heav'n his, and all the Earth
9364: Not this Rock onely; his Omnipresence fills
9365: Land, Sea, and Aire, and every kinde that lives,
9366: Fomented by his virtual power and warmd:
9367: All th' Earth he gave thee to possess and rule,
9368: No despicable gift; surmise not then
9369: His presence to these narrow bounds confin'd
9370: Of Paradise or *Eden*: this had been
9371: Perhaps thy Capital Seate, from whence had spred
9372: All generations, and had hither come
9373: From all the ends of th' Earth, to celebrate
9374: And reverence thee thir great Progenitor.
9375: But this praeeminence thou hast lost, brought down
9376: To dwell on eeven ground now with thy Sons:
9377: Yet doubt not but in Vallie and in Plaine
9378: God is as here, and will be found alike
9379: Present, and of his presence many a signe
9380: Still following thee, still compassing thee round
9381: With goodness and paternal Love, his Face
9382: Express, and of his steps the track Divine.
9383: Which that thou mayst beleeve, and be confirmd,
9384: Ere thou from hence depart, know I am sent
9385: To shew thee what shall come in future dayes
9386: To thee and to thy Ofspring; good with bad
9387: Expect to hear, supernal Grace contending
9388: With sinfulness of Men; thereby to learn
9389: True patience, and to temper joy with fear
9391: By moderation either state to beare,
9392: Prosperous or adverse: so shalt thou lead
9393: Safest thy life, and best prepar'd endure
9394: Thy mortal passage when it comes.  Ascend
9395: This Hill; let *Eve* (for I have drencht her eyes)
9396: Here sleep below while thou to foresight wak'st,
9397: As once thou slepst, while Shee to life was formd.
9399: Ascend, I follow thee, safe Guide, the path
9400: Thou lead'st me, and to the hand of Heav'n submit,
9401: However chast'ning, to the evil turne
9402: My obvious breast, arming to overcom
9403: By suffering, and earne rest from labour won,
9404: If so I may attain.  So both ascend
9405: In the Visions of God:  It was a Hill
9406: Of Paradise the highest, from whose top
9407: The Hemisphere of Earth in cleerest Ken
9408: Stretcht out to amplest reach of prospect lay.
9409: Not higher that Hill nor wider looking round,
9410: Whereon for different cause the Tempter set
9412: To shew him all Earths Kingdomes and thir Glory.
9413: His Eye might there command wherever stood
9414: City of old or modern Fame, the Seat
9415: Of mightiest Empire, from the destind Walls
9420: Down to the golden *Chersones*, or where
9424: *Turchestan*-born; nor could his eye not ken
9425: Th' Empire of *Negus* to his utmost Port
9430: Or thence from *Niger* Flood to *Atlas* Mount
9433: On *Europe* thence, and where *Rome* was to sway
9434: The World: in Spirit perhaps he also saw
9439: Call *El Dorado:* but to nobler sights
9441: Which that false Fruit that promis'd clearer sight
9442: Had bred; then purg'd with Euphrasie and Rue
9443: The visual Nerve, for he had much to see;
9444: And from the Well of Life three drops instill'd.
9445: So deep the power of these Ingredients pierc'd,
9446: Eevn to the inmost seat of mental sight,
9447: That *Adam* now enforc't to close his eyes,
9448: Sunk down and all his Spirits became intranst:
9449: But him the gentle Angel by the hand
9450: Soon rais'd, and his attention thus recall'd.
9451: ¶*Adam*, now ope thine eyes, and first behold
9452: Th' effects which thy original crime hath wrought
9453: In some to spring from thee, who never touch'd
9454: Th' excepted Tree, nor with the Snake conspir'd,
9455: Nor sinn'd thy sin, yet from that sin derive
9456: Corruption to bring forth more violent deeds.
9457: ¶His eyes he op'nd, and beheld a field,
9458: Part arable and tilth, whereon were Sheaves
9459: New reapt, the other part sheep-walks and foulds;
9460: Ith' midst an Altar as the Land-mark stood
9461: Rustic, of grassie sord; thither anon
9462: A sweatie Reaper from his Tillage brought
9463: First Fruits, the green Eare, and the yellow Sheaf,
9464: Uncull'd, as came to hand; a Shepherd next
9465: More meek came with the Firstlings of his Flock
9466: Choicest and best; then sacrificing, laid
9467: The Inwards and thir Fat, with Incense strew'd,
9468: On the cleft Wood, and all due Rites perform'd.
9469: His Offring soon propitious Fire from Heav'n
9470: Consum'd with nimble glance, and grateful steame;
9471: The others not, for his was not sincere;
9472: Whereat hee inlie rag'd, and as they talk'd,
9473: Smote him into the Midriff with a stone
9474: That beat out life; he fell, and deadly pale
9475: Groand out his Soul with gushing bloud effus'd.
9476: Much at that sight was *Adam* in his heart
9477: Dismai'd, and thus in haste to th' Angel cri'd.
9478: ¶O Teacher, some great mischief hath befall'n
9479: To that meek man, who well had sacrific'd;
9480: Is Pietie thus and pure Devotion paid?
9481: ¶T' whom *Michael* thus, hee also mov'd, repli'd.
9482: These two are Brethren, *Adam*, and to come
9483: Out of thy loyns; th' unjust the just hath slain,
9484: For envie that his Brothers Offering found
9485: From Heav'n acceptance; but the bloodie Fact
9486: Will be aveng'd, and th' others Faith approv'd
9487: Loose no reward, though here thou see him die,
9488: Rowling in dust and gore.  To which our Sire.
9489: ¶Alas, both for the deed and for the cause!
9490: But have I now seen Death?  Is this the way
9491: I must return to native dust?  O sight
9492: Of terrour, foul and ugly to behold,
9493: Horrid to think, how horrible to feel!
9494: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Death thou hast seen
9495: In his first shape on man; but many shapes
9496: Of Death, and many are the wayes that lead
9497: To his grim Cave, all dismal; yet to sense
9498: More terrible at th' entrance then within.
9499: Some, as thou saw'st, by violent stroke shall die,
9500: By Fire, Flood, Famin, by Intemperance more
9501: In Meats and Drinks, which on the Earth shal bring
9502: Diseases dire, of which a monstrous crew
9503: Before thee shall appear; that thou mayst know
9505: Shall bring on men.  Immediately a place
9506: Before his eyes appeard, sad, noysom, dark,
9507: A Lazar-house it seemd, wherein were laid
9508: Numbers of all diseas'd, all maladies
9509: Of gastly Spasm, or racking torture, qualmes
9510: Of heart-sick Agonie, all feavorous kinds,
9512: Intestin Stone and Ulcer, Colic pangs,
9513: Dropsies, and Asthma's, and Joint-racking Rheums.
9514: Dire was the tossing, deep the groans, despair
9515: Tended the sick busiest from Couch to Couch;
9516: And over them triumphant Death his Dart
9517: Shook, but delaid to strike, though oft invok't
9518: With vows, as thir chief good, and final hope.
9519: Sight so deform what heart of Rock could long
9520: Drie-ey'd behold?  *Adam* could not, but wept,
9521: Though not of Woman born; compassion quell'd
9522: His best of Man, and gave him up to tears
9523: A space, till firmer thoughts restraind excess,
9524: And scarce recovering words his plaint renew'd.
9526: Degraded, to what wretched state reserv'd?
9527: Better end heer unborn.  Why is life giv'n
9528: To be thus wrested from us? rather why
9529: Obtruded on us thus? who if we knew
9530: What we receive, would either not accept
9531: Life offer'd, or soon beg to lay it down,
9532: Glad to be so dismist in peace.  Can thus
9533: Th' Image of God in man created once
9534: So goodly and erect, though faultie since,
9535: To such unsightly sufferings be debas't
9536: Under inhuman pains?  Why should not Man,
9538: In part, from such deformities be free,
9539: And for his Makers Image sake exempt?
9541: Forsook them, when themselves they villifi'd
9542: To serve ungovern'd appetite, and took
9543: His Image whom they serv'd, a brutish vice,
9544: Inductive mainly to the sin of *Eve*.
9545: Therefore so abject is thir punishment,
9546: Disfiguring not Gods likeness, but thir own,
9547: Or if his likeness, by themselves defac't
9548: While they pervert pure Natures healthful rules
9549: To loathsom sickness, worthily, since they
9550: Gods Image did not reverence in themselves.
9551: ¶I yeild it just, said *Adam*, and submit.
9552: But is there yet no other way, besides
9553: These painful passages, how we may come
9554: To Death, and mix with our connatural dust?
9555: ¶There is, said *Michael*, if thou well observe
9556: The rule of not too much, by temperance taught
9557: In what thou eatst and drinkst, seeking from thence
9559: Till many years over thy head return:
9560: So maist thou live, till like ripe Fruit thou drop
9561: Into thy Mothers lap, or be with ease
9562: Gatherd, not harshly pluckt, for death mature:
9563: This is old age; but then thou must outlive
9564: Thy youth, thy strength, thy beauty, which will change
9565: To witherd weak & gray; thy Senses then
9566: Obtuse, all taste of pleasure must forgoe,
9567: To what thou hast, and for the Aire of youth
9568: Hopeful and cheerful, in thy blood will reigne
9569: A melancholly damp of cold and dry
9570: To waigh thy spirits down, and last consume
9571: The Balme of Life.  To whom our Ancestor.
9572: ¶Henceforth I flie not Death, nor would prolong
9573: Life much, bent rather how I may be quit
9574: Fairest and easiest of this combrous charge,
9575: Which I must keep till my appointed day
9576: Of rendring up.  *Michael* to him repli'd.
9577: ¶Nor love thy Life, nor hate; but what thou livst
9578: Live well, how long or short permit to Heav'n:
9579: And now prepare thee for another sight.
9580: ¶He lookd and saw a spacious Plaine, whereon
9581: Were Tents of various hue; by some were herds
9582: Of Cattel grazing: others, whence the sound
9583: Of Instruments that made melodious chime
9584: Was heard, of Harp and Organ; and who moovd
9585: Thir stops and chords was seen: his volant touch
9586: Instinct through all proportions low and high
9587: Fled and pursu'd transverse the resonant fugue.
9588: In other part stood one who at the Forge
9589: Labouring, two massie clods of Iron and Brass
9590: Had melted (whether found where casual fire
9591: Had wasted woods on Mountain or in Vale,
9592: Down to the veins of Earth, thence gliding hot
9593: To som Caves mouth, or whether washt by stream
9594: From underground) the liquid Ore he dreind
9595: Into fit moulds prepar'd; from which he formd
9596: First his own Tooles; then, what might else be wrought
9597: Fulfil or grav'n in mettle.  After these,
9598: But on the hether side a different sort
9599: From the high neighbouring Hills, which was thir Seat,
9600: Down to the Plain descended: by thir guise
9601: Just men they seemd, and all thir study bent
9602: To worship God aright, and know his works
9603: Not hid, nor those things lost which might preserve
9604: Freedom and Peace to men: they on the Plain
9605: Long had not walkt, when from the Tents behold
9606: A Beavie of fair Women, richly gay
9607: In Gems and wanton dress; to the Harp they sung
9608: Soft amorous Ditties, and in dance came on:
9609: The Men though grave, ey'd them, and let thir eyes
9610: Rove without rein, till in the amorous Net
9611: Fast caught, they lik'd, and each his liking chose;
9612: And now of love they treat till th' Eevning Star
9613: Loves Harbinger appeerd; then all in heat
9614: They light the Nuptial Torch, and bid invoke
9615: Hymen, then first to marriage Rites invok't;
9616: With Feast and Musick all the Tents resound.
9617: Such happy interview and fair event
9618: Of love & youth not lost, Songs, Garlands, Flours,
9619: And charming Symphonies attach'd the heart
9620: Of *Adam*, soon enclin'd to admit delight,
9621: The bent of Nature; which he thus express'd.
9622: ¶True opener of mine eyes, prime Angel blest,
9623: Much better seems this Vision, and more hope
9624: Of peaceful dayes portends, then those two past;
9625: Those were of hate and death, or pain much worse,
9626: Here Nature seems fulfilld in all her ends.
9627: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Judg not what is best
9628: By pleasure, though to Nature seeming meet,
9629: Created, as thou art, to nobler end
9631: Those Tents thou sawst so pleasant, were the Tents
9632: Of wickedness, wherein shall dwell his Race
9633: Who slew his Brother; studious they appere
9634: Of Arts that polish Life, Inventers rare,
9635: Unmindful of thir Maker, though his Spirit
9636: Taught them, but they his gifts acknowledg'd none.
9637: Yet they a beauteous ofspring shall beget;
9638: For that fair femal Troop thou sawst, that seemd
9639: Of Goddesses, so blithe, so smooth, so gay,
9640: Yet empty of all good wherein consists
9641: Womans domestic honour and chief praise;
9642: Bred onely and completed to the taste
9643: Of lustful apperence, to sing, to dance,
9644: To dress, and troule the Tongue, and roule the Eye.
9645: To these that sober Race of Men, whose lives
9646: Religious titl'd them the Sons of God,
9647: Shall yeild up all thir vertue, all thir fame
9648: Ignobly, to the trains and to the smiles
9649: Of these fair Atheists, and now swim in joy,
9650: (Erelong to swim at larg) and laugh; for which
9651: The world erelong a world of tears must weepe.
9652: ¶To whom thus *Adam* of short joy bereft.
9653: O pittie and shame, that they who to live well
9654: Enterd so faire, should turn aside to tread
9655: Paths indirect, or in the mid way faint!
9656: But still I see the tenor of Mans woe
9657: Holds on the same, from Woman to begin.
9659: Said th' Angel, who should better hold his place
9660: By wisdome, and superiour gifts receavd.
9661: But now prepare thee for another Scene.
9662: ¶He lookd and saw wide Territorie spred
9663: Before him, Towns, and rural works between,
9664: Cities of Men with lofty Gates and Towrs,
9665: Concours in Arms, fierce Faces threatning Warr,
9666: Giants of mightie Bone, and bould emprise;
9667: Part wield thir Arms, part courb the foaming Steed,
9668: Single or in Array of Battel rang'd
9669: Both Horse and Foot, nor idely mustring stood;
9670: One way a Band select from forage drives
9671: A herd of Beeves, faire Oxen and faire Kine
9672: From a fat Meddow ground; or fleecy Flock,
9673: Ewes and thir bleating Lambs over the Plaine,
9674: Thir Bootie; scarce with Life the Shepherds flye,
9675: But call in aide, which tacks a bloody Fray;
9676: With cruel Tournament the Squadrons joine;
9677: Where Cattel pastur'd late, now scatterd lies
9678: With Carcasses and Arms th' ensanguind Field
9679: Deserted: Others to a Citie strong
9680: Lay Siege, encampt; by Batterie, Scale, and Mine,
9681: Assaulting; others from the Wall defend
9682: With Dart and Jav'lin, Stones and sulfurous Fire;
9683: On each hand slaughter and gigantic deeds.
9684: In other part the scepter'd Haralds call
9685: To Council in the Citie Gates: anon
9686: Grey-headed men and grave, with Warriours mixt,
9687: Assemble, and Harangues are heard, but soon
9688: In factious opposition, till at last
9689: Of middle Age one rising, eminent
9690: In wise deport, spake much of Right and Wrong,
9691: Of Justice, of Religion, Truth and Peace,
9692: And Judgement from above: him old and young
9693: Exploded, and had seiz'd with violent hands,
9694: Had not a Cloud descending snatch'd him thence
9695: Unseen amid the throng: so violence
9697: Through all the Plain, and refuge none was found.
9698: *Adam* was all in tears, and to his guide
9699: Lamenting turnd full sad; O what are these,
9700: Deaths Ministers, not Men, who thus deal Death
9702: Ten thousand fould the sin of him who slew
9703: His Brother; for of whom such massacher
9704: Make they but of thir Brethren, men of men?
9705: But who was that Just Man, whom had not Heav'n
9706: Rescu'd, had in his Righteousness bin lost?
9707: ¶To whom thus *Michael*; These are the product
9708: Of those ill-mated Marriages thou saw'st;
9709: Where good with bad were matcht, who of themselves
9710: Abhor to joyn; and by imprudence mixt,
9711: Produce prodigious Births of bodie or mind.
9712: Such were these Giants, men of high renown;
9713: For in those dayes Might onely shall be admir'd,
9714: And Valour and Heroic Vertu call'd;
9715: To overcome in Battel, and subdue
9716: Nations, and bring home spoils with infinite
9717: Man-slaughter, shall be held the highest pitch
9718: Of human Glorie, and for Glorie done
9719: Of triumph, to be styl'd great Conquerours,
9720: Patrons of Mankind, Gods, and Sons of Gods,
9721: Destroyers rightlier call'd and Plagues of men.
9722: Thus Fame shall be achiev'd, renown on Earth,
9723: And what most merits fame in silence hid.
9724: But hee the seventh from thee, whom thou beheldst
9725: The onely righteous in a World perverse,
9726: And therefore hated, therefore so beset
9727: With Foes for daring single to be just,
9728: And utter odious Truth, that God would come
9729: To judge them with his Saints: Him the most High
9730: Rapt in a balmie Cloud with winged Steeds
9731: Did, as thou sawst, receave, to walk with God
9732: High in Salvation and the Climes of bliss,
9733: Exempt from Death; to shew thee what reward
9734: Awaits the good, the rest what punishment;
9735: Which now direct thine eyes and soon behold.
9736: ¶He look'd, & saw the face of things quite chang'd;
9737: The brazen Throat of Warr had ceast to roar,
9738: All now was turn'd to jollitie and game,
9739: To luxurie and riot, feast and dance,
9741: Rape or Adulterie, where passing faire
9742: Allurd them; thence from Cups to civil Broiles.
9743: At length a Reverend Sire among them came,
9744: And of thir doings great dislike declar'd,
9745: And testifi'd against thir wayes; hee oft
9747: Triumphs or Festivals, and to them preachd
9748: Conversion and Repentance, as to Souls
9750: But all in vain: which when he saw, he ceas'd
9751: Contending, and remov'd his Tents farr off;
9752: Then from the Mountain hewing Timber tall,
9753: Began to build a Vessel of huge bulk,
9754: Measur'd by Cubit, length, & breadth, and highth,
9755: Smeard round with Pitch, and in the side a dore
9756: Contriv'd, and of provisions laid in large
9757: For Man and Beast: when loe a wonder strange!
9758: Of everie Beast, and Bird, and Insect small
9759: Came seavens, and pairs, and enterd in, as taught
9760: Thir order; last the Sire, and his three Sons
9761: With thir four Wives, and God made fast the dore.
9762: Meanwhile the Southwind rose, & with black wings
9763: Wide hovering, all the Clouds together drove
9764: From under Heav'n; the Hills to their supplie
9765: Vapour, and Exhalation dusk and moist,
9766: Sent up amain; and now the thick'nd Skie
9767: Like a dark Ceeling stood; down rush'd the Rain
9768: Impetuous, and continu'd till the Earth
9769: No more was seen; the floating Vessel swum
9770: Uplifted; and secure with beaked prow
9771: Rode tilting o're the Waves, all dwellings else
9772: Flood overwhelmd, and them with all thir pomp
9773: Deep under water rould; Sea cover'd Sea,
9774: Sea without shoar; and in thir Palaces
9775: Where luxurie late reign'd, Sea-monsters whelp'd
9776: And stabl'd; of Mankind, so numerous late,
9777: All left, in one small bottom swum imbark't.
9778: How didst thou grieve then, *Adam*, to behold
9779: The end of all thy Ofspring, end so sad,
9781: Of tears and sorrow a Floud thee also drown'd,
9782: And sunk thee as thy Sons; till gently reard
9783: By th' Angel, on thy feet thou stoodst at last,
9784: Though comfortless, as when a Father mourns
9785: His Childern, all in view destroyd at once;
9786: And scarce to th' Angel utterdst thus thy plaint.
9787: ¶O Visions ill foreseen! better had I
9788: Liv'd ignorant of future, so had borne
9789: My part of evil onely, each dayes lot
9790: Anough to bear; those now, that were dispenst
9791: The burd'n of many Ages, on me light
9792: At once, by my foreknowledge gaining Birth
9793: Abortive, to torment me ere thir being,
9794: With thought that they must be.  Let no man seek
9795: Henceforth to be foretold what shall befall
9796: Him or his Childern, evil he may be sure,
9797: Which neither his foreknowing can prevent,
9798: And hee the future evil shall no less
9799: In apprehension then in substance feel
9800: Grievous to bear: but that care now is past,
9801: Man is not whom to warne: those few escap't
9802: Famin and anguish will at last consume
9803: Wandring that watrie Desert: I had hope
9804: When violence was ceas't, and Warr on Earth,
9805: All would have then gon well, peace would have crownd
9806: With length of happy days the race of man;
9807: But I was farr deceav'd; for now I see
9808: Peace to corrupt no less then Warr to waste.
9809: How comes it thus? unfould, Celestial Guide,
9810: And whether here the Race of man will end.
9811: To whom thus *Michael*.  Those whom last thou sawst
9812: In triumph and luxurious wealth, are they
9813: First seen in acts of prowess eminent
9814: And great exploits, but of true vertu void;
9815: Who having spilt much blood, and don much waste
9817: Fame in the World, high titles, and rich prey,
9818: Shall change thir course to pleasure, ease, and sloth,
9819: Surfet, and lust, till wantonness and pride
9820: Raise out of friendship hostil deeds in Peace.
9821: The conquerd also, and enslav'd by Warr
9822: Shall with thir freedom lost all vertu loose
9823: And feare of God, from whom thir pietie feign'd
9824: In sharp contest of Battel found no aide
9825: Against invaders; therefore coold in zeale
9826: Thenceforth shall practice how to live secure,
9827: Worldlie or dissolute, on what thir Lords
9828: Shall leave them to enjoy; for th' Earth shall bear
9829: More then anough, that temperance may be tri'd:
9830: So all shall turn degenerate, all deprav'd,
9831: Justice and Temperance, Truth and Faith forgot;
9832: One Man except, the onely Son of light
9833: In a dark Age, against example good,
9834: Against allurement, custom, and a World
9835: Offended; fearless of reproach and scorn,
9836: Or violence, hee of thir wicked wayes
9837: Shall them admonish, and before them set
9838: The paths of righteousness, how much more safe,
9839: And full of peace, denouncing wrauth to come
9840: On thir impenitence; and shall returne
9841: Of them derided, but of God observd
9842: The one just Man alive; by his command
9843: Shall build a wondrous Ark, as thou beheldst,
9844: To save himself and houshold from amidst
9845: A World devote to universal rack.
9846: No sooner hee with them of Man and Beast
9847: Select for life shall in the Ark be lodg'd,
9848: And shelterd round, but all the Cataracts
9849: Of Heav'n set open on the Earth shall powre
9850: Raine day and night, all fountaines of the Deep
9851: Broke up, shall heave the Ocean to usurp
9852: Beyond all bounds, till inundation rise
9853: Above the highest Hills: then shall this Mount
9854: Of Paradise by might of Waves be moovd
9855: Out of his place, pushd by the horned floud,
9856: With all his verdure spoil'd, and Trees adrift
9857: Down the great River to the op'ning Gulf,
9858: And there take root an Iland salt and bare,
9859: The haunt of Seales and Orcs, and Sea-mews clang.
9860: To teach thee that God attributes to place
9861: No sanctitie, if none be thither brought
9862: By Men who there frequent, or therein dwell.
9863: And now what further shall ensue, behold.
9864: ¶He lookd, and saw the Ark hull on the floud,
9865: Which now abated, for the Clouds were fled,
9866: Drivn by a keen North-winde, that blowing drie
9867: Wrinkl'd the face of Deluge, as decai'd;
9868: And the cleer Sun on his wide watrie Glass
9869: Gaz'd hot, and of the fresh Wave largely drew,
9870: As after thirst, which made thir flowing shrink
9871: From standing lake to tripping ebbe, that stole
9872: With soft foot towards the deep, who now had stopt
9873: His Sluces, as the Heav'n his windows shut.
9874: The Ark no more now flotes, but seems on ground
9875: Fast on the top of som high mountain fixt.
9876: And now the tops of Hills as Rocks appeer;
9877: With clamor thence the rapid Currents drive
9878: Towards the retreating Sea thir furious tyde.
9879: Forthwith from out the Arke a Raven flies,
9880: And after him, the surer messenger,
9881: A Dove sent forth once and agen to spie
9882: Green Tree or ground whereon his foot may light;
9883: The second time returning, in his Bill
9884: An Olive leafe he brings, pacific signe:
9885: Anon drie ground appeers, and from his Arke
9886: The ancient Sire descends with all his Train;
9887: Then with uplifted hands, and eyes devout,
9888: Grateful to Heav'n, over his head beholds
9889: A dewie Cloud, and in the Cloud a Bow
9890: Conspicuous with three lifted colours gay,
9891: Betok'ning peace from God, and Cov'nant new.
9892: Whereat the heart of *Adam* erst so sad
9893: Greatly rejoyc'd, and thus his joy broke forth.
9894: ¶O thou that future things canst represent
9895: As present, Heav'nly instructer, I revive
9896: At this last sight, assur'd that Man shall live
9897: With all the Creatures, and thir seed preserve.
9898: Farr less I now lament for one whole World
9899: Of wicked Sons destroyd, then I rejoyce
9900: For one Man found so perfet and so just,
9901: That God voutsafes to raise another World
9902: From him, and all his anger to forget.
9903: But say, what mean those colourd streaks in Heavn,
9904: Distended as the Brow of God appeas'd,
9905: Or serve they as a flourie verge to binde
9906: The fluid skirts of that same watrie Cloud,
9907: Least it again dissolve and showr the Earth?
9908: ¶To whom th' Archangel.  Dextrously thou aim'st;
9909: So willingly doth God remit his Ire,
9910: Though late repenting him of Man deprav'd,
9911: Griev'd at his heart, when looking down he saw
9912: The whole Earth fill'd with violence, and all flesh
9913: Corrupting each thir way; yet those remoov'd,
9914: Such grace shall one just Man find in his sight,
9915: That he relents, not to blot out mankind,
9916: And makes a Covenant never to destroy
9917: The Earth again by flood, nor let the Sea
9918: Surpass his bounds, nor Rain to drown the World
9919: With Man therein or Beast; but when he brings
9920: Over the Earth a Cloud, will therein set
9921: His triple-colour'd Bow, whereon to look
9922: And call to mind his Cov'nant: Day and Night,
9923: Seed time and Harvest, Heat and hoary Frost
9924: Shall hold thir course, till fire purge all things new,
9925: Both Heav'n and Earth, wherein the just shall dwell.
9926: Thus thou hast seen one World begin and end;
9927: And Man as from a second stock proceed.
9928: Much thou hast yet to see, but I perceave
9929: Thy mortal sight to faile; objects divine
9930: Must needs impaire and wearie human sense:
9931: Henceforth what is to com I will relate,
9932: Thou therefore give due audience, and attend.
9933: This second sours of Men, while yet but few,
9934: And while the dread of judgement past remains
9935: Fresh in thir mindes, fearing the Deitie,
9936: With some regard to what is just and right
9937: Shall lead thir lives, and multiplie apace,
9938: Labouring the soile, and reaping plenteous crop,
9939: Corn wine and oyle; and from the herd or flock,
9940: Oft sacrificing Bullock, Lamb, or Kid,
9941: With large Wine-offerings pour'd, and sacred Feast
9942: Shal spend thir dayes in joy unblam'd, and dwell
9943: Long time in peace by Families and Tribes
9944: Under paternal rule; till one shall rise
9945: Of proud ambitious heart, who not content
9948: Over his brethren, and quite dispossess
9949: Concord and law of Nature from the Earth;
9950: Hunting (and Men not Beasts shall be his game)
9951: With Warr and hostile snare such as refuse
9953: A mightie Hunter thence he shall be styl'd
9954: Before the Lord, as in despite of Heav'n,
9955: Or from Heav'n claming second Sovrantie;
9956: And from Rebellion shall derive his name,
9957: Though of Rebellion others he accuse.
9958: Hee with a crew, whom like Ambition joyns
9959: With him or under him to tyrannize,
9960: Marching from *Eden* towards the West, shall finde
9961: The Plain, wherein a black bituminous gurge
9962: Boiles out from under ground, the mouth of Hell;
9963: Of Brick, and of that stuff they cast to build
9964: A Citie & Towre, whose top may reach to Heav'n;
9965: And get themselves a name, least far disperst
9966: In foraign Lands thir memorie be lost,
9967: Regardless whether good or evil fame.
9968: But God who oft descends to visit men
9969: Unseen, and through thir habitations walks
9970: To mark thir doings, them beholding soon,
9971: Comes down to see thir Citie, ere the Tower
9972: Obstruct Heav'n Towrs, and in derision sets
9973: Upon thir Tongues a various Spirit to rase
9974: Quite out thir Native Language, and instead
9975: To sow a jangling noise of words unknown:
9976: Forthwith a hideous gabble rises loud
9977: Among the Builders; each to other calls
9978: Not understood, till hoarse, and all in rage,
9979: As mockt they storm; great laughter was in Heav'n
9980: And looking down, to see the hubbub strange
9981: And hear the din; thus was the building left
9982: Ridiculous, and the work Confusion nam'd.
9984: O execrable Son so to aspire
9985: Above his Brethren, to himself affirming
9986: Authoritie usurpt, from God not giv'n:
9987: He gave us onely over Beast, Fish, Fowl
9988: Dominion absolute; that right we hold
9989: By his donation; but Man over men
9990: He made not Lord; such title to himself
9991: Reserving, human left from human free.
9992: But this Usurper his encroachment proud
9993: Stayes not on Man; to God his Tower intends
9994: Siege and defiance: Wretched man! what food
9995: Will he convey up thither to sustain
9996: Himself and his rash Armie, where thin Aire
9997: Above the Clouds will pine his entrails gross,
9998: And famish him of Breath, if not of Bread?
10000: That Son, who on the quiet state of men
10001: Such trouble brought, affecting to subdue
10003: Since thy original lapse, true Libertie
10004: Is lost, which alwayes with right Reason dwells
10005: Twinn'd, and from her hath no dividual being:
10006: Reason in man obscur'd, or not obeyd,
10008: And upstart Passions catch the Government
10009: From Reason, and to servitude reduce
10010: Man till then free.  Therefore since hee permits
10011: Within himself unworthie Powers to reign
10012: Over free Reason, God in Judgement just
10013: Subjects him from without to violent Lords;
10015: His outward freedom: Tyrannie must be,
10016: Though to the Tyrant thereby no excuse.
10017: Yet somtimes Nations will decline so low
10018: From vertue, which is reason, that no wrong,
10019: But Justice, and some fatal curse annext
10020: Deprives them of thir outward libertie,
10021: Thir inward lost: Witness th' irreverent Son
10022: Of him who built the Ark, who for the shame
10023: Don to his Father, heard this heavie curse,
10024: *Servant of Servants*, on his vitious Race.
10025: Thus will this latter, as the former World,
10026: Still tend from bad to worse, till God at last
10028: His presence from among them, and avert
10029: His holy Eyes; resolving from thenceforth
10030: To leave them to thir own polluted wayes;
10031: And one peculiar Nation to select
10032: From all the rest, of whom to be invok'd,
10033: A Nation from one faithful man to spring:
10034: Him on this side *Euphrates* yet residing,
10035: Bred up in Idol-worship; O that men
10036: (Canst thou believe?) should be so stupid grown,
10037: While yet the Patriark liv'd, who scap'd the Flood,
10038: As to forsake the living God, and fall
10039: To-worship thir own work in Wood and Stone
10040: For Gods! yet him God the most High voutsafes
10041: To call by Vision from his Fathers house,
10042: His kindred and false Gods, into a Land
10043: Which he will shew him, and from him will raise
10044: A mightie Nation, and upon him showre
10045: His benediction so, that in his Seed
10046: All Nations shall be blest; hee straight obeys,
10047: Not knowing to what Land, yet firm believes:
10048: I see him, but thou canst not, with what Faith
10049: He leaves his Gods, his Friends, and native Soile
10051: To *Haran*, after him a cumbrous Train
10052: Of Herds and Flocks, and numerous servitude;
10053: Not wandring poor, but trusting all his wealth
10054: With God, who call'd him, in a land unknown.
10055: *Canaan* he now attains, I see his Tents
10056: Pitcht about *Sechem*, and the neighbouring Plaine
10057: Of *Moreb* there by promise he receaves
10058: Gift to his Progenie of all that Land;
10059: From *Hamath* Northward to the Desert South
10060: (Things by thir names I call, though yet unnam'd)
10061: From *Hermon* East to the great Western Sea,
10062: Mount *Hermon*, yonder Sea, each place behold
10063: In prospect, as I point them; on the shoare
10065: *Jordan*, true limit Eastward; but his Sons
10066: Shall dwell to *Senir*, that long ridge of Hills.
10067: This ponder, that all Nations of the Earth
10068: Shall in his Seed be blessed; by that Seed
10069: Is meant thy great deliverer, who shall bruise
10070: The Serpents head; whereof to thee anon
10071: Plainlier shall be reveald.  This Patriarch blest,
10072: Whom *Faithful Abraham* due time shall call,
10073: A Son, and of his Son a Grand-childe leaves,
10074: Like him in faith, in wisdom, and renown;
10075: The Grandchilde with twelve Sons increast, departs
10076: From *Canaan*, to a Land hereafter call'd
10078: See where it flows, disgorging at seaven mouthes
10079: Into the Sea: to sojourn in that Land
10080: He comes invited by a yonger Son
10081: In time of dearth, a Son whose worthy deeds
10082: Raise him to be the second in that Realme
10083: Of *Pharao*: there he dies, and leaves his Race
10084: Growing into a Nation, and now grown
10085: Suspected to a sequent King, who seeks
10086: To stop thir overgrowth, as inmate guests
10087: Too numerous; whence of guests he makes them slaves
10088: Inhospitably, and kills thir infant Males:
10089: Till by two brethren (those two brethren call
10090: *Moses* and *Aaron*) sent from God to claime
10091: His people from enthralment, they return
10092: With glory and spoile back to thir promis'd Land.
10093: But first the lawless Tyrant, who denies
10094: To know thir God, or message to regard,
10095: Must be compelld by Signes and Judgements dire;
10096: To blood unshed the Rivers must be turnd,
10097: Frogs, Lice and Flies must all his Palace fill
10098: With loath'd intrusion, and fill all the land;
10099: His Cattel must of Rot and Murren die,
10100: Botches and blaines must all his flesh imboss,
10101: And all his people; Thunder mixt with Haile,
10102: Haile mixt with fire must rend th' *Egyptian* Skie
10103: And wheel on th' Earth, devouring where it rouls;
10104: What it devours not, Herb, or Fruit, or Graine,
10105: A darksom Cloud of Locusts swarming down
10106: Must eat, and on the ground leave nothing green:
10107: Darkness must overshadow all his bounds,
10108: Palpable darkness, and blot out three dayes;
10109: Last with one midnight stroke all the first-born
10110: Of *Egypt* must lie dead.  Thus with ten wounds
10111: This River-dragon tam'd at length submits
10112: To let his sojourners depart, and oft
10113: Humbles his stubborn heart, but still as Ice
10114: More hard'nd after thaw, till in his rage
10115: Pursuing whom he late dismissd, the Sea
10116: Swallows him with his Host, but them lets pass
10117: As on drie land between two christal walls,
10118: Aw'd by the rod of *Moses* so to stand
10119: Divided, till his rescu'd gain thir shoar:
10120: Such wondrous power God to his Saint will lend,
10121: Though present in his Angel, who shall goe
10122: Before them in a Cloud, and Pillar of Fire,
10123: To guide them in thir journey, and remove
10124: Behinde them, while th' obdurat King pursues:
10125: All night he will pursue, but his approach
10126: Darkness defends between till morning Watch;
10127: Then through the Firey Pillar and the Cloud
10128: God looking forth will trouble all his Host
10129: And craze thir Chariot wheels: when by command
10130: *Moses* once more his potent Rod extends
10131: Over the Sea; the Sea his Rod obeys;
10132: On thir imbattelld ranks the Waves return,
10133: And overwhelm thir Warr: the Race elect
10134: Safe towards *Canaan* from the shoar advance
10135: Through the wilde Desert, not the readiest way,
10137: Warr terrifie them inexpert, and feare
10138: Return them back to *Egypt*, choosing rather
10139: Inglorious life with servitude; for life
10140: To noble and ignoble is more sweet
10141: Untraind in Armes, where rashness leads not on.
10142: This also shall they gain by thir delay
10143: In the wide Wilderness, there they shall found
10144: Thir government, and thir great Senate choose
10145: Through the twelve Tribes, to rule by Laws ordaind:
10146: God from the Mount of *Sinai*, whose gray top
10147: Shall tremble, he descending, will himself
10148: In Thunder Lightning and loud Trumpets sound
10149: Ordaine them Lawes; part such as appertaine
10150: To civil Justice, part religious Rites
10151: Of sacrifice, informing them, by types
10152: And shadowes, of that destind Seed to bruise
10153: The Serpent, by what meanes he shall achieve
10154: Mankinds deliverance.  But the voice of God
10155: To mortal eare is dreadful; they beseech
10156: That *Moses* might report to them his will,
10157: And terror cease; he grants them thir desire,
10158: Instructed that to God is no access
10159: Without Mediator, whose high Office now
10161: One greater, of whose day he shall foretell,
10162: And all the Prophets in thir Age the times
10163: Of great *Messiah* shall sing.  Thus Laws and Rites
10164: Establisht, such delight hath God in Men
10165: Obedient to his will, that he voutsafes
10166: Among them to set up his Tabernacle,
10167: The holy One with mortal Men to dwell:
10168: By his prescript a Sanctuary is fram'd
10169: Of Cedar, overlaid with Gold, therein
10170: An Ark, and in the Ark his Testimony,
10171: The Records of his Cov'nant, over these
10172: A Mercie-seat of Gold between the wings
10173: Of two bright Cherubim, before him burn
10174: Seaven Lamps as in a Zodiac representing
10175: The Heav'nly fires; over the Tent a Cloud
10176: Shall rest by Day, a fierie gleame by Night,
10177: Save when they journie, and at length they come,
10178: Conducted by his Angel to the Land
10179: Promisd to *Abraham* and his Seed: the rest
10180: Were long to tell, how many Battels fought,
10181: How many Kings destroyd, and Kingdoms won,
10182: Or how the Sun shall in mid Heav'n stand still
10183: A day entire, and Nights due course adjourne,
10184: Mans voice commanding, Sun in *Gibeon* stand,
10185: And thou Moon in the vale of *Aialon*,
10186: Till *Israel* overcome; so call the third
10187: From *Abraham*, Son of *Isaac*, and from him
10188: His whole descent, who thus shall *Canaan* win.
10190: Enlightner of my darkness, gracious things
10191: Thou hast reveald, those chiefly which concerne
10192: Just *Abraham* and his Seed: now first I finde
10193: Mine eyes true op'ning, and my heart much eas'd,
10194: Erwhile perplext with thoughts what would becom
10195: Of mee and all Mankind; but now I see
10196: His day, in whom all Nations shall be blest,
10197: Favour unmerited by me, who sought
10199: This yet I apprehend not, why to those
10200: Among whom God will deigne to dwell on Earth
10201: So many and so various Laws are giv'n;
10202: So many Laws argue so many sins
10203: Among them; how can God with such reside?
10204: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Doubt not but that sin
10205: Will reign among them, as of thee begot;
10206: And therefore was Law given them to evince
10207: Thir natural pravitie, by stirring up
10208: Sin against Law to fight; that when they see
10209: Law can discover sin, but not remove,
10210: Save by those shadowie expiations weak,
10211: The bloud of Bulls and Goats, they may conclude
10212: Some bloud more precious must be paid for Man,
10213: Just for unjust, that in such righteousness
10214: To them by Faith imputed, they may finde
10216: Of Conscience, which the Law by Ceremonies
10217: Cannot appease, nor Man the moral part
10218: Perform, and not performing cannot live.
10219: So Law appears imperfet, and but giv'n
10220: With purpose to resign them in full time
10221: Up to a better Cov'nant, disciplin'd
10222: From shadowie Types to Truth, from Flesh to Spirit,
10223: From imposition of strict Laws, to free
10224: Acceptance of large Grace, from servil fear
10225: To filial, works of Law to works of Faith.
10226: And therefore shall not *Moses*, though of God
10227: Highly belov'd, being but the Minister
10228: Of Law, his people into *Canaan* lead;
10230: His Name and Office bearing, who shall quell
10231: The adversarie Serpent, and bring back
10232: Through the worlds wilderness long wanderd man
10233: Safe to eternal Paradise of rest.
10234: Meanwhile they in thir earthly *Canaan* plac't
10235: Long time shall dwell and prosper, but when sins
10237: Provoking God to raise them enemies:
10238: From whom as oft he saves them penitent
10239: By Judges first, then under Kings; of whom
10240: The second, both for pietie renownd
10241: And puissant deeds, a promise shall receive
10243: For ever shall endure; the like shall sing
10244: All Prophecie, That of the Royal Stock
10245: Of *David* (so I name this King) shall rise
10246: A Son, the Womans Seed to thee foretold,
10247: Foretold to *Abraham*, as in whom shall trust
10248: All Nations, and to Kings foretold, of Kings
10249: The last, for of his Reign shall be no end.
10250: But first a long succession must ensue,
10251: And his next Son for Wealth and Wisdom fam'd,
10252: The clouded Ark of God till then in Tents
10253: Wandring, shall in a glorious Temple enshrine.
10254: Such follow him, as shall be registerd
10255: Part good, part bad, of bad the longer scrowle,
10256: Whose foul Idolatries, and other faults
10257: Heapt to the popular summe, will so incense
10258: God, as to leave them, and expose thir Land,
10259: Thir Citie, his Temple, and his holy Ark
10260: With all his sacred things, a scorn and prey
10261: To that proud Citie, whose high Walls thou saw'st
10263: There in captivitie he lets them dwell
10264: The space of seventie years, then brings them back,
10265: Remembring mercie, and his Cov'nant sworn
10266: To *David*, stablisht as the dayes of Heav'n.
10267: Returnd from *Babylon* by leave of Kings
10268: Thir Lords, whom God dispos'd, the house of God
10269: They first re-edifie, and for a while
10270: In mean estate live moderate, till grown
10271: In wealth and multitude, factious they grow;
10272: But first among the Priests dissension springs,
10273: Men who attend the Altar, and should most
10274: Endeavour Peace: thir strife pollution brings
10275: Upon the Temple it self: at last they seise
10276: The Scepter, and regard not *Davids* Sons,
10277: Then loose it to a stranger, that the true
10279: Barr'd of his right; yet at his Birth a Starr
10280: Unseen before in Heav'n proclaims him com,
10281: And guides the Eastern Sages, who enquire
10282: His place, to offer Incense, Myrrh, and Gold;
10283: His place of birth a solemn Angel tells
10284: To simple Shepherds, keeping watch by night;
10285: They gladly thither haste, and by a Quire
10286: Of squadrond Angels hear his Carol sung.
10287: A Virgin is his Mother, but his Sire
10288: The Power of the most High; he shall ascend
10289: The Throne hereditarie, and bound his Reign
10290: With earths wide bounds, his glory with the Heav'ns.
10292: Surcharg'd, as had like grief bin dew'd in tears,
10293: Without the vent of words, which these he breathd.
10295: Of utmost hope! now clear I understand
10296: What oft my steddiest thoughts have searcht in vain,
10297: Why our great expectation should be call'd
10298: The seed of Woman: Virgin Mother, Haile,
10299: High in the love of Heav'n, yet from my Loynes
10300: Thou shalt proceed, and from thy Womb the Son
10301: Of God most High; So God with man unites.
10302: Needs must the Serpent now his capital bruise
10303: Expect with mortal paine: say where and when
10304: Thir fight, what stroke shall bruise the Victors heel.
10305: ¶To whom thus *Michael*.  Dream not of thir fight,
10306: As of a Duel, or the local wounds
10307: Of head or heel: not therefore joynes the Son
10308: Manhood to God-head, with more strength to foil
10309: Thy enemie; nor so is overcome
10310: *Satan*, whose fall from Heav'n, a deadlier bruise,
10311: Disabl'd not to give thee thy deaths wound:
10312: Which hee, who comes thy Saviour, shall recure,
10313: Not by destroying *Satan*, but his works
10314: In thee and in thy Seed: nor can this be,
10315: But by fulfilling that which thou didst want,
10316: Obedience to the Law of God, impos'd
10317: On penaltie of death, and suffering death,
10318: The penaltie to thy transgression due,
10319: And due to theirs which out of thine will grow:
10320: So onely can high Justice rest appaid.
10321: The Law of God exact he shall fulfill
10322: Both by obedience and by love, though love
10323: Alone fulfill the Law; thy punishment
10324: He shall endure by coming in the Flesh
10325: To a reproachful life and cursed death,
10326: Proclaiming Life to all who shall believe
10327: In his redemption, and that his obedience
10328: Imputed becomes theirs by Faith, his merits
10329: To save them, not thir own, though legal works.
10330: For this he shall live hated, be blasphem'd,
10331: Seis'd on by force, judg'd, and to death condemnd
10332: A shameful and accurst, naild to the Cross
10333: By his own Nation, slaine for bringing Life;
10334: But to the Cross he nailes thy Enemies,
10335: The Law that is against thee, and the sins
10336: Of all mankinde, with him there crucifi'd,
10337: Never to hurt them more who rightly trust
10338: In this his satisfaction; so he dies,
10339: But soon revives, Death over him no power
10340: Shall long usurp; ere the third dawning light
10341: Returne, the Starres of Morn shall see him rise
10342: Out of his grave, fresh as the dawning light,
10343: Thy ransom paid, which Man from death redeems,
10344: His death for Man, as many as offerd Life
10345: Neglect not, and the benefit imbrace
10346: By Faith not void of works: this God-like act
10347: Annuls thy doom, the death thou shouldst have dy'd,
10348: In sin for ever lost from life; this act
10349: Shall bruise the head of *Satan*, crush his strength
10350: Defeating Sin and Death, his two maine armes,
10351: And fix farr deeper in his head thir stings
10352: Then temporal death shall bruise the Victors heel,
10353: Or theirs whom he redeems, a death like sleep,
10354: A gentle wafting to immortal Life.
10355: Nor after resurrection shall he stay
10356: Longer on Earth then certaine times to appeer
10357: To his Disciples, Men who in his Life
10358: Still follow'd him; to them shall leave in charge
10359: To teach all nations what of him they learn'd
10360: And his Salvation, them who shall beleeve
10361: Baptizing in the profluent streame, the signe
10362: Of washing them from guilt of sin to Life
10363: Pure, and in mind prepar'd, if so befall,
10364: For death, like that which the redeemer dy'd.
10365: All Nations they shall teach; for from that day
10366: Not onely to the Sons of *Abrahams* Loines
10367: Salvation shall be Preacht, but to the Sons
10368: Of *Abrahams* Faith wherever through the world;
10369: So in his seed all Nations shall be blest.
10370: Then to the Heav'n of Heav'ns he shall ascend
10371: With victory, triumphing through the aire
10372: Over his foes and thine; there shall surprise
10373: The Serpent, Prince of aire, and drag in Chaines
10374: Through all his realme, & there confounded leave;
10375: Then enter into glory, and resume
10376: His Seat at Gods right hand, exalted high
10377: Above all names in Heav'n; and thence shall come,
10378: When this worlds dissolution shall be ripe,
10379: With glory and power to judge both quick & dead,
10380: To judge th' unfaithful dead, but to reward
10381: His faithful, and receave them into bliss,
10382: Whether in Heav'n or Earth, for then the Earth
10383: Shall all be Paradise, far happier place
10384: Then this of *Eden*, and far happier daies.
10386: As at the Worlds great period; and our Sire
10387: Replete with joy and wonder thus repli'd.
10389: That all this good of evil shall produce,
10390: And evil turn to good; more wonderful
10391: Then that which by creation first brought forth
10392: Light out of darkness! full of doubt I stand,
10393: Whether I should repent me now of sin
10394: By mee done and occasiond, or rejoyce
10395: Much more, that much more good thereof shall spring,
10396: To God more glory, more good will to Men
10397: From God, and over wrauth grace shall abound.
10398: But say, if our deliverer up to Heav'n
10399: Must reascend, what will betide the few
10400: His faithful, left among th' unfaithful herd,
10401: The enemies of truth; who then shall guide
10402: His people, who defend? will they not deale
10403: Wors with his followers then with him they dealt?
10404: ¶Be sure they will, said th' Angel; but from Heav'n
10405: Hee to his own a Comforter will send,
10406: The promise of the Father, who shall dwell
10407: His Spirit within them, and the Law of Faith
10408: Working through love, upon thir hearts shall write,
10409: To guide them in all truth, and also arme
10410: With spiritual Armour, able to resist
10411: *Satans* assaults, and quench his fierie darts
10412: What Man can do against them, not affraid,
10413: Though to the death, against such cruelties
10415: And oft supported so as shall amaze
10416: Thir proudest persecuters: for the Spirit
10417: Powrd first on his Apostles, whom he sends
10418: To evangelize the Nations, then on all
10419: Baptiz'd, shall them with wondrous gifts endue
10420: To speak all Tongues, and do all Miracles,
10421: As did thir Lord before them.  Thus they win
10422: Great numbers of each Nation to receave
10423: With joy the tidings brought from Heav'n: at length
10424: Thir Ministry perform'd, and race well run,
10425: Thir doctrine and thir story written left,
10426: They die; but in thir room, as they forewarne,
10427: Wolves shall succeed for teachers, grievous Wolves,
10428: Who all the sacred mysteries of Heav'n
10429: To thir own vile advantages shall turne
10430: Of lucre and ambition, and the truth
10432: Left onely in those written Records pure,
10433: Though not but by the Spirit understood.
10434: Then shall they seek to avail themselves of names,
10435: Places and titles, and with these to joine
10436: Secular power, though feigning still to act
10438: The Spirit of God, promisd alike and giv'n
10439: To all Beleevers; and from that pretense,
10440: Spiritual Lawes by carnal power shall force
10441: On every conscience; Laws which none shall finde
10442: Left them inrould, or what the Spirit within
10443: Shall on the heart engrave.  What will they then
10444: But force the Spirit of Grace it self, and binde
10445: His consort Libertie; what, but unbuild
10446: His living Temples, built by Faith to stand,
